HEADLINE: First Union to Sell Annuities at Branches

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
The already weakened barriers between banks and insurance companies were further breached yesterday, when the First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., announced plans to license 800 of its employees to sell annuities through its branch offices.
Annuities, which offer a stream of payments after retirement, are attracting more attention from banks that want to offer investment products that are more attractive than certificates of deposit. The United States Supreme Court ruled two months ago that banks could sell annuities, but left unanswered questions about who should regulate the activity. 
 First Union is the nation's ninth-largest banking company and is already a leader among banks in the mutual fund business, where it has licensed 1,700 workers at its branches to sell funds. About 800 of those workers -- one for each branch, except in Florida, where banks are not permitted to sell insurance -- will be licensed to sell annuities. The bank's workers are also responsible for selling other products like small loans and credit cards.
"We want to use our branch system to sell a full range of financial products," said Dave deGorter, director of the First Union insurance business.
By offering fixed annuities, which earn a specified interest rate, as well as variable annuities, in which earnings fluctuate according to changes in the stock and bond markets, thebank hopes to have annuities that will be attractive in different market conditions, he said.
Mr. deGorter said 70 percent of the recent sales of annuities in a pilot program at some branches in North Carolina had been of the fixed variety, whereas in 1993, when interset rates were lower but stock and bond prices were rising strongly, variable annuities accounted for 70 percent of sales.
For now, First Union will sell fixed annuities issued by insurance companies -- Western National Life in Houston for the fixed annuities and Nationwide Insurance in Columbus, Ohio, for the variable type. "Right now we are not permitted to issue our own annuities," Mr. deGorter said, adding that if the rules changed, "it is not beyond the realm of comprehension" that the bank would do so.
The agreements between insurers and First Union are reminders that the insurance industry is of two minds about the banks entering the $80-billion-a-year annuity business. Insurance agents oppose the entry of the banks, but many insurance companies have agreements to provide banks with annuities to sell to banks' customers.
Western National Life is controlled by the American General Corporation, based in Houston, which also owns the Variable Annuity Life Insurance Company. Variable Annuity filed lawsuits nine years ago against banking regulators to stop banks from selling annuities, but lost the case in a Supreme Court decision issued in January.

HEADLINE: From the Land of St. Patrick, a Dove

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY 

DATELINE: DUBLIN, March 16

 BODY:
A few months ago, John Bruton's political career was at its nadir, his popularity at an all-time low, his party apparently destined to remain in frustrated opposition. But the man who met with President Clinton in Washington today has changed all that in his three months as Ireland's Prime Minister.
In an interview before he left on Tuesday, Mr. Bruton said his primary mission on his weeklong visit to the United States would be to advance a political settlement of the 25 years of sectarian guerrilla violence in Northern Ireland, to "get a few messages into the political system about the need to get a balanced approach to this problem, to recognize the rights of both communities" -- Northern Ireland's Protestant majority and its Roman Catholic minority. 
 "I think I'm realistic enough to know that people in America don't wake up every morning and ask what's happening in Ireland," Mr. Bruton said, discussing the timing of his visit. "They think about Ireland maybe twice or three times a year in a serious way." St. Patrick's Day, he said, "is one of those times."
Mr. Bruton's meeting with President Clinton today was his first, but it was upstaged by another first encounter, that between the President and Gerry Adams, the political leader of the Irish Republican Army.
Since he became Prime Minister quite unexpectedly last December in a maelstrom over a domestic issue in Irish politics, Mr. Bruton has become instrumental in trying to advance a settlement in Northern Ireland.
But before he became Prime Minister, Mr. Bruton was a frequent critic of Mr. Adams and of the I.R.A.'s violent struggle to end British rule over Northern Ireland. The tall, balding, 47-year-old lawyer and gentleman farmer from rural County Meath was often described by Irish nationalists like Mr. Adams as a unionist -- a supporter of the Protestant leaders who want the North to remain part of Britain.
Mr. Bruton, a Catholic, denies this, and he is generally considered to have moderated his views. But much of what Mr. Bruton said in the interview would seem likely to make Irish nationalists and their Irish-American supporters grind their teeth.
Discussing Mr. Adams's refusal to make a categorical denunciation of the I.R.A. "armed struggle" even though the I.R.A. has observed a cease-fire for six and a half months, and Mr. Adams's hesitancy to discuss I.R.A. disarmament in the peace negotiations, Mr. Bruton said, "The insistence on the maintenance of substantial amounts of arms is not consistent with saying you are entirely and exclusively willing in all circumstances only to use political, nonviolent methods." But he said the British and the unionists must also make concessions.
Mr. Bruton's view of the republicans is a legacy of his party, Fine Gael. The grandfathers of many Fine Gael supporters defeated the republicans in the civil war that followed Irish independence from Britain in 1922, under a treaty that left the six counties of the North part of Britain. Today, Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political wing, gets about one-third of the Catholic vote in the North, but not quite 2 percent in the Irish Republic.
In polls taken a few weeks before Mr. Bruton took office, only 10 percent of the voters who responded said he was their choice to lead the country, and his party had not led a Government since 1987. But he was vaulted to power when Mr. Bruton's predecessor, Albert Reynolds, was forced from office after a scandal in which his Government was accused of failing to act in the case of a Catholic priest accused, and later convicted, of sexually abusing children in Northern Ireland.
In recent weeks, the polls show him gaining in popularity and that more than half of the people are satisfied with him.
He has been accused, mostly by political enemies, of being gruff with his party colleagues, some of whom had tried to oust him, and stiff and uncharismatic in leading Fine Gael in Parliamentary debates. His critics said he was unable to focus on a single issue for very long, but his supporters noted his intelligence and dedication to the art of government, which he has learned in 25 years as a member of Parliament.
He also knows politics. When Mr. Reynolds's Government fell, he was able to make a deal with the Labor Party and the Democratic Left to form a center-left Government. He came into office charged not only with trying to advance the peace effort, but also with dealing with serious difficulties in the economy. While economic conditions have been improving, Ireland still has one of the highest unemployment rates in Europe -- about 16 percent.
He is generally considered a liberal on social affairs, and his Government overcame strong opposition over the last two weeks to win final approval in Parliament for a measure guaranteeing women access to information about foreign abortion clinics. Mr. Bruton has indicated, however, that his Government will not take on a revision of the country's constitutional ban on abortion. Abortion is legal only if the woman's life is in danger.
Asked whether his trip -- which includes visits to New York, Chicago and St. Louis -- was primarily to seek economic aid in Washington, he said: "This is not a poor country. We have plenty of resources, education, talent. What we need from the United States is political support, political recognition, political encouragement. We're not going to the United States in any mendicant mode."

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Debate? Campaign Issues? But This Is Scarsdale

BYLINE: By Evelyn Nieves 

DATELINE: SCARSDALE, N.Y.

 BODY:
ROBERT HARRISON is trying to bring American democracy to Scarsdale, but he is having a tough time of it.
He is running for mayor, but at a candidates' forum at the public library the other night, it was just he on the dais. Following a longstanding Scarsdale tradition, his opponent, Ann Janiak, refuses to debate. 
"We do things a little differently than in the rest of the country," she said.
In fact, the election is on Tuesday and Ms. Janiak, a village trustee, hasn't stated any campaign positions. Mr. Harrison, a write-in candidate, is running around making promises about open government and distributing fliers listing his membership in civic associations. Ms. Janiak is lying low.
"The Scarsdale Citizen's Party feels strongly that the candidate for mayor does not run on issues," she said.
She was picked as a candidate by the nonpartisan Citizens' Party, which is batting 1.000. For about 70 years, the party's candidate has won every time.
"People are selected for their knowledge of their community, for their good judgment, rather than their particular stand on an issue," she said. "If people state a position, then they're beholden to certain groups."
PRECISELY, Mr. Harrison said.
"We should tell people what we're going to do," he said. "We should be beholden to the people."
He said he wants to talk about moving the village compost heap. He wants to talk about downtown development. He wants to talk about new tennis courts. He wants to talk.
"I believe in freedom of speech and democracy," he said, sounding more "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington" than he intended.
But the current Mayor, Walter J. Handelman, said that Mr. Harrison just doesn't understand.
"There is no such thing as issues when you run a municipal government," said Mr. Handelman, who is stepping down, as village tradition dictates, after one term.
"When you talk about 'issues,' " he said, "it has to really be in quotes. Because what you're talking about is solving certain problems with particular respect to municipal government that people have a point of view on."
Mr. Harrison decided to run for mayor three weeks ago, after attending a village board meeting where several items he wanted to discuss were not brought up. After 15 years of wrestling with Scarsdale's brand of government, he said he is ready for the old-fashioned system of open debate.
"There is no interaction," he said. "That's wrong. We want to totally open up the system and find out why everything takes so long to get done."
He is a former Wall Street broker with firm good-citizen credentials. He founded the New York Junior Tennis League of Scarsdale, co-founded the Scarsdale Spring Youth Tennis League, headed a neighborhood association and formed the Scarsdale Taxpayer Alert. "To protect our property values," he said. He has been a regular presence at the biweekly village board meetings for years.
His bid for election is one of the few times a citizens' committee candidate has ever been challenged. Scarsdale, one of the jewels of Westchester County, is rich and beautiful and basically happy. Its schools consistently land on national Top 10 lists. The median price of a one-family house is more than $500,000. Residents join clubs. The League of Women Voters (Ms. Janiak is a past president) has close to 700 members and is the largest suburban chapter in the country.
 THE current political system was devised about three generations ago by a reform-minded civic association now known as the Town and Village Civic Club. The Scarsdale Citizens' Party, with 36 members elected from Scarsdale's 18 election districts, meets privately to select candidates for office from resumes. Term limits are built in. Village trustees serve no more than two two-year terms; the mayor, usually chosen from among the trustees, serves one two-year term.
The mayor is a part-time volunteer. A village manager is responsible for the day-to-day work of running the village. This year, the city manager is retiring and a new manager, hired by the village trustees, is slated to take over.
At the candidates' forum, Mr. Harrison promised the two dozen people assembled that he would set regular office hours and address citizens' questions in open meetings that are as long as required. He promised to get the issue of the compost heap, which many residents hate, squared away. He was cheerfully received.
"I'd like to know what kind of vitamins you take," Susan Levine said.
Mayor Handelman, however, said that Mr. Harrison shouldn't make any promises. "Nobody, not even somebody who is on the board now and is a candidate for re-election -- none of those people can say, 'If you elect me, I will move the compost heap,' " he said. "It's just not the way it works. We decide things collectively. That's why we've had such a remarkable record of clean, efficient, forward-thinking government."

HEADLINE: Stock Prices Set Records Once Again

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Despite some new and conflicting economic reports, traders sent stock prices to record levels yesterday as bond prices fell slightly and the dollar seemed to steady overseas.
For the second time this week, the leading stock indexes surged past records to hit new highs. Stocks started out strong, and for the most part rose throughout the day. But traders said some of the action was most likely prompted by today's quarterly expiration of stock options. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 30.78 points to a record 4,069.15, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 3.53 points, to 495.41, also a record. And the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 1.96 points to 809.34, another record.
Meanwhile, after rallying sharply in the morning, bonds gave up all of their gains in the afternoon. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 7.37 percent, from 7.36 percent on Wednesday. [Page D16.]
In international trading, the dollar steadied and continued to trade above post-World War II lows of 1.3895 German marks and 89.50 Japanese yen, but remained under pressure. The dollar fell as low as 89.14 yen before rising to 90.20 yen in late New York trading, up 0.70 yen, and as low as 1.3791 German marks before finishing at 1.3965 marks, up from 1.3895 marks.
Big stocks led the rally. They included oil companies like Exxon, conglomerates like General Electric, beverage companies like Coca-Cola, long-distance phone companies like AT&T, and health-maintenance organizations like U S Healthcare.
Stock traders said, however, that the increase in stock prices might have been exaggerated by the "triple witching" phenomenon that begins today with the quarterly expiration of three kinds of stock options.
In the past, to exercise their options traders have furiously bought and sold stocks on expiration day, but they now appear to spread their activity over two or even three days.
"In the last couple of quarters, every time we get into this thing, we rally before it," said Todd Clark, managing director of equity trading at Mabon Securities. A telltale sign that triple witching played a big part in the rally was that bond prices began falling around 1:30 P.M. and stocks continued to rally later in the day, he said.
Another sign was that on the New York Stock Exchange, nearly two stocks advanced for each one that declined, with 1,420 winning stocks and 801 losers. New highs were established for 107 stocks and new lows for 21 issues.
The market news at 8:30 A.M. was both good and bad, at least by the logic of the market. The Consumer Price Index rose in February by three-tenths of 1 percent, instead of the two-tenths of 1 percent expected by Wall Street, reinforcing a possibly inflationary reading on wholesale prices on Wednesday.
But a report released at the same time, a 2.6 percent drop in housing starts in February, seemed to reassure traders who think the economy is slowing. A report at 10 A.M. by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, indicating little or no growth in manufacturing in its region, served to confirm the idea.
Stock and bond traders therefore concluded that it was safe to buy stocks and bonds because there would be little chance that the Fed would raise interest rates while the economy was slowing.
Bond prices rose sharply until the afternoon, when prices suddenly dropped, wiping out the gains of the morning. Barry Kirschner, bond trader at Chase Securities, said "a very large seller of bonds" entered the market at about 1 P.M. and helped to drive prices down.
As many traders had expected, the Bundesbank, the German counterpart to the Federal Reserve, did not cut interest rates. And in Italy, Prime Minister Lamberto Dini won a vote of confidence on his deficit-cutting proposals.
Both moves meant, at least for now, that European and other traders would not suddenly dump dollars and lira to move to the German mark.
Whether nervous stock traders will dump dollars today in advance of the weekend, as they sometimes do in periods of extreme volatility, is unclear. But Victor Polce, a currency trader at the New York office of Commerzbank, said he thought the dollar was likely to fall at some point.
David De Rosa, a director of foreign exchange trading at Swiss Bank, said a crucial development to watch is whether Spain remains in the European Union's exchange rate mechanism.
He said the Bundesbank's decision to keep interest rates high, or at least not to reduce them in the short run, may have the effect of forcing the Spanish peseta out of the exchange mechanism, rather than simply into further devaluations.
And as the mark rises in value, the pressure on the dollar increases, because to buy marks traders must sell other currencies, including dollars.
But as the dollar weakens, American stocks and bonds fall in value for foreign investors. In a week of record-breaking rises in stocks, the Dow has still fallen 3.82 percent in Japanese yen and 4.36 percent in German marks for the year.
Tektronix, a maker of electronic test equipment, rose 4 3/8 to 37 3/8 after it reported that its third-quarter earnings rose 39 percent, to 70 cents a share. Xerox rose 3 5/8 to 120 1/8 after Salomon Brothers raised its earnings projection for the office-equipment company.
The Merix Corporation, which makes printed circuit boards and other products, fell 4 1/8 to 23 3/4 after a Montgomery Securities analyst lowered his rating to "hold" from "buy." Roberts Pharmaceutical's share price was down for a second day after the company reported disappointing drug dales for the fourth quarter. Roberts dropped 3 to 38.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above normal, with 339.8 million shares changing hands, about 4 percent above this year's daily average of 327 million shares.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.77 points to 267.92, and the American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.69 point to 456.47.
The most-active stock, at 6.1 million shares, was Telefonos de Mexico, which fell 3/8 to 26 1/8.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds End Mixed After Early Rally Fades

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended mixed yesterday after a rally set off by signs of an economic slowdown faded.
A series of reports released yesterday indicated the economy had slowed enough to subdue inflation. These reports, which included a modest pickup in consumer prices in February, suggest that the Federal Reserve is unlikely to raise short-term interest rates when its policy-making committee meets on March 28. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 5/32 , to 1032/32 , after being up about a point in intraday trading. At that price, the bond was yielding 7.37 percent, up from 7.36 percent on Wednesday. Prices and yields move in opposite directions. Market participants said the yield had been down as low as 7.28 percent, the lowest in nine months.
In early trading, the market turned higher following the release of the Consumer Price Index for February. The index rose three-tenths of 1 percent. Its core rate, which excludes the volatile categories of food and energy, also rose three-tenths of 1 percent.
In a separate report, housing starts fell 2.6 percent in February, to an annualized rate of 1.323 million from 1.38 million in January.
The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, in a survey of regional business activity, said its index fell in March to 3.3 from 11.9 in February. Traders had been expecting the index to slip to 10.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Securities, said bond market participants paid close attention to both housing starts and the Philadelphia Fed business outlook because they were "statistics that further indicated a slowdown in business activity, although by now this is news only for those recently arriving from Mars."
The increase in the Consumer Price Index was duly noted, he said, but had little market impact because it was fully anticipated.
Mr. Fine says inflation as measured by the consumer index is a lagging indicator and is likely to increase further as the year progresses, though in a nonthreatening manner. "But inflationary expectations, which matter most for bond yields, have clearly lessened in response to the slower rate of economic growth," he said.
Some analysts, however, are not as optimistic that the threat of inflation has receded. Anthony E. Spare, chief investment officer of Spare, Kaplan, Bischel & Associates, a $2 billion San Francisco money management firm, sees the economy in transition. "We are going to go from the best of all worlds of rapid growth and low inflation to the worst of all worlds, higher inflation and slower growth," he said. "Everyone has built in their own expectations of a soft landing, but the odds are low for such an occurrence."
Bond prices were also supported for most of yesterday by a stronger dollar. But there was late profit taking after word of a large bond sale by a large institutional investor. There was talk among traders that an insurance company had sold substantial holdings in five-year notes and other longer maturities, though the identity of the insurer could not be determined.
In the municipal market, where investors have been hungry for new issues, the Virginia Housing Development Authority competitively priced $100 million of its commonwealth mortgage revenue bonds won by Prudential Securities.
Underwriters said the bonds were insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corporation, giving them a triple-A rating from Moody's Investors Services Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The maximum yield was 6.45 percent for a bond due in 2028, with the next-best yields at 6.40 percent for a bond due in 2022 and 6.35 percent in 2018. For shorter maturities, yields on serials bond range from 6.15 percent in 2011 to 6.30 percent in 2014 and 2015.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rebounds Somewhat Aided by U.S. Bond Rally

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar staged a moderate recovery against leading currencies yesterday, helped by an early rally in the United States bond market.
But market analysts and traders said the dollar's recent tumble seemed far from over, with yesterday's recovery mostly tied to technical, not fundamental, factors. 
 "The general market feeling is the dollar is still going down," said Paul Downs, a foreign-exchange analyst with Technical Data in Boston. "The dollar is still very much under pressure."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 90.20 Japanese yen from 89.50 yen on Wednesday. The dollar also rose to 1.3965 German marks from 1.3895 marks and to 1.1640 Swiss francs from 1.1520 francs. The British pound fell to $1.5885 from $1.5999.
The dollar initially strengthened overnight in Asia. Many currency dealers were speculating early yesterday that the German central bank would discuss cutting interest rates, which would make United States rates more attractive to foreign investors, thus supporting the value of the dollar.
The president of the Bundesbank had encouraged such speculation, saying yesterday that the central bank's policy makers would have to decide whether there was room to reduce rates.
Hopes for a drop in German rates, though, were deflated later in the day when the Bundesbank chose to leave key interest rates unchanged at its twice-monthly policy meeting.. German rates have been fixed since July.
The news sent the dollar skidding before it recovered in New York trading.
The dollar received support yesterday from a resurgent United States Treasury market. Treasury bond prices shot higher as fixed-income investors seized on a report by the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank as a further sign of an economic slowdown in the United States.
The increased allure of the dollar-denominated securities encouraged further buying of dollars by foreign investors, traders said.
"Once you see a rally like this, everybody who wants to get in better get in now," said Elena Shperling, chief trader at Banco di Sicilia in New York.
While bond prices retreated late in the day, the dollar held onto its gains.

HEADLINE: New York Fed Names No. 2 Official

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday that it had promoted Ernest T. Patrikis, its general counsel, to be its No. 2 executive.
Mr. Patrikis, 51, will succeed James H. Oltman, 64, who is retiring as the first vice president of the bank. 
 Mr. Patrikis has been involved in the fraud investigation at Bank of Credit and Commerce International and in the recent enforcement action related to the sale of derivatives by Bankers Trust.
In his new role, he said, he wants to work on the continuing problems that arise when corporations and investors buy derivatives that they later say were too risky.
Mr. Patrikis has been active in the Fed's initiative to establish a code of conduct for banks selling derivatives and similar products.
"Derivatives are in their adolescent stage," he said. "Adolescents misbehave. Some people want to kill adolescents, and some people want to kill derivatives."
He said the New York Fed would push the derivatives industry to make better prices available to customers so they can monitor the value of their positions. Similarly it will work to make sure that derivatives dealers clarify whether they are acting as advisers or merely as suppliers.
In his new role, Mr. Patrikis will also be an alternate member on the key Federal Reserve body that sets interest rates -- the Federal Open Markets Committee -- serving in the absence of the New York Fed president, William J. McDonough.
Like many New York Fed officials, he has worked in the bank his entire career, joining in 1968 after graduating from Cornell Law School.
The New York Fed operates the bond and currency trading desk on behalf of the Federal Government, acting to influence foreign exchange and interest rate levels. It operates the Fedwire money transfer system that moves more than $1 trillion a day. And it supervises the bank holding companies based in New York, northern New Jersey and southern Connecticut.
The bank also announced two executives to fill Mr. Patrikis's role. Thomas C. Baxter Jr. will replace Mr. Patrikis as general counsel. Kathleen A. O'Neil will head the bank's staff functions.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ernest T. Patrikis, general counsel of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, whom the bank promoted to its No. 2 job yesterday. He was involved in investigating fraud at B.C.C.I. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Up 0.3%; Data Point to a Slowdown

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
A variety of fresh Government statistics released today showed that an economic slowdown, becoming more pronounced by the day, was helping to moderate the sting of inflation.
Retail prices climbed three-tenths of 1 percent for the second consecutive month in February, the Labor Department reported, a result that analysts considered in line with expectations that the inflation rate this year will be held to less than 3.5 percent. 
 Prices are rising, "but very glacially," said Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist for Paribas Capital Markets in New York.
Signs of the slowdown could be seen in other reports today. Higher interest rates are exacting a particularly heavy toll on the housing market, where builders broke ground on 2.6 percent fewer homes in February than in January, the Commerce Department found. It also reported that the January results were revised to a 12 percent decline, from the 9.8 percent originally reported.
In the industrial sector, where activity remained brisk last month, a survey covering March that was published today by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia indicated a sudden slowdown in the economy. Those who characterized activity as rising barely outnumbered those who thought it was declining.
Securities traders said it was this news that touched off a midmorning rally in the stock and bond markets, although bond prices later retreated.
In still another report, the Labor Department said first-time claims for unemployment insurance climbed 5,000 last week, to 343,000, with the average for the latest four weeks edging down to 339,250.
But it was the Consumer Price Index that held the biggest potential for unpleasant surprises. The February rise, though not without some unsettling aspects, was generally reassuring, economists said.
"Inflation seems to be right around 3 percent, which is taken as not enough for the Federal Reserve to do anything further" to raise interest rates, said Paul W. Boltz, an economist at T. Rowe Price in Baltimore.
Still, he noted that when the erratic food and energy components were excluded, the index had risen at a 4.2 percent compound annual rate in the first two months of the year. This could prove worrisome, he and others said, even taking into account that the index seems to have an upward bias in the winter.
Some important contributors to the February rise, including a 1.1 percent jump for personal and educational services, do seem unlikely to be repeated. The core index, excluding food and energy, climbed three-tenths of 1 percent last month compared with four-tenths of 1 percent in January.
Food prices staged a turnaround, to a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent from a rare January decline. The price of apparel slumped six-tenths of 1 percent as higher-priced spring and summer merchandise arrived in amounts that were somewhat smaller than usual for February.
The housing component showed higher prices for cable television, refuse collection and furniture and bedding, while fuel oil and telephone charges declined.
In transportation, automobile finance charges leaped another 2.4 percent to bring the 12-month advance to 29.3 percent while used cars posted another hefty increase to bring the yearly total to 14.3 percent, the report showed.
The cost of medical care rose three-tenths of 1 percent, with prescription drugs and other medical commodities easing one-tenth of 1 percent. The department reported Wednesday that drug prices at the wholesale level rose sharply last month.
Today's report on housing starts showed that the decline was concentrated in the South -- the other three regions actually had modest increases -- and mainly involved apartment houses and other multifamily dwellings.
Still, nationwide starts of single-family homes were down six-tenths of 1 percent, to a rate of just 1,053,000, a level that would once have been considered recessionary, observed Carol A. Stone, senior economist at Nomura Securities International. Saying that she had expected some snapback from January's double-digit plunge, she said that the February results only confirmed the weakness in housing.

HEADLINE: Ruling Keeps Alive Hopes for Bronx Railyard

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
A judge's ruling has revived the possibility that a moribund railyard in the South Bronx could be turned into a major center for transfering freight from trains to trucks.
Advocates of the proposal say the creation of the transfer point would lower the cost of shipping goods into New York City, create thousands of jobs and reduce air pollution. But the State Department of Transportation, which once supported the concept, had opted instead to lease the 96-acre Harlem River Yard, at the southern tip of the Bronx near Randalls Island, to a private developer who planned a smaller transfer operation. 
 Justice Jerry L. Crispino of State Supreme Court in the Bronx, voided that lease last week, ruling that the department had not given fair consideration to other options or to the environmental impact of the developer's plans.
The department plans to appeal the decision, said Michael R. Fleischer, a department spokesman.
The ruling came in a suit filed by several community and environmental groups in the Bronx. They wanted the state to return to a 1982 Department of Transportation plan that called for turning the unused yard, which the state bought that year, into the region's primary transfer point.
Little freight enters New York City by rail because, among other reasons, unlike most American cities, it does not have a site for transfering truck containers from trains to trucks. Most freight is trucked into the city, instead, which raises the cost of merchandise and adds to air pollution.
Bringing freight into the city by train is crucial to keeping the region competitive, said Robert D. Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association, a private group that studies land use and other issues in the metropolitan area. "We simply don't have a modern rail-freight system in the region," he said. "Forty percent of the freight in the country is moving by rail, but in this region it's 4 percent, and in New York City it's only 2 percent."
Faced with legal and labor problems, the state backed away from the plan in the late 1980's, and in 1991 it agreed to lease the site for 99 years to Harlem River Yard Ventures, a group headed by Francesco Galesi, a developer. The group's plan, approved by the state last May, called for a much smaller rail-to-truck freight transfer yard, warehouses, a paper recycling plant and a truck-to-rail transfer site for solid waste.
The 1982 plan projected taking hundreds of trucks off the region's highways every day, while creating thousands of jobs at the transfer site and benefitting the entire city by lowering freight costs. The plaintiffs argued -- and the judge agreed -- that the Harlem River Yard Ventures plan would add thousands of trucks each day to traffic on Bronx streets, while falling far short of the demand for freight transfer.
To develop the Harlem River Yard, the 1982 plan called for building a rail line along the Harlem River so that freight trains would not have to cross or share lines used by Metro-North commuter trains. That work is nearly complete. The plan also called for increasing the height of several bridges over lines leading to the city so that modern freight cars could fit under them, and that work has been finished.
John McHugh, a lawyer for the plaintiffs, said the transfer station is so close to being ready that it could start operations this year.

GRAPHIC: Map of the South Bronx showing location of the Harlem River railyard.

HEADLINE: World Bank Must Snap Out of its Midlife Crisis

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your March 12 news article on President Clinton's recommendation of James D. Wolfensohn as the new World Bank president was correct that the bank has been the subject of growing criticism, but mistaken in asserting that the "50 Years Is Enough" Campaign has the simple message that the bank "should mark its 50th anniversary by going out of business." 
 We have never made a statement to that effect. What this coalition, made up of more than 135 citizens' groups in the United States, is calling for is what will be on the table when world leaders gather in Halifax, Nova Scotia, in June for the G-7 economic summit conference: profound changes in an institution whose extended midlife crisis must come to an end.
Mr. Wolfensohn will need to be more than a "Renaissance Banker" (Man in the News, March 13) if he is to succeed at sorting out the problems that plague this institution: a legacy of environmentally and socially destructive programs and projects, a portfolio in which bank officials have identified a project failure rate of more than 30 percent, an inability to translate all manner of policies into action, a shrinking budget and a stunning inability to achieve its ostensible purpose of poverty alleviation.
Mr. Wolfensohn should already be familiar with some of the problems. This year, a high-level report prepared by the Bretton Woods Commission recognized the imminent need to reconsider the roles of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
That commission was headed by Paul Volcker, former head of the Federal Reserve and now chairman of the private investment firm James D. Wolfensohn Inc.
As if the legacy of problems is not enough, Mr. Wolfensohn must also deal with the Mexican disaster and the bank's role in it. Mexico is the bank's largest cumulative borrower and until recently its poster child, the country whose economic recovery was meant to vindicate the economists at the bank and the I.M.F., whose highly criticized structural adjustment prescriptions are failing the world over.
Internationally, thousands of nongovernmental organizations believe that restructuring of the bank should be based on principles of openness, accountability and democratic governance that will support development led by those most affected by it. Such changes will require a leader of extraordinary vision and courage.
Mr. Wolfensohn may have rebuilt Carnegie Hall; the World Bank is something else.
 
JULIETTE MAJOT
Berkeley, Calif., March 14, 1995
The writer is a policy analyst with International Rivers Network.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;
The Melancholy Images That Made an Era Real

BYLINE: By CHARLES HAGEN 

 BODY:
The first task some viewers will face when they look at the photographs in "Dorothea Lange: American Images," the stirring exhibition now at the International Center of Photography, is to strip the pictures of their dulling glaze of fame. Lange had an astonishing ability to make images that summed up the terrible impact of the Depression of the 1930's on people's lives, and many of the pictures here have become classics, not only of photography but of the history of America.
As a result, they have been endlessly reproduced, and it may be difficult for some people to break through the pictures' familiarity and to recognize the human realities they record. These are the images that have defined our understanding of Depression America, and particularly of its people, with their weary eyes and worn faces. 
 Take, for example, "Migrant Mother, Nipomo, California," Lange's 1936 photograph of a worried-looking woman in a farm-labor camp flanked by her children. That image seems to embody the anxiety and heroism of people confronting social forces beyond their control, and has been used on posters, postage stamps and book jackets around the world.
The show at the center includes not only two prints of this famous image, one with an intruding hand retouched out, but also two other shots Lange took of the same woman and her children. These alternative pictures break down some of the sense of inevitability that has made "Migrant Mother" an icon, and provide valuable insights into Lange's way of working.
The story of how Lange came to photograph the effects of the Depression is itself a famous chapter in the history of photography. She was born in 1895, and was working in San Francisco as a portrait photographer who specialized in genteel, dramatically lighted images when, in the early 30's, she took her camera into the streets to record the protests and social strife of that tumultous decade.
When Paul Taylor, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, saw her photographs in an exhibition, he enlisted her to illustrate reports on agricultural conditions. The two began a personal and professional relationship that lasted until Lange's death in 1965.
Many of Lange's best-known images were taken between 1935 and 1939, when she worked for the Farm Security Administration, the New Deal agency concerned with agricultural policy; in 1939, Lange and Taylor published "An American Exodus," a book that combines Lange's photographs with quotes from the people in them.
Lange's pictures from this period are rightly considered classics of documentary photography, but they are seldom neutral. Even the most rundown and bedraggled of her subjects are portrayed as heroic; a remarkable sense of generosity and concern pervades her pictures.
Lange's striking ability to gain the confidence of her sitters is apparent in the intimacy with which they present themselves to her. This skill may have stemmed from her experience as a portraitist. Her pictures also demonstrate a sophisticated command of expressive form; photograph after photograph draws its emotional charge from simple yet subtle compositions and lighting.
A gaunt woman photographed in 1938 in the Texas Panhandle, for example, holds one hand to her head and the other to her neck, creating an angular frame for her face. Lange photographed the woman from a low angle against a backdrop of wispy clouds, heightening the sense of her strength.
"Dorothea Lange: American Photographs" provides an extensive selection of her Depression-era images, as well as examples from other documentary projects she undertook, including a deeply moving series of photographs of Japanese-Americans in California forced into internment camps at the outbreak of World War II. Also represented is a study of industrial workers during the war, when the labor force was opened up to women and blacks, as well as images of rural communities in Utah, made in the early 50's.
But the show, which was organized by Sandra S. Phillips, curator of photography at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, is not a thorough survey of Lange's work. Missing are her early portraits, as well as examples of the photographs she took in the 50's and 60's, when Taylor, by then her husband, was invited to teach overseas and she went along. Also absent are the pictures she took of her own family as ill health increasingly limited her ability to undertake more ambitious projects.
What the exhibition offers instead is the official Lange, the New Deal propagandist and unabashed liberal who was able to show human faces behind the slogans and the statistics. And it is those faces that impress themselves most strongly on memory.
There's the little girl in a grimy shift in Oklahoma who stares at the camera with sunken eyes, the cotton picker in Arizona who holds his splayed fingers in front of his face, the water boy who stands in a cotton field in the Mississippi Delta with his bucket planted squarely on his head. These and many other faces linger in Lange's photographs, patiently encouraging us to try to understand not only the times in which the people lived, but also their own unique lives.
In Lange's extraordinary photographs, ordinary people are recognized as leading characters in a profoundly important social drama. Her pictures have the riveting interest of the best fiction, and the moral weight of history.
"Dorothea Lange: American Photographs" remains at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street, through April 30. It will then travel to the Phillips Collection in Washington (May 20 to Aug. 27) and the Joslyn Art Museum in Omaha. (Sept. 30 to Nov. 26).

HEADLINE: Prominent Black Americans Take Aim at Nigeria

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
A group of prominent blacks began a national campaign today to press Nigeria's military dictatorship to restore democracy, the first time African-Americans have embarked on a protest of such magnitude against a black African government.
"We must isolate Nigeria, politically, socially and economically, in the same way we were able to isolate South Africa and Haiti," said Randall Robinson, executive director of TransAfrica, the black lobby for Africa and the Caribbean that is leading the campaign. The effort will include newspaper ads and protests outside the Nigerian Embassy. 
 He added, "You change the color, and there is not much distinction between the South African situation of the past and Nigeria today, except you don't have people discriminated against as a group simply on the basis of their skin color."
Among the group of black Americans supporting the effort are the poet Maya Angelou; Bryant Gumbel, the broadcaster for NBC's "Today"; A. Leon Higginbotham Jr., a retired Federal appeals court judge; the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Danny Glover, Quincey Jones, Alice Walker, and Sugar Ray Leonard, the former welterweight boxing champion.
The organization sent a letter on Monday to Nigeria's head of state, Gen. Sani Abacha, protesting what it called the "absolute military dictatorship" that has led to the detention or killing of hundreds of the military junta's critics.
General Abacha's Government has banned political opposition, dissolved labor unions and removed elected political leaders from office. The general ousted Moohood Abiola, the alleged winner of a national election, in a bloodless coup in November 1993.
"Nigeria is not only harming their own people, but military leaders continue to line their pockets with drug payoffs to transport narcotics through Nigeria to our youth on the streets of every city in the United States," said Representative Donald M. Payne, a New Jersey Democrat who heads the Congressional Black Caucus.
Mr. Robinson said TransAfrica, best known for its successful anti-apartheid campaign against South Africa, also plans to lobby the Administration to increase its pressure on the Nigerian Government by refusing to buy Nigerian oil, which makes up 4 percent of all oil imported by the United States. Nigeria is Africa's largest oil producer, and the United States is its biggest buyer.
"It would do major damage to Nigeria, and we think more than diplomacy is needed."
Although the Administration opposes the Lagos Government, it maintains a policy of "engagement" to effect change.
In the past the Administration has imposed some sanctions on Nigeria, and visas have been denied to those who have supported the military Government. In addition, Nigeria has been barred from receiving aid from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank because of drug trafficking.
Mr. Robinson said that on Monday he spoke to George E. Moose, an Assistant Secretary of State, about the group's proposed action and informed other members of the Administration. A copy of the letter also went to Anthony Lake, the national security adviser.
In the past, the group has condemned conditions in Ethiopia, Zaire and Angola, but Mr. Robinson said today's effort was the first time it had undertaken a major effort against a black African government.
"Nigeria should be the bellwether state of sub-Saharan Africa," said Mr. Robinson. "It is Africa's largest and should be its wealthiest country, given its great oil wealth. Instead, it is verging on economic collapse."
The Nigerian campaign is the latest political effort by TransAfrica, which was founded in 1977 and credited with elevating the influence of African-Americans in foreign policy through 1960's-style civil rights protests. Its anti-apartheid campaign, begun in 1984, featured several demonstrations outside the South African Embassy here that resulted in the arrests of prominent participants like Senator Edward M. Kennedy.
Last spring, Mr. Robinson engaged in a 27-day hunger strike that heightened public awareness of conditions in Haiti. Observers say this and the group's other efforts contributed to a change in American policy toward Haiti and ultimately helped lead to the military intervention in September that restored Haiti's democratically elected President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide.

HEADLINE: Entrepreneur Gets $30 Million To Establish For-Profit Schools

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
A few months after financial pressures seemed to put its future in jeopardy, the Edison Project, the media entrepreneur Christopher Whittle's groundbreaking venture into for-profit education, announced yesterday that it had secured $30 million in financing and would open its first schools next fall.
Mr. Whittle will provide half of the money himself and the president of the project, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., a former president of Yale University, is heading a group that will provide another $3 million. The rest will come from the Sprout Group, one of the nation's oldest and largest venture capital firms. By securing $12 million from the firm, Edison has allied itself with an investor with broad resources and far-ranging experience in start-up ventures. 
 After a harrowing period in which Edison scrambled for the financial backing it needed to say alive, the new financing gives Edison a chance to show whether it can deliver on its promise of innovative public schools that it says will both turn a profit and improve the education of the nation's children.
"This speaks to the strength of the idea," said Mr. Whittle, whose mixed record in other ventures, lavish life style and accounting practices were the subject of withering publicity, particularly in a long article in The New Yorker last October.
There is still enormous skepticism among many educators about Edison's assertion that it can lengthen the school day and school year, provide extras like a computer in every student's home and still turn a profit. The two original partners along with Mr. Whittle, Associated Newspapers, which owns, among other things, the Daily Mail in London and Philips Electronics, the Dutch conglomerate, made no new investments in the venture, which has spent $40 million in start-up costs.
"There's a lot of hype that may sell in the short run, but if you ask me if I think they'll recoup their investment, I'd say flat out, 'No,' said Henry Levin, a Stanford University economist, who founded that university's Accelerated Schools Program, which works with troubled students in 700 schools in 37 states.
But Michael Moe, who follows trends in for-profit education for Lehman Brothers in New York, said education was a fertile area for investors. "I know they've spent a lot of time studying the education market," he said of Sprout. "If you look at the education market, you see a classic situation where you've got a big problem and a huge market, and so companies with innovative solutions represent significant investment opportunities."
Edison originally planned to operate private schools and said it would open 100 schools in the fall of 1996. Later, it shifted its ambitions to operating public schools by contract with school districts. Dr. Schmidt said Edison would begin with 3 or 4 schools in the fall and perhaps 7 to 10 others a year later, far fewer than the company had talked about just a few months ago. The first Edison schools will include the Renaissance Charter School in Boston, and elementary schools in Mount Clemens, Mich., and Wichita, Kan.
He said the movement for charter schools, public schools operated autonomously at the school level, and the overall ferment in education made Edison right for the times. "Charters are a perfect avenue for us," he said. "But I also think they reflect just how widespread is the desire for the creation of alternative models for public schools."
Edison is a very modest investment for the Sprout Group, the venture capital affiliate of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, which since its inception in 1969 has raised or has under management a billion dollars. The $12 million Edison investment will be spread between two investment partnerships.
Mr. Whittle said his areas of responsibility would include capital formation and long-term strategic planning, while Dr. Schmidt would be in charge of the day-to-day management of the company.

HEADLINE: Republicans Lop $100 Billion from Budgets to Pay for Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
Much as they have promised for months, Republicans on the House Budget Committee voted today to lop $100 billion from future Federal budgets to pay for a hefty chunk of the tax relief promised in their Contract With America.
This, at least, is the way the Republicans tell it. Furious Democrats offer a different account. Others who were there remain uncertain of everything that occurred but would pay admission to see such a bar fight again. 
 "We think we have produced a truly amazing document here today," Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the Budget Committee chairman, said after the session ended. Few would dispute it.
In practical terms, Mr. Kasich and his fellow Republicans on the budget panel did take an important step today toward offsetting the $189 billion that their party's tax-cut proposals would drain from Federal revenues in the next five years.
By a 24-to-11 vote, the panel ordered the House Appropriations Committee to make $95 billion in unspecified cuts from the $2.8 trillion it had planned to spend over that period on discretionary programs, including space exploration, agriculture and foreign aid, to name a handful. And it voted to cut the anti-crime trust fund approved by the House only last month by $5 billion in the next five years, to a total of $23 billion.
Republicans intend to combine that $100 billion cut with legislation that would reduce projected spending on other programs like welfare and Federal pensions, and to approve them -- and the tax cuts -- in a single House vote later this spring. The package would then go to the Senate, where opposition to tax cuts is strong and its prospects are cloudy.
But what seemed clear on Republican charts quickly stumbled into a heap of conflicting numbers. The problem began when Mr. Kasich handed out a list of "illustrative" budget cuts, intended to show how $100 billion in savings could be found once the Appropriations Committee starts hunting.
Sharp-eyed Democrats studied the list. And they concluded that some $35 billion on it had been discussed by the full House the previous evening -- and specifically reserved for deficit reduction, not financing tax relief.
"You're double-counting," said Representative Charles Stenholm, a conservative Texas Democrat who is often Mr. Kasich's ally on deficit matters. Mr. Kasich replied: Am not.
In truth, it depends. To underscore their seriousness about budget-cutting, Republicans plucked $17.3 billion this month from programs in the current Federal budget and marked them for elimination. And to win Democratic support, they agreed Wednesday night, in a 418-to-5 vote, to apply most of those savings to deficit reduction and not to paying for tax cuts that many Democrats oppose.
Mr. Kasich believed that the amendment, dubbed a "lockbox" provision, applied only to savings from the current budget. But in fact, it covered any future savings from cuts in those programs through 1998, which was a $35 billion subtraction, potentially, from the $100 billion in Mr. Kasich's package.
"It's to buy down the debt, for deficit reduction," said Representative William K. Brewster, the Oklahoma Democrat who wrote the amendment. "It's not available for any spending: tax cuts, social programs."
Told of that, the irrepressible Mr. Kasich committed a faux pas and spoke the truth. "Frankly, the whole lockbox thing is going to get dropped" once legislation reaches the Senate, he said. "Everybody knows it's a big game on the lockbox."
Mr. Stenholm was shocked. "It's not a game," he said. "It's very serious. And those of us who think a tax cut is absurd are doing everything we can to insure that spending cuts go to deficit reduction, period."
Mr. Kasich and Mr. Brewster were later seen walking toward the House chamber, for a final vote on the $17.3 billion in cuts, engaged in an animated argument. Mr. Brewster was later spied on the House floor in another animated, finger-pointing discussion with Republican leaders.
Moments later, he voted for the cuts and said the Republicans had admitted that Mr. Kasich was mistaken. "I can explain it, but I can't understand it," Mr. Brewster said of Mr. Kasich's assertions. "He apparently never read the amendment."
For his part, Mr. Kasich returned to the Budget Committee to assert that his view was correct, but that it was really a moot point anyway. His "illustrative" spending cuts were just illustrations, he said; once the entire Republican deficit-cutting package is in place, there will be more than enough money to finance tax cuts and obey Mr. Brewster's deficit-cutting strictures as well.
Indeed, Mr. Kasich's panel still intends to produce a five-year budget plan in May that cuts at least $400 billion more from spending, and place the Federal deficit on a path toward zero by the year 2002.
"You're arguing about nothing, folks," he told the Democrats.
Democrats accused Mr. Kasich and the Republicans of playing fast and loose with the figures. But Mr. Kasich asserted that it was the Democrats, and specifically the White House, that is playing a "carny game" with the deficit issue.
Mr. Kasich stressed today that the panel's $100 billion reduction is a "real" spending cut -- that is, it would require the Government to spend less in each of the next five years than the $546 billion it will spend on discretionary programs in this fiscal year.
By comparison, he noted, the White House used standard Federal budget forecasts, adjusted upward for inflation each year, in calculating the $30 billion in spending cuts that it proposed in its five-year budget last month. Under that formula, Mr. Kasich said, the Budget Committee's $100 billion reduction balloons to $191 billion, with the excess available to reduce the annual deficit.
"This package has $60 billion more in deficit reduction than in the entire President's budget," he said, adding later, "You ain't seen nothing yet."

HEADLINE: Still Seeking Cuts, Senate Votes Extra $1.9 Billion for Military

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
The Senate today approved $1.9 billion in emergency Pentagon spending for unexpected overseas missions, but the bill called for a similar amount to be cut from existing Pentagon programs.
The vote was 97 to 3 to approve the spending that military commanders say they need before the end of this month to avoid canceling training exercises and halting purchases of spare parts. 
 But under pressure to avoid adding to the Federal deficit, the legislators offset the request by cutting existing Pentagon appropriations, including $300 million from environmental cleanup at military bases, $175 million from research and $200 million from a Democratic plan to encourage military contractors to develop products with military and commercial uses.
Senior Defense Department officials said they were concerned that the Senate was setting a precedent that could endanger future military readiness.
"The department is willing to offset a portion of the supplemental, but a requirement to offset the full amount will do unnecessary damage to the important technology and modernization programs," Defense Secretary William J. Perry and Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said in a letter this week to senior members of the Senate and House Appropriations Committees.
The Defense Department's budget, $264 billion this year, goes to pay, train and equip the armed forces. The Pentagon must request extra money from Congress to pay for wars, peacekeeping operations and humanitarian missions.
What started as a straightforward Defense Department request for $2.5 billion to pay for unanticipated operations in Kuwait, Somalia, Cuba and Haiti has in many respects turned into a tussle between the House and Senate for bragging rights on deficit reduction.
The House last month approved $3.2 billion, including additional money for troop salaries, but offset it largely with a combination of cuts in military and domestic programs.
The Senate slashed the $670 million for training and salaries that the House added to the Pentagon's original request, then cut $600 million more from the Pentagon's request, and offset the remaining $1.9 billion with other Pentagon cuts.
In the same bill, the Senate also cut $1.5 billion from existing domestic programs not related to the military and earmarked those reductions for reducing the deficit.
Congressional aides said House and Senate conferees would meet next week to work out a compromise version. Even some influential senators expressed reservations with the Senate's approach.
"I am concerned about the precedent we may be setting in offsetting Defense Department dollars," Senator Strom Thurmond, the South Carolina Republican who heads the Armed Services Committee, said last week on the Senate floor.
Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat on the Armed Services Committee, added, "A complete offset sounds good in speeches, but the effect will be readiness will go down."
Senators also attached to the spending bill two amendments unrelated to the military. One would require the Clinton Administration to report on a monthly basis, beginning April 1, on a wide variety of Mexican economic indicators and policies. The second would withhold American aid to Russia's atomic energy ministry if Moscow goes ahead with its plan to sell nuclear reactor parts to Iran.

HEADLINE: Destructive Tuition Hikes

 BODY:
Politicians in Albany have discovered to their distress that slashing state aid to New York State's public higher education system would require closing down programs and even campuses as well as stiff tuition increases. The Legislature thus appears ready to restore some of the disproportionate cuts imposed on higher education in Gov. George Pataki's budget. Whatever else is done, the priority should be to ease up on the huge tuition increases proposed by Mr. Pataki and academic leaders -- even if that means cutting academic programs.
Until this week, many fans of Governor Pataki's calls for austerity lulled themselves into thinking that state aid to the City University and State University of New York could be reduced by nearly a third, with savings achieved from painless tuition increases and a few snips here and there in the mythically bloated administrative bureaucracy. 
 In reality, of course, scrapping even the entire administration of SUNY or CUNY would not save the money needed. This week the state university trustees warned that even after painfully high tuition hikes, as many as eight campuses would have to be merged or closed and hundreds of programs eliminated or curtailed.
There is little doubt that in an era of terrible fiscal problems, both the city and state university systems can find places to cut, especially when there are duplicative programs on different campuses. Several two-year technology and agriculture schools scattered throughout the state could easily be consolidated, were it not that they provide jobs and resources in the districts of powerful Republicans in the State Senate.
What the Legislature must be careful to do is observe first principles. A tuition increase between $1,000 and $1,600 now on the table for the State University, where tuition is already $2,650, and the City University, where it is $2,450, would impose a terrible hardship on working-class and poor families and undermine the historic role of the university as a route up for the next generation.
The huge tuition hikes are especially cruel in light of parallel cutbacks proposed in financial aid to students. If there are to be curbs on financial aid, they surely should be restructured to avoid hurting those with the highest need. It makes no sense to eliminate all aid to part-time students when more than 40 percent of the City University's students are part-timers trying to get a college education while holding down jobs.
Access to quality higher education is one of the proudest traditions New Yorkers have. But mere sentimentality is not at work here. An educated work force is surely as crucial to the city's and state's economic health as lower taxes, the goal to which higher education is being sacrificed. Ambitious but needy families, including immigrants from Africa, Asia and parts of Europe, are working in kitchens, sweatshops and cabs in New York City. Cutting off their access is not only unjust. It is economically self-defeating.

HEADLINE: Javits Center Figures Blame Each Other

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
The former head of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and a local labor leader pointed fingers at each other yesterday for appointing two men said to have ties to organized-crime figures to head the carpenters union at the convention center.
Fabian Palomino, who until January served as chief executive officer of the center, told a State Senate committee that he had nothing to do with Anthony Fiorino's and Leonard Simon's becoming shop stewards --with responsibility for doling out high-paying carpenters jobs and negotiating labor contracts. 
 But Frederick W. Devine, president of the New York City District Council of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, said he appointed Mr. Fiorino and Mr. Simon largely on Mr. Palomino's recommendation. A Federal investigation has linked Mr. Fiorino and Mr. Simon to members of organized crime families and has alleged that they are using the Javits Center to provide employment to mobsters and their friends and family members.
The testimony from Mr. Palomino and Mr. Devine came on the first day of a Senate inquiry into corruption and mismanagement at the Javits Center, Manhattan's primary center for trade shows and expositions. After a long history of allegations and investigations surrounding the nine-year-old center, state officials have begun an investigation aimed at rooting out organized crime and lowering the exorbitant costs of producing trade shows there.
Addressing senators from the finance, tourism and labor committees, Gov. George E. Pataki said the center, which is operated by the state, is "failing as an economic engine." He noted that of $73 billion spent directly on conventions around the country each year, only 2 percent, or $1.6 billion, is spent in New York City.
Citing the Javits Center's administration and 13-member board as part of the problem, Mr. Pataki repeated his call for the resignation of the board. He nominated Robert Boyle, the former head of the Hudson Valley Hospital Center and Mr. Pataki's campaign treasurer, to replace Mr. Palomino as chief executive officer of the center. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo had appointed Mr. Palomino, an old friend.
Mr. Pataki also nominated Gerald McQueen, a former New York City detective who currently investigates labor racketeering in the Manhattan District Attorney's office, to become the center's inspector general. Both nominations require approval from the center's board, and Mr. Pataki is unlikely to place the nominations before the governing body until he has the people he wants on the board in place.
For the fiscal year that ended on March 31, 1994, the convention center had total operating revenues of $35 million, but posted a net operating loss of $1.1 million, compared with a loss of $17,000 in the previous year, according to a private auditor's report. Although the report was completed last July, it still has not been approved by the entire board.
Yesterday's five-hour hearing was scheduled on short notice, and there were times when that short notice and the legislators' little preparation were apparent.
While questioning Mr. Devine, who in recent days has come under fire from a Federal investigator monitoring organized crime in the carpenters union, the senators relied heavily on newspaper clippings despite the extensive detail in court filings that are on the public record concerning Mr. Devine and activity by the carpenters union at the Javits Center.
With his lawyer at his side, Mr. Devine said his union members were being unfairly blamed for the high cost of trade show and convention business in New York City.
The problem, he said, is not labor costs, but the wide cost margins that show managers and contractors set. "Don't ask my members to take less than a decent wage so that national and international companies can profit on the backs and sweat of honest, hardworking New Yorkers," he said. "The New Yorkers I refer to vote for you. The contractors from out of town don't."
Mr. Devine tried vigorously to distance himself from Mr. Fiorino and Mr. Simon, saying he knew little about them when he gave them authority for carpenter job referrals last year. According to Federal court papers, Mr. Devine sent an April 25, 1994, letter addressed, "To Whom it May Concern," giving control of hiring at the Javits Center to Mr. Fiorino and Mr. Simon.
Since that time, Kenneth Conboy, an investigator appointed as the result of a Federal racketeering case brought against the carpenters union, has presented evidence showing that Mr. Fiorino and Mr. Simon are both in-laws of men involved in the Genovese crime family. Further, Mr. Conboy has charged, Mr. Fiorino and Mr. Simon used their authority to give jobs only to people on a preferred list of about 100 workers, instead of to the entire union membership.
Neither Mr. Fiorino nor Mr. Simon were invited to appear before the committee. Though both men still work at the center they have not returned telephone calls seeking comment. Mr. Fiorino, court papers show, is the brother-in-law of Liborio Bellomo, the reputed acting boss of the Genovese crime family. Mr. Simon is the brother-on-law of Ralph Coppola, also a member of the crime family, court papers say. Mr. Devine told the Senate committee that if he's given proof "other than them being related to family members, I will remove them."
Mr. Palomino told the panel that an associate had warned him that the two shop stewards might have mob ties, but he had continued working with them and turned all mob-related intelligence that he gathered over to Mr. Conboy. He denied that he recommended that Mr. Devine make the two men shop stewards and insisted that he never even talked to them until "I got the letter from Devine."
Appointed in 1991 by Mr. Cuomo, Mr. Palomino has worked in the administration of three New York Governors. He vehemently denied accusations that he acted improperly in awarding contracts at the Javits Center without putting them out for competitive bidding.
"I wasn't running around looking to do business with my friends," he said. "Look, I never did that in my life."
Yesterday's hearing, held in the midtown offices of the State Power Authority, was the first of several that will explore the problems at the Javits Center and search for ways to rid it of corruption and to make it a more cost-effective and attractive venue for events.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appeared before the panel and outlined several steps that he said the state should take to make the center competitive with exhibition halls in other cities.
Mr. Giuliani, a former prosecutor, said that a Federal racketeering case against the center was likely the most "comprehensive and expeditious" way to root out organized crime. Once the center is free of the mob, he said, it should be put in the hands of professional managers. Privately managed centers in San Francisco, Miami and Denver operate "at a much lower cost and greater efficiency than the Javits Center," the Mayor said.
He also noted that his recent attempts to attract the Republican and Democratic National Conventions made it clear to him that the Javits Center is not big enough to meet the space requirements for such large conventions.
Others who addressed the panel also noted that the Javits Center may eventually need to be expanded or another center like the Coliseum, renovated and reopened.
