HEADLINE: Cortines Has Plan to Coach Minorities Into Top Schools

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

 BODY:
With white and Asian students dominating enrollment in the city's best high schools, Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines yesterday proposed opening a new math and science institute to coach 350 seventh and eighth graders, most of whom would be black and Hispanic, for the notoriously difficult entrance exams to Stuyvesant High School, Bronx High School of Science and Brooklyn Technical High School.
At Stuyvesant, a school nationally renowned for its academic excellence and the most selective of the three, only 4.8 percent of the students are black, down from 12.9 percent in 1979. Half the students at Stuyvesant are Asian, 40 percent are white and 4.3 percent call themselves Hispanic. Total enrollment at the three high schools is 10,145. 
 By giving special training aimed at enlarging the pool of black and Hispanic candidates eligible for admission to the selective schools, Mr. Cortines would avoid setting quotas, which are currently under challenge in several cities.
In San Francisco, for example, Asian parents have brought a Federal suit saying that racial quotas limiting Asian students to 40 percent of enrollment have kept some talented Chinese-American students from attending the city's best schools, even though their entrance test scores may have been better than those of students in other groups.
"I am not offering any free rides," Mr. Cortines said in a statement released yesterday.
Under the plan, to begin this summer, seventh and eighth graders will be selected by the superintendents of the 32 local community school districts, working jointly with the staff for the new program, which has yet to be hired. Many details have not been worked out -- for instance, there are plans to house the institute at one of the three elite high schools, but that is not certain.
Students will attend classes during the summer, and in some cases on weekends or after school, though they will get no extra academic credit toward admission. Classes will try to improve time management and study habits, as well as critical thinking and research skills. The staff will also work with students' families to help them support the rigorous academic exercises.
Mr. Cortines is not acting out of any mandate to make changes at the high schools, said Dr. Beverly Hall, the deputy chancellor for instruction, nor has he particularly felt pressure from community groups to offer such help. Instead, she said, Mr. Cortines is adhering to a plan he set when he became Chancellor in 1993 that the schools should be raising the standards for all students, regardless of race and economic background. (Mr. Cortines was on vacation yesterday and could not be reached for comment.)
Dr. Hall said Mr. Cortines and other officials studied data that showed students entered the specialized science schools more often from some districts than from others, and they concluded that poor preparation by teachers and socioeconomic pressures may be to blame.
District 2 in Manhattan, which includes the affluent Upper East Side, sent the most children to ninth grade in the specialized schools in September, and District 7, in an impoverished area of the South Bronx, sent the fewest.
"As educators, we have a responsibility to insure that every child has an opportunity to excel," Mr. Cortines said in his statement. "The data suggest to me that we are not meeting this responsibility."
And part of this may also have to do with the feelings of some black and Hispanic children about the specialized schools. On the sidewalk outside Intermediate School 54 on West 107th Street, some seventh and eighth graders said that they had never considered attending any of the specialized high schools.
"Why would I want to go there?" said Josue Mendez, a seventh-grader, referring to Stuyvesant. "It's a white school."
Students of any race and from any part of the city will be accepted at the planned institute, tentatively named the Math-Science Institute, but the emphasis will be on the districts that are now underrepresented at the specialized high schools.
"If we're talking about higher standards for all students, and if we believe that all children can learn and learn at the highest levels, then the question became, shouldn't we be addressing some of these problems?" Dr. Hall said. "These schools are considered among the finest schools in the country. Why shouldn't they represent the children of this school system?"
The school system is projecting that the cost of the institute will be $680,000 the first year, and $880,000 per year after that. The financing is expected to come from Federal funds or from private foundation money, she said, although that also has not yet been decided.
Reaction to the plan from parents and students was mixed.
Monique Little, a seventh grader who said she planned to apply to Brooklyn Tech, said that schools would be better environments for learning if all ethnic groups were better represented.
"It gives other races the opportunity to learn about each other," she said. "There's the stereotype that white schools are good and black and Hispanic schools like this are bad."
At Stuyvesant High School, in lower Manhattan, some students said the rigorous curriculum required students to be self-motivated as well as academically prepared.
Howard Hua, a 17-year-old senior from Manhattan, said that offering what he called a prep test program aimed at minority students was "reverse racism."
"If you're going to do it, you've got to do it for everybody," he said. "People who are here know they are here because they earned it. Doing something like this would change a lot of the academic scene here."
But his friend, Johnny Eng, 17, from Queens, said many Stuyvesant students do have the advantage of extra help.
"There are students here whose families are rich enough to pay for courses that helped them do better on the exams, and that gave them an unfair advantage, so this could even things out for others who can't afford something like that," Mr. Eng said.
Jamil Ellis, 17, the senior class president, who is black, said that offering a prep course to minorities, especially black students, was a good idea.
"Right now, the demographics of the school aren't representative of the city," he said. "Preparation for the exam is essential, and in some other districts that are predominantly black, the kids aren't as prepared as they need to be."
Stoney McMurray, whose son attends Brooklyn Technical High School, which has higher black and Hispanic enrollment than the other two schools, said that not all poor districts did a bad job of preparing children.
"There are some junior high schools that don't even tell their black and Hispanic kids about the exams and don't encourage them," said Mr. McMurray, a co-leader of the parent association at Brooklyn Technical. "But then, there are districts in poor minority neighborhoods that have run their own little courses to help them on tests."
Mr. McMurray said he worried that some white parents would see the institute as giving an unfair advantage to minority students.
"I don't feel that way," he said. "It really is a shame to waste the kind of mind that can do math or science. We need those folks, whatever they are and wherever we get them from."

HEADLINE: President of Serbia: A Pendulum Halted in Mid-Arc

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia

 BODY:
During a recent spell in prison, the leader of Serbia's extreme nationalist Radical Party taught wardens and other inmates rousing songs about the day President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia hangs from a pylon in central Belgrade.
"It was my best spell ever in prison," said the party leader, Vojislav Seselj, who was once a close ally of Mr. Milosevic. "The songs were really popular with the guards. One had a chorus about Milosevic hanging there and all his secret police were crying." 
 Ultranationalists like Mr. Seselj, who was imprisoned for spitting at the Speaker of the Serbian Parliament, are not strong enough to pose a direct threat to the Serbian leader. But their attacks are a reminder of the political distance traveled by Mr. Milosevic, who once used Mr. Seselj's volunteers to spread terror in Bosnia.
The contradictions of this political voyage -- from bellicose Serbian nationalist to calculating peacemaker -- are now closing in on Mr. Milosevic, leaving him in a state of unusual indecision, senior Serbian officials and Western diplomats say.
This uneasiness stems from the fact that the abandonment of virulent nationalism, an abandonment symbolized by the imposition of a blockade on the Bosnian Serbs last August, has not won Mr. Milosevic any new constituencies, leaving him increasingly dependent on repression to maintain his hold on power.
In recent weeks Mr. Milosevic, 53, has embarked on a ferocious attempt to stifle the remaining independent news outlets, especially through an attempted takeover of Belgrade's most important independent television station, Studio B.
The attack on Studio B follows that on the opposition newspaper Borba, and has been based on the same dubious allegation that the properties were never legally transferred to private hands.
Behind the onslaught there appears to lie a sudden concern that all dissenting voices should be silenced.
Business executives and politicians say Mr. Milosevic has also increased harassment of opposition parties and private companies through his police force, now thought to number as many as 130,000 armed men, and stepped up repression of ethnic Albanians.
"Milosevic is trying to centralize and control everything because he is nervous," said Zoran Djindjic, the leader of the opposition Democratic Party. "He abandoned the nationalist card that brought him to power but has no economic benefits to show in return. So he is tightening the police state because he does not know which way to turn."
The increased repression has come at a time when Serbia's economy, battered by sanctions, is showing signs of renewed inflation. Money-changers have abruptly reappeared on the street offering 1.7 dinars for a German mark, while the official exchange rate is one to one.
It is against this background that Mr. Milosevic was recently presented by the United States and Europe with a crucial choice: bring about the lifting of sanctions and shore up your economy by recognizing the international borders of Bosnia and Croatia, or remain in isolation with your thinly veiled ambitions for a Greater Serbia intact.
Officials close to Mr. Milosevic -- who, true to his reclusive style, declined to be interviewed -- say he was angered by the offer because he believes that his blockade of the Bosnian Serbs should have been enough to end the sanctions. Instead some minor concessions were made, including an opening of the Belgrade airport.
"The immediate lifting of all sanctions is the key question," said Vladislav Jovanovic, the Foreign Minister of Yugoslavia, which is dominated by the Serbs. "Serious negotiations are impossible until we have been placed on an equal footing."
Behind this official bluster, however, lurk deeper concerns. The fact is that Mr. Milosevic has to demand a lifting of sanctions without recognition of Croatia and Bosnia because recognition is an almost impossible political step for him at this stage.
Several Serbian and Western officials said that beyond the attacks by people like Mr. Seselj, there lurks a solid body of opinion in the army, in the police and in the population at large that simply would not accept the formal abandonment of the Serbs of Bosnia and Croatia that recognition would represent. Serbs currently hold 70 percent of Bosnia and 30 percent of Croatia.
"Milosevic now feels he cannot risk an all-out attack on Karadzic," a Western official said, referring to the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic. "He's a little nervous and surprised that he had been unable to deal with Karadzic. He turned the propaganda machine on him for a couple of months, calling him a scurrilous crook, but then he saw the lie of the land, especially in the Yugoslav Army, and he dropped it."
A sharp enmity now exists between Mr. Milosevic and Dr. Karadzic, who has become ever more outspoken in his support for the Serbian Orthodox Church, private enterprise and even the possible return of the Serbian royal family.
Banished from the Government-run television since last August, Dr. Karadzic has been appearing regularly on Studio B -- one possible reason for the attack on the station.
Thus, almost six years after Mr. Milosevic descended in a helicopter onto the sacred Serbian battlefield of Kosovo, where Serbs were defeated by the Ottoman Turks in 1389, and warned of the war he saw looming in Yugoslavia, he finds himself transformed from the acclaimed hero of a resurgent Serbia into the cornered strongman of a devastated country.
He is in no immediate danger because his police force is strong and intensely loyal, but his policies appear to have led his country to economic ruin and a political dead end.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In more civil days, President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, left, gave moral and material support to Radovan Karadzic, right, the leader of the Bosnian Serbs. Now Mr. Milosevic has cut off aid to Dr. Karadzic in an effort, so far futile, to convince the West to lift crippling economic sanctions on Serbia. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Ahmed Khomeini Is Dead; Son of Ayatollah Khomeini

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Ahmed Khomeini, a leading Islamic radical who was Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's son and a member of Iran's Supreme National Security Council, died yesterday at a hospital in North Teheran. He was about 50 and lived in the Teheran area.
Mr. Khomeini had been in a coma since Sunday, when he suffered cardiac arrest and was admitted to the hospital, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. 
 One of his doctors said he died some hours after he was put on a life-support machine.
"He was a prominent face in the struggle against the oppressors," the news agency said, "and spared no efforts to safeguard the legacy of his immortal father." The Government announced two days of national mourning.
A torch-bearer for his father's anti-Western radicalism, Ahmed Khomeini was viewed as Ayatollah Khomeini's closest aide during the decade after the 1979 Islamic revolution.
Many speculated he might eventually succeed his father as Iran's political leader, but he lost a brief power struggle with the pragmatic Speaker of Parliament, Hashemi Rafsanjani, who was elected President after Ayatollah Khomeini's death in June 1989.
Mr. Khomeini instead became the overseer of his father's mausoleum south of Teheran and was named to the Supreme National Security Council, which oversees defense and security policy and coordinates intelligence activities.
As his father's chief of staff, Ahmed Khomeini played a prominent role in the Iran hostage crisis of 1979 to 1981, making tough anti-American statements and visiting the United States Embassy compound to congratulate the captors of more than 50 American hostages there. The hostage-takers were said to have told him in advance of their plans to invade the compound.
He spoke out frequently against the United States and Israel and what he described as exploitative Iranian capitalists.
In 1993 he denounced the peace accord signed by Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization as "treachery to the aspirations of the Palestinian nation and the world of Islam."
Addressing himself to the United States during a speech last month marking the 16th anniversary of the Islamic revolution, he cried "Death to you!" as thousands of Iranian listeners cheered.
Mr. Khomeini also wielded influence over Iranian Government policy through allies in the Revolutionary Guards militia and in other centers of power.
News reports have suggested recently that he may have been connected to the Iranian Government's smuggling of military equipment and parts from Europe.
A Shiite Muslim cleric who held the religious title of hojatolislam, Ahmed Khomeini first came to international attention during the Islamic revolution that ousted the pro-Western regime of Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlevi in 1979.
Television broadcasts showed him at his father's side when the Ayatollah returned to Teheran on Jan. 31, 1979, after 15 years in exile. The Shah's Government was toppled 10 days later.
As the Ayatollah's chief assistant and only surviving son -- two others had died -- Mr. Khomeini wielded immense power by controlling access to him.
He quickly assumed a prominent role when the hostage crisis began on Nov. 4, 1979. By some accounts militant Iranian students informed him in advance of what they originally planned as a sit-in at the United States Embassy.
Recalling the days after the takeover, Gary G. Sick, a White House aide at the time, later wrote: "It was with relief that we learned that Ahmed was on his way to the embassy. What we had not expected was that Ahmed would clamber excitedly over the embassy wall, losing his turban in the process, and congratulate the students for their action. As that fact became known, the deadly seriousness of the situation became apparent for the first time."
Scores of Americans in the embassy were held prisoner until early 1981, when the United States released more than $7 billion in Iranian assets and the captives were set free.
Later a former hostage, Robert O. Blucker, an embassy economics officer, described watching Mr. Khomeini visit the compound "to see the Persians and greet them and encourage them in what they were doing."
"He was fingering his worry beads and smiling and talking to them," Mr. Blucker went on. "He didn't want to look at any of us."
Mr. Khomeini asserted that documents found at the embassy showed that "some of the hostages are officially C.I.A. agents," and repeated a threat by his father to put some of the captives on trial for spying if the recently dethroned Shah was not returned to Iran.
Accounts of Khomeini family history vary, but the Egyptian editor Mohamed Heikal, in his book "The Return of the Ayatollah" (1981, Deutsch), and the Indian author Dilip Hiro, in his book "Iran under the Ayatollahs" (1985, Routledge), have written that Ahmed was one of eight children born to Ayatollah Khomeini and his wife, Khadijah.
Before the revolution, Ahmed Khomeini underwent military training in 1974 and 1975 with Palestinian fighters outside Tyre in Lebanon.
He is survived by his wife and three sons, of whom the eldest, Hassan, 23, is studying theology in Qom, a religious city 75 miles south of Teheran.

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
Religion played a leading role in the story of the United Nations Conference on Population and Development, which was held in Cairo last August. The Vatican rallied Muslim leaders and some other religious believers to eliminate language in official statements that could have become the basis for an international right to abortion.
That jousting continued this week. The Religion News Service reported that for the moment, the Vatican had kept an American abortion rights group, Catholics for a Free Choice, and sister organizations in Brazil, Mexico and Uruguay from gaining credentials to September's World Conference on Women, to be held in Beijing. 
 But what about the United Nations World Summit for Social Development, which concluded in Copenhagen last weekend with fresh pledges from Vice President Al Gore and more than 120 other world leaders to eradicate global poverty? Was religion absent? Or was this a classic example of "no conflict, no news"?
Definitely the latter, said the Rev. Joan B. Campbell, General Secretary of the National Council of Churches, and William F. Vendley, Secretary General of the World Conference on Religion and Peace, two religious leaders who had been active at both Cairo and Copenhagen.
They pointed out that similar religious forces -- the Vatican, the World Council of Churches and an array of Muslim, Buddhist and other religious groups -- were represented at both gatherings. But this time the forces of faith agreed, with each other and their secular counterparts.
Muslim leaders, the Vatican and Hillary Clinton, who spoke at the meeting, all insisted that education for girls and young women was essential to economic and social development. Religious groups participating in a parallel conference of nongovernmental organizations were among the loudest voices calling for the forgiveness of poor nations' international debts. The Vatican converged with feminist lobbies, Ms. Campbell pointed out, in demanding that the economic value of women's work at home be recognized in the kind of economic statistics that underlie every nation's planning and policy making.
The conference on social development was "ready-made for people of faith," Ms. Campbell said. She noted that at the beginning of the gathering's official declaration and program of action, world leaders acknowledged that their societies must meet the "spiritual needs of individuals" as well as the material ones.
"The United Nations document read more like something from a church," she said.
Dr. Vendley suggested, by way of explanation, that when the United Nations tried to flesh out what it meant by a notion like "social development," it was "being forced into language familiar to religions" by addressing questions like "who are we?" and "where are we going?" and "what do we owe one another?"
The organizers of the Copenhagen conference even held a preparatory "Seminar on the Ethical and Spiritual Dimensions of Social Progress" last October in Bled, Slovenia. In this and other conversations that took place in connection with the gathering, Dr. Vendley sees the first steps toward "elaborating a positive vision of a common human destiny, although obviously in the appropriately this-worldly terms."
Much in these gropings toward a new vision is sharply at odds with the market-based, growth-oriented, technology-driven economic development plans that are in use.
"Our current dilemma is that we use a social development model when we state our intentions, but that we apply an economic growth model when we act," Konrad Raiser, General Secretary of the World Council of Churches, told a plenary session of the Copenhagen conference.
Of course, the resemblance of Copenhagen to the Sunday pulpit may also spring from the fact that exhortation, fervor and pledges are generally the stuff of such conferences.
Ms. Campbell wryly noted the parallel between the gathering and her own National Council of Churches, which can advise, prod, inspire and assist its 32 member churches but cannot tell them what to do.
Both Ms. Campbell and Dr. Vendley contrasted the charged atmosphere of Cairo with the urgent but cooperative mood of Copenhagen. At Cairo, the abortion debate created such acrimony that even a proposed prayer service aimed at healing the divisions was abandoned, Ms. Campbell recalled.
At Copenhagen three interfaith services were among the religious events marking the gathering. Still more significant was the formation by some of the world's largest Christian and Muslim relief organizations of a joint Committee on Interreligious Development Action.
The new committee, organized with the help of the World Conference on Religion and Peace, is taking a step beyond Christian-Muslim dialogue, said Kamel al-Sherif, who heads the International Islamic Council based in Cairo. "We are undertaking concrete projects in development and relief," he said. "Now we are getting practical."
The committee, which brings together Orthodox Christian, Protestant and Catholic as well as Islamic groups, is organizing a joint delegation to Russia to insure the flow of humanitarian aid to Chechnya, where Christians and Muslims, as in Bosnia and the Sudan, are divided by war.
"Religion has been exploited and misused to promote hatred," Mr. Sherif said. "It is time to present religion in its true spirit."
This initiative alone speaks volumes about the spirit of Copenhagen.

HEADLINE: G.M. to Delay Introductions of Several Vehicles

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that several new vehicles, including its next generation of mini-vans, would reach showrooms three to six months later than it had planned.
G.M. portrayed the decision as a result of a routine reappraisal of product schedules. But Wall Street analysts said G.M.'s seven-month struggle to introduce two new small cars had diverted engineers from the other vehicle programs, contributing to the delay. 
 Whatever the cause, the scheduling change will give G.M.'s competitors more breathing space in crucial market segments. The Chrysler Corporation, for example, plans to start selling a new mini-van this spring, and can now look forward to a year and a half without serious competition from G.M.
G.M. brought out its current line of front-wheel-drive mini-vans, including the Chevrolet Lumina, in 1989, and their doorstop shape never caught on.
Further, the later the new cars and trucks arrive in showrooms, the more likely that G.M. could find itself with more new vehicles than buyers, should the economy weaken.
But Wall Street analysts said that if the delay prevented in future introductions the kind of production problems G.M. has experienced lately, it would be a boon.
"They could rush the program, and then you end up with problems," said Joseph S. Phillippi, an auto stock analyst with Lehman Brothers in New York. "The delay is more than likely going to result in -- I would hope, I would expect -- in launching cleaner."
John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s president and chief executive, has made establishing a strict "cadence" for new product introductions a cornerstone of his turnaround strategy. Too often, he has said, G.M. postponed or canceled product plans when the economy went sour, allowing its lineup to grow stale.
While G.M. has managed new light-truck introductions without serious delays, it has had great difficulty bringing out some cars. G.M. began producing the new small cars -- the Chevrolet Cavalier and Pontiac Sunfire -- last August, but executives say the plant where they are made might not reach full production before the third quarter of 1995.
G.M. denied that the scheduling changes would cause even short-term competitive woes. "We can assure you that our product lineup of offerings will be very competitive, in terms of their timing," said Linda Cook, a G.M. spokeswoman. "There were some minor adjustments made in a few programs, but no more than a few months."
She acknowledged that G.M.'s next generation of mini-vans was among those programs. The vans were originally set to arrive in late spring 1996, but are now unlikely to reach showrooms until fall 1996.
At a meeting with securities analysts near New York on Wednesday, G.M.'s top executives indicated that the new Pontiac Grand Prix would also be delayed from mid-1996 to late 1996, analysts who were present said. And an all-new model, the Chevrolet Malibu, is also likely to be delayed, since it shares a basic chassis with the two other vehicles.
David Healy, auto industry stock analyst with S. G. Warburg, said he had already expected the vehicles to arrive late. "It appeared to me that G.M had almost nothing for 18 months, and then a lot coming all at once, which sort of conflicted with the objective of a smooth regular introduction of new models," he said.
The bunching of new models at G.M. means that at least for the next two years, its "market share will tend to continue to drift down," Mr. Healy said.
But David Bradley, a stock analyst at J. P. Morgan, said that the new vehicles would be worth the wait. "They're stunning," he said after getting an early look at them.

'GM' Is Gone From Unit's Name
 (By Bloomberg Business News) -- LOS ANGELES, March 17 -- The General Motors Corporation said today that it had dropped its name from the GM Hughes Electronics Corporation, leading some analysts to speculate that the auto maker might be preparing to sell all or part of the military and electronics unit.
GM Hughes Electronics, which is based in Los Angeles, will now be known as the Hughes Electronics Corporation. In a second name change, the unit's military, electronics and information-systems business, the Hughes Aerospace and Electronics Company, will operate under the name Hughes Aircraft Company.
Industry analysts said that by dropping GM from the name, the company could be moving closer to selling the electronics unit.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Hits Low vs. the Yen And Mark Continues Surge

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled yesterday, falling to a record low against the Japanese yen in New York trading.
 The dollar was weakened by the continued advance of the German mark, which surged to record highs against the British pound, Italian lira and Spanish peseta. 
 When the mark rises against European currencies, it tends to rise against the dollar also, as currency dealers around the world buy the German currency. "The mark is again dominant in Europe, and that filters into the mark against the dollar as well," said Belal Khan, chief customer dealer at the Bank of Tokyo in New York.
 A surplus of dollars on the world's currency markets has also worsened the dollar's slide against the yen. And the slide has accelerated in the last two weeks as Japanese companies and funds sell foreign currencies -- and the dollar in particular -- for yen ahead of the close of their fiscal year on March 31.
 In New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 89.06 yen from 90.20 yen on Thursday, and the lowest late New York price since Wednesday, when it settled at 89.50. The dollar is near its intraday trading low of 88.76, which was touched on March 8. The dollar fell to 1.3865 marks, from 1.3965 marks on Thursday.
 The mark has gathered strength in recent months from continuing political uncertainty in Britain, Italy and Spain. As the currency of Europe's strongest and most stable economy, the mark typically benefits from political and economic volatility elsewhere on the Continent.
Yesterday's buying was also bolstered by a decision by the Bundesbank on Thursday to leave interest rates unchanged. Higher rates help a currency by making bank deposits denominated in it more attractive.
 The pound dropped to a low of 2.1872 marks late yesterday, from 2.2176 marks, in New York. The mark hit a high of 1,275.92 lire yesterday, up more than 60 lire from 1,213.96 lire, and a high of 93.45 pesetas yesterday, up from 91.92 pesetas.
 The central banks of Italy and Spain bought their currencies for marks in an effort to stem the rout, traders said.
 The market is rife with speculation that the peseta will withdraw from Europe's exchange rate mechanism, which prescribes trading bands for nine currencies.
 The currencies are allowed to move 15 percent in either direction from their assigned parity levels against other currencies. When they reach their outer limits, the countries' central banks must buy or sell them to keep them within their bands. Italy and Britain were forced out of the exchange rate mechanism more than two years ago.
 "The E.R.M. is unraveling," said Robert White, manager of currency trading at the Standard Chartered Bank in New York. "You have to question its ability to stay intact."

HEADLINE: Opening the Fed's Doors From Inside;
Alan Blinder Preaches Communication at Tight-Lipped Central Bank

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
What is most striking about Alan S. Blinder's large, sunny office at the Federal Reserve is how quiet it is. That's partly tradition. The men and women who set the nation's interest rates don't drop in on one another very often. But for Mr. Blinder, who came aboard last summer as the Fed's vice chairman, hoping to make his voice heard, the isolation was a big obstacle.
"I thought there would be more governor-to-governor chitchat," Mr. Blinder said in an interview. "I thought the staff would be walking in to my office more, telling me, 'You ought to know about this; you ought to know about that.' That happens to some extent, but not nearly as much as I had imagined it would." 
 Mr. Blinder found his impact inside the Fed largely limited to what he had to say at meetings of the central bank's policy makers -- meetings dominated by the chairman, Alan Greenspan. But he also took his case to the public, revealing in speeches and interviews the dynamics of the Fed's private policy debates. And gradually Mr. Blinder's influence is starting to be felt.
"My biggest disagreement with my colleagues at the Fed is over openness," Mr. Blinder said. "I believe we should talk to society more and say what we are doing and why we think it is right. But the position of this institution has always been to be extremely tight-lipped."
In breaking with that tradition, he has emerged as the highest official in Washington to publicly caution the Federal Reserve -- his colleagues -- against raising interest rates too much before it is clear to what extent earlier increases will brake the economy. In the past, the White House and Congress played this role. Mr. Blinder's efforts are aimed partly to offset pressure from bond traders who want more rate rises to fight inflation.
"Someone asked me during a recent speech, do I think we can ever achieve zero inflation," Mr. Blinder said. "I said, 'Absolutely, yes.' We can get there in only a couple of years if we are willing to pay the price. But I think if you put the question to ordinary people -- 'Would you like right now to have a recession like the one in the early 1990's to get inflation to zero by 1997?' -- you would be hard put to find a single vote. You can have a more moderate strategy, arriving more slowly with less pain."
Mr. Blinder's impact on the Federal Reserve's actual decisions -- as the first vice chairman appointed by a Democratic President since the 1970's -- is harder to measure. While his predecessors as vice chairman, David W. Mullins Jr. and Manuel H. Johnson Jr., were mainly inflation fighters like Mr. Greenspan, Mr. Blinder provides a different counterpoint. For him, unemployment and inflation should be of equal concern.
Most of the Fed's policy makers -- its governors and the presidents of its regional banks -- endorse at their periodic gatherings the decisions on interest rates their chairman favors. But one or two are beginning to acknowledge the influence of Mr. Blinder and of another Clinton appointee, Janet L. Yellen, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley who also became a Fed governor last year.
"Hopefully, when the time comes to move in the other direction and ease interest rates to avoid a recession, we will be able to move sooner than we otherwise might have," said a top Fed official who declined to be identified. "The Blinder-Yellen analysis may be part of that change."
But not yet. Mr. Blinder's first two attempts to buck rate increases fell short, Fed officials say. Last November, four months after joining the Fed, he argued unsuccessfully against Mr. Greenspan's proposal to raise short-term interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point. Mr. Blinder and Ms. Yellen instead favored an increase of half a percentage point, Fed officials said. Two meetings later, they reportedly argued against the half-point increase that the Fed's policy makers approved on Feb. 1.
"I believe the classic mistake of Fed policy is to not look far enough ahead and to overreact," Ms. Yellen said. "You have to guard against a possibility that we could say, 'Let's clobber the economy because it has not slowed down enough yet.' "
For all their resistance to higher rates, however, Mr. Blinder and Ms. Yellen voted with the majority in November and in February. "Dissent around here, any dissenting vote, is a big deal," Mr. Blinder said. "This is not like the Supreme Court, where you regularly get 6-3 or 5-4 votes. So you hold your fire until you feel you must shoot."
That dissenting vote almost certainly will not come at the next meeting, on March 28. Evidence in recent weeks of a slowing economy seems likely to keep the policy makers from making any changes in rates.
What's more, the talkative Mr. Blinder, who is 49, shares with the more solemn Mr. Greenspan, who is 69, a basic view that softens their differences. Rate increases are indeed necessary, Mr. Blinder says, when future inflation threatens. He had no problem, he says, with the Fed's rate increases through most of last year. And these increases should curb rising prices over the long run.
Where Mr. Blinder's differences with Mr. Greenspan show up is in the short run, the two or three years of hardship that rising interest rates often bring. Mr. Blinder argues that unemployment might rise to unnecessarily painful levels starting next year if he and his colleagues go too far now in their effort to slow the economy with rate increases.
Mr. Greenspan, as Fed chairman, has argued that whatever this risk, fighting inflation should be the primary goal -- a view he repeated in Congressional testimony this month.
There are other differences, which seem to work against Mr. Blinder's being considered for Fed chairman when Mr. Greenspan's term expires next year. While Mr. Blinder argues that reversing an increase in inflation is no more difficult than reversing disinflation and a declining economy, Mr. Greenspan says an uptick in inflation is the greater danger and the more difficult to reverse.
Mr. Blinder, the theoretician, relies heavily on computer models that demonstrate the long lags between changes in interest rates and their effects on the economy. Pay less attention to what is happening today, he says. The real impact on employment and inflation from the rate increases of the last year will not begin until months from now.
Mr. Greenspan, on the other hand, puts more faith in projections based on what he sees happening now in various crucial sectors of the economy, which is how he built his reputation as a private economist.
Finally, Mr. Blinder, an economics professor at Princeton University before he joined President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers in 1993, has not yet built the alliances within the institution that some of his predecessors had. Mr. Blinder's sway with his Fed colleagues is concentrated in the appeals he makes at the Fed's periodic meetings. They rely heavily on his skill as a theoretician, laced with what Edward W. Kelley Jr., a Fed governor, called Mr. Blinder's "wry sense of humor and a way of expressing himself that is really nice."
But Mr. Greenspan is the more skilled and experienced politician, having developed close ties over the years to the Fed's other leaders -- ties that Mr. Blinder lacks.
Mr. Blinder has instead taken his views much more to the public, offering to outsiders an insider's glimpse of the debate that takes place when the policy makers gather around the huge oak table in the closed-off board room at the Fed's headquarters. Although the Fed has gradually become more open in the last year -- announcing its decisions on interest rates, for example, on the day they are made -- there is resistance among the policy makers to going further.
Mr. Blinder has argued for an essay-style communique to accompany announcements of rate changes, instead of the two-sentence releases that are now the standard. Under current practice, the heavily edited minutes are only issued six weeks after each meeting.
But don't look for more detailed explanations on the day of decision anytime soon. Too much of each meeting, Mr. Greenspan has argued, would have to be devoted to writing carefully worded releases rather than to debating policy.
Still, Mr. Blinder plans to keep plugging away. "If the central bank makes good decisions," he said, "we should not have any trouble explaining them."
 
ALAN S. BLINDER
 
BORN -- Oct. 14, 1945, Brooklyn
 
POSITION -- Vice chairman, Federal Reserve Board
 
RESIDENCE -- Princeton, N.J.
 
EDUCATION -- B.A., Princeton University; M.S. London School of Economics; Ph.D., Massachusettes Institute of Technology .
 
CAREER HIGHLIGHTS -- 1971-93, economics professor, Princeton; 1993-94, member of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers; June 1994, joined Federal Reserve Board as vice chairman.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Mom-and-Pop Travel Agencies Fight to Survive

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

DATELINE: CLARK, N.J.

 BODY:
On one wall of the Travel Wise agency here are rows of glossy brochures beckoning adventurers to the Himalayas, lovers to the Caribbean and families to Disney World. And there are plenty of pictures of Hawaii, Europe and other places that also promise once-in-a-lifetime vacations.
 These days, vacations are something Carol A. Poppel, Travel Wise's owner, sends clients on but no longer takes herself. 
 Buffeted throughout the 90's by downturns in the travel industry, Mrs. Poppel has been the self-described "chief cook and bottle washer" at the agency for quite a while, putting in long hours and six-day weeks to make up for the two fulltime employees she had to drop several years ago. Lately, only one part-timer has been around to help her run the agency, which she has owned since 1977 and is one of five in this city of 15,000, some 20 miles south of Newark International Airport in Union County. Mrs. Poppel no longer even has the time to take advantage of the travel agent's greatest perk: the familiarization, or fam, trips that many resorts and other tourist destinations offer agents at big discounts.
 Now, Mrs. Poppel is trying to adjust to the latest pocket of turbulence to hit her industry: the decision early last month by the major airlines to put a cap on commissions. And while she thinks she will make it through this newest rough spot, others may not be so lucky.
 "For many agencies our size, this is definitely survival time," the 60-year-old Mrs. Poppel said the other day in her cheery storefront.
 Indeed, the American Society of Travel Agents, a trade group, has estimated that as many as 20 percent of the nation's 250,000 agents could lose their jobs as a result of the cap. Under the change, the traditional 10 percent commission on domestic air fares is limited to $50 for a round-trip ticket and $25 for a one-way fare.
 The trade group has plenty of reason to paint the bleakest picture, but it is unclear whether the situation is quite that dire. In any event, the group has filed an antitrust suit against the airlines and asked that the cap be lifted in the interim.
 Travel agents, particularly mom-and-pop operators like Mrs. Poppel, were having a tough go of it even before the cap.
 In the last three years, more than 7,500 travel agencies closed, victims of everything from the recession to travel jitters caused by the Persian Gulf war, and many others affiliated or merged with larger agencies to survive. Small, unaffiliated agencies like Travel Wise still outnumber the big ones -- there are about 32,500 agencies in all -- but they are the most vulnerable to the vagaries of the economy and to the growing incursion of electronic ticketing through on-line computer services.
 Now comes the commission cap, which threatens the bedrock of most agent relationships with customers: the free ride.
 "We don't have any choice but to charge fees," said Mrs. Poppel, who hasn't set a date yet for imposing them after years of running advertisements boasting, "No charge for our service." She added, "Except for our steady clients, we're going to have to charge for things like reissuing tickets, long-distance calls, sending faxes -- the kinds of services we always did for free."
 Industry giants like American Express/Thomas Cook and Carlson Wagonlit have already imposed some fees, followed by a growing number of smaller agencies. Some are charging for the booking itself. Even if the cap is lifted, fees for reissuing tickets and other loss leaders are likely to stay and spread, industry experts say, given all the other cost pressures in the business.
 The danger, of course, is that such fees will drive customers away, either to book directly with airlines and hotels or to do so electronically.
 For Mrs. Poppel, the commission cap crisis could delay her journey back to the high point of her business, in 1989, when Travel Wise had bookings of $1.03 million. Bookings declined every year since, until last year, when they started back up, along with the economy, and hit about $900,000. When this year began, Mrs. Poppel had hopes of reaching the $1 million mark again.
 Until the commission flap started, her cut of most bookings had averaged slightly more than 10 percent, with tickets for cruise ships and many international flights paying more. Out of those commissions, roughly $90,000 last year, Mrs. Poppel, who is divorced and the mother of two adult children, has to pay her overhead. That includes all those fee-free long-distance calls and faxes as well as the cost of her office and the salary of her part-time employee, Angela Beninato-DaSilva, who does the paperwork.
 Mrs. Poppel thinks she will be hurt less by the commission cap than will most other agencies because of the nature of her clientele. About 60 percent of her bookings come from corporate accounts, typically engineering, environmental and electronic companies with 5 to 20 employees whose travel budgets are too small to interest the big agencies.
 In general, the cap will fall heaviest on corporate air fares, since business travel is largely spur-of-the-moment and therefore does not qualify for advance purchase discounts. But because of their tight budgets, many of Mrs. Poppel's clients tend to be thriftier than other business travelers, making the imposition of the cap less of a jolt to her bottom line while keeping the clients eager for her services.
 "Carol gets us good deals," said Eric Kash, president of Organica Inc., an environmental technology company based in Great Neck, L.I. Organica had two employees when it started in January 1994 and now has 18, and it has done about $100,000 worth of business with Travel Wise.
 Still, Mrs. Poppel is nervous. There isn't that much she can do to generate more income. Much of the lucrative cruise business, for instance, is bypassing small traditional operators in favor of the growing number of agencies, more than 2,000 at last count, that deal exclusively with cruises and generally offer a better price.
 She got her foot in the door, however, with honeymoon trips, a specialty mentioned in many of the agency's ads. Booking the cruises and all-inclusive packages favored by honeymooners provides commissions far higher than on air fares alone.
 But whether the commissions are high or low, Mrs. Poppel said, she earns her keep by winning clients' loyalty, and she does that by scrambling to get them the best deals.
 Larry Kaimowitz of Rahway, N.J., said she did exactly that in planning his honeymoon to Tahiti this July. "We wanted to include a cruise, some time to see the South Pacific and some time to settle down," said Mr. Kaimowitz, who publishes The Commonwealth Courier, a Union County shopper. "She created an itinerary to match. She's very dollar-conscious, so most times she suggested options to save us money."
 But all that takes time. "You can't sit back and rest in this business," Mrs. Poppel said, as she juggled calls and pored over faxes amid all the bucolic images of beaches and mountains. "Especially now, when we're in the battle of our lives."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Independent travel agencies have been hurt by the airlines' decision to put a cap on commissions. Carol A. Poppel, who owns an agency in Clark, N.J., said this was "survival time" for operations like hers. (Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Fiscal Monitors Say Plan For Budget Has Pitfalls

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
The state's Financial Control Board said yesterday that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had proposed significant steps toward straightening out New York City's finances. But it also warned that his plan to close a $2.7 billion budget gap relied heavily on risky assumptions and actions by the state that could fall through, forcing deeper cuts.
 In its report on the Mayor's budget plan, the board, which monitors the city's finances, also said the city faced persistent imbalances in the years ahead because spending would continue to outpace revenues, leaving future budget gaps that will require still more austerity. 
 The board's report underscored the severity of the city's nagging budget problems -- present and future -- despite $2 billion in cuts in the current fiscal year, which ends June 30, and the austere $30.5 billion preliminary budget that Mr. Giuliani proposed in February for the fiscal year that begins in July 1.
 The Mayor's preliminary budget would reduce total city spending by $1.3 billion, or 4 percent, the largest percentage reduction since the Great Depression, by cutting programs that affect millions of New Yorkers, including those for welfare, health care, foster care, education and sanitation.
 "I don't think anyone is fooling themselves that the problem can be solved in one year," said Jeffrey A. Sommer, the acting executive director of the board. "The Mayor has made that clear."
 In the near future, Mr. Sommer said, "There will have to be more cuts," but he added that the Mayor's preliminary plan addressed those, at least in general.
 In contrast to reactions to earlier reports of the board, the Mayor's office responded favorably yesterday. His budget director, Marc V. Shaw, said the report showed that Mr. Giuliani had confronted the city's budget woes head on.
 "It reflects the reality of the tough fiscal situation the city is in," Mr. Shaw said of the report. "And it was very positive in the sense that it complimented the Mayor in addressing that reality."
 In general, the board welcomed the Mayor's preliminary plan to close the $2.7 billion gap in the next fiscal year, saying it relied on far fewer one-time savings. In this fiscal year, the board said the Mayor has used $1.8 billion of these "one shots," including $395 million in savings by refinancing debt and $120 million from the sale to the state of two prisons the city built in upstate New York during the 1980's.
 But the report also noted that the Mayor's plan relied on $600 million in savings from the unions that must still be negotiated and nearly $1.4 billion in savings that require legislative approval in Albany.
 The savings from the state are far from certain. The Mayor, for example, hopes to receive $1.2 billion in savings by cuts in welfare and Medicaid, the cost of which are shared by City Hall and Albany. But Gov. George E. Pataki's budget would save the city only about $800 million.
 Thomas L. McMahon, the finance director for the City Council, which will negotiate the final budget with the Mayor, said the board's report failed to consider the impact on the economy of the state and city cuts in Medicaid and welfare, which, he said, could worsen the city's budget problems.
 "The Council is concerned that many of the proposals in the Mayor's gap-closing plan will have significant social and economic costs and should not be adopted," he said.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Stanford Finally Wins One

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
FIFTY-THREE years is a long time, even for people who take the long view. The scholar-athletes of Stanford University are currently taking exams in their hotel rooms here, and you'd like to think their subject matter is a bit weightier than "When was the last time Stanford won a game in the N.C.A.A. tournament?"
 You could even say it's trivia. But the year 1942 stuck in their minds, even though none of them was born then. 
 "I could have sworn I saw you in that picture," Darren Allaway said to his coach, Mike Montgomery, who wasn't born then, either.
 A lot of things happened between the time Stanford won in 1942 (you have a few seconds to come up with the circumstances) and yesterday, when Stanford beat the University of North Carolina-Charlotte, 70-68, in the first round of the national tournament.
This is what makes the first two days of the tournament such a delight, year after year. There is always an Old Dominion, Manhattan, a Miami of Ohio, to beat a higher-rated team, and there is always a Texas Southern to scare an Arkansas or a St. Peter's to push a Massachusetts, all of which happened on the first two days.
 Or it's a chance for a distinguished university like Stanford to break a 53-year streak, while its cone-shaped green mascot named Tree, wearing what look like $1.98 pajama pants, frolics on the court.
 Among the people who attended Stanford between N.C.A.A. victories were: Dianne Feinstein ('55), Ken Kesey ('59), Sandra Day O'Connor ('50), Sally Ride ('73), Charles Schwab ('59) and Sigourney Weaver ('72).
 With all that talent on campus, Stanford did not qualify for the tournament again until 1989, when it lost in the first round. It also lost in 1992. It did win the 1993 National Invitation Tournament, which, for the last few decades, hasn't meant that much.
 "I don't think about it," Allaway said about the N.C.A.A. gap. "Hank Luisetti -- he was on that team, right?"
 Nice try. Since it's exam week, how do we grade Allaway? Bear in mind, he's from London, the real London, and his pronunciation includes "we had a chawnce." So does he get a B for knowing that Hank Luisetti, the great all-American, even existed? Or does he get a C because Luisetti's last season was 1938? I'm going with the B.
 The first weekend of this national tournament is fun because all sorts of history and people and teams and fans and mascots come winging into an eight-team, four-game opening day. I wasn't aware that Jeff Mullins is the Charlotte coach until he materialized at a news conference. Check the ponytail on scrawny Mike Frensley of St. Peter's. Look at Edgar Padilla dunk for UMass. And watch Tree frolic on the court for Stanford.
 The Stanford mascot used to be an Indian, but in these politically correct days the mascot is Tree. "I think that I shall never see/A column written on a Tree." (Apologies to Joyce Kilmer.) And not only that, but a fighting Tree. Earlier this season, Tree duked it out on court with Oskie the California bear, and both of them got hauled off by the authorities. Tree is actually a sophomore from Chicago named Ari Mervis, and someday he'll be back for the Tree Reunion. There have been three, so far.
The Stanford basketball history is still evolving. This team still hears about the loss to tiny Siena in the first round in 1989. Montgomery took his players to work out in the Siena gym in nearby Loudonville the other day and suddenly realized what a big deal the upset was.
 Now it's up to Stanford to produce the upset. It gets Massachusetts tomorrow. The Stanford players rushed back to work on their papers and their exams yesterday, so they missed Massachusetts swatting St. Peter's, 68-51. But they're thinking big.
 "We can keep taking our finals on the road," said spindly Brevin Knight, the point guard from East Orange, N.J.
 It's a three-weekend endurance haul now. There's a lot of money involved. Stanford's last victory was for the championship in 1942. It was over Dartmouth, of all schools. According to the Stanford media guide, the entire gross for the 1942 tournament was $23,500. After deducting expenses, the champions' share of the booty was exactly $93.75. This year's swag will be slightly more. Sounds like a good economics paper for one of the Stanford players.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Brevin Knight and Mike Montgomery (Michael Okoniewski)

HEADLINE: Don't Spend $1 to Move Yankees to Manhattan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your March 9 article on the Yankees' dissatisfaction with the most recent plans by New York City for renovating Yankee Stadium highlights the absurd lengths to which the Yankees have been successful in dragging the city in their quest to build a state-of-the-art showplace. 
 For years the city has been advancing increasingly more elaborate schemes to transform the structure and environs of Yankee Stadium into a complex that would be more in keeping with the ambiance of Anaheim, Calif., or Central Florida than the Big Apple.
It is becoming clear that no renovation plan, no matter how sound, will satisfy George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the team's principal owner. It can be assumed that what the Yankees really want is a location in midtown Manhattan, most likely the type of structure former Gov. Marion M. Cuomo proposed last year.
As a native-born New Yorker who served last year on a committee organized by former Assemblyman John C. Dearie to keep the Yankees in the Bronx, I feel it is time for the city to put its final offer on the table without the possibility of a midtown location. Until the city makes clear that no midtown option exists, it is unlikely Mr. Steinbrenner will agree to any plan that calls for the team to remain in its historic home.
The Yankees are only worth the vast contemplated expenditure if they remain in the Bronx. As a cornerstone for a renewal that will improve the face of the South Bronx, the $600 million plan recently proposed would be justifiable in this time of massive city budget deficits. Spending that sum on the economically viable West Side of midtown Manhattan is not so justified.
There are alternative uses for that site more beneficial for the city, like housing, office development, entertainment or even recreation for average citizens. A midtown stadium site provides little in the way of return to New York that the city could not duplicate without the expenditure of $600 million or more of public funds.
The site discussed is one of the least accessible parts of Manhattan by public transportation. Indeed the Bronx site, located on two subway lines serving both sides of Manhattan, as well as large parts of the Bronx and Brooklyn, is easier to reach for New Yorkers.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani should no longer sacrifice the dignity of his office in playing along with Mr. Steinbrenner's endless games. If the price of sanity is to lose this once-fabled institution to the New Jersey swamps, that is unfortunate. But spending $1 to relocate the Yankees to Manhattan when city employees are being fired because of lack of money not only is questionable morally, but also makes no economic sense.
 
EUGENE G. BRENNAN
New York, March 15, 1995

HEADLINE: Iraq Holding 2 Americans Seized Near Kuwaiti Border

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
The State Department said today that Iraq is holding two Americans who apparently strayed from Kuwait into Iraq by mistake earlier in the week.
The two civilians were working for an American company in Kuwait, Administration officials said, and were visiting friends near the Iraqi border when they lost their bearings. 
American officials said they did not know how the two men could have mistakenly crossed into Iraq because last year Kuwait built a 10-foot-deep, 16-foot-wide trench and a 13-foot-high rampart along its 130-mile-long border with Iraq.
Iraq's detention of the Americans is expected to aggravate already bitter relations with Iraq, which was defeated by an American-led coalition in the Persian Gulf war in 1991.
The United States has no diplomatic relations with Iraq and has taken the lead in maintaining severe economic sanctions on President Saddam Hussein's Government.
The Administration has succeeded in lining up a majority in the United Nations Security Council to overcome a drive by France, Russia and China to ease the sanctions that have wrecked Iraq's economy and imposed hardships on the Iraqi people.
The State Department said the United States Embassy in Kuwait had asked the United Nations Iraq-Kuwait Observer Mission to make inquiries in Iraq about the two Americans.
"We have also been in contact with Polish officials in Baghdad, who provide service to American citizens in Iraq," said David Johnson, a State Department spokesman.
According to American officials, the two men were arrested Monday night and the United States learned about their detention on Tuesday. One American official said the Administration was seeking to play down the arrests for fear that it would be harder to persuade Iraq to release the two should the episode blow up into a major confrontation.
The State Department said it had contacted the families of the two Americans, but refused to release their names for reasons of privacy.
Officials with the United Nations observer mission based in Kuwait told the Reuters news agency that the mission had been in touch with the Iraqi authorities to confirm the whereabouts of the Americans and to insure their safety.
Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, said, "The President has been following this and is satisfied that we are taking the appropriate steps to secure the expeditious release of the Americans."
A spokesman for the United Nations observer mission said the two Americans went to the mission's headquarters in the southern Iraqi town of Umm Qasr, but either turned back because they realized they were in the wrong place or were denied entry because they did not have the proper papers.
It was then that the Iraqi police seized them.
The United Nations mission in Iraq and Kuwait has been stationed along the border since the end of the six-week Persian Gulf war, which forced Iraq to end its seven-month occupation of Kuwait.
In the past, Iraq has charged some people who have crossed the border with espionage. Some have been released in less than a year; others have been held for eight years.
On the same day the two Americans were arrested, the United States succeeded in persuading the United Nations Security Council to vote to extend economic sanctions against Iraq.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 19, 1995, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the arrest of two Americans at the Iraq-Kuwait border misidentified the country that built a trench there in some editions. It was Kuwait, not Iraq.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Market Mixed for Second Day in Slow Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended mixed yesterday for the second consecutive session.
Trading was lackluster, and a weaker-than-expected consumer sentiment report failed to draw many buyers from the sidelines. 
 The market was "dead, dead and dead as a doornail," said Charles Roden, managing director and head of fixed-income investing for Josephthal, Lyon & Ross.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 2/32 , to 1034/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, slipped to 7.36 percent, from 7.37 percent on Thursday. Other maturities were down slightly, with the exception of the 10-year note. The yield on the 10-year note rose 2 basis points, to 7.10 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. Prices of Treasury bills were mixed.
The University of Michigan released its preliminary consumer sentiment index yesterday, and traders said the number was 91.8 for March, compared with 95.1 in February. Although the number was lower than expected, it had no apparent impact on the market.
"What you have here with the long-term bond at about the 7.36 percent level, is a market saying two things," Mr. Roden of Josephthal said. He said they were that the Fed would induce the economy to make a soft landing or would be forced to reduce rates if the economy fell into a real recession.
There is a tug-of-war in the market, Mr. Roden said, between those who still believe despite recent data that the economy is robust and that inflation is a threat and those who believe that the economy is landing softly or is headed for recession.
"My guess is that the Fed will not increase interest rates," Mr. Roden said. "They read the papers like we do. Inflation is not a threat, especially if the consumer is not going to buy."
But other analysts remain vigilant for signs of accelerating inflation, which erodes the value of fixed-income investments like bonds.
Eugene J. Sherman, director of research for M. A. Schapiro & Company, said he expected the Fed would tighten "probably three more times this year and that the whole scale of interest rates is headed higher."
He said the rate of growth had slowed in the first quarter but that the slowing would prove to be temporary. "We anticipate a snapback in the spring," he said. "Inflation, in contrast, appears to be accelerating, and that is likely to be longer lasting."
By the time the Fed's policy-making committee meets on March 28, he said, there will be enough new data showing strong growth and a pickup in inflation "so that the Federal Reserve will be duty-bound to tighten once again."
In the municipal market, yields remained low yesterday as demand from mutual fund investors offset concern that bonds were too expensive. Investors continued to buy bonds amid expectations that securities would be harder to find later, with new sales down 60 percent this year so far and demand for tax-exempt paper constant.
For example, this week insured general obligation bonds with a maturity of 10 years showed a Bloomberg Fair Market Value yield of 5.34 percent, down 12 basis points from the previous week.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 20, 1995, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Saturday about trading in the bond markets misstated the date of the Federal Reserve meeting at which one analyst expects interest rates to be raised. Eugene J. Sherman, director of research for M. A. Schapiro & Company, said he expected the higher rates to come at the Fed meeting of May 23, not at the one on March 28.

HEADLINE: FILM;
The Oscars Upstaged (Almost)

BYLINE: By ALJEAN HARMETZ 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
IF 1994 WERE A MOVIE, IT WOULD HAVE BEEN called "Revenge of the Little Ones." Thirty-three Academy Award nominations this year -- including two for best picture, two for best actor, all five nominations for best supporting actress and all five for original screenplay -- went to films that were not made by the major studios. And that's not counting all five nominees for best foreign-language film. Paramount Pictures, a major studio with 17 nominations, had to settle for second to scrappy Miramax, an independent that had 22.
Those nominations and the box-office success of movies like Miramax's "Pulp Fiction" and Gramercy's "Four Weddings and a Funeral" have pushed independent films, not for the first time, into the spotlight. Paradoxically, this has happened when the line separating studio and independent has become blurred. 
 Miramax, the feistiest and most successful of the independent companies, was purchased a year ago by Disney. New Line has been bought by Ted Turner. Universal is a co-owner of Gramercy. And 20th Century Fox has just created Searchlight Pictures, which will make movies aimed at sophisticated adults.
When the nominating committee for the independent film world's top prizes -- the Independent Spirit Awards -- met last December, its toughest decision was not which movies to nominate but which movies to make eligible. "Because of the murkier origins of films today, the board looked for solutions that didn't cut off one's nose to spite one's face," says Geoffrey Gilmore, the director of the Sundance Film Festival, who was the chairman of the Spirit Awards nominating committee.
One solution was to throw out the standard definition of an independent film: that it was not financed by a major studio. Instead, the new regulations allowed the committee to consider "percentage of financing from non-studio sources," along with "uniqueness of vision," "economy of means" and "original, provocative subject matter." Among the movies declared eligible were New Line's "Dumb and Dumber," Woody Allen's $19 million "Bullets Over Broadway" and "I Like It Like That," a low-budget first feature that was made by a major studio, Columbia Pictures.
The Independent Spirit Awards (which are administered by the Independent Feature Project/West) are handed out two days before the Oscars, an act of self-promotion that may be unnecessary this year. The ceremony on Saturday, to be held in a tent on the Santa Monica beach, sold out its $10,000 tables and $125 tickets immediately.
"Ten years ago, the I.F.P. director used to pop her own popcorn and take it to our screenings in an effort to get people to come see independent films," says Dawn Hudson, director of the Independent Feature Project (I.F.P.)/West. "The Spirit Awards used to be 200 people crammed into a restaurant. Now we've sold all 1,100 tickets and have a waiting list." The event is sponsored this year by the Independent Film Channel, Bravo, Entertainment Weekly magazine and Panavision.
Portions of the event will be broadcast on March 27 on the Bravo cable channel, during commercial breaks in the Academy Award telecast. Among the actors who will present Spirit Awards this year are Bridget Fonda and Linda Fiorentino.
After 10 years of handing out awards, however, the Independent Spirit can hardly be mistaken for the Oscars. Although Oscar nominees like "Bullets Over Broadway" got four Spirit nominations and "Pulp Fiction" got five, "Mrs. Parker and the Vicious Circle," which also got five, was nominated as best picture by the Spirit Awards, and shut out by the Academy. "Eat Drink Man Woman," which got only one Academy nomination, for best foreign-language film, led the Spirit nominations with six, including best picture. And the fifth film nominated for a Spirit Award for best feature, "Wes Craven's New Nightmare," would never have crossed the collective mind of the members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.
First-time film makers are not required to compete against Woody Allen and Quentin Tarantino at the Spirit Awards, which hand out prizes for best first film, screenplay, director and performance. Nominees include "Clerks," which Kevin Smith made for $27,000. Mr. Smith is now shooting his second movie, the $10 million "Mall Rats," for Gramercy Pictures. The movie will star Shannen Doherty.
"The purpose of the I.F.P. was -- working within the belly of the beast -- to foster the kind of film making that was outside the studio system, that worked forward from a passion rather than backward from a deal memo," says Howard Rodman, a screenwriter and former I.F.P./West board member. "Now, at festivals like Sundance, the studios view independent film makers as a farm team. The industry is always looking for people who make inexpensive, interesting films so they can offer them employment on films that are neither."
The blurring of the line between independent films and studio movies is exhilarating to Harvey Keitel, an actor who has usually chosen the lower salaries and more complex characters that are the bailiwick of independent films. "The idea is to synthesize the spirit of the independent with what the majors have to offer," says Mr. Keitel, who will be seen next summer in Miramax's low-budget "Smoke" and in Universal's not-so-low-budget "Clockers," directed by Spike Lee. "Don't forget that Tom Pollock of Universal made 'The Last Temptation of Christ' six years ago when nobody else would."
That same blurring of the line disturbs Haskell Wexler, a two-time winner of the Oscar for cinematography who shot John Sayles's new independent film, "The Secret of Roan Inish." "Studio films are filtered through marketing, bankers and completion bond people. They're made the way a product is made, not unlike what you'd find in a grocery store. In 'The Secret of Roan Inish,' John and I talked about the transformation of the seal into a woman and decided we'd do it without any digitalizing or effects. That was a crucial decision, but there were no cables back to Hollywood and no tests we had to run for anyone."
Is the rise of the independents something new, or is it part of a cycle? In Hollywood, ideas are constantly being raised up, only to be cast down again. Westerns fall out of favor, and then they're hot. Science fiction nearly disappears and then becomes trendy again. Twelve years ago, the major studios formed classics divisions to make and distribute smaller, artier films. Within two years, all but one of those art-film wings had failed.
"IT'S TOTALLY DIFFERENT now," says Tom Rothman, who was wooed away from the Samuel Goldwyn Company to create Searchlight Films for Fox. "Because the baby boomers are getting older, the audience for these films has expanded substantially. 'Much Ado About Nothing' did $25 million in America and $50 million worldwide. 'Four Weddings,' a $4 million British picture, is going to do over $250 million worldwide. It's not a fad. It's a change."
Other factors cited by Peter Chernin, chairman of Fox Filmed Entertainment, include the growth of video and cable television and the building of new movie theaters in Great Britain and elsewhere, which are attracting "older, better educated and more sophisticated audiences" bored with studio fare.
Hollywood films often fall victim to a pedestrian repetitiveness -- what Mr. Wexler calls "vacuity" -- because they are based on high concepts and stale formulas. In 1989, three independent films excited Hollywood: Steven Soderbergh's "Sex, Lies and Videotape," which became a commercial success, and Gus Van Sant's "Drugstore Cowboy" and Michael Lehmann's "Heathers," which did not. Over the next few years, the quality of such Spirit Award winners as "The Grifters," "Rambling Rose" and "The Player" made mainstream studios hungrier for smarter movies -- as long as they could be made and marketed cheaply enough to insure a profit.
"The independents are usually out there forging into new territory, and then everybody jumps on the bandwagon if they think they can make a buck," says Victoria Wozniak, a founder of the I.F.P./West and the director of "Purple Haze," which won the grand prize at Sundance in 1983. Ms. Wozniak and Greg Nava (who directed "El Norte") had already founded the I.F.P./West a year earlier so that maverick film makers could share information. "If one person could figure out where to get the money, how to sell their movie, it would be cool," says Ms. Wozniak.
Martha Coolidge, the director of "Rambling Rose," says the difference between then and now is apparent in the fact that she is currently finishing a $30 million movie, "Three Wishes," which stars Patrick Swayze and will be distributed by an independent, Savoy. That sum is about average for studio-made films.
"If the small movie were to become the purview of the studios and they start dictating everything from casting to hair styles, the diversity of film making would be severely limited," she says. "But if the studios buy small companies and keep them entities with artistic autonomy, it's not a bad thing."
Ms. Coolidge pauses, then adds, "So long as it's not a mass group grope that messes up the movie."
