HEADLINE: Golf Courses Proliferate, But Welcome Isn't Assured

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

DATELINE: WEST NEW YORK, N.J.

 BODY:
PING. The sound is everywhere these days. Even here, hard by the Hudson River, with the Manhattan skyline looming like a scoreboard, on a blustery, bone-chilling March afternoon.
"It's like this every weekend," said David Borngesser, the manager of Port Imperial Golf Center, a deluxe two-tiered driving range, putting green and miniature golf course that can be reached by ferry from Manhattan. "Sometimes even at lunchtime during the week." 
 There was a time, not long ago, in the 60's and 70's, when golf seemed to be fading in fashion, if not in the actual number of players then at least in the national sports consciousness. Weekend athletes whacked tennis balls; they wore out running shoes; they aerobicized; they Nautilusized.
Golf was a game for middle-age suburbanites tooling around in canopied carts.
Then, when land prices soared, some real estate developers subdivided courses, both potential and existing, into more lucrative housing and office projects.
By the late 1980's and early 90's, though, the sport's appeal appeared to be resurging -- to the chagrin of some environmentalists and non-golfers who apparently fail to see beauty in a fairway.
Suddenly, baby boomers -- including large numbers of blue-collar workers and women who had shied away from the game in the past -- had become golfers (and middle-age suburbanites).
"We fully expect that the trend in golf courses is that they will increase over the next few years," said Richard L. Norton, vice president of operations for the National Golf Foundation in Jupiter, Fla. "Golf is a game you can play at any age, and as the baby boomers move into retirement and preretirement, we expect them to play more golf."
Indeed, lines of die-hard duffers routinely queue up in the predawn hours on weekends these days at many public courses in the New York area, even though 22 courses opened in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and eastern Pennsylvania in 1994 and 45 more are under construction.
Thanks to heated stalls, driving ranges are also often packed year-round, sometimes from dawn to dusk and, thanks to lights, into the wee hours in some places. The number of ranges in the nation has increased in the last year by 9 percent to 1,731, almost triple the number in 1990, according to Golf Range & Recreation Association, a Manhattan-based trade group. A new four-tier, 52-tee driving range and learning center is scheduled to open this fall on 18th Street and the Hudson River in Manhattan, as part of the Chelsea Piers sports complex.
"We expect growth to continue in the 5 to 8 percent range for the next five years or so," said Steve di Constanzo, founder of the Golf Range & Recreation Association. "There is a little bit of a consolidation going on, however, as smaller ranges are being sold for better or higher use.
"The most dramatic development has been larger or more full-service practice facilities that combine teaching programs, some pro shop sales and some family entertainment, such as miniature golf and batting cages," he added. "The industry is maturing."
THE boom in golf is evident in the number of new players; there were about 24.5 million golfers in 1993 (the latest figure available) compared with 23 million in 1988, according to the National Golf Foundation.
"I never ever thought I'd play golf," said Marla Glick, teeing up a shot at the Port Imperial Center. Ms. Glick is 31 years old, lives in the West Village in Manhattan and plans to soon open a small restaurant.
"I thought, what a waste of time, tearing up land just so people in funny clothes can hit a ball in a hole," she added, smacking a drive in the general direction of the Upper West Side.
Not everyone, though, is enamored of the increase in golf-related development. Some environmentalists complain that chemicals used to irrigate courses can pollute groundwater, or, in the arid Western states, that courses use too much water.
Mr. Norton, however, said that most of the environmental concerns are largely unfounded. "They have been addressed by recent research conducted by the U.S. Golf Association and the findings indicate that when chemicals are applied appropriately, the impact is negligible on the environment," he said. "Golf courses are good for the environment."
Some conservationists, however, believe that even if golf courses don't pollute the groundwater they visually scar the landscape, turning it into an ersatz environment, a sterile substitute for nature.
Mr. Norton scoffed. "Golf courses are some of the most beautiful landscape that you are going to ever find, and that is borne out repeatedly by market research," he said.
Nevertheless, examples of the conflicts between golf developers and local residents abound. In East Hampton, L.I., for example, some residents are trying to stop a local sand-pit owner, Barry Bistrian, from building an 18-hole course on land his family owns in the Springs. Some opponents fear pollution. Others fear increased traffic and a potential change in the area's bucolic quality of life. They also note that the East End of Long Island is already crowded with golf courses; there are 40 public courses and 30 private courses in Suffolk County.
The Bistrian family plans to go ahead with the project, which has received the necessary approvals from local officials, and possibly open the public course by sometime next year. "The alternative here is to build 57 homes," Mr. Bistrian said, adding that there may be many courses in the area but there are also many golfers and many early-morning lines.
At the 578-acre Liberty State Park in Jersey City, nongolfers have fought plans to build a course on 150 acres of undeveloped land, even though greens fees from the course would be used to provide a playground and other amenities at the park.
Critics of the plan contend that the land would be put to better use if the entire area were turned into a park with free playgrounds, lawns and meadows, gardens and picnic groves, especially considering the need for such space in heavily urbanized Jersey City and Hudson County.
"They, in essence, would like a family park funded with taxpayer money, and could care less if it takes 10 or 20 years to develop those facilities," said Peter L. Ylvisaker, president of the Liberty State Park Development Corporation, a nonprofit organization created 10 years ago to finance the development of the park. "We, on the other hand, have developed a consensus for a project that includes a golf course, which is a revenue-generator."
"It will complete the greening of Liberty State Park, and provide the amenities people want, and do it immediately," he continued. "We're sort of mystified as to what all the fuss is about. Some people say it's not in the spirit of Ellis Island. Well, when people arrived at Ellis Island, it was a mess."
A decision on whether the course will be constructed is expected from the Governor's office this spring.
OTHER parts of New Jersey have been more welcoming to golf courses. Two years ago, Sussex County, in the rural northwest corner of the state, started an initiative called the Sussex Golf Preserve.
Initiated by a nonprofit group, the Sussex Golf Preserve Foundation, its aim is to promote private investment in open space recreation and economic growth to the area by building 15 to 20 golf courses and related projects in the county by the year 2007.
One course is already under construction -- the Black Bear Golf and Country Club in Franklin -- and four more are planned.
"The theory is that with the baby boomers and the seniors that are going to live a lot longer, there is a tremendous demand for golf," said Davis R. Chant, a real estate agent in neighboring Milford, Pa., who is active in the Sussex County golfing community. "It's an activity that almost anyone can take part in. People will drive an hour to two hours to go to a golf course."
He added that the Sussex County courses would offer a refuge for golfers who wait in long lines at odd hours at suburban courses.
"There are also many people, empty-nesters, who may choose to trade down and move here to be part of a golfing community," he added. "They are the same people who might have a winter place in Hilton Head or Myrtle Beach, so they can golf all year around. Golf people are like that. They are almost fanatical."
Golf course development, however, is not cheap, especially considering that a full-size 18-hole course requires at least 140 acres of land, and often additional acreage. The land often includes water hazards, woods that cannot be cut down and other landscape elements that cannot be disturbed.
With land in the suburban New York area often costing about $100,000 an acre, that means that the land costs alone for a golf course are, generally, at least $7 million. Many courses are also part of larger "golf communities." About 12 percent of all golf facilities today are associated with residential or commercial real estate development. In 1993 alone, about 34 percent of the new courses built included housing or offices.
THAT figure is higher than in 1992, when it was 27 percent. It is, however, lower than in the mid and late 80's when it was about 50 percent. "It has decreased from what it was in the roaring 80's," Mr. Norton said. "We had so many planned communities built in the 80's, and a lot of them had golf courses as real estate amenities, and during the 90's you saw it become hard for large communities to get funded.
"So, we are seeing more golf courses being built because they make economic sense, rather than just to sell real estate," he added.
Still, golf communities remain popular, particularly in suburban areas, like Westchester County, where there are 40 private and 6 public courses. In Harrison, N.Y., ground was broken in late 1993 on a 73-home, Jack Nicklaus-designed, 18-hole, 7,100-yard championship course complex called the Country Club of Purchase.
"The town is looking forward to getting it on the tax roll," said Harrison Town Attorney Bob Weinginger.
Falling land prices in the late 80's and early 90's have helped make golf courses more appealing to some developers. In fact, the 12-acre Port Imperial golf center, which has 90 tee stations, half of which are heated, is a temporary facility; it was constructed, for under $2 million, in 1990 as an interim use for part of a 250-acre tract of riverfront land in Weehawken, N.J., and West New York. The developer, Arcorp of North Bergen, N.J., had hoped to build 800 to 1,000 apartments and offices on the property.
"The market collapsed," said Arthur Imperatore Jr., a vice president at Arcorp, which bought the property in 1981 for $7.5 million and also owns and operates the New York Waterway ferry service.
"So, we thought about it," he said, "and we felt that there was a great demand for a golf facility in the area, and it could be done easily and quickly and enhance the value of the surrounding property."
"The highest and best use for the property is still residential, and at some point it will be redeveloped," he added. "But for the foreseeable future it will be a golf range."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/United Nations;
Other Cities and Countries Woo the U.N.'s Agencies

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
IT must be a strange feeling: courted by so many, yet still waiting for concrete overtures from the one whose courtship would be most welcomed -- and, in fact, most expected.
That is the position that many United Nations agencies find themselves in these days. Bonn, facing the specter of empty buildings as the German Government moves to Berlin, wooed Unicef, and now is wooing the United Nations Development Program. Vienna and Geneva have made rich offers to agencies as well. 
 In the United States, New Rochelle, which almost snagged Unicef in 1993, has made it amply clear it would welcome other agencies. So have Atlanta, San Diego and San Francisco, although lack of support from the United States Mission to the U.N. has kept them from making a full-court press.
And then there is New York City. The administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has scuttled a plan to elicit bids from private-sector companies to do a study, to be jointly financed by the city's Economic Development Corporation and the state's Urban Development Corporation, to delineate the United Nations' needs.
"The Mayor recognizes that the U.N. is a multimillion-dollar contributor to the city's economy, but the planned study was not cost effective," said Clay B. Lifflander, the Economic Development Corporation's chief. He says that this fall the city will unveil a plan for "addressing the U.N.'s needs into the 21st century." But such promises do not mollify all U.N. officials.
"We are paying $10 million each year in New York rent, and we are outgrowing our facilities," said Kerstin Leitner, acting director of the U.N. Development Program's division of administrative and information services. "You'd think the city and the state would try to make our lives easier."
The growing isolationism in Washington is not helping matters, either. "The mood in Congress is not favorable to things U.N.," said James P. Rubin, a spokesman for Madeleine Albright, the chief United States delegate to the U.N. Mr. Rubin says that Ms. Albright plans to give speeches pumping up the importance of the U.N. in at least six cities where isolationist feelings seem to run high. Another U.N. official said that Ms. Albright had been prodding Mayor Giuliani into "being more proactive in keeping the United Nations here."
The question of U.N. facilities is coming into sharp relief now for a host of reasons. In July the Ford Foundation issued a study called "Renewing the United Nations System" that recommended that the U.N. concentrate its offices, currently dispersed around the world, in one location. But the study made it clear that New York was not the only location that would do.
The U.N. itself is for the first time studying its own costs and administrative methods. Some of its largest agencies are exploring whether they would be better off owning their buildings rather than paying exorbitant rents in some high-cost countries, particularly in Latin America and Africa.
AN informal committee, spearheaded by Nicholas Sardegna in the Secretariat, is taking a similar look at costs in New York. The committee will probably try to determine how to finance repairs to existing U.N. buildings, and how to handle a growing shortage of back-office space and housing for U.N. employees.
Local developers are not waiting for such studies to be completed. Albanese Development says it is negotiating with a foreign government to build it a 23-story mission at 871 First Avenue, opposite the main U.N. buildings. The mission will own the building.
David A. Falk, a Williams Real Estate senior managing director who handles leasing for 801 Second Avenue, at 43d Street, has stepped up marketing to foreign missions. He already has three -- Haiti, Madagascar and St. Vincent -- and he says he is negotiating with two more, who are now located about five blocks away. "They really want to be around the corner from the General Assembly," Mr. Falk said.
City officials cannot take such locational preference for granted, as the close call with Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund, proved. "Unicef took the offers from Germany and Austria and New Rochelle very seriously, and that made New York take the fact that Unicef might leave seriously," said Peter C. Roberts, a senior vice president with La Salle Partners who, during the Unicef negotiations, was an adviser to the United Nations Development Corporation, the quasi-governmental group that handles U.N. real estate.
Former city officials remember it that way, too. "Until Unicef really put itself in play, the city always looked at the U.N. and its agencies as a captive industry," recalled Carl Weisbrod, Mr. Lifflander's predecessor at the Economic Development Corporation.
Unicef's seeming willingness to defect has kindled other cities' interest in U.N. agencies. New Rochelle went after the Development Fund and the Population Fund when Unicef decided to stay in New York. Joseph G. Madonna, New Rochelle's development director, says his city was ready to set up a United Nations district, large enough to accommodate five large agencies, and offer free buses to Manhattan.
Mr. Madonna says that a U.N. oversight committee twice concluded that New Rochelle's proposals were more economical than Manhattan's counterproposals. "We just could not counteract the intensive lobbying by the U.S. Mission to keep the agencies in New York," Mr. Madonna said.
Within New York City, internecine warfare for U.N. business may cause divided loyalties. Manhattan developers and officials want the U.N. to expand within the borough. Queens Borough President Claire Shulman wants the U.N. to expand across the East River, to the state-owned Queens West development, which could easily be linked by ferry to United Nations Plaza.
"There shouldn't be these artificial borders between boroughs," said Rosina K. Abramson, an attorney who resigned last month as president of Queens West and now practices development law. "New York must show the U.N. that its resources go beyond a square mile of Manhattan."
Real estate industry sources who insisted on anonymity say Queens West people have, in fact, actively pursued two agencies, the Population Fund and the International Training and Research Institute. Vincent M. Albanese, the developer who also is chairman of the Queens West Development Corporation, denies that he is soliciting agencies. But, he adds, "When we hear of an agency that is looking to move, we certainly will contact them."
Chances are good that, despite the studies and grumblings, New York will remain the hub of U.N. activity. No one seriously suggests that the General Assembly will move, and administratively, it makes sense to cluster all U.N. activities around that body.
"It helps if everyone is a local phone call away," said Bruce Russett, director of Yale University's U.N. Studies Program.
MOREOVER, despite appearances of apathy, New York is unlikely to let the U.N. go without a fight. No mayor wants to preside over the departure of any part of a body that means so much to New York's reputation as an international center and that provides $1.2 billion a year in revenues.
Past and present city officials say that Mayor Giuliani's administration would combat any threatened defection today as quickly as the former administration did when Unicef threatened to move. At that time the city let the U.N. Development Corporation take title to the Unicef building at 3 United Nations Plaza. City officials also helped facilitate a deal in which the Development Corporation will buy 18 floors of condominium space for Unicef at 633 Third Avenue, the building that Travelers Insurance owns at 40th Street.
The deal obligates the Development Corporation to take several more floors now occupied by the Mobil Corporation if Mobil does not renew its lease, which expires in 1998. And, it gives the Development Corporation options on several other floors.
"We could certainly find other U.N. agencies to take that space," said Thomas Appleby, president of the Development Corporation. (Another possibility: The state's Urban Development Corporation, currently at 1515 Broadway, is seriously considering moving to 633 Third Avenue, to one of the floors that Mr. Appleby's group would otherwise be contractually obligated to buy.)
For U.N. agencies, ownership is key. While they pay taxes on space they rent outside the U.N. district, they are exempt from taxes on property they own.
That might be a moot point if Washington agrees to requests to add more buildings to the U.N. District, which already includes some isolated buildings outside the official territory of 42d to 48th Streets, from the East side of First Avenue to the F.D.R. Drive. And, although no city official will say that the city would exercise eminent domain to force existing tenants out of space that U.N. agencies might favor, no one will categorically rule out that possibility, either.
"Whatever it takes to win U.N. business, it is prudent for us to do," Mr. Lifflander said.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Historic Brass Mill Giving Way to a Waterbury Mall

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: WATERBURY

 BODY:
THE Scovill Brass Works in Waterbury, a 200-year-old icon of the Naugatuck Valley's glory days as the industrial engine of Connecticut's economy, is being dismantled to make way for a $120 million shopping mall that will be built by the Homart Company of Chicago.
Occupying 87 acres off Interstate 84 adjacent to the business district, Scovill's 63 deteriorated, empty buildings are being turned into recyclable piles of steel, brick, wood and concrete. 
 Once the site has been cleared, some 118,000 tons of soil, contaminated with PCB's, lead paint, oils and asbestos will be carted off, leaving the land environmentally clean and scraped bare of its history.
When the mall opens in the fall of 1997, anchored by Sears, Lechmere's, J.C. Penney and Filene's department stores, it will be called Brass Mill Center. In addition to the anchors, 120 stores and restaurants will fill a 900,000-square-foot building, joined by landscaped walkways to a 220,000-square-foot open shopping plaza.
Filene's and Sears will move from the 25-year-old, 500,000-square-foot Naugatuck Valley Mall on the other side of town. The stores will be replaced, according to Anne Marie Powers, spokeswoman for the Naugatuck mall, possibly by outlet stores. "There is no rivalry," she said. "Homart is regional, we are very local."
The Homart project will include 5,445 parking spaces and a linear park along the Mad River, an 800-foot stretch of which will be moved closer to East Main Street, consolidating land for the park. Mall construction is expected to begin in the spring of 1996.
Homart, builders of nearly 79 million square feet of retail space nationwide, almost all of it in malls, has optioned the land and received the enthusiastic support of the city, which rezoned the tract from industrial to commercial use.
But Homart will not take title until the state's Department of Environmental Protection certifies that a $36 million demolition and decontamination process financed by state and Federal money has been successfully completed.
"We have agreed to pay back $31 million to the state if we do not build the mall," said Cathy Shields, spokeswoman for Homart. The $5 million in Federal funds does not have to be repaid.
Dismantling the 2.2 million square feet of buildings started last month and will take almost a year of manipulating wrecking balls and bulldozers. "We cannot dynamite," explained Jack Barlow, head of Brass Center Ltd., the demolition company. "Most of these buildings were constructed in the 1800's and during World War I and some, we understand, were bombproof. Construction methods were secret and are unknown. You can't implode a building without detailed drawings."
From the War of 1812 through the Vietnam War, Scovill, which shut down its plant in the late 70's, fabricated brass buttons, time fuses, cartridge casings and vehicle and aircraft parts for the military. It also made kerosene and whale-oil lamps, buckles, hinges, paper clips, zippers, photographic equipment, small appliances under the Hamilton Beach trade name and blanks for coins.
Totally self-sufficient, it had its own fire and police squads, a water-treatment plant, forges, and a power plant paid for during World War I by Czar Nicholas II of Russia in return for munitions that he could not produce at home.
Only two mid-1800's German Romanesque buildings are to be preserved for as yet undetermined uses. The whistle that signaled shifts for 12,000 workers and an extensive collection of photographs dating back more than a century will be housed in the Mattatuck Museum of the Mattatuck Historical Society on West Main Street.
"IT would have been nice to have saved more buildings," said Jack Shannahan, executive director of the Connecticut Historical Commission in Hartford. "But Homart could not have done that and had the space it wanted, and Waterbury didn't want to lose this project."
Indeed, the mall proposal breezed through public hearings with hardly a dissenting word. Even downtown retailers, whose counterparts in other cities complain bitterly about the loss of customers to malls, rallied to the cause.
"Our downtown retail has been tremendously weakened over the years," said Henry R. Paine, president of Howland-Hughes, a 105-year-old department store on Bank Street that is the only such establishment remaining in any Connecticut downtown outside a mall. "I will lose a large percentage of my customers and possibly have to close, but the mall will accomplish a tremendous number of positives for the city."
"This is a piece of an economic base that the city must develop to survive," said Mayor Edward D. Bergin. He recalled how the flight of industry to the South during the energy crisis of the 70's was exacerbated in Waterbury by the extensive use of plastics.
"Metal objects produced here by Scovill, Anaconda and Chase Brass were replaced by plastic," said the Mayor, "and the companies couldn't or wouldn't retool."
Nonfarm jobs declined from 52,790 in 1985 to 44,620 in 1993, according to the state's Department of Economic Development.
Today, 40 percent of downtown Waterbury's stores and offices are vacant, according to Michael Pacowta, president of the Greater Waterbury Chamber of Commerce. "We have become a city known for its desolation instead of its thriving smokestack industries," he said. "We hope that the mall will produce a more positive image to the commercial office sector and retailers that have been passing us by."
On the theory that malls create satellite retail activity, as the Danbury Fair Mall has done, Mayor Bergin has been a staunch advocate of the Homart project as a catalyst for downtown redevelopment. He expects to reclaim even students who drifted away from downtown during the 1970's when Waterbury's three high schools were moved from the business center to the periphery of the city for desegregation purposes. "Kids spend money in downtowns and malls," said the Mayor. "They have cars and there are buses."
Unlike suburban malls, which draw taxes out of cities, Brass Mill Center is expected to enrich Waterbury by $3 million to $5 million in tax revenues annually. The higher figure reflects Connecticut's tax on business equipment. "The shift of property taxes from commercial to residential will shift back to commercial," the Mayor said, adding that the shift would ease the pain of tax increases that will result from the revaluation that Waterbury is under state order to complete by Oct. 1, 1996.
Like children with their noses pressed against the candy store window, many small business owners like Joseph Begnal can't wait for the mall to begin building. A former machinist at Scovill himself, he has owned Begnal's Brown Derby bar opposite the plant on Main Street since 1956.
"I used to tell time by the 3, 4 and 5 o'clock shifts coming in for a shot and a beer," he said. "I lost 80 percent of my business when the plant closed 15 years ago. Downtown is so dead my son-in-law closed his sports shop on Grand Street last month, after seven years."
But now Mr. Begnal plans to open for lunch for the first time in years, he said, "for the construction workers and then for spillover from the mall."

HEADLINE: Veteran Jazzman Swings With the Young

BYLINE: By COREY KILGANNON 

 BODY:
BILLY MITCHELL does not refer to his traditional weekly engagement at Sonny's Place in Seaford as a jam session.
"At a jam session," said the 65-year-old tenor saxophonist, "a guy will choose a tune he's been practicing all week, play his solo, and then walk away and start a conversation on the other side of the room." 
 One main lesson that Mr. Mitchell teaches every Wednesday night, when he invites guests to play with his quartet, is that it is not enough to play in the band. They have to play with the band.
But for two weeks this month, the band does not have its leader to maintain the high standards of jazz protocol, which Mr. Mitchell takes to Sonny's Place from as far back as his early days in Detroit in the late 1940's. Mr. Mitchell is in Stuttgart, Germany, where he is playing six concerts. He is leading a band made up of top German musicians called the Alexander Swingtime Band.
"He has to make these trips every so often so he can afford to play at Sonny's Place," said the club owner, Sonny Meyerowitz.
Although Mr. Meyerowitz said his business was also feeling the effects of the slow economy on Long Island, Mr. Meyerowitz runs the lone Long Island club, which features jazz seven nights a week, with a quality that rivals that of top Manhattan clubs. Much of the reason is Mr. Mitchell's long association with the club.
When Mr. Meyerowitz started the Steer Inn in Freeport in 1963, he called on Mr. Mitchell for the music. When Mr. Meyerowitz opened Sonny's Place in 1972, Mr. Mitchell followed, and the club has been his home bandstand ever since.
"If it weren't for Billy, there wouldn't be a Sonny's Place," Mr. Meyerowitz said.
As the Wednesday night host for 11 years, Mr. Mitchell has maintained a high level of musicianship, reaching beyond technical expertise. "It takes 20 years to learn what to play," he said, "and five years to learn what to leave out."
Born in Kansas City, Mr. Mitchell moved to New York in 1948 with the Lucky Millander Orchestra and was taken by another tenor saxophonist, Ben Webster, to Minton's Playhouse in Harlem. "I walked in and on the bandstand was Charlie Parker, Lester Young, Dizzy Gillespie and Kenny Clarke," Mr. Mitchell recounted. "You'll never see anything like that again."
He then settled in Detroit, where he led the house band at the Blue Bird Club, a band that had Tommy Flanagan on piano and Elvin Jones on drums. Frequent guests included Miles Davis, Cannonball Adderly and Paul Chambers.
After tours with the big bands of Count Basie, Dizzy Gillespie, Woody Herman and others, Mr. Mitchell settled on Long Island, whose musical culture, he said, was a far cry from that of Detroit in his early days.
"In those days," he said, "I could leave my house with my horn at 9 P.M. and play at 10 different clubs and learn from 10 different musicians, fine musicians."
That tradition of jazz education is what Mr. Mitchell is trying to keep alive at Sonny's. He says that young jazz musicians today have nowhere else to play on Long Island.
The first thing he looks for in an aspiring musician hoping to sit in with his band is a spark, a desire to learn. "You see someone with some talent but looking for more," Mr. Mitchell said, "and you help him."
Young musicians find no shortage of qualified teachers on Wednesday nights at Sonny's, when Mr. Mitchell takes the bandstand, often accompanied by colleagues like Frank Wess, Tootsie Bean and Frank Foster. Indeed, the club has been visited by such jazz legends as Count Basie, Sarah Vaughan, Lionel Hampton, Betty Carter and others, whose presence is documented in pictures on the walls.
Mr. Mitchell, who has lived on Long Island for 35 years, said he preferred his limited engagements and traditional weekly gig at Sonny's to the strenuous schedule of the big-band days.
"When I was with Count Basie," he added, "we were on the road 13 months out of the year."
Although he has trimmed his schedule, Mr. Mitchell can continue to lean back in midsolo on the bandstand, close his eyes, slowly cross one leg over the other and start to roar.
"This joint," he said in a quiet moment at the bar, "is a part of me, part of my heart."
With his feel for timing and symmetry, he took a slow drag of his cigarette and added, "All we need is more people to be aware of what is really here."

HEADLINE: Social Studies and an Economist

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

DATELINE: PORT CHESTER

 BODY:
WHEN Dr. Peter F. Bell accepted the year's Distinguished Social Studies Service Award from the New York State Council on the Social Studies recently, he spoke about the issues that were on his mind: his shock at the country's limited knowledge of economics, the subject he has taught at Purchase College since 1972; policies that he suggested would "end welfare and create poverty" and the "political ideologues of a very dangerous kind" who had found power.
To his surprise, spontaneous applause greeted his brief remarks. This was the most charged moment of an award banquet held during the council's three-day yearly conference at the Rye Town Hilton here. It was the 57th conference sponsored jointly by the council and the New York State Social Studies Supervisory Association. 
 Nearly 800 social studies teachers, local historians and others converged on the hotel at a time when the national debate over multiculturalism raged on and a framework for a new social studies curriculum had not yet been accepted by the state. In sessions held throughout the conference, teachers considered questions like how can students be kept interested in current events, what issues should be covered when teaching about a third world country and are interdisciplinary courses valid?
Steven A. Goldberg, president of the Council on the Social Studies and chairman of social studies for the New Rochelle School District, said discussions also centered on the future of social studies during a time of flux in the State Education Department. Commissioner Thomas Sobol, who did not accept a committee's recent efforts to design a new social studies curriculum, has announced that he will resign at the end of the year.
Dr. Bell also directs the New York State Council on Economic Education, a teacher-training organization with 15 centers statewide. He received a plaque for his 10-year effort in helping teachers become more knowledgeable about economics, a subject many must teach but few have studied. He was the only county educator to receive an award at the conference, which also honored outstanding teachers in elementary school through high school.
"He deserves it -- he has been wonderful," said Sandra G. Abt, chairwoman of the social studies department of the Byram Hills School District in Armonk. In 1989, Byram Hills was one of 10 school districts nationwide to be cited for excellence in its economics program. Dr. Abt said Dr. Bell, working through the SUNY-Westchester Schools Partnership of Purchase College, helped shape a course of study for teaching economics at every grade level. Dr. Bell, an Armonk resident who received the Chancellor's Award for Excellence in Teaching from the State University of New York in 1982 and the Outstanding Service Award from the Westchester Council for the Social Studies in 1991, also directs the Westchester Center for Economic Education at Purchase.
Mr. Goldberg said Dr. Bell "serves as a good model of how university people can collaborate with secondary-school people to do the best for kids." Mr. Goldberg added, "He sees us as equals."
A native of England, Dr. Bell is a specialist in the economies of third world countries, and is an internationally known expert on Thailand. At a session devoted to global studies earlier in the conference, he was on a panel of teachers that also includedTimothy Miller of Fox Lane High School in Bedford, Judith Mella of Blind Brook High School in Rye and Douglas Young of Croton High School in Croton. Dr. Bell suggested that the more than 60 teachers at the session focus their third world lessons on issues like women's role in the global industrial labor force, women and underdevelopment and what he called "the feminization of poverty."
"The core of what we call development is built on cheap female labor for cheap imports in the rest of the world," he told the group. "Why are women chosen? That's a good question to discuss with your students. Women are at the bottom of the development tier and are seriously disadvantaged in education, health and access to jobs."
He added that the Thai Government counts on prostitution for billions of foreign dollars. Development in Thailand, he said, is "literally built upon the backs of women."
Ms. Mella described her use of novels and films in teaching global studies, while Mr. Young showed a video on his students' use of CD-ROM's and other technology in preparing reports. Mr. Miller acknowledged that it was "impossible to cover every issue" in the vast amount of social studies material that must be taught. He suggested that teachers pose general questions that will stimulate class discussions like: "What would make a better world?"
"That's a loaded question," he observed. "Better for whom? We want children to question the vocabulary we use."

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
What Do I Hear for This 1988 Burgundy? Fine Wine on the Block.

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
LOOKING for an insouciant little Bordeaux with a supple body -- something, perhaps, with an unadorned bouquet, a hint of humus on the tongue and a finish of ripe pear with overtones of persimmon, plum and clover? Until recently, the only place New Yorkers could hope to buy such a bottle (with or without that elusive persimmon overtone) was ye olde friendlie neighborhood spirits shoppe. For after the end of Prohibition the State Legislature endowed liquor retailers with a monopoly on the wine trade, much the way 16th century monarchs parceled out monopolies in spices.
But in 1993 New York retailers specializing in upscale wines hammered out a deal with New York's two international art auction houses, which run wine exchanges in Europe and have long been lobbying Albany for a piece of the local action. Now anyone can auction wines if they can find an established retailer to serve as a partner. Indeed, New York City is on the verge of becoming the wine auction capital of America, rivaling the markets in Chicago and California in both variety and dollar volume. 
 The next New York auction, jointly sponsored with Zachy's, the big wine store in Scarsdale, is scheduled for Christie's Park Avenue gallery on April 8. And while auctions are no place for those who don't know the difference between Muscadet and muscatel, the promoters are going out of their way to make it easy for amateur enthusiasts to try their hand at the bidding game.
CATALOGUES, available a few weeks before the auction date, spell out the rules in plain English. And while Christie's is hoping to fetch at least $60,000 for 21 rare bottles of Burgundy from the collection of Rusty Staub, the former New York Mets star, every auction includes dozens of lots likely to sell for less than $500. Perhaps the best part of the scene is the pre-auction hoopla designed to loosen up billfolds. The auction houses generally sell tickets to tastings and blowout gourmet dinners, with rare wines in abundance and commentary from the most sophisticated palates in the business.
Actually, anybody who has been to an art auction should feel at home with the mechanics of bidding at a wine auction. Auctioneers start the bidding at prices below the low end of the estimated range printed in the catalogue and go up in specified increments. At Sotheby's, for example, a bid of $300 can only be topped by a bid at least $20 higher, while a bid of $3,000 must be topped with a bid of $3,200.
Bids made in advance by mail or during the auction by telephone are welcome. "An absentee bid is identical to one from the room," explained Serena Sutcliffe, the head of Sotheby's wine department. Thus, even if a mail bidder had indicated that he would pay up to $1,000 for a lot, he would still be able to buy the wine for just $20 more than the next highest bid of, say, $600.
Don't even dream about walking away with the odd unwanted case of wine for pennies on the dollar. For one thing the auction houses are eager to avoid the embarrassment of very light bidding and commensurably low gavel prices, and thus don't accept wines for auction that lack a real market. More important, wines are generally assigned "reserve prices" -- unannounced minimums that must be topped. At an auction run in February by Morrell & Company, the New York wine dealer, roughly 1 lot in 20 (among them a lot of 15 half-bottles of Chateau Lafite Rothschild 1953) was withdrawn for want of an adequate bid.
Both sellers and buyers pay commissions. The bite on the seller, usually about 15 percent, is often negotiable. "It depends on the amount of wine being sold, its value and the difficulty of tracing provenance," said Bruce Kaiser, director of the wine department at Butterfield & Butterfield, the auction house in San Francisco.
The buyer's commission is added to the winning bid, along with state and local sales taxes. At Morrell's February auction, the high bid for a case of prized red Burgundy, an Echezeaux from the 1990 vintage, was $800. But the actual price was increased 10 percent to cover the buyer's commission. And unless the buyer proved to be a reseller like a restaurant or lived out of state, sales tax of 8 3/4 percent would be tacked on to both the bid price and the buyer's commission.
Auction houses are go-betweens, not sellers. Hence, in theory it is the buyer's job to judge the quality of older wines with uncertain histories. In fact, says Michael Broadbent, head of the wine department at Christie's, quality assurance is much less of a problem than might be expected.
Bottles are checked for deterioration -- broken "capsules" covering the corks, unexpected color, seepage through corks -- and the signs are listed in the catalogue. Generally, auction houses will not accept wines unless they have been stored properly. "If we're not sure," said Peter Morrell, chairman of Morrell & Company, "we send someone to look at the cellar."
The catalogues also note any decline in the level of wine in the bottle. Young wines should reach the neck, or close to it. But wines older than 15 years will often be perfectly good even if they only reach midway up the rounded "shoulder" of a Bordeaux or Burgundy-style bottle: very slow evaporation need not damage the wine.
"It's in our interest" to auction good bottles only, Mr. Broadbent said. And while neither Christie's nor its competitors offer unconditional guarantees, they generally do allow buyers to return wines that have been damaged.
"If the issue is really in doubt," Mr. Kaiser of Butterfield & Butterfield said, "I take home a bottle and drink it."
Where are the bargains likely to lurk? Orley Ashenfelter, publisher of a semiannual newsletter on wine economics called Liquid Assets, says there is little sense in bidding for wines from recent vintages because prices will generally be no better than those from discount retailers. But not all recently made wines are easily available at retail. If you are pining for a collector's wine the auction may still be your best bet.
The wines being sold by Mr. Staub, for example, come from the 1988, 1989 and 1990 vintages. But it is hard to find all seven from the rarest of rare Burgundy estates, the Domaine de la Romanee-Conti. And it would be virtually impossible to buy them in six-liter bottles known as Methuselahs.
"If I had my druthers I'd keep these babies, but I have to think about my family," said Mr. Staub, a restaurateur who maintains a spectacular personal collection of top-rank wines from Burgundy, Bordeaux and California. Translation: It is best to sell when the market is hot.
MOST of the action, however, is in mature red Bordeaux wines from the better vintages of the 1960's, 1970's and early 1980's. Good selections of these are found in only a few dozen stores in America, and generally at prices far above those at auctions.
So-called first-growth Bordeauxs (Chateaux Latour, Margaux, Lafite-Rothschild, Mouton-Rothschild, Ausone, Haut-Brion, Cheval Blanc, Petrus) are so well known that auction prices are fairly stable. That is not the case, though, for lesser Bordeaux wines from lesser vintages where, Mr. Ashenfelter says, "prices bounce all over the place." And it is certainly not true for older wines that do not fit into the life style of the local rich and famous.
In New York that latter category includes most California wines, most Burgundies, most Rhone wines, most Italian wines and virtually all whites from Germany. "There are endless bargains in German wines -- people just don't understand the labels," said Mr. Broadbent, referring to Germany's incredibly arcane system of grading and classifying the estates along the Rhine and Moselle Rivers.
The auctions also assemble interesting lots that give aficionados unique opportunities to create tastings. In February, for example, Sotheby's auctioned a "vertical" -- a case of one wine, Chateau Haut-Brion Blanc, with bottles from the 1970, '71, '75, '82 and '83 vintages. The high bid, incidentally, was $1,150, plus a 15 percent buyer's premium. The Sotheby's auction also included a case of a great white Burgundy, Batard-Montrachet, all from the same vintage (1986) but from four different producers. The price: $1,840, plus commission.
Ready to put your money where your mouth wants to be? A solid bidding strategy is to use recent London auction prices for European wines and California auction prices for California cabernets as benchmarks. Liquid Assets, available for $30 a year, (169 Nassau St., Princeton, N.J. 08542) lists prices and sales volumes for hundreds of wines. If you know what you like to drink, do your homework and are patient, the rewards will be bountiful.

HEADLINE: Your Car, the Sitting Duck

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
EVEN the detectives stalking Guy Gralto admitted a certain admiration for his devotion to work and family. Each morning, at 6:30 A.M., Mr. Gralto, a swarthy dark-mustachioed man who favored off-the-rack jogging suits, left his home in East Rockaway, L.I. Driving east against the traffic, he arrived within half an hour at his small junkyard in Oceanside. Inside his trailer-office, he phoned home. "Vera, I'm here," he reassured his common-law wife.
 Mr. Gralto then fed the junkyard's guard dog, a 125-pound German shepherd named Bandit, before his employees arrived promptly at 8 A.M. and the orders came ringing in. A hard worker and a hard-driving boss, Mr. Gralto typically ordered in lunch, worked untgil early evening and drove straight home. At his modest six-room home, a converted one-story bungalow on the waterfront, he and Vera Marino usually shared quiet dinners, though occasionally they dropped in on her daughter and son-in-law's. In the summer, the couple sometimes went boating, or had the kids over for a cookout.
 "He put in long days," said Detective Paul Vitucci of the Nassau County Police. "He demanded punctuality from his workers. He demanded very high productivity. One time, he had a guy out there who had nothing to do. Gralto had him work in the yard, sweep up the yard, rake it clean."
 But the admiration ended there. The orders coming in, according to an indictment in State Supreme Court in Queens, were from traffickers in stolen auto parts. Someone would ask for the nose of a 1992 Nissan Maxima. The fender of a 1991 Plymouth Acclaim. A couple of phone calls later, the indictment charges, Mr. Gralto had arranged for one of his trusty "steal men" to cruise parking lots and residential streets, mostly in Queens, occasionally in Nassau County. He would then "chop up" the cars, fulfill the order with the buyer and stockpile the remaining parts, the indictment says.
To business associates, Mr. Gralto's favorite comment was: "I'm an honest businessman trying to make an honest day's dollar." But law-enforcement officials say this case, broken last month and based on hundreds of hours of wiretaps of his conversations as well as video surveillance, offers an unusually vivid glimpse into the workings of an auto theft ring, a core group of 13 that extended from a reputed captain in the Bonanno crime family to Mr. Gralto, down to the "cutters" and the "steal men." The case sheds light on why more than half the cars stolen in New York vanish in Byzantine networks of thieves, chop-shop owners, thieves who specialize in certain parts, illegal parts suppliers and unscrupulous mechanics -- all of whom create an artificial demand for the supply of auto parts.
Organized crime syndicates have been involved in auto theft since at least the 1960's. But since the 1980's, car theft has grown increasingly organized, as a new breed of expensive and sophisticated cars, equipped with a growing array of gadgets and parts, multiplied the potential profits from theft. And because a police department overwhelmed with more serious crimes virtually ignored auto theft until the early '90s, the risk of punishment was low.
Beleaguered by perhaps the most skillful auto thieves in the nation, the city's car owners -- already suffering from a scarcity of garages and monthly indoor parking fees of up to $700 -- can take some comfort in statistics, if nothing else. Partly because of rising police attention, the number of reported thefts has fallen steadily since a record 146,309 in 1990. Still, 94,525 were reported stolen last year, or almost 260 cars a day. Of the 30 biggest American cities, only drivers in Detroit and San Francisco were more likely to have their cars stolen in 1993, says the Highway Loss Data Institute, an insurance trade organization.
But because of New York's sophisticated rings, its 1.8 million car owners paid the highest theft premiums: $248, or five times the average for the 30 cities. "Though the theft claims are not as frequent as in Detroit or San Francisco, the average loss is higher because the chances of recovery are far lower," said Kim Hazelbaker, senior vice president of the Institute.
So pervasive is the problem in some neighborhoods that drivers have adopted an almost fatalistic attitude -- particularly in Queens, home to 38 percent of all cars registered in the city in 1993. Near the Fresh Meadows shopping mall, one of the hardest-hit areas in the hardest-hit precinct of the city and a favorite target of the ring, so many cars were stolen last year that officers were posted on high-rise rooftops to watch the streets and residents could rattle off the names of victimized neighbors.
Under pressure to combat auto theft, law enforcement officials involved in the yearlong investigation by detectives assigned to the Queens District Attorney and by the Nassau County police were eager to talk about the case, which they describe as a benchmark in their efforts.
"This is the first auto-theft prosecution under the state's Organized Crime Control Act," said Queens District Attorney Richard A. Brown. "These weren't isolated thefts. You're talking about a highly sophisticated enterprise that stole and dismantled cars and set up a business in stolen parts."
At the arraignment last month, all the defendants pleaded not guilty. Joseph Mure, a lawyer representing Mr. Gralto and Ms. Marino -- as well as her son-in-law Frank Merendino, who is also charged with assisting Mr. Gralto -- said recently that they maintain their innocence and denied any connection to organized crime. Lawyers who represent the other suspects and who chose to comment said their clients also declare their innocence.
Vincent Asaro, 60 -- who is charged with being a captain in the Bonanno crime family and with being at the top of this theft ring -- further denies that he controlled Mr. Gralto. "He denies any involvement with organized crime, period," said his lawyer, Stephen G. Murphy, who has been involved in many high-profile cases in New York.
 
THIEF, CUTTER, BROKER: THE CAR-THEFT LADDER
 Guy Gralto, 34, grew up in Ozone Park. Investigators believe he has been involved in the auto-theft business for at least the last 11 years, climbing his way up, from thief to cutter to broker, in the tightly knit car-theft industry in southeastern Queens. He had been arrested only once, for possession of two stolen vehicles with illegal vehicle identification numbers, in 1988, and that case was later dismissed. Detectives who shadowed him for a year described him as an excitable man, who spoke in a loud voice even during normal conversations, barking into his telephone. At work, he kept his phone conversations short and businesslike, though last Sept. 5, unsure of the holiday, he spent minutes trying to persuade every caller that it was actually Memorial Day.
Not all his business associates were privy to Mr. Gralto's softer side, his love of pets. Besides Bandit, the German shepherd he had taken in as a sickly stray in Howard Beach, he poured affection on a small dog and three parrots at his East Rockaway home. Last summer, when a friendly chop shop was raided by the police and its guard dog was shot, Mr. Gralto's first telephone call, say detectives listening to wiretaps, was to inquire about the pit bull. "Oh no, jeez, they shot the dog. Poor dog."
According to the indictment, Mr. Gralto's Oceanside business traced its roots to another auto-theft ring that he and a former partner set up in an inconspicuous warehouse in Maspeth, Queens, in November 1993. In Queens' auto-theft industry, a tight network where everyone knows everyone else, it was perhaps natural for Mr. Gralto to join forces with Martin Bosshart, a Woodhaven resident with a criminal record, law enforcement officials said. It was also natural that in an industry with its own peculiar hierarchies and codes of advancement that Mr. Bosshart, who was only 25, became the junior partner, with Mr. Gralto taking the lion's share of the profits. But Mr. Bosshart's inexperience was more than compensated for by his extremely violent behavior, officials said, pointing out he had been arrested on charges of attempted murder in 1990, though never convicted. In 1988, he pleaded guilty to a reduced charge of attempted grand larceny in another case.
The joint operation earned millions of dollars by stealing and chopping up roughly 20 cars a week, Detective Vitucci and other officials said. But they said there was a conflict larger than both men: Mr. Bosshart paid tribute to the Gambino organized crime family. But Mr. Gralto, who had been loosely allied with Mr. Asaro for a number of years, was holding back payments from the reputed Bonanno captain.
The indicted individuals -- all "stand-up guys who don't rat on each other," according to Detective Vitucci -- have provided few details of the ensuing fallout. But investigators believe that on Feb. 25, 1994, with the Bonanno captain's consent, Mr. Bosshart and two accomplices forced Mr. Gralto out of the Maspeth business. Inside the warehouse, the indictment says, Mr. Bosshart and two associates severely beat Mr. Gralto, stole thousands of dollars and then dragged him into an office and shot him in the leg.
After the shooting, Mr. Gralto -- to continue his career in the auto-theft business -- had no choice but to turn to Mr. Asaro for protection, law enforcement officials said. Mr. Gralto moved to Long Island, abandoning a salvage yard, Conduit Auto Parts, he owned in Howard Beach. In an industrial corner of Oceanside, he rented space in a carpet warehouse where he showed up to work, six days a week, dressed invariably in jogging suits.
Mr. Asaro shielded Mr. Gralto against other auto-theft rings looking to expand, steered business his way and sometimes provided him with his own car thieves, said Detective Cary Brenner, of the Queens District Attorney's Office Squad. A flat weekly fee, typically around $500, was delivered to the Great In Pasta, a restaurant in Hewlett, L.I., where Mr. Asaro spent his evenings.
 
 
A SMALL CIRCLE OF TRUST
 In Oceanside, or sometimes at his home, Mr. Gralto received orders and dispatched his thieves, the indictment says. Whenever he did not perform those tasks himself, Mr. Gralto trusted only Ms. Marino, 49, her son-in-law Mr. Merendino, 32, or Louis Scarantino, 31, a childhood friend accused of financing a warehouse for stolen parts in East Rockaway. They were all indicted.
Two others indicted were acquaintances from Mr. Gralto's years in the auto-theft business -- Anthony LaGreca and Keith Hillman, who worked at auto-supply shops in Jamaica, Queens, and Bay Shore, L.I., respectively -- regularly called him with orders, said Detective Brenner, who eavesdropped on hundreds of conversations.
"Nose off a '91 Max, white, two-door," was a typical order for a Nissan Maxima.
"O.K. I'll buy it," Mr. Gralto said, after haggling over a price.
Mr. Gralto then paged one of his steal men, who were paid between $400 and $600 to find the car and drop it off at a pre-arranged location, Detective Vitucci said. One of Mr. Gralto's employees would pick up the car and drive it to a friendly chop shop where it would be dismantled, generally for $1,800, the detective said.
"I bought it," Mr. Gralto would say, calling back the orderer of the part. "I'll have it to you in a day or two." The parts were delivered to Mr. LaGreca, 30, who had previously been convicted of insurance violations, burglary, attempted possession of stolen property and attempted forgery. Other valuables were warehoused, and, after everyone was paid, Mr. Gralto could clear several thousand dollars.
The indictment says that two of Mr. Gralto's regular thieves were Victor Norwood, 35, and Thomas Parker, 42, two tall, thin men from Jamaica who over the years had acquired reputations as dependable steal men, Detective Brenner said. Although the operators of an auto-theft ring are often shielded from scrutiny, the steal men are the organization's foot soldiers, often desperate people who are willing to expose themselves to great risks for a few hundred dollars and, unlike their bosses, are unable to afford top-notch lawyers.
Mr. Parker's criminal record, dating to 1970, includes multiple convictions for grand larceny, possessing an illegal vehicle identification number and making a false report of a stolen vehicle; Mr. Norwood, with convictions for harassment and the unauthorized use of a vehicle, also spent five years in prison for first-degree manslaughter.
 
 
THE M.O.: DAYLIGHT, PARKING LOTS, TRAIN STATIONS
 Dressed in dungarees, driving junk-cars with stolen out-of-state license plates, the steal men favored spots in northeast Queens -- parking lots at the Fresh Meadows shopping mall, St. John's University and at Long Island Rail Road stations, say the detectives. They stole not at night, but during working hours.
From their surveillance investigators inferred that the two suspects worked like other professional car thieves. They usually broke in by smashing a small window. If an alarm blared, they popped open the hood, went around to the front and smashed the alarm, housed usually next to the engine. If a Club was used, they simply cut through the steering wheel. Finally, they started the car by breaking the steering column.
"It took them usually less than 20 seconds to start a car," Detective Brenner said. "What made them good? Experience. Most car thieves are young, and not as reliable."
Admired for his efficiency, Mr. Gralto, investigators pointed out, possessed another quality that led to his downfall: foolhardiness.
A simple, unostentatious man, Mr. Gralto eschewed the grand ambitions that drive many of his peers, Detective Vitucci said. Unlike a John Gotti who used car theft as a stepping stone into one of New York's five traditional crime families, Mr. Gralto apparently had no aspirations of joining the Bonanno family, of ever becoming a "made man."
Instead, Mr. Gralto revealed a more pedestrian goal in phone calls: "I want to make a million a year." That goal, investigators said, pushed him to grow reckless.
When an industry associate alerted him that his Oceanside yard was under surveillance, Mr. Gralto ignored the tip. When detectives, waiting in ambush a stone's throw from Mr. Gralto's home, phoned him on Feb. 15 at 6 A.M., to warn him that they were coming to arrest him, Mr. Gralto simply said, "Knock it off," and hung up. When the police called back immediately, he still believed it was a joke. Spitting out an expletive, he slammed down the receiver. It was only when the police began breaking down his front door that the truth hit him, Detective Vitucci said.
Mr. Gralto tried to save the door by opening it. But it was too late.
By the time all 13 suspects were arrested last month, the ring had operated 10 months, from May 1994 to February 1995, the indictment charges. During a period of intense surveillance, from May 9 to Aug. 11, 1994, the ring chopped up and sold parts from 21 cars -- worth $244,000 on the used car market but almost $1 million in parts, the District Attorney's office charged.
In a related indictment, Mr. Bosshart, the alleged Gambino loyalist, and his two associates from Maspeth were also charged last month with possessing and dismantling stolen vehicles, and with assaulting Mr. Gralto. Murray Richman, Mr. Bosshart's lawyer, said his client denies all the charges against him.
 
THE TOP CARS AT HOME AND ON THIRD WORLD ROADS
 Because of the immense profits from cannibalizing cars, the police estimate that more than half of all cars stolen in the city are taken for their parts, said Lieut. Robert Martin of the Auto Crime Squad.
Not surprisingly, the cars most frequently stolen are made by General Motors -- because of the greater demand for used G.M. parts.
By contrast, Lieutenant Martin attributed the theft of three cars in the top 10 list of most stolen cars -- 1994 Toyotas, Hondas and Nissans -- to the growing number of stolen cars exported to Third World nations, where there are few or no dealerships that sell new cars and where vehicle registration is often nonexistent.
The Japanese makers' reputation for durability make them popular in underdeveloped nations with unreliable roads, Lieutenant Martin said. This market is controlled by recently established rings, based among the new immigrant groups, specialize in illegal exports. They steal new cars and resell them, for double or triple their original worth.
In the end, organized crime rings account for almost nine out of 10 car thefts in the City, Lieutenant Martin said.
Faced with the disquieting statistic that more than nine cars a day were reported stolen in the 107th Precinct last year, Linda Leuzzi thinks her Jeep Cherokee could be next. She and her husband, Vincent, live in Jamaica Estates, on a block where brazen thieves have been known to career down the street, searching for cars in broad daylight -- even on Mother's Day.
Three times in the last three years, inside their second-floor bedroom, which faces the driveway, the couple were awakened in the predawn hours by breaking glass. Each time, they chased away the thieves in time.
"Now, if we hear a noise outside, we jump out of bed and go to the window," she said. "We have the window open, even in the middle of winter. We want fresh air, but it's also because we want to know what's happening out there."
 
 
The Indicted: A Flow Chart"
 Though it is on the decline, auto theft remains a scourge in many neighborhoods. As cars have become more sophisticated, so has car theft. Law enforcement officials in Queens and Nassau County say a recent indictment is a key step in efforts to combat the crime and illustrates the power of market forces for blackmarket auto parts. Their case: Vincent Asaro, a reputed captain in the Bonanno crime family, was at the top, receiving $500 per week in tribute from the man they say operated the ring, Guy Gralto. They say Mr. Gralto connected with buyers and helped hire car cutters and thieves. All those charged have pleaded not guilty.
 
 
You and the 'Steal Men': Get Protection and Say a Prayer
 IN a densely populated city where few residents own private garages, and where monthly indoor parking fees can cost as much as a studio's rent, New Yorkers must leave their cars to the gods of the streets. Experts say that in New York -- especially in New York -- nothing will stop a thief. But there are devices that will make stealing your car more difficult, and maybe persuade the thief to move on to your neighbor's car. Here's a look at the most popular.
 
 
IGNITION CUT-OFF SYSTEM
 HOW IT WORKS: If the proper encoded ignition key is not used, or if an attempt is made to start the car without a key, electronic sensors built into the ignition lock automatically cut off the electric power. Usually, the system also activates an alarm. Some sought-after cars, like the Corvette and Lexus LS400, come already equipped with the system. But it can be installed in any car for a few hundred dollars.
 THE BOTTOM LINE: The best, experts say. "We've seen this to be effective even in very high-profile vehicles, like the Camaro or Corvette," says Kim Hazelbaker, senior vice president of the Highway Loss Data Institute. "Compared to previous models that did not have this system, the thefts have come down, and have stayed down. Now the theft of Corvettes is only twice above average, whereas in the past it used to be 10 times the average."
 HOW THIEVES GET AROUND IT: Tow the car away.
 
 
 
ALARM
 HOW IT WORKS: Sirens, flashing lights, or robotic voice warns thieves to "stand back."
 THE BOTTOM LINE: "They don't do much good," Mr. Hazelbaker says. "It's a harsh statement. But we simply don't find the difference in the theft records of cars that have these alarms and those that don't." Especially in New York, people tune them out.
 HOW THIEVES GET AROUND IT: One thief breaks into the car and immediately releases the lever of the hood. An accomplice pops open the hood and smashes the alarm, which is usually installed near the engine. Frank Vasquez, an officer with the city police's crime prevention division, recommends adding a lock to the hood latch.
 
 
 
LOJACK
 HOW IT WORKS: A radio transceiver is hidden somewhere in the car. When the car is stolen, the police enter the vehicle identification code into a computer system, and a broadcast system emits radio signals to turn on the transceiver in the car. Each precinct has at least one patrol car equipped with a tracking computer, says Officer Jim Muller of the crime prevention division.
 THE BOTTOM LINE: The recovery rate in several states for stolen cars with Lojack is 95 percent, according to the manufacturers. But the unit, which costs $595 or less, is unproven in New York City, where here it has just been introduced and where there are special problems.
 HOW THIEVES GET AROUND IT: The owner must report the theft to the police immediately. If the owner dallies, especially in New York, the car could be in a chop-shop by the time the owner makes the call.
 
 
STEERING-WHEEL IMMOBILIZERS
 HOW IT WORKS: The most famous is the Club, a device that is locked to the steering wheel and limits turning.
 THE BOTTOM LINE: Many auto-security experts regard these devices, used by themselves, as minor deterrents.
HOW THIEVES GET AROUND IT By spraying Freon, a refrigerant, on the immobilizer's lock, thieves can easily smash it. Most don't even bother doing that. They simply cut through the steering wheel, which (to prevent injuries during accidents) is usually made of an aluminum wire covered with foam and vinyl.
 
 
COMBAT AUTO THEFT
 HOW IT WORKS: Under a police program, car owners stick a notice on their windshields, allowing the police to stop their cars between 1 A.M. and 5 A.M.
 THE BOTTOM LINE: It deters car thieves who don't want to needlessly increase their chances of being stopped. For no cost, drivers who register cars at the local precinct can get between 5 and 15 percent discounts on insurance premiums, Officer Vasquez said.
 HOW THE THIEVES GET AROUND IT: Once the car is stolen, the chances of recovery are no different from cars not registered in this program. Since the program's inception in the mid-1980s, 126,000 cars were registered, said Barbara Keimes, an officer in Crime Prevention. Of that total, 1,000 cars were stolen. But only 45 cars were recovered, and 20 thieves were arrested.

PUB-DATE: March 19, 1995

SECTION: Section 3; Page 9; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1045 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
If the Market Hates It, He's Buying

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
Over the last decade, the Clipper Fund, a no-load growth fund run from Beverly Hills, Calif., by James A. Gipson, has put together a good record by searching for value, often among the stocks that Wall Street hates. The fund stumbled a bit in 1994, losing 2.4 percent in a year when the hot sector was technology, an area where the fund rarely ventures. But this year, through Friday, the fund is up 11.1percent.
When asked last week, Mr. Gipson said he loved brokerage houses, thought some health care stocks were still good values despite their recent rally and generally found that some of the best companies were the best buys.
Floyd Norris 
 Q. Your portfolio is extremely heavy in financial stocks. Why?
A. Basically, it is high-quality companies that are the cheapest in the current market. There's an old saying: In investing you can choose to eat well or sleep well, but not both. This is one of those rare occasions when in fact you can do both. The structure of values in the market makes high-quality companies cheap, and that's what we have in the portfolio. The average price/earnings multiple of our portfolio is about 12, using 1995 estimates. So, the price is cheap but the quality is quite high.
Some of the best financial service companies in the country are among the cheapest right now. And basically we have two commitments there. One is to the Government-sponsored enterprises, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, with about 20 percent of the portfolio. They are some of the best and highest-return financial services companies in the country, selling for about nine times earnings. They have a very low cost of funds. They share a duopoly and have reasonable growth prospects.
Q. Why are they cheap?
A. I'll go back over the last three years. People were afraid, as short-term interest rates were going down, that this would cause problems for Fannie and Freddie. And then when rates went up a year ago, people were afraid that, oh, this would cause problems for Fannie and Freddie. In fact, both companies have matched their assets and liabilities very well and have come through one of the more volatile interest rate environments in recent years with their profits and their growth rates largely intact. Yet people really don't seem to care.
Q. How fast do you think they will grow?
A. Both of them have a pretty high probability of being able to grow their earnings at 12 to 15 percent per year over the next five years. Fannie and Freddie are two companies that, if the economy does slow down or, worse yet, goes into a recession, still have a reasonable prospect of being able to grow with their earnings at double-digit rates.
Q. You've also got a lot of money in brokerage stocks. Haven't you heard that higher interest rates have killed off that industry?
A. There is a good deal of controversy about those stocks. One of the cheapest assets on Wall Street is stock in Wall Street itself. And to take the negative for a moment, they made very good money in 1991 to 1993. Last year was not a banner year, and this year is turning out the same. And for people who focus on earnings momentum, the brokerage place is not the place to be.
If, on the other hand, you are looking for a good long-term business in which to become a long-term partner, this is a good opportunity to buy some of the best investment banking franchises in the country very cheaply and to buy them when their own managements are buying back their shares.
Q. Name names.
A. Two good examples are Morgan Stanley and Merrill Lynch. In both cases you're paying only a very small premium over stated book value. Book value, remember, is largely stock and bond inventory. So that is a hard book value not a soft one. But they are both fine companies with very good franchises, very good long-term prospects.
Q. Merrill isn't very popular in some parts of your home state of California, such as Orange County.
A. We significantly increased our position in Merrill back in November, during the crisis. Interestingly enough, the company itself repurchased 6 percent of its shares in the fourth quarter of last year. So, they were making a very large bet. It turned out to be a correct one that the market had gone off the deep end in worries over the Orange County crisis. The shares have rallied substantially since then.
Q. You bought Salomon a few years back when everyone hated it. And you still own some, although you've cut back. Its stock has slumped lately because people wonder whether they can make money and whether they can get the accounting right.
A. A financial firm that can't perform its basic bookkeeping well doesn't inspire confidence that it can do other things well. But the accounting problems are not central to Salomon's future. They say they fixed them; they probably have.
What is much more central is their capacity to build and defend a good trading franchise, and Salomon has slipped in that.
Q. So why own Salomon?
A. We've cut our position back from about 9 percent of the portfolio to around 2 percent. In retrospect, I wish we'd eliminated it.
Q. You've moved into some consumer products companies.
A. Right. That is another example of what I said at the beginning, that some of the nation's highest-quality companies are the cheapest. Pepsico, McDonald's are new to the portfolio in the last year. Frito-Lay is Pepsi's biggest profit contributor. But they are enjoying 10 percent unit growth. I don't know where people put all those pretzels. They've got 45 percent of the market, while the next two competitors are around 6 percent and losing money. Pepsi just coins money in the market.
Q. You've got almost 10 percent of your portfolio in three health-care companies. Have they been there long?
A. I never bought a drug stock in my life until two years ago. And at that point, there was nothing but fear that the Federal health care reform was going to wipe out profits. That gave us an almost unique opportunity to buy some of the world's best pharmaceutical companies very cheaply.
They've come back. We sold off Schering-Plough, but we still have Merck, Johnson & Johnson and Pfizer. I would classify them today as excellent highly profitable businesses that are moderately cheap.
