HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

TRADE
Conoco Gets Its Wrist Slapped
Boy hits little sister on head. Father scolds him. Boy, a budding defense lawyer, says, "You didn't tell me not to hit little sister on the head." Conoco's recent oil deal with Iran had a bit of that flavor: Iran has been firmly in the doghouse for a decade and a half, but no, nobody said, "Thou shalt not make this kind of deal." Conoco went ahead. So last week, after cries of anger on many fronts, the Administration made it perfectly clear: Don't hit little sisters on the head, don't stick beans in your ears and don't make such deals with Iran. Conoco promptly backed off. 

TIMING
And Now, a Tip From Baring
Newspapers have it easy: Something happens, it's in print within hours. But pity, for a brief moment, the folks who put out those glossy bound reports -- so much can happen in the weeks between cup and lip. Take a report that landed in the mail last week, one that hinted strongly of time travel: the first of its two picks for the world's "best developed stock markets" was Japan. That, to put it mildly, seems a bit odd when you notice that the issuer of the report was Baring Securities, which, you may recall, had a bit of trouble when one of its young go-getters bet big on Japanese stocks. And that was nearly three weeks ago.
 
AFTER THE DELUGE
Far More Than Pricey Broccoli
It's been said that California is simply too precarious to live in, and that certainly seemed the case in last week's killer floods. But people do live there, so the economic costs must be sorted out. First estimates of mopping up are $2 billion or so, including at least $350 million in damage. Broccoli and other items might be costlier, but not for too long. But the real pain will be for homeowners without flood insurance -- there are a lot of those -- and for farm workers. When things dry out, most people's jobs will be intact, but many of the state's 40,000 farm workers will lose their livelihood. In the words of one grower, "They don't really have anywhere to go."
 
AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
White Men Still Jump
"You do not have to be a brain surgeon to deduce that something is wrong out there," said Bob Dole, referring to workplace discrimination. That was in 1991, when he helped create the Glass Ceiling Commission to look into it. But last week -- as he proposed an end to affirmative action for women and minorities -- Mr. Dole, a white male, said, "The race-counting game has gone too far." How far is too far? Well, that commission made its report last week, and for all the screams by white males about being an endangered species, it seems that they're still running the corporate show. Even though white women are now 40 percent of the work force, white men hold 95 percent of top management positions. These men, the report said, see women and minorities as "a direct threat" to their career goals.
 
CHARITY
Yale Has to Say, 'No, Thanks'
As donations flow to colleges and universities, that old axiom -- the rich get richer -- is in full flower. Why, just last week John Loeb, of Wall Street fame, and his wife, Frances, gave $70.5 million to Harvard, already the nation's richest university. For the Loebs -- he's 92, she's 88 -- that's most of their earthly wealth. Yale, though, got a bit poorer last week. Lee Bass -- yes, one of those Texas brothers -- had given $20 million to his alma mater four years ago, but he'd put strings on it: it was for more Western civilization courses. Those pushing multiculturalism didn't like that idea much, and the gift caused all sorts of trouble. And the last straw came recently when Mr. Bass tacked on a new condition: he'd approve the faculty. So Yale finally decided to give the money back -- plus interest.
 
CONGRESS
Attacking the Budget
The Republican budget-cutters moved solidly ahead last week, passing a record $17.3 billion in budget cuts for this year, but it may not prove the victory it seemed. Only six Democrats joined them, so the vote was 227 to 200 -- far short of what would be needed to survive a promised Clinton veto. The President said the measure would "cut too much people and not enough pork" -- since the cuts fall heavily on social welfare programs. But the Republicans weren't buying what they called the "rhetoric about compassion." Representative Gerald Solomon of New York asked, "What is so compassionate about saddling our children and grandchildren with such staggering debt?"
 
EDUCATION
New Way to Invest in Students
Education is looking more and more like just another business. For one thing, Christopher Whittle's Edison Project -- which recently seemed precarious -- said last week that it had gotten $30 million in financing and would open its first for-profit schools in the fall. Also last week, the S.E.C. approved the public sale of bonds backed by private student loans. And while Sallie Mae loans are based on both need and good credit, these loans have no such tests. The loans are offered by colleges and universities, and the bonds they back are issued by a nonprofit group called the National Collegiate Trust. The loan rates -- set by each college -- will probably be a bit higher.
 
AUTOS
Jobs Come, Jobs Go
The nation's auto industry seems to have a split personality these days -- it can't make some models fast enough, but many plants are still slated for closing. The sense of dislocation was readily apparent last week when 900 people lined up for jobs at General Motors' North Tarrytown plant. That's right -- the one G.M. says it's closing next year. What's up? Well, union workers -- the ones G.M. must stick by -- are gradually being offered transfers to other plants. But the assembly line must go on -- so it's hiring up to 1,500 temporary workers, and a lot of people want the jobs. The pay -- $12.90 an hour -- is about $6 less than union workers get, but it's far better than minimum wage. And as one applicant said, it's "better than standing on the welfare line."
 
TECHNOLOGY
Today's News? You Pick It
Yes, it's often said that people hear what they want to hear, see what they want to see. But that's just fuzzy psychology -- it has no place in a world overrun by technology. Today's computers allow you, more and more, to truly customize your own little universe. Want to watch the news, but don't care about half the stuff? Simple. Create your own newscast. That's the goal of Oracle, the software company, which is talking to various telephone, computer and news outfits about setting up a nationwide service that would let PC users pick and choose items for a video newscast. Want some crime? Click once for a dose of blood and cops. Something heartwarming? A lost-puppy-found tale is surely available. Nonstop O.J.? Well, of course.
 
THE NUMBERS
It All Adds Up for the Dow
It's often hard to know what the markets want from the economic numbers, but last week's mix seemed to be the right one. The numbers showed strength in factory production, but only moderate inflation, with consumer and producer prices both up just 0.3 percent for February. That signaled that things were on track for annual inflation, as hoped, to stay under 3.5 percent. And those who feel better if things cool off a bit got just that in a report that housing starts had slowed. What this added up to in the markets was three more record closes for the Dow industrials, which closed the week comfortably above the 4,000 threshold at 4,073.

LENGTH: 680 words

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT: NOT SO FAST;
Plastic That Pays You Back May Not Be Your Best Payoff

BYLINE: BY SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
WOULD you sign up for a weight-loss program that promises you can eat as many gallons of chocolate ice cream as you want because all the extra pounds will melt away -- after 20 years?
The Mellon Bank of Pittsburgh is making a variation on that offer with its unusual Cornerstone Mastercard, which promises to let you indulge now and get back all the finance charges you pay over the years. For people struggling to make their credit card payments, it sounds great. And 700,000 people have taken the card. 
 But there are two significant catches. First, you have to wait 20 years before you can get the full rebate, although a partial rebate is possible after only two years. Second, the interest charged is much higher than average, and almost double that of the best offers in the market.
The Cornerstone card charges the prime rate plus 11.9 percentage points, which would be 20.9 percent today given the current 9 percent prime. Mellon's gold Cornerstone card charges prime plus 8.9.
Standard pricing these days is 7 to 10 points above prime. And there are a number of cards that offer rates of no more than 5 points above prime.
With the rebate, a few people could come out ahead if they stay with Mellon's deal for five years or more, but consumer advocates say don't bother.
"There is so much competition out there," says Ruth Susswein, director of the Bankcard Holders of America, Salem, Va. "The low-rate offers are far more tempting than getting your interest back down the road but paying a high rate now."
Because inflation eats away at the value of money year after year, a dollar is worth more today than it will be 20 years from now. What's more, you are taking the risk that Mellon will continue the program and even continue to exist for two decades. The bank reserves the right to change the terms, charge higher interest or cancel the plan altogether, leaving you little choice but to cash out with a partial rebate.
Moreover, you have to remain attentive. You will lose your entire rebate if you don't use the card for any 12-month period in that 20 years.
As an alternative, Ms. Susswein pointed to the Wachovia Bank, of Winston-Salem, N.C., which offers cards with rates of prime plus 3.9 percentage points (12.9 percent today) for an $18 annual fee. The bank offers other cards with even lower rates in return for higher fees.
It's rarely a good idea to get into a deal you don't understand, and the sheer complexity is one good reason to avoid the Cornerstone card. It takes a penchant for algebra or nimble fingers on the spreadsheet to figure out how much the Cornerstone card actually costs. Whether it's a good deal depends on how long you keep it and what the interest rate is of the card you would use instead.
Kerry Ryan, senior vice president for credit cards at Mellon, says the Cornerstone card is a better deal than a standard card with a rate four or five points lower if you keep it for three to seven years.
But a truly low-rate card, like the one from Wachovia, beats Mellon's basic card no matter what.
Let's say you have a constant balance of $2,500. On the regular Cornerstone card, at current rates, you would pay $523 a year in interest. If you had the Wachovia prime plus 3.9 card, you would pay $323 a year, savings $200.
But what if you kept each card for five years? You would pay Mellon $2,613 in interest, and you would be entitled to a rebate of 25 percent of that amount, or $653. That's a nice rebate, but the Wachovia card would have saved you $347 more, even before any interest you might have earned by investing the savings.
But why invest the savings? Consider doing something really bold, namely paying off that balance. If you took the Wachovia card and applied the $200 a year you saved in interest to your balance, in five years you would have slashed the amount owed by more than half and would have saved $640 more than with the Cornerstone card, even after the rebate. In eight years, the bill would be paid off.
Such savings will buy a lot of ice cream. Or aerobics classes. Or both.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Are You Your Own Boss? Only if the I.R.S. Says So

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
IT'S a question, it might seem, that only an accounting professor could love: when is a job a job, and when is it a business deal?
But for five million Americans who consider themselves their own boss, the issue is much more than an academic curiosity. It's a matter of money. 
 For the past 10 years, the Internal Revenue Service has been busily stripping away the tax advantages that have been enjoyed by more than a million doctors, computer programmers and others who sell their services as independent contractors. The I.R.S. has decided that these contractors are actually employees of the hospitals and businesses for which they work. And employees can't deduct most business expenses and travel costs, or shelter serious money for retirement, as contractors can. All of which translates into many more tax dollars for the agency.
The contractors, not surprisingly, don't like this development a bit, and their lawyers have made it the most contentious employment tax issue in the nation today.
But there is another group of contractors who would like nothing better than to be employees -- the poor ones like farm workers, janitors and seamstresses toiling in Brooklyn sweatshops.
Many of these workers want to be employees just to be covered by the minimum wage laws. As employees, they also would have taxes withheld from their pay, making them eligible for jobless, disability and old-age benefits.
But the I.R.S. is not spending much time reclassifying these low-wage people. Why? Because their tax bills are so small that the issue is not an agency priority.
"The service does take into account the practicalities of where to place its resources to get the best long-term results in encouraging compliance," explained the I.R.S.'s chief spokesman, Frank Keith.
In other words, there are five million people whose job status may be in question. Some want to remain as independent contractors; the I.R.S. is turning them into employees. Some want to become employees; the agency is continuing to call them independent contractors.
This leaves virtually everyone angry, and that includes the I.R.S. The agency is trying to apply tax laws that were largely written for an age of manual work and factories to an era of intellectual labor, often conducted in home offices.
And while Congress has held repeated hearings on the problem, more than two dozen tax experts and lobbyists said in interviews that they did not expect corrective legislation this year.
This is just one example of how the classification of workers for tax purposes has vexed businesses and individuals for many years. The problem began in the 1960's, when the I.R.S. started looking at the underground economy -- home gardeners, nannies -- as a source of unreported income and uncollected taxes.
In the 1970's the issue expanded, as some companies began paying significant numbers of workers as independent contractors in order to avoid a growing list of payroll and other taxes.
And the problem persists today. Laws that no one likes remain on the books. Business owners are distracted from their jobs by time-consuming tax intricacies. Workers and bosses cross swords over who wanted which job classification. Here is how three people have had their lives -- and their pocketbooks -- shaped by the continuing confusion:
Dale B. Rostad likes living in Bloomington, Minn. And so when his employer asked him in 1982 to transfer to Boston to work in its finance department, he quit. But the company did give him a contract to work on its computers while he remained in Minnesota and, with that first customer, Mr. Rostad founded his own computer services business.
Today Mr. Rostad, 41, has a long list of clients for his company, Business & Business Systems Consulting. Last year, though, one minor client paid him $6,000 as an independent contractor. And now the I.R.S. is trying to make him an employee of that company.
That worries Mr. Rostad for two reasons. If the I.R.S. does this with all his clients, then he will lose all the tax deductions he gets as an independent contractor -- deductions upon which he and his business have come to depend. But he also has more work than he can handle on occasion, and when he does he sometimes farms this work out to others. And he worries that the I.R.S. may do to him what it did to his $6,000 client: reclassify as employees the people he retains as independent contractors.
The uncertainty creates headaches for a busy businessman.
The law at issue is Section 1706 of the Internal Revenue Code, which targets computer programmers, engineers and other technical services workers. The law requires them to pass a 20-part test for distinguishing between employees and independent contractors.
For example, if Mr. Rostad's hired programmer travels to the client's facility, the I.R.S. hears "employee." If Mr. Rostad pays him by the job instead of the hour, that means "contractor." If the programmer submits a report to Mr. Rostad, that means "employee." If he does work for others, though, "contractor" it probably is. And on and on.
The laundry list certainly distracts Mr. Rostad from his business, but the stakes are indisputably high. If Mr. Rostad guesses wrong and his programmers are deemed employees, he will be on the hook to pay taxes for unemployment compensation, workers' compensation and Social Security. At worst these levies can kill a business; at best they can hobble it competitively.
Mr. Rostad's solution is to limit the size of his business. That results in less income for himself and the I.R.S.
"I do a little bit of farming work out, but I don't let it grow ," Mr. Rostad said. "I know there is a lot of business out there, but getting it just is not worth the hassles with the Government."
Christine Macke, a registered nurse who owns a nurse-placement agency, said her company would be 50 percent larger if it were not for another tax law, Section 530. Under that statute, her competitors can treat workers as independent contractors if they formed their companies in 1977 or before.
But Mrs. Macke's enterprise, Med-Force, of Arlington, Va., was launched in 1987. And so her company, which places nurses in temporary jobs, is of modest size, with a work roster equal only to about 50 full-time jobs.
"I have had large contracts I have been underbid on because the law lets some of my competitors have independent contractor status," she said, thus freeing them from Social Security and other taxes. The handicap "forced me to redirect my business away from traditional medical-surgical and intensive-care staffing to a niche market, psychiatric staffing."
Confusion reigns over this tax question, too. Mrs. Macke doubted that any nurse, at a hospital or elsewhere, can really be an independent contractor no matter how old his or her company is. Why? Because nurses work at the direction of physicians.
A hallmark of independent contractors -- indeed, it is a main theme of the 20-part test Mr. Rostad must puzzle over -- is that they can proceed as they see fit as long as they get the job done, while employees must follow the detailed directions of bosses.
Ramiro Murillo, a native of Mexico, was paid $200 to $250 a week as an independent contractor to hoe weeds and do other work for Robert and Pat Criswell, who live near Plainview, Texas. Now the I.R.S. is garnishing his pay at his new job; the agency says he and his wife, Berene, owe $3,155.80 in taxes, penalties and interest from that past job.
Mr. Murillo told a Congressional committee that he asked the Criswells to deduct his taxes, but they declined. In 1990 he was fired.
When he applied for unemployment, "they said I could not get benefits because nothing was submitted under my Social Security number," Mr. Murillo testified, through an interpreter,
Kay Drought, an attorney with Texas Rural Legal Services, said Mr. Murillo eventually received his jobless benefits. But that has become a hollow victory because his wages are being garnisheed. "They are having trouble getting enough money together just to eat," she said.
Tens of thousands of farm workers in Texas are still paid as independent contractors, she said.
But, here too, there is confusion and finger-pointing. Robert Criswell said in an interview that Mr. Murillo did not want any taxes withheld from his checks. He said this was a common request among farm workers in the Texas Panhandle who emigrate from Mexico but who plan to return there someday.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Christine Macke (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times); Ramiro and Berene Murillos (Associated Press); Dale Rostad (Terry Gydesen for The New York Times)
 
Charts: "What You Are. . ."
The Internal Revenue Service uses a 20-part test to see if a person is an independent contractor or an employee. Here are some of the elements.
 
WHOSE RULES?
If a worker must follow rules about the manner of work -- the how, when and where -- that's a sign of an employee. But an independent contractor can proceed as he wishes, as long as the job gets done.
 
ENDING IT.
Most employees can be fired or quit without reason or notice. But with independent contractors, both the worker and the company must follow their agreement's rules about when and why they can part ways.
 
OTHER GIGS.
You are more likely to be considered an independent contractor if you are able to work for more than one busoness at a time, the I.R.S. says. But an employee often works full time, or must be available to do so.
 
WHOSE TOOLS?
Do you furnish your own tools and material for your work? Then the I.R.S. hears "independent contractor."
 
RISKY BUSINESS
Independent contractors make make money or lose money on a job. But employees will get their paychecks however a project turns out.
 
". . .and Why It Matters"
Some major differences in the tax treatment of an independent contractor and an empployee.
 
INDEPENDENT CONTRACTOR
Can deduct work expenses
Makes quarterly estimated tax payments
Pays full Social Security and Medicare taxes
May be able to deduct part of residence as home office
Can shelter 15 percent of income, up to $30,000, for retirement
Can deduct work-related travel
 
COMPANY EMPLOYEE
First 2 percent of work expenses not deductible, and the deduction is phased out above $55,900 in income ($111,800 for couples)
Taxes withheld by employer
Pays only half of Social Security and Medicare taxes; other half paid by employer
Hard to qualify for home officer deduction
Retirement savings usually capped at $9,500 or less
no deduction for paying salaries to other people
Can deduct only unreimbursed travel expenses

HEADLINE: Parents, Schools And the 'Extras'

 BODY:
Re: "A New Way to Pay for School Extras" (Feb. 26): The energetic, enthusiastic fund-raising efforts of all these volunteers for their children and the schools they attend are commendable but misguided.
If they truly wanted to achieve economic efficiencies, and lower their property tax bills in the bargain, they would seriously address two overriding issues: first, the inane duplication of educational efforts that makes virtually every community in the state a school district, frequently without any logical basis; and second, the economic ramifications of this duplication, which create a highly paid superintendent and almost as highly paid principals plus support staffs in each of the about 600 districts. 
 That a large number of these superintendents earn as much as New Jersey's Governor and Education Commissioner, yet have far, far less supervisory responsibility and almost no direct accountability to taxpayers/voters, is worse than illogical. It is ludicrous.
RON DE PAOLO
Stockholm, N.J.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1343 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
If Gingrich Only Knew About Victoria's Secret

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:
It wasn't so long ago that the term "Victorian" was a pejorative one, conjuring up images of Dickensian slums, uptight moralists, pompous prigs, paternalistic moralizers, fussy architecture and overstuffed furniture. Taking our cue from Lytton Strachey -- whose classic book "Eminent Victorians" (1918) lanced that era's pretentions with malicious wit -- we tended to shrug off the Victorians as sanctimonious imperialists or faintly ridiculous prudes.
 All this is changing now, and it's not just the current vogue in Pre-Raphaelite paintings, Laura Ashley furnishings, Gothic revival architecture and neo-Victorian novels. Victorianism has suddenly become a social model -- for both the left and right. 
 The Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, has not only praised that most Dickensian of institutions, the orphanage, but last week he also hailed the Victorians' "moral leadership," their willingness "to look at people In the face and say, 'You should be ashamed when you get drunk in public; you ought to be ashamed if you're a drug addict.' "
 His remarks, as he acknowledged, owe a decided debt to the arguments laid out by the historian Gertrude Himmelfarb in her new book "The De-Moralization of Society: From Victorian Virtues to Modern Values" (Alfred A. Knopf). Ms. Himmelfarb's arguments, in turn, recall those of former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher during the 1980's, hailing the "Victorian values" of hard work, self-reliance, thrift, self-respect, neighborliness and national pride.

 
 
Women on a Pedestal
 But Victorian values, or at least our perception of them, belong not just to the right wing. On the left, radical feminists like Catherine MacKinnon, Andrea Dworkin and Robin Morgan are promoting views of women that consciously or unconsciously recall Victorian sexual stereotypes. Not only do many of these feminists want to ban pornography and curtail free speech in the name of protecting women, but they also promulgate a kind of sexual paranoia, suggesting that men are beasts and women are in constant danger of physical or emotional rape.
 As Katie Roiphe pointed out in "The Morning After: Sex, Fear, and Feminism on Campus" (Little, Brown), some of the current pamphlets warning college women of date rape are reminiscent of those Victorian guides to conduct that used to teach young women how to avoid "vulgar familiarity." Rene Denfeld goes even further. In her new book "The New Victorians" (Warner Books), she writes that "the women's movement has come to duplicate Victorianism in all its repressive glory: the woman revered on the pedestal, charged with keeping society's moral order yet politically powerless and perpetually martyred."
 What's behind this Victorian revival? In part, of course, it's simple nostalgia for a seemingly simpler, more innocent age -- a time when the notions of progress and technology could still summon hope instead of anxiety, the last era before the terrors of the 20th century were brought home by two World Wars. The Victorian era seems, at once, close enough to embody recognizable problems, and yet distant enough to elicit more than just the sort of knee-jerk, filial rebellion purveyed by members of Bloomsbury.
 But is it Victorianism that we are reviving or a caricature? As A.N. Wilson noted in his recent book "Eminent Victorians" (W.W. Norton & Company), a kind of response to Lytton Strachey's book of the same title, popular attitudes toward the Victorian age have been strongly shaped (until recently at least) by the savagely satirical portraits drawn by Strachey, Virginia Woolf and their peers. The problem with much of the current commentary on the Victorians, both pro and con, is that it tends to be similarly arbitrary, selective and in some cases, downright cartoon-like.
 In "The Rise of Selfishness in America" (Oxford University Press), the jazz historian and social critic James Lincoln Collier attributes most of our current social ills to the demise of the Victorian belief system and its replacement by "the new ethic of the self," but he virtually ignores such 19th-century realities as child labor, debilitating poverty and high unemployment, noting simply that the Victorians prided themselves on "a willingness to protect the weak."

 
 
Cleanliness Without Sanitation
 As for Ms. Himmelfarb, she has written with great subtlety and insight about the Victorians in the past, but in her new book and recent essays, she seriously downplays the era's gross social inequities and the often yawning gap between its professed values and its day-to-day realities.
 She writes in one op-ed piece, for instance, that "we might rediscover the ideas of cleanliness and orderliness, which Victorians elevated to the level of virtues," and yet she overlooks the fact that for most of the poor, simple sanitation was often an unaffordable luxury.
 She also asserts that the Victorians managed to achieve "a substantial decline" in illegitimacy rates, neglecting to deal with the findings presented by Michael Mason in his new book "The Making of Victorian Sexuality" (Oxford University Press): during the first half of the 19th century, he writes, prenuptial pregnancy was prevalent; 40 percent of the brides in many small English town were pregnant before they were married, and "in some areas the rate pushed up past the half-way point as the century advanced."
 In fact the work of such scholars as Peter Gay, Steven Marcus and Thomas Boyle has revealed that beneath the prim, respectable surface of Victorian life were deep currents of sensuality and even violence -- currents that have been glossed over by many recent commentators on Victorian values. Rene Denfeld's attack on what she calls neo-Victorian feminists, for instance, revolves around the Victorian ideal of feminine purity; she never really comes to terms with the fact that that cliched image of frigid frailty often belied a spirited interest in sex.
 In calling for a revival of Victorian values, does Mr. Gingrich realize everything that his support may embrace? What would he think of Mr. Wilson's observation that in England, divorces could not be obtained through the law courts until 1857 or his finding that women were not given equal guardianship of their children until 1925? What would he make of Mr. Marcus's assertion that pornographic writings were "produced and published in unprecedented volume" during the middle and latter decades of the 19th century? Or of his finding that "there grew up in the latter part of the Victorian period a veritable and unique cult of homosexuality" whose "influence in the society at large was in disproportion to the number of its members"?

 
 
Diversity and Perversity
 No doubt a measure of reductionism and over-generalization adheres to any historical inquiry, but Victorian England seems particularly resistant to easy characterization, for it was a culture in flux, a culture that changed fundamentally between the beginning and end of Victoria's long reign from 1837 to 1901. As Ms. Himmelfarb herself has pointed out in an earlier book called "Victorian Minds," "it managed, at different times and in different degrees, to absorb quite distinct and even contrary ideas, ideologies, sentiments, and policies." Indeed, "the Victorian age exhibited, and not at its periphery but at its very center, all the diversity, and much of the perversity, of which the human mind is capable."
 While the Victorians were grappling with problems that may appear to be familiar to us (growing urbanization, accelerating social changes, concerns about education and health) they also inhabited a vastly different world, a world that was far less heterogenous, far less egalitarian than our own. Analogies between that age and our own can, therefore, be highly deceptive.
 In fact the more one thinks about the Victorians, the more one is inclined to agree with the British novelist L.P. Hartley, who once declared: "the past is a foreign country; they do things differently there."

LENGTH: 1441 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Name That Era;
Pinpointing A Moment On the Map Of History

BYLINE: By JAMES ATLAS 

 BODY:
WHEN does an era end? Sometimes a momentous event -- the beginning of the Civil War, the death of Franklin D. Roosevelt -- provides the definitive finale to what historians can later give a name -- the Antebellum period, the Age of Roosevelt. The end of the Cold War had a literal end: on Dec. 25, 1991, the Soviet Union "went out of business," as the historian Michael Beschloss puts it, and the red flag was lowered over the Kremlin, never to be raised again.
 But what about the era we find ourselves in now? Historians and journalists operate on the assumption that world politics has entered a new phase, that we find ourselves in a pattern of events radically distinct from that of the last 50 years. The trouble is, it doesn't yet have a compelling name. The phrase routinely employed by political pundits -- the post-cold war era -- is tentative, vague; it lacks authority. Unlike, say, the Era of Good Feelings (1815-1825), when the United States dwelled in apparent harmony, untroubled by foreign wars and prosperous at home, the tepid label we reflexively invoke these days carries a suggestion of self-doubt. It's as if our own historical moment is somehow after the fact, overshadowed by the more significant era that preceded it. 
 Our age is fixated on the notion of being post-. The prefix is ubiquitous. The cultural critic Russell Jacoby, writing in Harper's magazine, remarks on the pervasive influence of "poststructuralist, post-Marxist, and post-everything thinkers." Scan the shelves of any decent bookstore and you're likely to find these titles: "Postmodernism," "Post-Modernist Fiction," "A Poetics of Postmodernism," "Postmodernist Culture."
 But isn't this obsession with post-ness simply another way of acknowledging that we don't know where we are? Aren't the labels we apply -- the Renaissance, the Age of Exploration -- simply titles for narratives that historians have contrived to unify the disparate events of an arbitrarily designated age?
 "History is lived forward, but it is written in retrospect," wrote the great English historian C. V. Wedgwood in "William the Silent," her biography of William of Orange, the 16th-century liberator of the Netherlands. "We know the end before we consider the beginning and we can never wholly recapture what it was to know the beginning only." In "The Proud Tower," Barbara Tuchman's magisterial "Portrait of the World Before the War, 1890-1914," the author created a portrait of an age of optimism without referring to the then-invisible slide toward Armageddon in which it would end. Why? Because "it was not a part of the experience of the people of this book. I have tried to stay within the terms of what was known at the time." That kind of approach would put journalists and political commentators out of business.
 This tendency to identify as eras the short bursts of experience that live in our memory is a new phenomenon in historical scholarship.
 "The concept of generations has only recently emerged as a unit of historical analysis," Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. writes in "The Cycles of American History." But with the increased pace of change, the need to impose a narrative on events becomes more urgent than ever. To name an era is to classify what otherwise feels random, to give what is still indistinct a clear identity.
 Compare and contrast -- as they say on exams -- the approach taken by Stanley Hoffmann, the chairman of Harvard's Center for European Studies and that taken by Samuel Huntington, the Eaton Professor of the Science of Government at Harvard, to categorize the era we are entering. Professor Huntington -- in an essay portentously titled "The Clash of Civilizations?" which appeared in the journal Foreign Affairs in 1993 -- tries to find a pattern in events that haven't happened yet. Ideological struggles are being replaced by cultural struggles, he argues. The political boundaries of the cold war are being replaced by "fault lines" between Western and Orthodox Christianity, Western and Islamic civilizations: "The Velvet Curtain of culture has replaced the Iron Curtain of ideology as the most significant dividing line in Europe."
 Professor Hoffmann offers a very different scenario. "On the one hand you have disintegrating states, fragmentation, and ethnic conflict," he says. "Then you have a trend that goes in the opposite direction -- the formation of a huge transnational capitalist economy that consists largely of private investors and private banks that can move money around the world in a matter of minutes. So that when we talk about nation-states we're really talking about only a small amount of what goes on across borders these days." In essence, he says, it is "a completely unprecedented world. It's very difficult to call this world anything." But if he must? "When you don't know what a thing is, you call it post-something else."

 
 
Some Other Event
 All definitions are provisional, limited by our inability to see beyond the moment. We are "prisoners of our own epoch," as Mr. Schlesinger observed. What we now think of as the post-cold war era may well turn out to have been defined by some other event. Are we already in the Age of Global Communication? Of Balkanization? Of Religious War? Of Social Austerity? Or several of the above. What Mr. Schlesinger named "the Age of Roosevelt" could have been named the Age of Fascism or the Age of Totalitarianism. The main event of our age, its consequences as yet ungrasped, could be the carnage in the Balkans, the rise of Islamic fundamentalism or the unraveling of European unity.
 There is a certain narcissistic pleasure in thinking of ourselves as living past the end -- as outliving history. "The grand narratives have become scarcely credible," writes the French theorist Jean-Francois Lyotard in "The Postmodern Explained." Francis Fukuyama claimed, in his grandly titled book, that we are living at "The End of History." The events of the 20th century -- world wars, totalitarianism, the Holocaust -- have consigned us to an existence on the margins of history; but they've also given us a special place in its narrative. George Steiner, in "Language and Silence," put the matter with stark simplicity: "We come after."
 But isn't it possible to imagine ourselves coming before? In his memoir, "Present at the Creation," Dean Acheson, Truman's Secretary of State, described the period between 1941 and 1952 as one of "great obscurity." "Not only was the future clouded, a common enough situation, but the present was equally clouded." In other words, a situation very much like ours. Yet for Mr. Acheson, the "disorderly and uncontrollable world" also offered challenges. The Marshall Plan would usher in "the dawn of a revivification unparalleled in modern history." Mr. Acheson compared "the mood of the beginning, of the early postwar period of action," to an earlier period of human energy: the Elizabethan Age, a time of "ignorance of the true situation, daring, and buoyant determination."
 What the vision of a posthumous world omits is the possibility of innovation. In this sense, Mikhail Gorbachev is a consummate transitional figure, a political artist who breaks down our way of seeing and invents new categories. The reports of his struggle to emerge from obscurity are a reminder of the transformations that have swept the world since he presided over the demise of the Soviet Union only four years ago. Are the recent peace initiatives in South Africa and Ireland and on the West Bank imaginable without him?
 Mr. Gorbachev's achievement is a perfect instance of the post-modern as defined by Lyotard: "The text he writes or the work he creates is not in principle governed by pre-established rules and cannot be judged according to a determinant judgment, by the application of given categories to this text or work."
 The legacy of perestroika -- the realignment of world powers, the unleashing of nationalism, the global outbreaks of freedom and anarchy -- has yet to be interpreted by historians; it lacks a title. But maybe it doesn't need one. As Mr. Beschloss says: "Only when you're past a period can you look back and do something so bold as to name it."
 
 
 
Name That Era
 Which of the disparate threads of this time will be woven together by future historians to define the era? The technologies or the hatreds? The holy wars? The markets? The Week in Review invites you to suggest a name for the post post-cold war era. By March 24, send your idea by mail to Era, Box 957, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or, E-mail to review@nytimes.com.

HEADLINE: The World;
Do Fickle Markets Now Make Policy?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE domino theory is alive and worried about in Washington.
 A generation ago, the fear was over Vietnam and whether its fall to Communism would inevitably take Thailand or Malaysia or Indonesia with it. The Vietnam of the economic age is Mexico, and the insurgents are brandishing not AK-47's and ideology but "hot money." That is what Wall Street calls the billions of dollars that investors move in and out of countries in minutes. And suddenly the task of trying to direct or at least contain that flow before it topples the next domino is remaking the conduct of American foreign policy. 
 To a degree rarely seen before, bond traders and the currency markets are driving policy, rather than reacting to it. For the evidence, just look at the faxes that that have been exchanged in recent weeks between officials at the Treasury Department and the leaders of Mexico, Argentina and Brazil. In Mexico's case, Treasury officials led President Ernesto Zedillo to the unhappy conclusion that he had to spark a deep recession -- sending interest rates on credit cards to upwards of 100 percent, bringing imports to a near halt -- if he had any hope of luring scared investors back into the country. Drastic measures have also been prescribed in Argentina, which just swallowed hard, accepted a $7 billion bailout package from the International Monetary Fund, and prayed that investors would stop fleeing the country in herds.
 In short, these days countries are often finding that they have to destroy prosperity in order to save it. In Mexico, that means laying off hundreds of thousands of people in the name of paying off the short-term bonds that the country sold with abandon last year. "It is a whole new set of priorities," said a Clinton Administration official. "Forget everything you learned about how to help developing nations. Now it's Fidelity first."

 
 
Can We Talk?
 Is this really the message America wants to send around the world? "It's a good question, and one we discuss a lot," said Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, the onetime co-chairman of Goldman Sachs, who has played this game from both sides of the table. "It is tempting to say that markets don't care about the social considerations, about schools or income disparities. But I think the truth is a little different. Don't get me wrong, we're not talking about investors with a conscience. But they want to get their money back, so they are interested in all the financial pieces, but also in what this will do to social and political stability. And in the end, I'm not sure the priorities are so different."
 Whether Mr. Rubin is right or not, ever since the Mexico debacle you cannot walk through Wall Street without tripping over Latin American leaders trying to convince investors to bring their billions back, or at least not suck away what little is left. Several made the trip last week; Peru's President, Alberto Fujimori, came just to make the case that his country is not like Mexico.
 But the fact that they come at all reveals how much has changed. When the Latin debt crisis struck a decade ago, all the lenders, representing the world's biggest banks, got into a room, negotiated austerity measures and reluctantly granted the countries time to work things out.
 In the '90's, bankers don't matter; markets do. "This isn't a situation where you can sit down and reason with someone, because there is no one to talk to," said Joan Spero, the Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs. "Have you ever tried to get a market into a hotel room?"
 But the harsh truth, as the Mexicans are learning, is that almost no amount of austerity will convince most investors to return. What fund manager will risk his job on the bet that Mexico is getting its act together -- especially when Indonesia is hot, India looks like a cheap Silicon Valley and Germany has become a safe haven of strong currency? As one fund manager said, "No one is going to get fired for staying out of Mexico."
 That is the price the country is paying for decisions made in the last days of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. He bet that he could keep the peso artificially high by hiding bad but complex news about the economy. He is now in self-imposed exile in the United States, sounding defensive.
 His biggest mistake was relying on hot money rather than following the example set by countries like China, Malaysia and Thailand -- who have urged foreign investors to invest in factories and other assets that cannot be swept out the country with a few strokes of the keyboard. A senior European finance official, however, blames not only the Mexicans but the industrialized nations that bailed the country out in the 1980's. "It is like being a doctor, and giving the patient a heart transplant, which is what we did a decade ago," he said. "You would expect that the doctor should be checking things out every year or so. But we were all so enthralled by the success of the operation that no one did a check-up."

 
 
Keeping Secrets
 Even when the doctors dropped by, Mexico set the rules: no X-rays, no blood tests. The Salinas Government carefully kept key statistics out of the public domain -- how much its foreign reserves had been depleted to prop up the peso, how dependent it had become on short-term money from abroad. The shell game deceived even the I.M.F.
 "The whole surveillance process did not work the way it should have," Karin Lissakers, the chief United States representative to the I.M.F., said last week. "We were too tolerant" of Mexico's reluctance to turn over vital numbers.
 Someone did see and understand many of the warning signs -- the United States Treasury. It has turned over hundreds of pages of documents to Congress, detailing warning after warning to the Salinas Government. Yet no one dared utter a word in public. In fact, President Clinton lauded Mexico's economic reforms at the Latin summit meeting in November.
 The case for silence is simple: Public warnings may trigger the rush for the exits that everyone is trying to prevent. But by keeping Mexico's secrets, the United States likely contributed to the ferocity of the ensuing panic.
 Mr. Rubin hopes that Mexico's extraordinary pain is sending a message. "I think there is no question that people who govern other countries, when they see what Mexico is having to do, are going to feel an enormous incentive to maintain sound policies," he said. Otherwise, he will be left to pick up the dominoes.

HEADLINE: African Democracies Worry Western Aid Will Evaporate

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: BAMAKO, Mali

 BODY:
For the three decades that constituted the infancy of African independence, Washington and its allies preached the virtues of democracy while supporting many of Africa's most corrupt one-party regimes, invoking the strategic considerations of the cold war.
Now, with the Soviet Union no longer the opponent that justified this policy, democratic systems have taken root for the first time in a score of countries. But as these sub-Saharan nations face grave crises of debt, population growth, poverty and religious militancy, leaders in Washington and in the capitals of Western Europe are increasingly telling African governments that they will have to rely on their own meager resources to solve the continent's problems. 
 According to a recent report by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, which monitors Western aid, the net flow of assistance to developing countries fell to $55.96 billion in 1993, down from $60.85 billion the year before. Aid to all of Africa accounts for about $20 billion a year.
American assistance to sub-Saharan Africa has followed a similar trend, falling to $1.2 billion in 1992, the latest year for which complete figures are available, from a high of $1.72 billion in 1985. Last year, in a round of budget cuts that hit Africa more than any other continent, the United States Agency for International Development closed 8 of its African missions, leaving 27.
President Clinton's national security adviser, Anthony Lake, widely seen as sympathetic to Africa's development needs, summed up the Administration's concerns in a speech in December at the headquarters of the Organization of African Unity in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.
"Those of us who recognize the importance of continued active engagement and support for Africa," he said, "are confronting the reality of shrinking resources and an honest skepticism about the return on our investments in peacekeeping and development. The world around Africa is fast coming together, and this continent risks becoming the odd man out."
Mr. Lake's comments followed the November elections, in which Republicans won control of Congress and began urging cuts in foreign aid, often singling out Africa.
As they struggle to carry out Western-prescribed economic reforms that focus on privatizing industry, trimming government payrolls and paying off the huge debts that benefited dictators' personal accounts, Africa's new generation of democratic leaders is warning that the growing indifference of the West imperils the continent's democratic spring.
A result, many say, will be the resurgence of military-led governments and a spread of misery and chaos throughout the continent.
"We are confronted with a series of grave inherited problems today, and if we do not receive the kind of help that we need, we will not make it," said Mali's President, Alpha Oumar Konare, an archeologist by training who was elected in 1992.
"This does not mean that we are stuck in a logic of eternal recipients, but the next two or three years will be critical for the future of democracy in Africa," he said. "So far there has been a lot of sympathy from the West, but there has been no real premium for democracies here."
Mali, a predominantly Muslim country of 9 million people who eke out an average per capita income of $280 a year and have a literacy rate of about 40 percent, is in many ways typical of the new democracies.
For decades development experts have spoken of Mali, with its long stretch of the Niger River winding through a fertile, flooded delta, as a potential breadbasket for a region that has long imported large quantities of grain. But if it is ever to fulfill this potential, development experts say, Mali will require new injections of foreign capital and much technical aid.
Diplomats also speak of this large landlocked country as a bulwark against the spread of Islamic militancy from its northern neighbor, Algeria. Already Mali faces a destabilizing conflict involving Tuareg tribesmen in the north, but any settlement has been thwarted by a lack of resources.
At the same time, Mali's debt burden, contracted under years of dictatorship, consumes so much of the country's revenues that there is little left for development needs.
Even though they have already sharply pared back their civil service, Malian officials say that giving priority to debt servicing, a requirement of staying in the good graces of Western financial institutions like the World Bank, has turned each month into a frantic juggling exercise to meet Government payrolls.
"Today our foreign debt is higher than our gross domestic product," said the Minister of Finance, Soumaila Cisse, who said 60 percent of fiscal receipts were used to service debt obligations.
"If we didn't have aid, we could not pay salaries. If we can't pay salaries, that means social disturbances, that means no scholarships for students, that means we give up on preparing for the future."
In the current climate in the West, few expect large new infusions of aid to countries like Mali. Many development experts say debt forgiveness, particularly for payments owed to the World Bank, the biggest lender to Africa, will go a long way toward helping some of Africa's poorest countries get back on their feet economically.
Officials with the World Bank say that they have long been in discussions with its leading contributors over debt relief, but that Western capitals have been unable to agree on a plan.
Already, many experts in the United States say inaction in the early part of this decade by the West may have squandered a crucial opportunity to help consolidate democracy in Africa.
"When you looked at Benin and Mali and Zambia and the experiences of several other places, it appeared at the beginning of the decade that what was happening in Africa would just overwhelm despotism," said Makau wa Mutua, director of the human rights project at Harvard Law School.
"The values so long preached by the West were being realized in fact, and many of us naively thought that the West would have shown patience in nurturing democratic movement, not just in Eastern Europe but in Africa too."
Instead, he and other critics say, after a burst of enthusiasm for the changes sweeping the continent, Washington and other Western capitals turned their interest elsewhere.
Experts like Mr. Mutua said the West's short-lived attention to Africa has had a doubly negative impact. On the one hand, dictators who might have been persuaded to make way for democratic systems interpreted the relative silence as acquiescence in their continued rule. The result, many say, has been a strengthening of autocratic leaders in Nigeria, Kenya, Zaire, Togo and Cameroon who have been able to hold out against the democratic trend.
On the other hand, the failure by the West to relieve economic misery in many newly democratic countries has discouraged Africans on democracy, and may ultimately fuel takeover attempts by new military or civilian dictators.
"In most of the countries where they have had elected democratic governments, the fundamental problem is that they are left with precisely the same economic and social problems they had before," said L. Gray Cowan, an expert in African affairs at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington.
"When people see that the new democratic systems are not capable of resolving their problems, the risk is that they will quickly grow disillusioned."

HEADLINE: U.S. Pressing Iraq to Release Two Americans

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
Relying mainly on foreign intermediaries to negotiate with Baghdad, American officials continued their efforts today to win the release of two Americans being held in Iraq.
Secretary of Defense William J. Perry, who is in the Middle East on a weeklong diplomatic mission, said the two men were working for the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, which has a contract to maintain Kuwaiti aircraft. 
 The Administration has asked the United Nations and Poland, which handles American interests in Iraq, to press President Saddam Hussein to release the Americans, who were seized Monday night just north of the Kuwait border. Washington has not had direct diplomatic relations since Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990.
Some American officials say they fear that gaining the men's release could prove difficult because relations are so strained, especially after Washington persuaded the United Nations this week to maintain economic sanctions against Iraq.
"We're still hoping for an expeditious resolution of this," said Sondra F. McCarty, a spokeswoman for the State Department.
Mr. Perry, who was on his way to Saudi Arabia, said the Americans had been taken to Baghdad. "The report we get is that they are in good condition," he said. "I mean, they are not in any danger."
[In Baghdad, in the first official Iraqi comment on the two Americans, Vice President Taha Yassin Ramadan acknowledged their capture and said, "Nothing much will happen to them," The Associated Press reported.]
Kathy Daliberti, of Jacksonville, Fla., told The Florida Times-Union on Friday that her husband, David Daliberti, 41, is one of the captives. In an interview today, she identified the other as Bill Barloon, of Iowa.
Talking about her husband, Mrs. Daliberti said, "It's just a terrible, terrible thing, and I am just about at my wit's end not knowing if he's all right and how they're treating him."
Mrs. Daliberti said her husband was employed by Kay Industries of Chicago, an airline maintenance company. American officials said Kay apparently is a subcontractor of McDonnell Douglas. The Administration has emphasized that the men are not Government employees and were not working on a Government contract.
Administration officials raised the question again today of how the men could have mistakenly entered Iraq, especially after Kuwait built a 16-foot-wide, 10-foot-deep trench last year along the 130-mile border.
American officials said the Americans had been driving a white Jeep similar to United Nations vehicles in the area, which apparently made it easier for them to pass through an Iraqi border checkpoint.
"As near as we can tell, it was a mistake, a blunder on their part," Secretary Perry said. "And the reason they got past the checkpoints was apparently they were mistaken for a U.N. vehicle. By the time they had realized their mistake they were in Iraq, and by that time the Iraqis realized they were not U.N. and arrested them."

HEADLINE: CATHOLIC BISHOPS CHALLENGE PIECES OF WELFARE BILL

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
As the House prepares for debate on welfare legislation next week, the leaders of the nation's Roman Catholic bishops today denounced parts of the Republican bill that could end cash assistance for many children born out of wedlock, unmarried teen-agers who have children and legal immigrants.
The bishops said they were speaking not as partisan political lobbyists but in an effort to illuminate "the moral dimensions and human consequences of this debate." 
 In the statement today, titled "Moral Principles and Policy Priorities for Welfare Reform," the bishops agreed that "the status quo is unacceptable" but said the Federal Government must not abandon its role in fighting poverty. They said the coming debate would be "a test of our nation's values and our commitment to the 'least among us.' "
The statement by the Administrative Board of the United States Catholic Conference, the top leadership of the nation's bishops, echoes the concerns of many Democrats who have criticized the bill on the ground that it would punish children for parents' behavior. That view is shared by diverse groups, including supporters and opponents of abortion rights, child welfare advocates and civil libertarians.
Despite such opposition, the bill is likely to be passed by the House. Its fate in the Senate, however, is far less certain, and the bishops' statement, which raises the concern that ending subsidies for children born to women on welfare would encourage abortions, could kindle opposition from conservative Republicans opposed to abortion rights.
The bill to be considered by the House would bar the use of Federal money to provide cash welfare benefits for a child born to a woman already receiving public assistance. Most states now provide extra money to indigent families for each additional child, and some Republicans say that encourages women to have more babies -- a contention disputed by the Children's Defense Fund and by some economists. The House bill would also deny cash assistance to children born out of wedlock to women younger than 18, and to the women as well.
The Roman Catholic Church, Catholic Charities USA, the National Right to Life Committee and opponents of abortion like Representative Christopher H. Smith of New Jersey say the proposed restrictions on welfare benefits would increase pressures on poor women to have abortions. They say that pressure would be particularly strong in states that pay for Medicaid abortions but not for the costs of rearing an additional child.
The bishops' criticism of the House bill, while not a surprise, is important because it is likely to influence debate in Congress. The Republicans have a majority in the House and can probably count on party discipline to pass the bill next week after an impassioned debate, but they may have to modify some important provisions.
In a signal to Republicans, the House majority leader, Dick Armey, and the majority whip, Tom DeLay, both from Texas, have indicated that they may support amendments to allow somewhat more generous treatment of children born to young unwed mothers and of children born to women already on welfare. The bishops' views could also sway the Senate, where members of both parties are still searching for the best way to deal with the problems of unwed teen-age mothers.
The Catholic hierarchy has been speaking out on issues of poverty and social equity for more than a century. It speaks with authority on both welfare and immigration policy. It resettles thousands of refugees and immigrants every year. Its churches and charitable agencies run hundreds of soup kitchens, food banks, orphanages and shelters for homeless people.
The bishops said they felt a special obligation to speak out now, as Congress begins debate on the bill known as the Personal Responsibility Act, which would reverse a 60-year trend toward increased Federal control of social welfare policy. The measure is projected to squeeze more than $50 billion from Federal welfare spending in the next five years.
"There's no question that some of what we're saying is running against the tide," said Bishop Howard J. Hubbard of Albany. "Unfortunately, those who will be most affected are not well organized and can't speak for themselves. If we don't make the point, I don't know who else will."
In his weekly radio address today, President Clinton focused on the importance of child support. "If deadbeat parents paid all the child support they should in this country, we could immediately move over 800,000 mothers and children off welfare," he said.
Mr. Clinton said Congress ought to require states to suspend the driver's licenses and professional licenses of parents who refuse to pay child support, and he criticized Republicans for not including such penalties in their bill.
Curiously, the more stringent aspects of the House bill have brought disparate political factions together in opposition. For instance, Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said the measure was unacceptably harsh on children. And in a recent interview, Mr. Smith, a Republican who was director of the Right to Life Committee in New Jersey from 1976 to 1978, said: "I don't think you should use the child as a pawn in trying to influence the mother's behavior. These proposals are inhumane, and unless they are fixed, I will vote no on the overall bill."
Assessing likely effects of the bill, the Department of Health and Human Services said today that cash benefits would be denied to 2.2 million children born to women already receiving welfare. About 70,000 children born out of wedlock would lose benefits, it said. A separate provision, which sets a five-year limit on cash benefits for any family, would eventually deny aid to more than four million children, it said.
But Republicans said those estimates were flawed because they took no account of changes in behavior likely to occur as the Government encourages work and marriage and reduces its subsidy for out-of-wedlock births.
The measure would give states vast new authority to design their own food assistance and cash welfare programs using Federal money. The main cash assistance program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children, created in 1935, and the national school lunch program, created in 1946, with all their Federal rules and guarantees, would be scrapped.
So far Republicans have deflected Democratic criticism with the argument that the current welfare system is a complete failure because it traps people in poverty.
But Sharon M. Daly, deputy director of Catholic Charities USA, said, "Members of Congress are stunned to see pro-life and pro-choice groups arguing against the same provisions of the House welfare bill for different reasons."
The abortion opponents have championed "the rights of unborn children." Abortion rights groups have emphasized reproductive freedom for women. Both have expressed concern for children.
In today's statement the bishops said, "Denying needed benefits for children born to mothers on welfare can hurt the children and pressure their mothers toward abortion and sterilization."
Commenting on the same proposal, Ann F. Lewis, vice president of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, said, "We oppose any attempts by government to coerce reproductive decisions."
The Catholic Church, the Council of Jewish Federations and Hispanic groups like the National Council of La Raza also oppose provisions of the House bill that would make many legal immigrants ineligible for welfare benefits, food stamps and Medicaid. The bishops said, "We cannot support punitive approaches that target immigrants, even legal residents, and take away the minimal benefits that they now receive."
The Catholic Church also expressed grave concern about an important feature of the House Republican bill that would end the guarantee of cash assistance for poor women and children who meet eligibility criteria set by law. The church said it could not support welfare legislation that ends such entitlements, especially if the Federal Government lets states reduce their commitment at the same time.
The church is supporting two amendments that would relax the bill's prohibition on aid to children born to unmarried teen-agers and to current welfare recipients.
One, proposed by Mr. Smith, would allow states to provide assistance in the form of vouchers for goods and services needed by a child born to a woman already on welfare. The vouchers could be used for items like diapers, clothing and school supplies.
The other amendment, by Representative Jim Bunn, Republican of Oregon, would allow states to provide vouchers for children born out of wedlock to women younger than 18.
John Cardinal O'Connor, the Archbishop of New York, recently sent a letter to Congress endorsing both amendments. The National Right to Life Committee said lawmakers should vote against the bill unless it includes those "corrective amendments."

HEADLINE: Javits Center's Chronic Problems Go Beyond the Mob, Experts Say

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
For unions, the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center has been an employment bonanza because of its notorious but legal work rules: nine workers for jobs that require three or fewer elsewhere. For campaign contributors, it has been a source of lucrative contracts for work that is frequently badly done. For friends of politicians with little experience in the convention industry, it has meant management posts.
The Mafia has recently been getting the most attention for troubles at the Javits Center, but experts who have studied it, as well as those who have worked or participated in shows there, say the mob does not deserve all the blame. Many law-abiding citizens have been making money there as well. The experts and workers say it will take much more than a crackdown on organized crime to eliminate New York's reputation as the least hospitable convention city in America. 
 To some extent, the Javits Center's problems are endemic to convention centers across the country. Subsidized by tax dollars and often financed by bonds of quasi-public agencies operating without voter approval, convention centers have become a favorite project for politicians promising to generate jobs and urban renewal, in many cases a dubious promise, economists and investment analysts say.
The jobs the centers unquestionably generate are for the architects, bond underwriters, board members, consultants, vendors, union laborers and others who work for it. Those groups are especially well entrenched in New York, because of the city's long tradition of large-scale public works.
"We have a phenomenally greedy nomenklatura feeding at the trough, everyone from white-shoe lawyers to Joe the Mobster," said William J. Stern, who oversaw the center's construction when he was chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation from 1983 to 1985. "At other cities' convention centers, the Zeitgeist is: Let's be reasonable so that everyone comes out ahead. In New York, the Zeitgeist is: My guy gets the contract for the paper towels in the men's room."
Mr. Stern said that he was frequently pressured by state officials and legislators to overlook the shoddy work and high bills of politically connected consultants and contractors during the construction of the Javits Center. Complicated by a bid-rigging scandal and structural problems at the center, the project fell two years behind schedule and was $111 million over budget.
The new center, opened in 1986, was supposed to reduce the labor problems that had plagued the exhibitors at the New York Coliseum, but from the start there were complaints about featherbedding and work rules. Although some excesses were eventually curbed -- exhibitors can now plug in a lamp without paying an electrician $80 -- the center is still renowned for its high costs.
"Everything is more difficult in New York," said Jay Atherton, the general manager of the Freeman Decorating Company, which hires labor for trade shows around the country. The firm's labor costs at the Javits Center, he said, are at least 40 percent higher than in any other city.
"In Boston or Washington," Mr. Atherton said, "you can hire one worker to put up the pipe structure and the drapes around a booth; at Javits, you have to hire three workers from different unions. In Chicago you can unload a truck with two Teamsters and one forklift operator; in New York it takes three Teamsters and six other workers using dollies.
"Because of the minimums for standby labor in the contract at Javits, we're required to have 40 guys standing around when we need only six or seven."
These legal work rules have been a much bigger problem than extortion by mobsters, say contractors, show managers and exhibitors. "There have been no checks and balances here on the unions," said one show manager, who spoke on condition of anonymity because, he said, any criticism might trigger a labor slowdown at his next show. "Chicago is no labor paradise, but at least the politicians and unions there realize they have to stay competitive. In New York the unions did what they wanted, and until this year we couldn't get anyone at City Hall or Albany to stand up for us."
Although the Javits Center has been losing business to cities with lower costs, the shows remaining in New York are still profitable for the organizers -- a point that union officials make in their defense. They blame New York's high costs on contractors and show managers who mark up the prices they charge exhibitors for services.
"Working men are again the scapegoat of rich contractors who blame everything on the lowest man on the totem pole," Frederick W. Devine, president of the local district council of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America, said at a State Senate hearing on Thursday.
At the hearing, politicians and law enforcement officials vowed to crack down on Mafia infiltration of the labor force at the Javits Center. Gov. George E. Pataki repeated his demand that the 13 members of the center's board resign. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani suggested that work rules be renegotiated and that a private firm replace the political appointees currently managing the center.
From 1991 until January, the chief executive at the Javits Center was Fabian Palomino, a lawyer who was appointed by his close friend Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. His lack of experience in the convention industry has often been cited by critics of the Javits Center, although the former Governor has defended Mr. Palomino, calling him "one of the best minds and best people in state service."
"The management at Javits has lacked any fundamental understanding of what the building is supposed to do," said Steven Hacker, the president of the International Association for Exposition Management. "It needs a new management team that not only understands the basics of the industry but has the competence to make real reforms."
Privatization is a growing trend at civic convention centers, said John H. Nicholson, a consultant in Boston who surveys the industry. About 15 percent of such centers are now privately managed, he said, and the results have attracted the attention of the many cities struggling with mounting operating deficits at convention centers.
"Some public facilities are run very well," Mr. Nicholson said, "and some private management companies have had problems. But in general, the private companies have proven to be more efficient. If current trends continue, nearly half of the convention centers could be privately run by the end of the century."
The most experienced private company is Spectacor Management Group, which runs 21 convention centers, including ones in San Francisco, Miami Beach, Denver and Salt Lake City. But Sims Hinds, a senior vice president of the company, said it would take more than just privatization to solve the problems at the Javits Center.
"A private company needs support to negotiate new work rules," he said. "We've been able to improve the bottom line and the work environment at every facility we've gone into because we have the experience to tell unions: This is what your brethren are doing in other cities, and this is the business they get as a result. But we couldn't have done it without the backing of the local political entity."
Nicholas Langella, a veteran of the Javits Center who now works for Spectacor as the general manager of the Rhode Island Convention Center, said that he has found a markedly different attitude at the center in Providence.
"This is a strong labor town," said Mr. Langella, who was the building services manager at Javits until 1992, "but we've been able to have cooperation from the unions because we all know that we have to be competitive. Our costs are one-third to one-fifth of New York's. There's no automatic overtime and double-time like there is at Javits. You only have to deal with one union, not three different ones, and you can set up your exhibit by yourself if you want. It's a user-friendly environment."
Revenues at the Javits Center have barely covered operating expenses in recent years, although convention center promoters argue that the facilities actually pay for themselves through the extra taxes they generate from visitors.
But academic critics disagree. Edwin S. Mills, an economist at Northwestern University, did a study for the Heartland Institute in Chicago that concluded: "There is no economic reason for governments to own convention centers." Another such critic, Heywood Sanders, a professor of urban administration at Trinity University in San Antonio, argues that politics, not economics, is what drives Javits and all other civic convention centers. "They're the best examples of corporate socialism on the earth," said Dr. Sanders. These projects "may not make economic sense, but they don't have to. They're built to reward the people with political clout."
