HEADLINE: Cuba's Financial Crisis Erodes Sports Programs

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: MAR DEL PLATA, Argentina, March 18

 BODY:
As the Cuban weight lifter Rafael Gomez stood on a podium to hear his country's national anthem, the three gold medals around his neck clinked like champagne glasses raised in a toast.
Halfway through the 16-day Pan American Games, a hemispheric version of the Olympics, Cuba is exerting its usual dominance in sports like baseball and weight lifting. It trails only the United States in the hunt for gold medals. But a far more dramatic story is unfolding: the unprecedented admission by Cuban officials and athletes of the severity of the problems caused in sports by the island nation's worsening economic crisis and its political isolation. 
 Since the 1991 Pan American Games in Havana, where Cuban athletes won 140 gold medals to 130 by the United States, at least 70 Cubans with international experience have defected, mainly to the United States and Puerto Rico. Athletes and coaches who did not defect speak loyally of remaining faithful to the Cuban revolution, but they also admit to growing difficulties in obtaining proper nutrition, equipment and medicine because of the American trade embargo.
"Sometimes the food is good, sometimes it is bad," said Mr. Gomez, the weight lifter who won three gold medals last Monday in the 154-pound weight class.
Said his coach, Manuel Gui-Sing: "We don't have the necessary money for big sports. We don't have the competitions we need."
The most urgent problem, Cuban officials have told others, is that Cuban athletes are no longer afforded cost-free training, lodging, food and transportation in the dismantled Eastern bloc. Financial strains have forced Cuban teams to reduce their participation in international competitions; teams also are traveling with fewer athletes than in the past.
Cuban wrestlers have declined an invitation to a meet in Chattanooga, Tenn., next month. Only athletes expected to win medals have traveled from Cuba for the Pan American Games, reducing the 1995 roster to 490 athletes, compared with 633 in Havana four years ago. While many elite athletes have remained at the top, developmental programs have begun to erode.
Just as President Fidel Castro of Cuba put on a suit this week and went to Paris seeking foreign investment, Cuban sports officials have come forward with a new frankness: They are having problems, they need money and sponsorships and they are ready to do business with the rest of the world by renting out coaches and players to other nations.
"We will not say no to help," said Esteban Brice Nichols, director of an athletic training center in Havana.
Cuban officials, coaches and athletes are nearly as accessible as the Americans. Alcides Sagarra, the renowned boxing coach, even admitted on Wednesday that two of his boxers had failed drug tests in Cuba before the Pan Am Games and had been replaced. Such candor from the Cubans is novel.
This new openness appears to have extended to relaxed security around the Cuban athletes. They have been spotted shopping by themselves, and they have spoken freely with American journalists without having their conversations monitored. Rumors of potential defections surfaced this week but have not been confirmed. The Argentine press reported that Cuban expatriates were attempting to contact athletes here in an attempt to induce them to defect. Still, Cuban officials seem to have adopted the attitude that since they cannot stop those who want to defect, it is largely futile to try.
"It's not really a concern," said Reinaldo Gonzalez Lopez, Minister of Sport in Cuba. "Athletes are free if they want to defect."
Ledys Balceiro Pajon, a gold medalist in canoeing at these Pan Am Games, said those Cuban athletes who have defected are "deserters." Good riddance, he said.
"I'm very happy about it," Mr. Balceiro said. "There will be fewer Cubans angry with the government inside Cuba."
Families, along with teams, have been torn apart by defections. Emilio Lara, an Olympic weight lifter, sought political asylum in Puerto Rico in 1993, leaving behind his brother Pablo Lara, a silver medalist in the 165-pound weight-lifting category at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics. Pablo Lara, who won three gold medals and set two world records at these Pan Am Games, said he remained in contact with his brother.
"We have our differences, but he is still my brother," Mr. Lara said.
Approximately 30,000 athletes remain in Cuba, 2,000 at the elite level, said Mr. Gonzalez, the sports minister. The country, whose President also happens to be its No. 1 sports fan, spends about $100 million a year on sports, Mr. Gonzalez said. That figure is approximately equal to the annual budget of the United States Olympic Committee, but it is artificial, pegged as it is to a one-to-one exchange rate between the Cuban peso and the American dollar. The black market rate has been as high as 100 pesos to the dollar but has dropped sharply in recent months.
"Sports is part of the culture and the national dignity," Mr. Gonzalez said. "It is not only a political experience but also one of patriotism in difficult times."
In striving for economic self-sufficiency in sports, Cuba has employed some decidedly capitalistic measures, such as charging a small amount of money to fans who attend sporting events. And if other countries need coaches to upgrade their Olympic-style baseball or volleyball teams, the Cubans are willing to rent them out in exchange for hard currency.
Some 500 Cuban coaches are now offering their expertise in various sports in 38 countries, Cuban officials said. Osvaldo Garcia, the former Cuban national water polo coach who defected to Miami, said in a telephone interview that coaches who work abroad keep 30 percent of their salary, give 70 percent to the Cuban Government and must travel without their families to assure that they will return.
Athletes are also being exported to other countries, where they compete and send home a large percentage of their earnings. Javier Sotomayor, the Olympic high jump champion, and six other track and field athletes compete for a professional club in Madrid. Five Cuban baseball players, joined by Cuban coaches, competed on Japanese amateur teams last season; another 15 players will play amateur baseball in Japan this season, Cuban officials said.
There has been talk of having Cuban boxers compete as professionals, but Felix Savon, the 1992 Olympic heavyweight champion, said Wednesday, "I don't want to be a professional; I want to still be a Cuban, a revolutionary one."
In many ways, it is remarkable that a poor nation with only 11 million people has developed into a world sports power. Successful Cuban athletes, as was the case in the Eastern bloc, can expect to be taken care of by the state. William Vargas Trujillo, a gold medalist in weight lifting, said that he had been provided with a house and that he had used money from his winnings to buy a car.
"Certain people think life is better in the United States than Cuba," Mr. Vargas said. "I don't think so. I feel very good in Cuba."
Some sports have shown less vulnerability to defections and Cuba's economic crisis than others. The baseball team is 71-1 since 1987 and has weathered such defections as Rene Arocha, a pitcher for the St. Louis Cardinals. "When Rene left, there were five others ready to take his place," said Miguel Valdez, the Cuban baseball coach.
Despite losing at least seven boxers in the past year -- the superheavyweight Roberto Balado died in an automobile accident, the lightweight Dios Belys Hurtado defected, four others were suspended because of drug use and another for an unnamed disciplinary problem -- Cuba remains a threat to win all 12 gold medals at the Pan Am Games.
Other sports have suffered staggering punches from the defections of its stop stars. In water polo, the entire coaching staff, a physician and a trainer and four of Cuba's seven starters have left in the past two years. Ricardo Matienzo, Cuba's top basketball player, defected during the 1993 world championships in Toronto. Because it was unlikely to win a medal, the Cuban men's team is not even taking part in basketball at the Pan Am Games. Odalys Hernandez, Cuba's top women's softball pitcher, defected in Puerto Rico in the fall of 1993. American coaches said they have noticed a lack of depth among the Cubans in such sports as weight lifting and women's gymnastics.
"It's pretty evident to me that Cuba is having some financial difficulties in training," said Steve Nunno, coach of the United States women gymnasts at the Pan Am Games. "The sport is moving ahead, and they are standing still."
That is precisely why the Cubans have come to the Pan American Games with open discussions and an open-for-business attitude. The Cuban sports machine is running low on fuel. It desperately needs gas, even if officials refuse to admit that a complete overhaul is necessary.
"We are a little country with many problems with the blockade of the United States," said Mr. Gui-Sing, the weight lifting coach. "But we have found that our system is best for the Cubans, for a little country, a poor country. Maybe for the United States, your system is best. The most important thing is for the United States Government to understand that we are Cubans."

HEADLINE: Novel Cafe: A Deadbeat Poets Society

BYLINE: By KIT R. ROANE 

DATELINE: SANTA MONICA, Calif.

 BODY:
In the four-and-a-half years that Diana Birchall and her kin have warmed seats at The Novel Cafe, she has produced five novels, none published. Her son, Paul, has written one play, to no avail. And her husband, Peter, has scribbled several volumes of poetry, without any intention of showing them to anyone.
Upstairs, David Carver is on his 23d year writing a memoir about being a homeless Vietnam veteran. And across from the fiction section, a place where books find their own uneasy order, Doug -- nicknamed "Dogfood" Doug because of an earlier failed script, not the cafe's food -- worries over his latest attempt at screenwriting, "Banana Rose." The title recently appeared in hardcover, written by someone else. 
 "You could skip a rock off the heads of at least 20 screenwriters any time of day in this place," said Bill F. Kelman, the author of several B-movie scripts, paraphrasing a line from "Barton Fink." "This place is kind of a microcosm of Los Angeles; anybody who buys a ream of paper calls himself a writer."
These are the heirs to Ernest Hemingway, Henry Miller and Anais Nin, a set of scribblers and laptop-toting typists who dream of big breaks rising from small ruminations and have so far failed. Some are unemployed, many are in debt, and a few live in their cars. There is not a Hollywood Player among them.
"We thought about plastering the first page of everybody's work on the front wall when it was published," said Richard Karno, the cafe's owner. "But there was the obvious problem -- it might be a pretty blank wall."
From 7 A.M. to 1 A.M., this cafe just off Santa Monica's Main Street is a hostel to Los Angeles's disenfranchised intelligentsia, a mix of aging Hollywood hopefuls, Generation X beatniks and local students, all crowded into an eclectic selection of odd seats on a worn parquet floor.
Outside, smokers line the sidewalk, puffing on hand-rolled cigarettes or stroking their Vandykes, or both. Others rush upstairs to the balcony overlooking the espresso machine where tattooed youths dispense bitter coffee and wry wit to the wails of Patsy Cline.
The Novel crowd still prefers caffeine to decaf, and in a town not known for its literature, likes to read -- a distraction well-provided for at The Novel, where books on everything from canoeing to crystal healing line hundreds of wooden shelves.
All are for sale, as are the works of interminably undiscovered artists. The paintings, stillborn like many of the manuscripts written below them, hang in every open space, collecting little more than dust and cobwebs.
"There are a lot of dysfunctional characters engaged in a lot of fantasy here," said Jerry Prager, a friend of many, as he nursed a cup of coffee at his window seat near the front of the cafe. "This is Santa Monica hip, bohemian cool," added Mr. Prager, an actor and telemarketer. "It's a lot of people in their 40's who like to hit on young women and have been working on the same script for years."
Diana and Paul Birchall may have achieved the closest thing to fame among the cafe regulars; they not only have agents, but real jobs. Both are employed as script readers in the entertainment industry, an occupation with only one hazard -- they are frequently harassed by fellow Novel customers.
"We get approached at least once a week by some screenwriter asking us to look at his stuff," Mrs. Birchall confided from her usual perch in an overstuffed armchair at the center of the cafe. "As a rule they are the weirder ones, about space aliens or lonely writers who hang out in coffee shops.
"And," she whispered, grabbing a chunk of brownie, then washing it down with a 16-ounce iced cappuccino, "they are all awful."
Mr. Karno opened The Novel in the summer of 1990. The characters began to show up shortly thereafter, and few have ever strayed to trendier establishments like Starbucks Coffee a mere six blocks away, where, they complain, the stools are uncomfortable, the cappuccino expensive.
At The Novel the first refill is free, and regulars like Mr. Carver are allowed behind the counter to fetch as much as they want. On Sunday, when the meter maids stay home, the few writers who live in their cars sometimes pull up and use The Novel's restroom to bathe.
Few customers have been banished from the cafe, and some have nowhere else to go anyway. When they are tossed out, it is usually because they have been caught stuffing costly volumes into their backpacks without paying for them, or because they have skipped out on weighty tabs that Mr. Karno was kind enough to let them run up during lean times.
Sometimes Mr. Karno longs for the well-heeled clients that frequent Il Fornaio, a cafe just a block away, where -- like the few stars who visit The Novel -- people buy coffee, tip well, then leave. But Mr. Karno's lot appears to have been decided soon after his cafe opened, when the first customer discovered his lax loitering policy and the abundance of electrical outlets scattered throughout the building. Since then, laptops have sprouted like mushrooms on his many tables, and customers have rooted like trees.
"I got more Powerbooks in here than in a school cafeteria," he complained while calculating their drain on his electric bill. "But the last thing I want to do is run around collecting a buck-fifty for electricity every hour from a bunch of starving writers. Besides, they would just switch to pens and pads and still sit there all day anyway."

HEADLINE: 2-Year-Old Slovakia Toddling Toward Democracy

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia

 BODY:
Slovakia, which recently celebrated its second anniversary of independence, is stumbling toward democracy and an open economy as Europe's youngest nation.
It has had three Governments, two of which have been led by the current Prime Minister, Vladimir Meciar, who in his determination not to lose power again has shown an authoritarian bent that alarms the opposition, foreign governments and potential investors. 
 Yet basic political freedoms are still respected, and as people come to terms with the double shock of abandoning first Communism and then the 74-year union with the Czech Republic, Slovakia's political culture is slowly maturing in ways that many politicians and diplomats say will assure the country of a bright future, if Mr. Meciar can curb his anti-democratic impulses.
"It's only been two years since the country was founded, and people here are still trying to figure out who they are," said Rick Zednick, a Slovak-American who recently helped start Bratislava's first English-language newspaper. "They are looking into themselves and at their history and asking themselves what it really means to be Slovak."
With low labor costs, a skilled work force among 5.4 million people, a location at the heart of Europe and an emerging generation of young entrepreneurs, Slovakia should be poised for an economic takeoff. Continuing political uncertainty, however, has hurt the country's image and scared off some investors.
Early this month, 10 newspapers across the country published nearly blank front pages to protest threats from members of Mr. Meciar's party to impose sharply increased taxes that could force them out of business. The front pages carried a statement asserting that the proposed increases "threaten the work of the press in Slovakia and the right of Slovak citizens to choose their sources of information."
Faced with criticism at home and abroad, leaders of Mr. Meciar's party disavowed the proposal, and it was killed by a parliamentary committee. Yet many fear that he will strike again.
"Meciar's method is to hit us and see if he can get away with it," said Oliver Brunovsky, an editor of the business newspaper Trend. "This time it didn't work, but he'll keep trying."
Earlier this year, after reassuming power in December 1994 in a coalition Government, Mr. Meciar arranged to remove the directors of the state radio and television networks and the Government news agency, replacing them with political allies.
Coverage of opposition activities has been curbed, and three satirical programs were taken off the air. Several thousand people showed up this month for a rally in Bratislava to protest the changes.
But despite the heavy-handedness by Mr. Meciar, who was Slovakia's Prime Minister before independence, few citizens fear that their new democracy is under imminent threat. In an indication of the country's direction, for instance, Slovakia has signed agreements with the European Union and the International Monetary Fund that require it to observe basic levels of political and economic freedom.
"What's going on here is nothing like what's going on in some other parts of Central and Eastern Europe," a foreign diplomat said. "Meciar is a very skillful populist politician and a bit of an opportunist, but the 'former Communist' stuff is vastly overplayed. It fits in Poland, maybe in Hungary and certainly in the Balkans, but here there's a very different dynamic."
Some Slovak intellectuals are more worried about the country's future, however.
"Everything we did in the 1980's was aimed at destroying the system, chipping away at the cement that held it together," said Martin Simecka, a novelist and former dissident.
"Now Meciar is doing exactly what we did, chipping away at the established order," he said. "All he thinks about is how to bring down the democratic system. My instinct is that things will get worse here. I'm afraid that in a year, we will be closer to a real dictatorship."
Mr. Meciar's support comes principally from rural, less-educated and older voters, many of whom look back fondly on the security of life under Communism. Even his critics acknowledge that he is Slovakia's best politician and that the opposition has no one to challenge him.
Among Mr. Meciar's favorite targets is President Michal Kovac, who helped engineer the Prime Minister's fall from power a year ago. Mr. Meciar, 52, is waging a guerrilla war against Mr. Kovac, pushing through a series of parliamentary measures aimed at reducing his powers.
In an interview, the soft-spoken President said he disapproved of Mr. Meciar's attacks on the press, but asserted that the country's democracy was not in danger.
"I'm not happy about the situation," Mr. Kovac said. "It's hard when the President thinks certain steps could improve the country's credibility but does not have the legal power to take those steps."
As Slovakia's approached independence in late 1992, many people assumed that its most prominent citizen, Alexander Dubcek, would be elected the first president.
But Mr. Dubcek, who won international acclaim for trying to lead Czechoslovakia out of the Soviet orbit in 1968, died of injuries from a car crash in 1992. His death deprived Slovakia of the one figure who might have won it the respect that has been accorded to the Czech Republic.
"The problem is that from the beginning, people looked at the split in a very simplified way," said Eduard Kukan, a former Foreign Minister.
"The Czechs were good, the Slovaks were bad. We were looked at as spoilers who ruined the unity of the country. The fact is that both sides realized the split was inevitable, but the Czechs prepared for it quietly. Slovaks are more emotional. We shouted.
"We are seen as less sophisticated, less developed, and less educated, some of which may be true," he continued. "Then of course, the Czechs had Vaclav Havel, who is greatly admired in the West. We had Meciar, who is not a very lovable guy."
The last Slovak Government, which held power for nine months in 1994, won widespread praise not only for its commitment to democracy but also for its determination to privatize formerly state-owned enterprises. Mr. Meciar has slowed the pace of privatization, and critics suspect that he is seeking to shape the process so it will benefit his supporters. Already, they say, Government officials often ask for "commissions" in exchange for contracts.
"Nobody believes that Meciar himself is getting money," Mr. Kukan said, "but he is arranging things so that his supporters get the biggest slices of the pie."
Mr. Meciar rarely receives foreign journalists, but an official of the Economics Ministry, Jozef Sucha, said the Government remains committed to completing Slovakia's transition to a market economy.
"I myself am not pleased with the state of affairs, but I can assure you that the process of privatization will proceed," Mr. Sucha said. "All parties favor it. I realize that the delays look bad from the outside, but we are determined to wipe away the old system. The discussion is not about whether, but how."
Several large foreign companies, among them Volkswagen and Samsung, have opened plants in Slovakia and say they are pleased with the results. Others, however, are waiting for the political situation to stabilize.
"Persuading foreign investors to come to Slovakia is a difficult job," said Peter Mihok, president of the Slovak Chamber of Commerce. "There have been so many changes here in the last few years, and the political situation is still fluid."
Lubo Roman, a prominent theater director and member of Parliament, is one of many opposition figures who believe that Mr. Meciar's mercurial personality is hindering the consolidation of democracy here.
"He is a politician who thrives on keeping everything in tension, but he is not a man with a vision of how Slovakia should develop and what it should be about," he said. "We are waiting for a person with new ideas to give the country direction. Everyone here who is culturally minded is waiting for such a person."

HEADLINE: Republicans' Vow of Budget Cuts Carries Risks Down on the Farm

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: CLEARWATER, Kan., March 17

 BODY:
Clutching a briefcase stuffed with business papers, Dwayne Schmeissner, a bottom-line conservative who cheered the Republican takeover of Congress last fall, spoke insistently about the need to slash Government spending.
He pointed to some fat targets: welfare, foreign aid, academic research. But when asked about cuts in agricultural subsidies, the 35-year-old wheat farmer sighed apprehensively, pulling on his thick red beard, and said, "Well now, that's a scary proposition." 
 The business papers inside Mr. Schmeissner's briefcase were applications for crop grants from the Federal Government. Last year, he received about $20,000 in such subsidies. In all, the Government paid farmers about $10 billion in grants in 1994.
For Republicans vowing to cut Federal spending, farm subsidies mark a treacherous crossroads between conservative philosophy and political self-interest. Nearly half of the new Republicans in Congress represent farming districts.
As is true in much of the nation, the typical voter here is all for cuts in Government spending -- until they hit home. And in the farm belt, cuts in agricultural subsidies would slice right through the backyard.
"Oh, I'm sure they can cut something else," said Rachel Barnes, 33, moments after stopping at a Government office to deliver her crop payment application, a subsidy she cheerfully labeled, "farmer welfare checks."
Here in this wheat-rich farming country, voters ousted Dan Glickman, an eight-term Democrat and a strong supporter of farm subsidies, in favor of Todd Tiahrt, a conservative Republican who embraced the party's campaign manifesto, the Contract With America, which promises deep cuts in spending.
Ronnie Gaithen, a 27-year-old farmer, applauded the Republican Party's goals. The Government, he said, cannot play Santa Claus. But he said politicians should steer clear of touching farm subsidies for one very good reason: "We need it. If we could get an honest price without it, fine. But we can't. It's that simple."
Mr. Schmeissner said farmers had already suffered subsidy cuts. The Government's target prices, which farmers are paid even though market prices might be lower, have been frozen since the 1980's, even though costs had risen. In fact, Government grants to farmers have dropped from a peak of $25 billion in 1986. And farmers are now allowed to receive subsidies only on 85 percent of their cropland.
A lot of farms "would die" without subsidies, Mr. Schmeissner said, adding: "Is that what we want? I don't think so."
Even so, some farmers believe the subsidies should stop. Arlis Day, 63, in pin-striped overalls with a ball point pen in the bib, said he did not see how farmers could be fairly exempted from Government cuts in spending.
"It might be cutting our throats, but we farmers have got to do our part to get this budget under control," Mr. Day said as he sat on the tailgate of a pickup on his farm and watched a grain auger empty wheat into a truck. "These young kids coming up aren't going to have any Social Security by the time they retire. Everybody's going to have to take their hits. And I'm afraid that means farmers, too."
The most lucrative time on his farm, he joked, was the hailstorm of 1992. Between disaster payments and crop subsidies, he said, "It seemed like every time you went to the mailbox, there was a check from the Government inside."
But even in his own house, Mr. Day said, he encounters opposition to the idea of cutting subsidies.
"My wife says, 'Well, if they're going to give it, you might as well take it,' " he said.
Mr. Day said he told her, "If somebody's getting it, somebody's losing it."
Farmers in nearby Sumner County, the world's top producer of wheat, received about $6 million in farm subsidies last year. Together with Social Security and welfare payments, the Government is responsible for perhaps three-fourths of the county's income.
And it is not just the farmers who would hate to see the checks stop.
"This area depends on the farmers," said Elsie Wier, 55, who runs The Hardware Store in Wellington with her husband, Bob, 55. "They're our livelihood. If the payments stopped, we'd be devastated."
The farm subsidies were established in the 1930's as part of the New Deal, a way to protect farmers from volatile markets and protect consumers from the wild price swings and food shortages that could result from a purely market-oriented farm economy. The subsidies help keep the cost of food low. Americans spend an average of 12 percent of their budget on food, among the lowest in the world.
Even with price supports, farming remains a perilous venture. Elderly people here can remember the Dust Bowl days, when crops shriveled and blew away, many farmers went broke and some children, gasping for breath in the storm of dirt, died of suffocation.
Thousands of farmers still go broke every year around the nation. Nearly half of all Americans worked on farms at the turn of the century. Today, there are only about 600,000 full-time farmers. And a big share of them could not survive without working a second job, or the income of a spouse working in town.
In exchange for the subsidies, farmers must agree to limit production, which allows the Government to discourage glutted markets. Some farm payments are tied to soil conservation practices and other stewardship of the land.
Subsidies paid to American farmers pale in comparison with those paid in some European countries, like France. Without the subsidies, American farmers say they could not fairly compete on the global market.
"Look," said Mr. Schmeissner, who farms 2,800 acres, "if there was a level playing field, then fine, do away with it. But the field is not level."
But Mr. Schmeissner said he did not want to sound like a complainer. "After all," he said, "nobody is holding a gun to your head and forcing you to farm."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Most farmers in the wheat-rich country of Kansas do not put crop subsidies in the same category as welfare when it comes to Government spending cuts, which they say are needed to control the budget. One with a different view, Arlis Day, 63, above, who farms near Wellington, Kan., said, "It might be cutting our throats, but we farmers have got to do our part to get this budget under control." (Steve Rasmussen for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Question Now: How Much War in Bosnia?

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
Having reduced the risk of war in Croatia by persuading it not to expel United Nations peacekeepers, President Clinton's foreign policy team is now seeking to prevent stepped-up fighting in Bosnia, but many officials predict a major outbreak of hostilities with the arrival of spring weather.
With a four-month cease-fire due to expire at the end of next month, Mr. Clinton's foreign policy advisers acknowledge that there is almost no chance of getting Bosnia's Muslim-dominated Government and the country's rebel Serbs to agree to a peace plan by then. 
 "The clouds of war are darkening," said Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke, who is the Administration's point man on Bosnia. "The four-month period, the cease-fire, is running out. The incidents are increasing."
After receiving some arms from abroad this winter despite an international embargo, the Government appears eager to attack Serbian lines to regain some of the 70 percent of Bosnia's territory held by the Serbs.
For their part, the Bosnian Serbs, helped by Croatian Serb soldiers, have mounted an offensive against the Muslim pocket of Bihac in northwestern Bosnia, an area where the cease-fire never took hold. Making matters worse, sniper fire in the country's capital, Sarajevo, has intensified in recent weeks.
"Things are bad and getting worse," said a longtime American negotiator on Balkan issues, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. "Right now, the Clinton Administration's Bosnia policy is twisting in the wind. They have a tough problem, and they don't know how to handle it."
All but abandoning hope that the warring factions would resolve their differences soon, Secretary of State Warren Christopher proposed a new stopgap policy this week that angered the Bosnian Government: extending the fraying cease-fire beyond its April 30 expiration.
Bosnian leaders immediately criticized the Christopher proposal, arguing that it would make it easier for the Serbs to solidify their control of the territory they had seized.
In an interview, Vice President Ejup Ganic of Bosnia said his country had originally insisted on a cease-fire of no more than four months for just this reason.
He also contended that his Government had never received the quid pro quo that was promised it for accepting the cease-fire. The United States, Britain, France, Germany and Russia -- the so-called contact group countries -- were supposed to exert pressure on Bosnia's Serbs to accept a peace plan that would reduce their holdings to 49 percent of Bosnia's land.
This week, Mr. Ganic and other Bosnian leaders called for ending the cease-fire, lifting the international arms embargo against Bosnia and having the North Atlantic Treaty Organization make good on its threats to bomb Bosnian Serb positions when the Serbs flouted the organization's warnings.
"What we have now is diplomacy without force, and that's weak diplomacy," Mr. Ganic said. "What we need is diplomacy backed by force."
Administration officials acknowledge that they see no settlement soon. The Administration has failed after months of threats, pressure and cajoling to persuade the Bosnian Serbs to accept a peace plan put forward by the United States, Russia and Europe.
Similarly, it has failed to persuade President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, the dominant figure in the former Yugoslavia, to grant formal recognition to Bosnia and its borders, a move that would undermine the claims and spirit of the Bosnian Serbs.
Adding to the Administration's problems, Senator Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, has promised to introduce legislation to lift the arms embargo against Bosnia if there is no peace settlement by May 1. While Senator Dole says lifting the embargo is needed to narrow the Bosnian Serbs' decisive arms advantage, the Administration contends that ending the embargo unilaterally will intensify the war, cause Britain and France to withdraw their peacekeepers and spread the war throughout the former Yugoslavia.
In a speech last week in Kansas, Defense Secretary William J. Perry described Mr. Dole's policy as "lift and pray." But some Republicans in Congress have countered by calling President Clinton's policy "don't lift and pray."
Many supporters of lifting the embargo acknowledge that it may heighten the fighting in Bosnia, but they argue that such a move can serve as vital leverage to get Bosnia's Serbs to accept the contact group's peace plan. Clinton Administration officials say it is wrong to lift the embargo unilaterally and thus violate a Security Council resolution. The Administration supports lifting it multilaterally, but Britain, France and Russia are opposed.
American officials assert that their Bosnia policy has had one unqualified success: it has prevented the war from spilling into other parts of the former Yugoslavia, including Macedonia and Kosovo.
In an interview, Mr. Holbrooke said: "We're not at a dead end. It's more peaceful on the ground in the region that it has been in the last few years, except for Bihac. The Bosnian Muslims are stronger than before. We've had to focus on Croatia for the past few months, and now we're refocusing on Bosnia."
Mr. Holbrooke sees some rays of hope. The political and economic isolation of Bosnia's Serbs could force them to accept the contact group's plan. And the stumbling year-old federation and military alliance between Bosnia's Muslims and Croats will add more pressure on Bosnia's Serbs, he said.
American officials continue to hope that President Milosevic will agree to recognize Bosnia and Croatia in exchange for getting the United Nations to lift economic sanctions against Serbia afterward. But in a bargaining position backed by Russia, Mr. Milosevic says he will recognize his neighbors only after the sanctions are lifted.
The Clinton Administration now sees little hope in persuading Mr. Milosevic. "That hole will probably turn out to be dry," Mr. Holbrooke said.

HEADLINE: On Sunday;
1,361 Executed Here, and Fear Restarts Count

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

 BODY:
EVEN with New York coming back on line more slowly than anticipated, Watt Espy, the nation's foremost historian of the gallows, remains confident that the United States will soon be breaking the single-year record of 199 executions set in 1935. That was a desperate time economically and criminally, but a good one for tabloid stories of cameras sequestered into the Sing Sing death house in carnival pursuit of the justly living's peeking at the condemned.
New York's actual return to capital punishment will take some time, and the impatience is palpable in some quarters. Still, Mr. Espy anticipates the nation's getting beyond that 1935 record by the year 2000. Splurging millennially, we will be dispatching close to 300 criminals a year, versus the 75 expected to go this year by electrocution, gunfire, hanging and the increasingly popular lethal injection, with its antiseptic gurney and trappings of social triage. 
 "Let's face it: When New York last had a death penalty it didn't just waste there on the books," Mr. Espy said, booting up the computer where he's stored 25 years of research labor on the death penalty. "A lot of New Yorkers were sentenced and a lot died."
THE numbers clicked forth on the screen in his ramshackle house in Headland, Ala., and Mr. Espy was fascinated anew at licit killing. "In fact, even after your layoff, New York is still second in the nation in total executions," he announced over the phone. "Second only to Virginia's 2,049. I document 1,361 New York executions, including 37 females."
As in the other states he's been studying, Mr. Espy says we can expect some leering overcoverage in the news of the first executions in New York. But then, except for that occasional "mad-dog" celebrity fiend, the news stories will shrink. They will slip away toward the mundane high-volume routine he finds capital punishment is already becoming in a nation that will soon stand alone among the major industrial countries in not abolishing execution but rather elevating it to record proportions.
"You'll be back in it strong in New York, yessir," said the historian, speaking as an authority respected for his researches in both lost data and human detail. He tracks executions back through 17th century records as well as through sympathetic correspondence with the modern flood of victims' survivors and perpetrators' families.
"I know some innocent people are going to be executed," Mr. Espy said, echoing the fearful prediction of the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau. "But if they're criminals with previous records, I think most people will say, 'So what?' People are not just cynical these days, they're scared."
The Headland computer is at 18,800 executions and counting since 1608, when Virginia got that lead and shot George Kendall as a Spanish spy. Mr. Espy is as opinionated against execution as much of the rest of the nation seems avid for it. He has reams to document its racist undertow, like an old newspaper headline: "Black Fiend Hanged/Jerked to Jesus."
But rather than proselytizing, Mr. Espy prefers just to amass the facts like some monk in the Dark Ages and await a change on the issue that, he concedes at age 62, won't occur in his lifetime. Change is more a matter of individuals than historic tide, according to his studies. "The only reason you have been out of the execution business in New York is because Governors Carey and Cuomo vetoed the legislation," he said. "Because of two men, not because of the Legislature or the people."
WATT ESPY understands the average citizen's fear of crime and the average politician's exploiting the fear. "Call it what you please, they want it: punishment, vengeance, whatever," he said. "In some states, they're allowing families of the victims to witness execution, like they used to do in the past. That just gives it purely and simply the aspect of revenge."
Anyone who has visited Mr. Espy and enjoyed his hospitality and biscuit sandwiches is struck by his singular dismay at the revival of execution. And by his dark humor, too, over grave statehouse debates when politicians proclaim the humaneness of lethal injection.
"Hell, we all know they don't really give a damn about the humanity of it," he said, chuckling. "They're doing that to make it easier to get the death sentence. They think somehow it can be presented that you're killing this man in the same way that you put beloved old Fido to sleep."
The laughter of the gallows historian echoed all the way to New York.

HEADLINE: Asked, Told, Pursued

BYLINE: By Lawrence Korb and C. Dixon Osburn; Lawrence Korb was Assistant Secretary of Defense from 1981 to 1985. C. Dixon Osburn is co-executive director of the Service Members Legal Defense Network.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the year since the Pentagon initiated its "don't ask, don't tell, don't pursue" policy, the lives of most lesbians and gay men in the military have not improved. So it is no surprise that lawyers for six gay service members told a Federal court in Brooklyn last week that the rules continue discrimination and accommodate the fears and prejudices of heterosexual troops.
 The new policy was intended to stop officials from prying into sexual orientation, to end the Salem-like witch hunts of the late 1980's and early 1990's and to stop physical and verbal harassment of homosexuals. But commanders continue to ask, pursue and harass those who are or are perceived to be gay, lesbian or bisexual, defying the spirit of the policy and violating constitutional rights. 
 A Navy psychiatrist in Charleston, S.C., turned in Cpl. Kevin Blaesing after he asked her questions about sexuality, which led Corporal Blaesing's commander to try to kick him out of the military.
 In Okinawa, Cpl. Craig Haack was subject to a full-scale witch hunt; a Navy investigator seized and read his diaries and letters in front of him, confiscated his computer and software and even took a pair of his platform shoes, arguing that they were evidence of homosexual conduct. Corporal Haack was discharged when his term expired.
 There have been at least 37 violations of the "don't ask" policy, and the Pentagon is pressing for the discharge of at least one gay service member although it concedes that his supervisor asked him about his sexual orientation.
 Overall, the services are discharging homosexuals at the same rate as under the old policy. In 1994, the cost of training replacements for the 597 men and women discharged was more than $17.5 million. This figure does not include the costs of conducting investigations or holding discharge hearings.
 Many of those investigated are 18 to 25 years old and still coming to terms with their sexual orientation. Some have been wrongly accused out of vengeance, including heterosexual women who have been denounced as lesbians after they claimed that they were raped or sexually harassed.
 Many service members have no clear idea of their rights and do not know how to respond to an investigation. They need legal help, but the military will not provide a lawyer until after a full investigation into a possible defendant's life has been completed. One hour with a private lawyer can cost a full week's military pay.
 Investigators often interrogate parents about their child's sexual orientation and then use their statements against the service member at the discharge hearing. The military often threatens a court-martial and jail unless the service member confesses, and also encourages the accused's friends to speculate about his or her sexual activities.
 The military guarantees few of the constitutional rights that civilians take for granted. The accused aren't allowed to object to the admission of illegally seized evidence, hearsay or circumstantial evidence. And their lawyers often find that witnesses are unavailable for cross-examination.
 If the service member loses, he or she will be discharged and can be imprisoned for up to 15 years, forfeits many military benefits, can be denied unemployment compensation and faces discrimination when a potential civilian employer reads the reason for discharge stamped on the papers.
 "Don't ask" means don't ask. "Don't pursue" means don't pursue. "Don't harass" means don't harass. It shouldn't be that difficult. Yet, some commanders blatantly defy the policy and hide behind a military judicial system that is tantamount to a kangaroo court. This is difficult not only on lesbian and gay men who simply want to serve their country free from harassment and Government intrusion but on the Pentagon, which must argue in Federal court why the military needs to treat heterosexuals differently from homosexuals. It is clear that "don't ask, don't tell, don't pursue" is a ruse for business as usual.

HEADLINE: Cuba: Time to Change Direction

 BODY:
The sight of Fidel Castro in a business suit being escorted about Paris this week as an honored guest deserves some consideration in Washington. With the Soviet Union gone and the cold war over, the only threat that the Cuban Communist poses to the United States lies in the imagination of ideological warriors like Senator Jesse Helms. While the time has not yet come to welcome Mr. Castro to Washington, a re-examination of Cuba policy is long overdue. The embargo of Cuba, begun when John Kennedy occupied the White House and Nikita Khrushchev was Soviet leader, has outlived its usefulness.
 Conservatives still cling to the notion that isolating Cuba and creating misery for its people will eventually cause an uprising and sweep Mr. Castro from power. Now that he is without Soviet support and his economy is in tatters, they reason, sanctions should be tightened. 
 This scenario is unwise and inhumane. Cuba will survive because other nations are investing there and are not participating in the embargo. Last year when a resolution against the embargo came up at the U.N., it passed by 101 votes to 2. The kind of outright rebellion envisioned by Senator Helms and some Cuban-Americans, if it did occur, would bring bloodshed and more misery for many Cubans. At a time when Washington is trying hard to encourage peaceful transitions elsewhere in the region and world, it makes little sense to encourage bloodshed in Cuba.
 An increasing number of younger, more moderate Cuban-Americans are fed up with the revenge fantasies of their elders, and would like to see more dialogue and commerce with Mr. Castro's regime. They feel that his repressive policies could not continue for long if the barriers were lifted and ordinary Cubans could have a taste of material success and a whiff of personal freedom from the north. Washington's anachronistic policy may even help Mr. Castro, by giving him a convenient scapegoat for all his failures at home.
 Without the embargo, the excuses would be gone. Open communication with the United States, freedom for Cuban-Americans to invest in businesses back home, and access to North American goods could be first steps. More favorable trade conditions could be held out as incentives to further reforms. Mr. Castro's Paris visit illustrated the power of the friendly gesture. After his warm reception by President Mitterrand, Mr. Castro agreed to allow a French human rights group to visit.
 There should be gradations in American policy toward repressive governments. When American national security is potentially threatened, as with Iran and its efforts to develop nuclear weapons, Washington is justified in banning commerce. In cases like China and Cuba, where internal policies are anathema to Americans but American security is not at risk, commerce can be encouraged but trade privileges should be withheld.
 Scuttling the embargo would take some political courage. All the White House had to do last week to inspire Mr. Helms's wrath was to hint that it might consider lifting some additional sanctions imposed last year during the immigration crisis. But the political clout of the Cuban exile community has diminished in recent years as more Cuban-Americans have abandoned the traditional confrontational stance.
 Long gone are the days when Soviet troops and bases in Cuba represented a real threat to the United States and Mr. Castro was exporting arms and revolution in the hemisphere. Cuba, absent the ghosts of the cold war, is an impoverished neighbor of the United States led by a dictator overtaken by history. American policy should reflect that reality rather than a world that no longer exists.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Yesterday's Man

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Warren Christopher did yeoman's service last week in cajoling and enticing Syria's president Hafez el-Assad to resume peace talks with Israel. But frankly I'm really tired of watching secretaries of state trudge off to Damascus to beg Mr. Assad to resume negotiations that are in his self-interest. It's time for a new approach. I propose that the next time Mr. Christopher sits down with Mr. Assad, he opens like this:
 "Hafez -- you don't mind if I call you Hafez? Hafez, you are yesterday's man. You're still living in the cold war. I know you've only traveled outside the Middle East a few times, so let me tell you a little bit about the new world.
"Hafez, Syria today can barely make a light bulb. That's sad. That's also why your per capita income is only $1,200 a year. Have you ever been to Japan, Hafez? At the Lexus factory in Toyota City, the Japanese produce 300 Lexus sedans each day with 66 human beings and 310 robots. And you can barely make a light bulb. The world is passing you by.
 "Now, Hafez, the reason I'm telling you this is because during the cold war, it didn't matter whether Syria made computer chips or potato chips, a Lexus or a light bulb, because you could make a good living just by milking the superpowers for aid and blackmailing your neighbors.
"Yes, I see you smiling, Hafez. You know it's true. You milked the Saudis for billions by letting them know that there could be, as the Mafia would say, 'an unfortunate accident' in the oil fields if they didn't pay. But those days are over. The price of oil is down and the Saudis can't pay their bills anymore. Now Hafez, during the cold war you milked us a little, too. You milked the Europeans even more and the Soviets a lot. They bought your third-rate products and gave you arms and aid in return for your friendship. It was a good living, Hafez -- and you played us off against each other brilliantly. Chapeau.
 "But, Hafez, the cold war is over. There is a new global architecture. There are no longer two superpowers to play against each other. There is only one and we're broke.
 "Instead of superpowers, Hafez, there are super markets. There's the Tokyo bond market and the Frankfurt bond market and the Singapore bond market and the Wall Street bond market. These bond markets are actually more powerful than many governments today. And let me tell you, Hafez, you don't play the Tokyo bond market off against the Frankfurt bond market. No, no, no. They play you off. That's right, they play Syria off against Mexico off against Brazil off against Thailand.
 "Whichever country has the most stable government, the most efficient economy, the most Westernized legal system, the most convertible currency and the most educated labor force, gets rewarded with investment capital from the super markets. Those countries that don't get their house in order are left as roadkill on the global investment highway. And, Hafez, you are destined to be roadkill.
 "Now, Hafez, every time I come to Syria the phones don't work in the press room. When we go to Jordan and Egypt, we have touch-tone phones, but here, in your Sheraton Hotel, they have these old rotary dials with these very nice Syrian women who spend all day dialing for our reporters, because it can take hours to get through. It's generous of you, but don't you think those women would be more productive making goods for export?
 "Tell you what, I'm going to leave you my cellular, satellite phone. It's the latest model from Motorola. You'll reach me in Washington in seconds. Because, Hafez, I don't intend to make any more trips out here. You bore me, and these nine-hour history lessons on the Crusades that you put me through each visit are not an efficient use of my time. Why don't you put them on a compact disk and just hand them out to every visiting secretary of state?
 "You see, Hafez, I've got too many other important places to be: Mexico, Russia, China. Who should rule the Golan Heights is a fascinating question, but it's utterly irrelevant to U.S. interests today. But, hey, we'd still love to hear from you. When you're ready to do business, just dial 001-202-647-4910. Ask for Chris. Otherwise, Hafez, stay out of my life."
 (Wednesday: Assad's answer.)

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: March 19, 1995

SECTION: Section 8; Page 6; Column 1; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 1414 words

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Prospect of an April Lockout by Owners Leaves Many Questions

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., March 18

 BODY:
With the scheduled start of the 1995 season two weeks from Sunday, about the only thing certain is that neither a negotiated agreement nor National Labor Relations Board action will get the striking players back in uniform by opening day.
The most intriguing development that could occur would have the players offering to return to work, with or without an injunction obtained by the labor board from a Federal court judge, and the owners refusing to let them do so and instead locking them out while continuing to use replacement players. 
 It is not certain that the owners, under the circumstances that would exist at the time, would have the right to lock out the returning strikers and use their strikebreakers; it is not certain that the owners would want to and run the risk of potentially incurring hundreds of millions of dollars in back pay and possible damages.
But it is lawful for an employer to lock out employees and use replacements. In 1987, the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, in Philadelphia, upheld an N.L.R.B. ruling that permitted the use of temporary replacement workers during a lockout.
In denying the petition from a local of the operating engineers union, the court held that Harter Equipment did not commit an unfair labor practice by hiring temporary workers when it intended to return regular employees to their jobs at the conclusion of the contract dispute.
Although there would seem to be little relationship between the baseball dispute and one involving mechanics, a truck driver and a painter, the court's opinion created a link. It noted that "employer was in financial straits and union was aware of its financial problems." From the outset, the court noted, "the company made it clear that it needed substantial cost concessions because it was operating at a loss."
The baseball owners, of course, have not convinced their employees that their claims of economic distress are valid; that's the primary reason the players have resisted making "substantial cost concessions" by accepting a salary cap or a severe luxury tax on payrolls.
Like the operating engineers, the players may challenge their employers' bargaining strategy if they are locked out and find their jobs taken by replacement players. The court, in denying the operating engineers' challenge, found that Harter's action was "for the sole purpose of applying economic pressure in support of a legitimate bargaining position."
The players could argue that the court's opinion would not apply in the baseball case for a few reasons. In the Harter dispute, the company didn't hire the replacements until six weeks into the lockout; the baseball strikebreakers are already in place. The players also probably would argue that the lockout was retaliatory rather than the application of economic pressure. As for a "legitimate bargaining position," the players could contend that the owners, as indicated by multiple N.L.R.B. complaints, have not bargained in good faith.
Then there's the possibility that the labor board could reverse its position. "Just as precedent got undone," one lawyer said, "it can get undone twice."
Within the context of a lockout, Peter Angelos could create the most intriguing development. The owner of the Baltimore Orioles, Angelos has defied baseball officials and fellow owners by refusing to field a replacement team. If three-fourths of his fellow owners vote to lock out the returning strikers, Angelos could defy their strategy again by trying to let his real players play.
The American League would probably take action to bar those Orioles from playing, but if they somehow did -- through a court decision, perhaps -- they would wipe up the rest of the league and wind up in the World Series.
 
Delaying by the Owners
 'Tis a funny game the owners are playing in these negotiations.
"This union keeps doing everything possible to stay away from the bargaining table," Stan Kasten of Atlanta said last week in what appears to be his role as the negotiating committee's union basher.
"We're just so upset with Don Fehr and his continued delay in negotiating," Bill Giles of Philadelphia said.
But it was the owners' negotiators who created a wasted week in bargaining as the season rapidly approached. Talks had been scheduled to resume last Tuesday or Wednesday. When the general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board last Monday summoned Chuck O'Connor, management's chief labor lawyer, to a meeting in Washington on Tuesday, the owners, already in Florida for the talks, called them off.
O'Connor was finished with his Washington meeting by noon Tuesday. The owners could have directed him to return to Florida that day, assessed the board's pending action, which they said they had to do before meeting with the players' negotiators, then begun bargaining Wednesday or, if they needed that day for assessment purposes, Thursday.
But they obviously did not want to meet, moving instead into a figurative four corners formation in recognition of the start of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament. While continuing to accuse the union of stalling, they put off even scheduling new talks.
"We still do not have baseball back because we are caught up in every conceivable diversion," Kasten said, adding about the N.L.R.B. complaint, "I guess this is going to stretch out the clock a little more, keep us farther away from getting a negotiated settlement."
But the owners were squandering valuable time in trying to negotiate a settlement before the labor board proceeded with its course. Fred Feinstein, the general counsel, didn't even go to the five-member board for permission to seek an injunction until Friday, three days after his meeting with O'Connor. The board isn't expected to act on his request until late this week.
The two sides had probably 10 days to negotiate before they would know if the board would seek an injunction. They have squandered more than half of that time, and it has been the owners who put off scheduling talks.
Asked yesterday about the delay, Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, said: "The union people had something Tuesday night and had something else scheduled Wednesday. At that point, given the N.L.R.B. and everything that happened, what looked like a definite pattern of negotiating had been totally disrupted."
However, even a prominent member of management questioned the owners' decision not to meet last week.
The owners have also accused the union of creating distractions by constantly going to the N.L.R.B. Yet the board repeatedly has found reason to cite the owners for bargaining in bad faith and allegedly violating labor law. Presumably, if the owners had bargained in good faith throughout the talks, the union would have had no reason to create the so-called distraction.
The owners, on the other hand, apparently have no grounds on which to accuse the union of bad-faith bargaining. When Feinstein was asked at a news conference last week if the players have bargained in good faith throughout the negotiations, he said, "We have not made any determination to the contrary, certainly."
 
Another Sticky Issue
 Not that the two sides are anywhere near debating settlement issues -- no settlement is in sight -- but a large issue looms. The union says it will have none of this replacement business once the real players return to work, but the clubs are faced with a dilemma.
If they were to acquiesce to the players' position and agree not to count the games, they would face a torrent of lawsuits from fans accusing them of fraud for having advertised the games as ones that counted in the championship season. Forget that some regular-season ticket prices have been reduced; the clubs will still call the games legitimate and the fans would have a legitimate argument if the clubs ultimately deem them otherwise.
Roger Clemens, the Boston pitcher, offered his view of replacement baseball.
"I don't know who they're trying to fool saying they're going to put a team on the field people are going to want to come see," Clemens said. "I disagree with that. In football, you can disguise somebody under some helmets and shoulder pads. Other than your topnotch superstar type caliber players, you just become a number and a name on the back of a uniform. You start three-hopping the ball from shortstop, you can't hide. If you ever watched paint dry, that's what it's going to be like."

And Bear in Mind
(Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
THE DIARY OF A YOUNG GIRL: The Definitive Edition, by Anne Frank. Edited by Otto H. Frank and Mirjam Pressler. (Doubleday, $25.) An expanded version that restores entries from the original diary, giving more texture and nuance to this renowned personal account of the Holocaust.
 
DREAMING: Hard Luck and Good Times in America, by Carolyn See. (Random House, $23.) The novelist's memoir of her family revels in a woman's point of view as it paints a portrait of drugs, drink and zany freedom set in California.
 
THE END OF REFORM: New Deal Liberalism in Recession and War, by Alan Brinkley. (Knopf, $27.50.) In the late 1930's, a distinguished historian argues, liberal interventionism lost its nerve and settled for underwriting consumer demand, with the results we now see around us.
 
FRANCO: A Biography, by Paul Preston. (Basic Books, $37.50.) A huge, all-inclusive life of the outright winner of Spain's civil war, the shrewd, lucky dictator of his country for almost 40 years.
 
IN LOVE WITH DAYLIGHT: A Memoir of Recovery, by Wilfrid Sheed. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) This writer's account of his battles with alcohol, drugs and cancer is grim, but it's told with whimsical wisdom and good-natured resolve.
 
MOVING HOUSE: Stories, by Pawel Huelle. (Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace, $18.95.) These tales by a Polish writer, which turn on the longings and workings of memory, are rooted in the highly idiosyncratic history of Gdansk.
 
SIX MYTHS OF OUR TIME: Little Angels, Little Monsters, Beautiful Beasts, and More, by Marina Warner. (Vintage, paper, $10.) Humorous, urgent essays on how myth and fiction enshrine and fix categories like the moral condition of children.
 
TERRIBLE HONESTY: Mongrel Manhattan in the 1920s, by Ann Douglas. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) New York analyzed with broad scope and minute complexity as the locus of the national psyche when Americans attacked the conditioned responses of the pre-1914 world.
 
TOMORROW IS ANOTHER COUNTRY: The Inside Story of South Africa's Road to Change, by Allister Sparks. (Hill & Wang, $22.) A South African journalist's fast-paced, gripping account of the process that led to the end of apartheid.
 
TOM PAINE: A Political Life, by John Keane. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) A good introduction to a difficult, often unlovable character, an effective propagandist of revolution (and, on the whole, liberty) in America, France and even England.
 
THE TUNNEL, by William H. Gass. (Knopf, $30.) This sprawling novel (652 pages) by an American master is all spun out of the head of its monstrous protagonist, a language-driven professor of fascist views who is as dreadful as he is plausible.
 
A VOID, by Georges Perec. (Harvill/HarperCollins, $24.) The letter E never occurs in this 1969 French novel or in its translation by Gilbert Adair; what does occur is a wildly amusing feast of puzzles, mind games and rules broken just to exhibit their latent existence.
