HEADLINE: A Star Is Built

BYLINE: By Thomas S. Hines; Thomas S. Hines is a professor of history and architecture at the University of California, Los Angeles. His most recent publication is a history of Wilshire Boulevard in Los Angeles, a chapter in "The Grand American Avenue, 1850-1920."

 BODY:

NEW YORK 1960
Architecture and Urbanism Between the Second World War and the Bicentennial.
By Robert A. M. Stern, Thomas Mellins and David Fishman.
Illustrated. 1,374 pp. New York: The Monacelli Press/Penguin. $125. 
 IN 1971 the poet and art critic John Ashbery, visiting the new SoHo art scene in Manhattan, wrote that, even though one had to trudge through trash-strewn streets to get to the artists' "glittering white lofts," a regular visit to SoHo was now mandatory, "another in the expanding list of inconvenient pleasures New Yorkers are heir to." "Inconvenient pleasures" might well apply to "New York 1960: Architecture and Urbanism Between the Second World War and the Bicentennial," a gigantic book, just under eight pounds, with 1,213 pages of text and pictures, 134 pages of scholarly notes and a 26-page index. It is the work of Robert A. M. Stern, an architect, historian and professor of architecture at Columbia University, and Thomas Mellins and David Fishman, historians who have worked with Mr. Stern on various projects, including "Pride of Place," the public-television series on the development of American architecture. The book joins "New York 1900" and "New York 1930" in a projected five-volume history of the city's architecture and urban design. Still to come are "New York 1876" and "New York 2000." The dates in the titles refer to key years in the periods covered by each book.
The first two volumes celebrated what the authors define as "metropolitanism" in the half-century before World War II, when the city sought to establish the prototypes and standards by which governments, local and Federal, would meet their responsibilities in such areas as museums, parks, transportation and public housing. Though somewhat myopic in their failure to recall attendant social and economic inequities, the authors see New York, in those years, as "constituting a paradigm of efficiently organized diversity." It was, they write, "de facto a world capital, the highest representative of cultured life in America. Urban density . . . was celebrated in a so-called cult of congestion inextricably linked to the advantages and aspirations of a progressive civilization." But that relatively self-contained character changed after the war, when New York became the major focus, but not the only one, in an urban-suburban sprawl from New England to Virginia that came to be known as Megalopolis.
During the years between the end of the war and the late 1970's, there were changes that affected the whole world's view of cities. New York became the acknowledged capital of world finance, as well as the home of the United Nations. The sudden concentration of national and international business brought, especially to Manhattan, both the demands for new building and the wealth to realize it. The competition among architects to be represented in the city was intense. Interior design became an exalted profession, and both architecture and design were subjected to severe critical and popular attention. Laws governing building, landmarks preservation and zoning all changed in ways that affected the fabric of New York, sometimes benignly, sometimes not.
The city itself seemed to become a gigantic media star. It was the world capital of art, and in many ways much of the art commented on, and affected, the esthetic values of architecture and design. It was the background, the subject, the very spirit of countless plays and films that also affected the world's perception of the city and the city's view of itself. The sheer excitement and energy of the physical changes transforming New York in this era fascinated the world -- and they give this vast and important study an irresistible force.
The most valuable and satisfying parts of the book are two synthesizing introductory chapters that trace in a roughly chronological way the development of New York architecture and planning over three decades. This includes not only a treatment of buildings but an analysis of the design and maintenance of parks, streets, bridges, traffic patterns, lighting and street furniture, as well as the public transportation nexus of buses, subways, trains and airports. These long chapters, in fact, could be published separately as an instructive monograph in American urban history.
They are followed by a phalanx of chapters arranged by geography that take one through the city as though on a long, intense walking tour that wanders inside and outside an astonishing number of places. The advantage of the book's geographical organization is that it gives one a greater sense of urban design and context. A liability is that it encourages redundancy and skews chronology. For example, the explication of such historically path-breaking buildings of the 1950's as Gordon Bunshaft's Lever House and Ludwig Mies van der Rohe's Seagram Building, both in midtown, follow by some 150 pages the related discussion of younger downtown buildings they influenced. The historically trend-setting midtown chapter might well have been placed first.
Yet several of the best chapters are those that ignore geography and cover interior design, New York in the theater, the city and the arts, and the city in the movies. Not only are these sections filled with wonderful stories and personalities, but they give one a larger and deeper understanding of what urbanism is, and of the intellectual and emotional rewards, and costs, of city life.
They show us in words and images how urban people define themselves and recognize themselves in plays like "On the Town" and "West Side Story" or films like "Babes on Broadway" (1941), "Breakfast at Tiffany's" (1961) and "The Pawnbroker" (1965), in the art of an Abstract Expressionist like Franz Kline or in the work of the Pop Art masters of the 1960's. There is a generosity, a democratic spirit, in this kind of presentation that makes this volume important and enjoyable. Sometimes, of course, the authors get carried away in their boosterism and present methodologically flawed statistical equations. The city's museum's, they assert, "were so popular with artists and the general public that annual attendance reached 3.5 million, exceeding the combined attendance of the city's two baseball stadiums." How would attendance at museums have compared with the annual attendance at professional sporting events in all seasons of the year, beyond the baseball summer?
THE tone of this book is not wholly celebratory. The authors can be forcefully critical and sometimes melancholy, as in a strong chapter on historic preservation, something the previous volumes discussed only in passing. The demolition of the great Pennsylvania Station in 1963 is still seen as an acute tragedy today. And the authors point to other kinds of losses; there are fascinating pages on great proposals never built, like Louis Kahn's design for a Holocaust memorial in Battery Park. One of the early losses was the old Produce Exchange Building designed by George B. Post in the late 19th century that once sat splendidly across Bowling Green from the Beaux Arts exuberance of the United States Custom House. It was replaced by a monolith of unrelieved tedium, and the authors gather eloquent testimony from architects and others about it. Such losses led in 1965 to the establishment of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, a significant weapon against unbridled development.
Not all changes in zoning law were that beneficent. In 1960 and 1961, the city largely overturned the pioneering zoning ordinance of 1916 that had maximized ground density and opened the city skyward with its "setback" rules, allowing tall buildings to rise flush from the sidewalks, but then requiring floors to be reduced in area as the buildings rose above specified heights. The new regulations of 1960 practically reversed that formula, encouraging "unmodulated, independently spaced skyscraper slabs rising from generously scaled plazas . . . a city that was space positive rather than mass positive, a city which if rebuilt completely along the lines of the new code would become one with the continuous open space of the essential ruralism of Megalopolis." It also stimulated a disruption of the traditional pattern of towers rising principally along the north-south avenues, with much smaller structures filling the side streets. As the plazas spread, towers began populating the side streets too. The authors call the result a "collapse of traditional street architecture" and say with some exaggeration that the new code resulted in the loss of "the camaraderie of street and neighborhood life, so long the glue that kept the city's social fabric together."
All this change did not pass unremarked, and the public disputes that accompanied it shaped the nation's discussion of what cities ought to be. In a crucial section titled "Two Power Brokers: Robert Moses and Jane Jacobs," these two key figures are shown in battle over different visions of what constituted the commonweal. They personified, the authors say, "the struggle between New York as the grandest metropolis in the world on the one hand and as the world's biggest village on the other, between the power of the purse, whether public or private, and the power of the public will." For Moses, who for many years championed massive redevelopment, "city life was the daily grind, a fundamental fact of modern existence but basically unsympathetic to the good life." For him, "city life meant sacrifice, with the individual bending his will to the collective." His attitude was exemplified by his fondness for quoting the old proverb "You can't make an omelet without breaking eggs." Toward the end of his imperious career, the authors contend, Moses seemed "actively hostile to the city he had so long served."
For Jane Jacobs, the sensitive but tough-as-nails editor, theorist and activist, "the city was a great liberation, the ultimate freedom, an intricate web of individuals, buildings and streets, a mosaic or tapestry that somehow amounted to more than any singular vision and was absolute anathema to the idea of a grand plan. In Jacobs's view, New York, or at least the parts of it she admired, had the ingredients of a post-industrial-age utopia; it was definitely not an ordeal to be endured." In her 1961 book "The Death and Life of Great American Cities," she bluntly attacked not only Moses' notions of urban order, but those espoused by Le Corbusier. She celebrated the "ballet of the street" and "order in variety" of much of New York, as epitomized by her own neighborhood in Greenwich Village. "The pseudoscience of planning," she asserted, "seems almost neurotic in its determination to imitate empiric failure and to ignore empiric success." Her manifesto turned the planning establishment on its head. Even the influential critic Lewis Mumford, who found occasional virtues in the book, referred to it patronizingly as "Mother Jacobs' Home Remedies."
The urgent voices of other power brokers are heard throughout the book, reminding us of the passions, and the principles, brought into play. John V. Lindsay, for example, more than any other mayor before him, put architecture, planning and urban design among his top priorities, recognizing, the authors say, "that physical planning was a key issue that could unite a wide section of an electorate that was seriously divided over issues of race, ethnicity and class." During his first six months in office, he killed Robert Moses' plan for a 30th Street expressway that would have slashed across the center of Manhattan, stopped various planned intrusions into the natural preserve of Central Park and closed the park to automobiles on Sunday mornings.
He also brought expert consultants into his administration and gave them responsibility, people like the architects Jonathan Barnett, Richard Weinstein, Jaquelin Robertson and Myles Weintraub whom he appointed as founding members of the Urban Design Group, an expanding cadre of professional urbanists who helped the Mayor turn theory into action. Later he moved members of the group into key city positions -- Richard Weinstein, for example, as director of the Office of Lower Manhattan Development and Jaquelin Robertson as director of the Office of Midtown Development.
AMONG the critics discussed at length, the authors believe that no one was more important than Ada Louise Huxtable. As an independent writer about architecture and design for some years, she had argued persuasively that the treatment of architecture in newspapers and magazines was scandalously inadequate and that, as a result, citizens were deprived of both information about and a voice in the development of their cities. In 1963 she became the first full-time architecture critic for any American newspaper, and she used her wit and her knowledge in The New York Times to tremendous effect. In 1965 she received the first Pulitzer Prize ever given for criticism of any kind. Her years at The Times established the view that no major newspaper in any great city of the world could afford to be without a full-time architecture critic. This became important not only for constantly informing the citizenry, but for informing later historians whose task it is to reconstruct the past.
Beginning with lower Manhattan -- the Lower East Side, Chinatown, the Civic Center, the financial district, the World Trade Center, the Battery Park area, New York University, Greenwich Village and SoHo -- the authors give excellent introductions to each section, evoking the social and cultural history of the area as prelude to the discussion of its changing architectural character. They strike an admirable balance between attention to the grand structures of the powerful and the environments of middle- and working-class New Yorkers, including public housing.
In lower Manhattan they first introduce readers not to the financial district but to the large public housing projects. They may lament the blandness of such "elevator tenements" as the Jacob Riis Houses along the East River from 6th to 14th Streets, but they point out that in 1965 a landscape architect, M. Paul Friedberg, with private funding from the Vincent Astor Foundation, transformed the central open area amid the Riis Houses into "one of the few attractive and engaging outdoor gathering spaces in a public housing project." It contained a children's playground with sand piles and recreational equipment, a series of trellised and brick-paved sitting areas for older residents, and "a thousand-person, pergola-enclosed, sunken amphitheater." The Village Voice opined that "for once, the poor of the city have the best of it." The authors also have high praise for some of the structures surrounding Riis, like Percival Goodman's Public School 126 and, behind it, his Alfred E. Smith Recreation Center.
Among the financial center skyscrapers they cite the handsome Chase Manhattan Bank headquarters (1960) by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, across Liberty Street from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, as the building most responsible for revitalizing downtown as a commercial center. Yet they have even higher praise for the same firm's 140 Broadway, directly to the west of the Chase, designed by Gordon Bunshaft and containing in its plaza Isamu Noguchi's memorable "Red Cube." Mrs. Huxtable believed it represented "one of the miracles of modern building: the skyscraper wall reduced to gossamer minimums of shining, thin material hung on a frame of extraordinary strength through superb contemporary technology."
IN a packed chapter of more than 200 pages, "New York 1960" explores midtown, with whole sections devoted to selected areas like Stuyvesant Town, Murray Hill and Chelsea, as well as to certain singular buildings, to the north-south avenues and to some of the side streets. While the authors carefully assess what they believe to be the good and the not-so-good, they seem overly cool to one of the prevailing masterworks of the area and the era: Roche & Dinkeloo's steel and concrete Ford Foundation on 42d Street (1967), connected so integrally to its glass-enclosed garden court. Other architects have criticized it, but Mrs. Huxtable thought it was one of the foundation's most charitable contributions to the arts, "a grant of some importance in a world where spirit and soul are deadened by the spectacular cheapness of the environment."
In their chapters on the Upper West Side and the Upper East Side, the authors include detailed and suggestive discussions of such institutions as Lincoln Center, Columbia University and the Guggenheim and Whitney museums, but, as throughout this book, they also examine housing projects and urban renewal sites. The breadth of their understanding and empathy is also notably apparent in their chapters on Harlem and Upper Manhattan. They give excellent whole chapters to the United Nations complex and to Central Park, including an assessment of the expansion of the Metropolitan Museum. One long chapter is devoted to the Outer Boroughs -- Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island -- where architectural development was obviously less intense than in Manhattan, but this section includes provocative assessments of La Guardia and Kennedy airports.
Mr. Stern, Mr. Mellins and Mr. Fishman say they have "sought to let the city tell its own complex story rather than to impose a contemporary perspective on it." That is somewhat disingenuous since they obviously have their biases, which ought to be noted. The most obvious is a distaste for mid-century modernism, particularly its expression in the variants on the mature International style. While they dutifully cite pros and cons from contemporary critics on buildings of this genre, they subtly stack the deck throughout the book against the late Modern movement. About Richard Meier's acclaimed Bronx Developmental Center (1977), for example, a total-care facility for 750 mentally and physically disabled children, they offer the loaded observation that it stood as "a symbol of Modernism" as well as "the butt of jokes." In Marshall Brickman's comic film "Simon" (1980), they tell us gleefully, the building is used as the fictitious Institute for Advanced Concepts, "within whose technologically perfect confines a group of brilliant scientists go mad."
The bias in the use of pictures is more subtle and pervasive: an endless repetition of calculatedly similar shots of mediocre International Style structures captured in relative isolation from people, other buildings and urban activity. As in a police lineup they stalk across the pages with a blandness more menacing even than that of Sixth Avenue north of 42d Street. Is the objective here to saturate readers with a Modernist overdose that is sufficiently toxic to make them cry for the purgative antidote of a Post-Modernist Nirvana, the world of Robert Stern's own architectural generation that will presumably decorate the pages of "New York 2000"?
This penchant is intensified with the excessively large coverage given to the work of Emery Roth & Sons, which the authors and their quoted sources usually describe as "banal" and "bland," without ever properly explaining their use of those terms. They would have performed a great service for students and lay readers by formally "deconstructing" a "banal" Roth skyscraper and comparing it specifically with a similarly explicated work of Gordon Bunshaft, like 140 Broadway, which usually earns the more flattering adjectives "extraordinary" and "superb."
There is also the old-fashioned matter of "function" and responsiveness to clients' needs. The Roths' great success was apparently based on this. Between 1950 and 1970, the firm "completed 70 New York office buildings, collectively containing in excess of 30 million square feet of space, or half of the total amount of office space created during that period." So apparently gifted was this office in making the "belly" of a building work that it was frequently engaged as the associate of fancier firms that designed the formal elements and gave the building its ultimate character. The problem, as always, lies in the mistaken perception that the two worlds cannot be integrated -- as they ultimately must be in the greatest and most successful architecture.
But those are not crippling faults. "New York 1960" should be read and pondered by all who value architecture and who understand, or wonder about, its importance in their lives. It should also be absorbed by all literate New Yorkers, actual and spiritual. Reading it will make them smarter and more loyal citizens and pilgrims. Despite its interesting flaws and its daunting length, there is very little here that should have been excluded. The authors are, by turns, optimistic and pessimistic. The writing is lucid and sprightly. Although the conclusion seems inappropriately downbeat, the book fairly crackles with energy and purpose, much like the city it examines so well.

HEADLINE: Japan Moves to Halt A Slide in the Dollar

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, March 20

 BODY:
The dollar recovered from a new postwar low set this morning, as the Bank of Japan aggressively bought dollars and sold yen, traders said.
Foreign investors were also buying dollars through banks in Singapore, pushing up offers for the currency, traders said. 
 "There's no doubt that the Bank of Japan is buying a fairly good amount of dollars," said Masahiro Yamaguchi, assistant manager for foreign exchange at Tokai Bank. The Japanese central bank does not comment on whether it is intervening in the market.
The dollar fell as low as 88.65 yen, a record. The previous record low in Tokyo was 88.75 yen, which was set on March 8. It was quoted later today at 89.20 yen, up from 89.05 yen in late New York trading on Friday, and 1.3850 German marks, down from 1.3865 marks in New York.
Traders said the dollar was likely to fall again. Hironobu Tsurugai, a trader for Citibank, said he expected the dollar to trade from 85 yen to 92 yen and from 1.36 marks to 1.41 marks this week.
That is because traders do not expect central banks around the world to take concerted action to prop up the dollar, which also fell to record lows of 1.3455 German marks and 1.1195 Swiss francs on March 8.
Traders and analyst say the dollar could rebound if the United States raises its interest rates while Germany and Japan cut theirs. No such action has been taken, however, and recent statements from central bank officials suggest that they may not act in concert.

HEADLINE: On Hustings, Paris vs. Anglo-Saxons

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, March 19

 BODY:
No matter which candidate wins this spring's French presidential elections, French foreign policy is likely to remain what it has been for three decades: proudly European and prepared to keep Anglo-Saxon influences at arm's length.
All of the three leading contenders, two conservatives claiming direct political lineage from the famously difficult de Gaulle and a Socialist hoping to inherit the mantle of President Francois Mitterrand, have been saying more or less the same things. 
 The campaign has been dominated by domestic concerns like unemployment, so foreign policy has not been an issue.
It was only Thursday that the front-runner, Mayor Jacques Chirac of Paris, a conservative, finally outlined his foreign policy platform in a speech to guests and the press. On relations with the United States, Mr. Chirac's position is not much different from that of his fellow conservative, Prime Minister Edouard Balladur, or the Socialist contender, Lionel Jospin.
The first round of voting will take place on April 23, and a runoff between the two most successful contenders will decide the winner on May 7.
"It is of course in France's interest to consolidate Franco-American friendship despite the periodic, and in general superficial, frictions that we experience in our relations with our oldest ally," Mr. Chirac said.
But he warned of new frictions ahead over expanded ties with Asia and Latin America, saying, "The United States has reacted by seeking to establish renewed ties with these regions, and wishes to remain their privileged and even dominant partner."
Mr. Chirac was at his most Gaullist in his vigorous defense of French cultural and linguistic identity against the inroads of American and British English, right up there with maintaining the French nuclear deterrent force on his list of foreign policy priorities.
"In a way, our language has never been spoken by so many," Mr. Chirac said. "But at the same time, it has never been as threatened by what seems to be the irresistible rise of English, or rather of the impoverished form of it that is tending to become the language of international communication."
France under a Chirac presidency would not declare war on the English language, he promised, but it would resist the international trend to uniformity just as, under Mr. Mitterrand, it fought and won the battle to keep European -- mainly French -- movies and television programming from being overrun by Hollywood.
There is a consistency in all this, a prickly insistence on a separate European political, cultural and military identity that goes back to de Gaulle's presidency, which lasted from 1959 to 1969. And Mr. Chirac's two leading rivals share it.
Mr. Balladur told the daily Le Figaro last week, "The Americans have to accept once and for all the existence of Europe -- that is, if Europe accepts being more independent and responsible itself."
And in his election platform, Mr. Jospin said, "To preserve their identity and also their economic competitiveness, it is crucial for France and Europe not to be simply receptacles for technologies and ideas from across the Atlantic."
All three candidates say they would, like Mr. Mitterrand, insist on maintaining European television programming quotas and filmmaking subsidies to keep Hollywood from swamping movie screens and living rooms on the continent.
And all three usually get cheers from audiences when they say they will maintain the European Union's protectionist policies on agricultural production and exports, another subject long dear to French hearts and a thorn to Americans.
Given the backgrounds of the three leading candidates, continuity in foreign policy is really no surprise. Mr. Jospin served as Education Minister under Mr. Mitterrand, Mr. Balladur has been Prime Minister for the last two years and Mr. Chirac has been Prime Minister twice, from 1974 to 1976 and again from 1986 to 1988.
If Mr. Chirac becomes President, and the latest polls predict that he will win more votes than any other candidate in both rounds, he is expected to ask the current Foreign Minister, Alain Juppe, to form the next Government.
All three of them now promise to bolster European trade defenses, to be able to retaliate against trade sanctions against them by the United States, and move to a common European currency as soon as possible. Mr. Balladur has set a target of 1997; Mr. Chirac offered no date but said he wanted a genuine national debate about it in France before it happened.
Mr. Chirac, who has sounded skeptical at times in the past about closer European integration, fell in line with the consensus on Thursday. "Hardly any different from the proposals made by Edouard Balladur," the left-leaning daily Liberation commented afterward.
All three candidates say the European Union needs to streamline its decision-making as it grows to take in the new democracies in Central Europe. And all three want to make Europe a more effective actor on the world stage by strengthening its common foreign and security policies, though not at the expense of national sovereignty.
"New mechanisms allow Europeans to use NATO resources under their own command," Mr. Chirac said, alluding to the concept of combined joint task forces that the allies approved last year. The European Union's military arm, the Western European Union, could use these in peacekeeping missions.
"This development makes a new type of relationship between France and NATO possible, and even necessary," Mr. Chirac said.
He said he would not have France return to NATO's integrated military structure, which is under the command of an American general based in Stuttgart, Germany.
But, he added, "Without returning to an integrated structure, our country must take part in all the organizations of the alliance based on the respect and sovereignty of states."

HEADLINE: Call for Moves On Currencies

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: CARCASSONNE, France, March 19

 BODY:
The President of the European Commission, Jacques Santer, called today for the Group of Seven industrial powers to take joint action to stabilize world currencies.
Mr. Santer said recent monetary turbulence was largely attributable to the effects of "benign neglect" of the dollar, and urged the group to coordinate policy as it had done in the 1980's with the so-called Plaza and Louvre accords to counter currency swings. 
 "We must act on the causes of monetary turbulence, which are not so much fundamentals as the effects of benign neglect vis-a-vis the dollar," Mr. Santer said after a European Union foreign ministers' meeting in this southwestern French town.
The recent turbulence, which has upset the European monetary system, has been largely caused by the dollar's drop to postwar lows, as investors seek safety in the mark and yen.
But the United States, while saying it did not encourage the dollar's slide, has so far resisted calls for concerted action, which have come mainly from the French.

HEADLINE: Encouraging Home Businesses;
Suburbs Revise Zoning Rules for Residential Entrepreneurs

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 19

 BODY:
Evelyn Simon was stunned the day a city inspector came to her door to investigate a violation of a law she had never heard of: her neighbors had filed a complaint against her for working out of her home.
"I couldn't believe it," said Ms. Simon, who was running a consulting business from home using a fax machine, a copier, personal computers and two secretaries. "It was totally absurd. I always assumed I had a right to work at home." 
 But things have only got worse in the four years since the inspection. The city fined Ms. Simon for operating a business in a residential zone. Her legal bills climbed to more than $5,000 as she fought the city in court over the case. Eventually, she moved her office elsewhere in frustration and dismay.
The peculiar experience of Ms. Simon -- who lost her case in December after an appeals court upheld the local restrictions on home occupations -- has added fuel to a debate here over whether the city's 40-year-old zoning regulations meet the demands of a modern working world driven by faxes and desktop computers. And New Rochelle City Council members are reviewing a proposal that would loosen the city's laws on working at home while still protecting the residential character of neighborhoods.
New Rochelle is not the only community looking to accommodate the legions of people who have embarked on a wide range of ventures from their dens, basements, garages and spare rooms. Planning officials in the suburbs have increasingly sought to draft new zoning rules that allow -- and sometimes even encourage -- home businesses. "Our zoning laws need to reflect the realities of the 90's," said Christina Selin, a New Rochelle City Councilwoman. "The fact is that many people no longer need to go to a centralized workplace with the advent of computers, faxes and other forms of telecommunications."
In the Hudson Valley community of Plattekill, N.Y., officials have made it easier for people to start businesses at home as a way to cope with layoffs at the nearby I.B.M. plants. Officials in the white-collar Westchester village of Scarsdale are considering a proposal that expands the number of professions permitted to operate within homes beyond the traditional list of doctors, lawyers and dentists. And in New Hanover, Pa., a suburb of Philadelphia, homeowners are now simply required to pay a registration fee to run businesses under their own roofs.
"The reality is that more people are working at home," said Marya Morris, a senior research associate with the American Planning Association in Chicago. "So communities around the country are broadening the range of businesses that they consider appropriate home occupations."
Most residential zoning rules were drafted decades ago to protect neighborhoods from heavy traffic, annoying smells and noises, billboards and other problems associated with businesses. Today, about 65 percent of communities across the country have laws that regulate home occupations, typically limiting them to doctors, dentists and other licensed professionals who are believed to provide needed services to neighborhoods.
But as more people work at home because of corporate layoffs, the high cost of commercial real estate and changes in family responsibilities, planners have come under increasing pressure to change their residential zoning codes. Many have concluded that their regulations are outdated, especially since sophisticated telecommunications equipment makes it possible for people to run all kinds of businesses from home without neighbors realizing it.
Many of Boine Johnson's neighbors probably have no idea that the ground floor of his Scarsdale home serves as the headquarters of a multimillion-dollar import business he started several years ago. What he mostly needs to run the company is a fax machine, three computers and some help from his family. He sees no clients at home and generally minds his own business.
There is only one problem: he is violating the local zoning ordinance.
He regards the law as absurd, and wonders whether the village is doing itself a disservice since many other people in Scarsdale run unobtrusive but prohibited businesses like his. "If you had a law that said you can't sleep past 6 A.M.," he said, "it would not only be ignored, but it would minimize respect for the law."
"I look at my own particular street here in Scarsdale," he added, "and 18 of the 22 houses have something going on."
Village officials are starting to see his point. In fact, they are considering changes in the zoning law that would expand the number of occupations allowed to operate from home.
"There are many professions and businesses that can operate in a home without affecting a community," said John Crary, the deputy village manager. "And they shouldn't be limited."
But in some other communities, residents have actively opposed loosening zoning restrictions, fearing this would spur a proliferation of home businesses and hurt the values of their homes. In the Westchester village of Irvington, a group of homeowners urged village officials to enact stricter zoning codes after a psychiatrist converted her garage into an office and built a circular driveway to provide parking for patients.
The new laws, adopted last year, prohibit establishing a new home office without registering with the village clerk and abiding by restrictions on the amount of floor space the business uses.
Linda Leary, a member of the group that lobbied for the new laws, said the case involving the psychiatrist caused concern that more home businesses would start turning up in the village without any regulations in place to protect neighborhoods from annoyances like heavy traffic.
"It was an issue that had been festering," said Ms. Leary, who has no quarrel with home offices that do not disturb neighborhood life. "The value of our real estate is very directly related to the quality of life in the area. And a small business could be a nuisance."
But the new restrictions have outraged many others, who say they have shaped their lives around the ability to do business from home.
Judith Lederman said she bought her home in Irvington several years ago largely because it had a front room that could be converted into an office for her public relations firm.
To Ms. Lederman, it was important to be able to work from home because she wanted to have time to raise her three children. "In the beginning, I even had a crib in the office," she said. "I learned how to nurse in front of my computer while typing with one hand."
So it is not surprising that Ms. Lederman did all she could to fight new zoning restrictions, including joining an ad hoc group of professionals opposed to such changes.
In the end, though, she relocated her office as the opposing side gained momentum. "The things they were asking for were absolutely ludicrous and would have made it impossible for me to stay in my home office," Ms. Lederman said.
But officials elsewhere in the region consider these new home businesses a valuable asset and have begun loosening restrictions. In Plattekill, planners realized many people were looking to start businesses at home after layoffs at nearby I.B.M. plants and other downturns in the economy. So last year they expanded the number of professions permitted to operate within homes.
"We're looking to encourage economic development in our community," said Judith Mayle, the Town Supervisor. "The new thinking is that these small home occupations will be a major force in the economic vitality of the area."
Raymond M. Uhrlass, a respiratory therapist at a hospital just outside the town, is one of the new entrepreneurs who took advantage of the zoning revisions. He went down to town hall one day in January and immediately obtained a permit to open a private practice in his mobile home. "I was suprised at how simple it was to get the permit," he said, adding that his business would not disturb neighbors because he plans to make house calls and use his home office only for work like billing.
He would not have been able to start a business, he said, if he had had to rent an office. "I wouldn't have been able to afford it," said Mr. Uhrlass. "I have a wife and two children to support."

HEADLINE: Republican Says Senators Put Deficit Over Tax Cut

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
The head of the Senate Finance Committee, which oversees tax legislation, said again today that his panel would have little appetite for reducing taxes until Congress had brought the Federal deficit under control.
The remarks by Senator Bob Packwood underscore the widespread presumption that any tax cut even approaching the five-year $189 billion package now in the House is a dead letter in the Senate. 
 "This feeling on the Finance Committee -- Republican and Democrat -- is that the best thing we can do for the taxpayers of this country is just try to move toward deficit reduction," Mr. Packwood, Republican of Oregon, said on the ABC News program "This Week." "And if that gets their mortgage interest rates down a point or two, that is more important than anything else we can do."
Mr. Packwood and many economists say that Federal borrowing to finance daily Government business drains so much money from the economy that it has raised everyone else's cost of borrowing the money that is left. But he and other legislators also say that they believe that average citizens prefer erasing the deficit to widening it with a tax cut.
Mr. Packwood has been saying this for a month, and other senators from both parties have echoed him. On the Finance Committee, senior Republicans like John H. Chafee of Rhode Island question the need for a tax cut. So do the ranking Democrat, Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, and a host of others.
Some also criticize the smaller $63 billion tax cut over five years that President Clinton proposed in February. One Democrat on the Finance Committee, Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, attacked both plans, calling the White House proposal unfortunate and the House plan "a political document."
"I find it very difficult to believe that the Senate will support it, either Republicans or Democrats," Mr. Bradley said of the House plan on the NBC News program "Meet the Press."
Mr. Packwood and others argue that a nation with a total debt approaching $5 trillion and growing by $200 billion a year cannot afford a tax cut. To balance the budget in seven years as promised, Republicans in Congress must already reduce projected spending by at least $1.1 trillion, and any tax cut would increase that figure.
The House Republican proposal would give a $500-per-child tax credit to families earning under $200,000 a year and reduce the capital gains and alternative minimum taxes. Mr. Clinton's proposal offers a similar break to families that are generally less well off and gives cuts to those who pay college tuition or invest for retirement.
Mr. Clinton proposes some spending cuts to offset those breaks. But his budget makes no overall attempt to reach a balance and instead will average $200 billion-a-year deficits through 2000, effectively diminishing the deficit as a percentage of the growing national economy.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Colombia Becoming an Oil Power in Spite of Itself

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TAURAMENA, Colombia

 BODY:
Once defined by creeks and cow paths, the arid landscape of the Andean foothills here is now marked by helicopters, drilling rigs and the cowboy boots of American oilmen.
Foreign oil companies are drilling three miles down, tapping into a sea of low-sulfur crude oil capable of making Colombia a major oil supplier to the United States. 
 "The U.S. could import 10 percent of its oil from Colombia by the end of this decade," said Thomas G. Finck, president of the Triton Energy Corporation of Dallas, who flew here last month for the inauguration of a $300 million oil-processing operation. The tanker trip from Colombia's Caribbean oil port to refineries in Texas and Louisiana takes four days.
With production in the United States at its lowest level in four decades, the emergence of a nearby source of clean-burning oil is increasingly important for Americans. Last year, imports accounted for more than half of American oil consumption. And United States oil companies now account for 11 of the 18 largest foreign oil concerns operating in this country.
Only a decade ago, Colombia was an importer of oil. Today, it is Latin America's third-largest exporter to the United States, after Venezuela and Mexico. With most of Colombia's known oil reserves having been discovered by private companies, private investment will be essential both to maintain future exports and to explore the two-thirds of the country not yet explored for oil.
But in recent years, foreign oil companies have shied away from Colombia because of heavy taxes. The Government has therefore begun to bear more of the cost of oil exploration and development. At the same time, it is planning a series of tax breaks.
And it has attracted the largest oil investment in the country's history. The British Petroleum Exploration Company, with financial assistance from three partners -- Triton of Texas, Total of France and Ecopetrol, Colombia's state oil company -- is undertaking a $7 billion development in Cusiana and Cupiagua, two huge fields near here, about 90 miles northeast of Bogota, the capital.
The oilfields, which cover a thinly populated area the size of Connecticut, hold 2.1 billion barrels in proven oil and gas reserves. Ecopetrol announced late last month that probable and possible oil and gas reserves in the area totaled a further 3.9 billion barrels.
Helped by the oil investments, Colombia's economy is expected to grow 5 percent this year, the same rate as in the last two years. At the fields here, the largest confirmed in Colombia, oil production is expected to increase to 185,000 barrels a day by the end of this year from 90,000 barrels a day at present, and to 500,000 barrels a day by the end of 1997.
Colombia also offers other energy opportunities to Western companies. After British Petroleum announced the discovery of five trillion cubic feet of gas near the oilfields here last August, the Government began a $3 billion program to pipe gas to all urban households by 1997. The new find, equivalent to a billion barrels of oil, doubled Colombia's proven gas reserves.
Centragas, an affiliate of the Enron Corporation of Houston, is building a $217 million, 357-mile natural gas pipeline. Fluor Daniel, another United States company, is part of an international consortium that has won a $310 million contract to build a second 215-mile-long branch of a national gas-pipeline network.
Still, the high cost of doing business in Colombia dampens interest in oil exploration. According to Byron E. Grote, Latin America director for British Petroleum, the Colombian Government takes up to 90 percent of the value of each barrel pumped here by his company. The Government's revenue comes from Ecopetrol's production-sharing agreements and from corporate-income and other taxes.
The Colombian Oil Association, which represents 18 major Western companies, in a recent study of foreign investments, concluded that Colombia "is not internationally competitive to attract risk investments."
Since 1988, seismic studies conducted by private oil companies in Colombia have dropped by about two-thirds. The number of wildcat exploratory wells drilled has also dropped, to about a dozen last year from 52 in 1988.
The disillusion of many foreigners with Colombia's oil conditions became clear last July when Colombia held its first auction of exploration lots. The Mines and Energy Ministry invited 150 companies to take part. Only three companies, all of them already operating in Colombia, submitted bids. Nowadays, the republics of the former Soviet Union as well as China, Vietnam and Cuba are all open to foreign oil exploration.
Colombia's President, Ernesto Samper Pizano, seems to be listening to the oil companies' complaints. He plans to submit to the nation's Congress a bill that would exempt new oil operations from a so-called war tax of $1 a barrel on production. The tax, enacted in 1992, helps pay for the army's defense of oil operations -- favorite targets of Colombia's leftist rural guerrillas, who demand nationalization of the oil industry and more spending for social programs in areas where oil is produced.
Last month, the Government announced that Ecopetrol would also pay more of the exploration costs incurred by its private partners. Ismael Enrique Arenas, an Ecopetrol vice president, said foreign companies are now negotiating for about 10 exploration and production lots.
The test of the new operating environment will come this summer, when Ecopetrol is to hold Colombia's second international auction of exploration lots.
Oil executives who visited the remote processing facility here were divided about the effects of the new measures.
"It is definitely a move in the right direction," said Steven Sparks, general manager of the Colombian subsidiary of Helmerich & Payne, an Oklahoma drilling company.
But the president of a major Western oil company operating here was cautious, saying: "The Government wants the oil money for social development. The war tax is being eliminated, but a new finance minister could come along with something new."

HEADLINE: Phone Bill Brings Out Big-Name Lobbyists

SERIES: Special Pleaders: A period look at lobbying.

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
Howard H. Baker Jr. has been many things over the years, from Senate Republican leader and Presidential candidate to a trusted adviser to President Ronald Reagan. But now the former Tennessee lawmaker is a hired gun -- and this is the week he must prove his worth.
His client: a coalition of long-distance telephone carriers, dominated by AT&T, MCI and Sprint. His mandate: to persuade his former Republican colleagues in Congress to keep the so-called Baby Bell companies out of the long-distance market for at least a few more years. 
 "My role is to craft a strategy and to move the markers of the debate," Mr. Baker said last week, clearly irked by the idea of pleading with politicians who once jumped to do his bidding.
Call him what you want -- statesman, strategist or influence peddler -- Mr. Baker has lots of company. Marlin Fitzwater, chief White House spokesman for President Bush, joins the long-distance team today. Roy M. Neel, a top aide to Vice President Al Gore for 17 years and President Clinton's deputy chief of staff in 1993, is now the top lobbyist for an association of local telephone companies.
And that doesn't even begin to exhaust the "A" list of political movers and shakers hired to influence the debate over rewriting the nation's telecommunications laws. Cable companies, broadcasters, newspapers -- every segment of industry with a stake in a sweeping bill now before Congress -- are fielding an army of high-powered lobbyists.
But is anybody listening? Having wrestled with telecommunications policy for years, key lawmakers are beginning to tune out the noise as never before. Increasingly, they are simply telling the lobbyists to let them get about their business.
"Members of Congress don't think there are any good guys or bad guys in this," said Mr. Neel, who left the White House last year to become president of the United States Telephone Association. "This is not about right or wrong -- it's ultimately about money."
Nonetheless, the big lobbying guns are still being brandished because no side feels it can afford to disarm. With so much at stake, and so little to pin on labels of "right" and "wrong," the various factions are seeking a personal edge by throwing into the fray as many people with friends in high places as possible. All of which has made telecommunications as much of a bonanza for lobbyists this year as health care was last year.
"Everybody in this town who has a pulse has been hired by either the long-distance coalition or the Bell operating companies," said Representative Michael G. Oxley, an Ohio Republican on the Commerce Committee. "It's just amazing."
The battle will be joined this time around on Thursday, when the Senate Finance Committee plans to vote on whether to send the bill to the floor. Broadly, the bill is intended to let local telephone companies, long-distance carriers and cable television providers enter each other's markets. If it passes, it could reshape virtually every corner of the industry by setting off a free-for-all for control of the so-called information superhighway.
After years of stalled debate, Congress came close to passing a similar bill last year. The measure passed the House but died in the Senate, partly because of last-minute opposition from the Bell companies. This year, there is broad support for legislation and many of the disputes have narrowed. Even so, the bill's chances are uncertain.
Senate Republicans and Democrats came close to working out an agreement late Friday on some of the most contentious issues. The chairman of the Commerce Committee, Larry Pressler, Republican of South Dakota, proposed a compromise in which he dropped a provision that would have automatically allowed the Bell companies to enter the long-distance business after three years.
Long-distance carriers immediately rejoiced at the retreat, but the move infuriated the Bell companies and did not immediately win over key Democrats. Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, for example, refused to endorse the plan.
As in years past, all sides proclaim support for the principle of open competition, while each jealously guards its turf. Many lawmakers say they are exasperated by the bickering among the factions they have heard for so long, and their eyes glaze over at the full-page advertisements and breathlessly promoted market studies by industry-financed research groups like Citizens for a Sound Economy and the American Enterprise Institute.
"We've heard these arguments for years now," Senator Pressler said.
The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, put the matter even more bluntly earlier this month in a speech to executives from every industry faction. "You better work this out quickly," he said, "because if you don't, then we're going to do it ourselves and you're not going to like what we do."
But this is Washington, where conflict is the coin of the realm. The communications industry contributed more than $13 million to Congressional campaigns in 1993 and 1994, according to the Center for Responsive Politics in Washington. Local telephone companies contributed $3.1 million, while the long-distance carriers tossed in $1.7 million.
Within weeks after the election last November, Senator Pressler held several fund-raisers here in which communications industry lobbyists contributed $24,500 for the privilege of saying hello.
Some in the industry see themselves locked in an arms race, forced to match rival business groups dollar for dollar.
"It's a hoot, an absolute hoot," Mr. Neel said. "I've heard of consultants who were hired just so they wouldn't be hired by the other side." Of course, Mr. Neel did not get his job by answering an ad in the newspaper, either.
Indeed, it is hard keeping track of all the rival agendas. The Bell companies, hemmed in by the antitrust decree that broke up the Bell system in 1984, want permission to offer long-distance and cable television service and to manufacture equipment. The long-distance carriers want to keep them out of long-distance, at least until the Bells give up their monopolies on local service. Cable television companies want to compete in local telephone service, if possible before the Bell companies are allowed into cable television. The cable companies are also pushing to end rate regulation, and have support from Senate Republicans.
Even traditional television broadcasters have an agenda. They want to relax restrictions on the number of stations a company can own. They also want the freedom to use new channels reserved for high-definition television to offer everything from wireless messaging services to pay-per-view movies.
The Republican sweep over Congress has forced many combatants to rethink their strategy. Long-distance carriers like AT&T knew they were on thinner ice, because Republicans have been much more hostile toward regulation and more supportive about freeing the Bell companies to enter long-distance services and manufacturing.
Mr. Baker, a senior partner in the law firm of Baker & Donaldson, may or may not prove to be the answer. But his credibility among senior Republicans, particularly in the Senate, is unmatched.
On New Year's Eve, Mr. Baker, Senator Dole and otherswere the hosts of a party at the Seaview beachside resort near Miami where they both own condominiums. One of Mr. Baker's personal guests was none other than Senator Pressler.
Some political operatives say Mr. Baker leaves most of the work to his subordinates. He says he wants nothing to do with corralling legislators in hallways. "I told them before they hired me that they already had plenty of lobbyists," said Mr. Baker, positioning himself as more of a senior adviser.
Others in the fray include William Diefenderfer, President Bush's deputy budget director, and the WEFA Group, a leading economic consulting firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., for the Bell companies; Ray Marshall, Secretary of Labor under President Jimmy Carter, for AT[T] Richard E. Wiley, former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, for CBS and the Newspaper Association of America; and Thomas H. Boggs, a legendary all-purpose lobbyist, also for the newspaper group.
What happens if Congress actually passes a bill this year? The most famous and well connected of the hired guns will probably always find new clients and causes. But more than a few mid-level soldiers are quietly nervous.
"Let's face it," an operative for one of the Bell companies said. "This is the big crusade. After this, there's not going to be much opportunity for a lot of us."

HEADLINE: Mr. Kasich's Numbers

 BODY:
The House Budget Committee has released a five-year plan to cut discretionary spending by $100 billion. Or, depending on who does the counting, $177 billion or perhaps $315 billion. The blizzard of numbers confuses debate. But no matter how the G.O.P. decides to count, its budget looks punishing and arbitrary.
The only reasonable sign to emerge from Congress last week was a mild outbreak of party disunity. Faced with the prospect of stiff, sometimes cruel, budget cuts, some moderate Republicans in the House and Senate are beginning to inch away from their commitment to large tax cuts. Senators Pete Domenici, John Chafee and Judd Gregg may not have seemed like paragons of moderation in the past. But they are positioning themselves between the House and fiscal folly. 
 John Kasich, chairman of the House Budget Committee, proposes to cut discretionary spending -- everything from the F.B.I. to defense, but not Social Security or other entitlements -- over five years by $100 billion below actual 1995 levels. But the shortfall would be larger, $180 billion, if Mr. Kasich's budget is measured against amounts that Congress currently intends to spend over the next five years. By the one measure that matters -- spending under Mr. Kasich's budget compared with spending that would be required, after taking account of inflation, to keep Government services whole -- the shortfall would be a whopping $315 billion. In focusing upon the smallest number, Mr. Kasich may have become the only politician in Washington who is prepared to cut more than he is willing to admit.
In the year 2000, Mr. Kasich would have the Government spend $530 billion on discretionary programs, rather than the $630 billion it would take to keep current programs in place -- a huge 20 percent cut. How hard will it be for Congress to find those cuts? Apparently, very hard.
Separately, the House passed last week a $17 billion package of mid-year spending cuts, known as rescissions. Most of the reductions picked on familiar G.O.P. targets such as summer jobs for disadvantage youths and nutrition programs for pregnant women. In one of the few places where Republicans were asked to show courage by taking on a powerful constituency, they backed away from taking a small amount of money from the overbuilt and largely wasteful system of veterans' hospitals.
The battle over rescissions gave moderate Republicans second thoughts about the $200 billion in tax cuts approved by the House tax committee. If passed, these tax cuts will absorb almost all of Mr. Kasich's spending cuts plus $60 billion that the G.O.P. hopes to knock out of welfare programs. The Congressional Republicans would then have to come up with a trillion dollars worth of cuts to fulfill another provision of the Contract With America: balancing the budget within seven years. That would force them to go after Social Security, Medicare and other targets that make the veterans look like pushovers.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Magazines Find Green Pastures Abroad

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY 

 BODY:
Forget about the weak dollar, said George J. Green, who shrugs it off as a minor irritant: These are great times for starting magazines overseas.
Mr. Green, who has been president of Hearst Magazines International since the group was founded in 1989, is looking 5 to 10 years down the road with the goal of developing a large international media operation within Hearst. This year alone he plans to add 8 to 10 new foreign-language magazines, a high number of start-ups for any company. 
 "Europe is coming out of a recession and Asia is strong," he said. "Eastern Europe has potential. We have been successful in Brazil, and Argentina looks good. And now we know how to do business in Russia."
Hearst, with 64 foreign-language editions of eight magazines, is the most aggressive player internationally, but companies like the Reader's Digest Association, Conde Nast Publications and Playboy Enterprises are also active. They, too, view the falling dollar as a temporary fluctuation that has far less importance to their foreign operations than the national economies of the countries in which they publish.
"A weak dollar does not have any great effect either positive or negative on our foreign operations," said Jonathan Newhouse, chairman of Conde Nast International, which publishes 31 magazines through wholly owned companies in five European countries and Australia.
Among the magazines Hearst publishes abroad are Cosmopolitan, Esquire, Good Housekeeping and Popular Mechanics. The magazines, published in 14 languages, are distributed in more than 80 countries. A separate company, the National Magazine Company, publishes nine Hearst magazines in Britain.
Most of the articles are generated by local editorial staffs. The magazines also include translations of articles that have appeared in their original American editions. Some of the magazines operate under licensing agreements in which Hearst allows other publishing companies to use its titles in exchange for royalties, while others are a result of 40 joint venture agreements that allow Hearst to share revenues with foreign publishers.
The runaway success story for Hearst thus far is the start-up a year ago of Cosmopolitan in Russia, where the magazine has been consistently selling out and has been profitable since the first issue.
In 1995 Mr. Green plans to introduce Esquire and Cosmopolitan in Thailand and India, Cosmopolitan in Argentina, and Good Housekeeping and Harper's Bazaar in Russia. He said there might also be two start-ups in Korea, which he declined to identify, and a possible Turkish edition of Popular Mechanics.
American publishers estimate that it costs $5 million to $20 million to start a magazine in the United States. Since Hearst is a privately owned company that does not reveal its finances, Mr. Green declined to disclose the cost of a typical foreign start-up, but he made it clear that it was far below the amount needed to start a magazine in the United States. Since most of its magazines overseas are sold on newsstands, Hearst does not have to spend a lot of money acquiring subscriptions.
In addition, advertising is generally easy to attract from global advertisers like Chanel and Estee Lauder that already have established relationships with other Hearst magazines around the world.
One of the largest American publishers overseas is the Reader's Digest Association. With the start-up of the Polish edition of Reader's Digest in May, the company will have 47 international editions in 18 languages, with a total circulation of 13 million. Nearly all of Reader's Digest's magazines are operated through wholly owned foreign subsidiaries.
"Our plan is to continue launching new editions at the rate of one a year for the next several years," said Craig Lauder, a spokesman for Reader's Digest. "The focus is now going to be toward the Pacific Rim and Latin America."
Mr. Newhouse of Conde Nast said his company had no immediate plans to enter new markets in Europe but was looking to expand in Asia. "I think we are looking very closely at China, Japan, Korea, Hong Kong and Taiwan," he said.
Mr. Newhouse said that 1994 was a good year for the company and that 1995 would be stronger than the last several years. "Advertising is up in every country, business is strong and magazines are up in advertising and circulation," he said.
Playboy, with 16 foreign-language editions, is in the midst of pruning some overseas editions that it says have not lived up to the company's standards. Playboy recently dropped its Hong Kong and Hungarian editions, but there are plans to begin publishing Playboy in Russia as part of a joint venture with Independent Media, a Dutch company that also publishes Cosmopolitan in Russia.
Henry W. Marks, director of international publishing for Playboy Enterprises, predicted that leading publishers of magazines and catalogues would increase their licensing operations around the world.
"There is more and more activity for more and more people," he said. "Everybody has discovered that the markets abroad are worthwhile going after."

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
When Fluidity Replaces Maturity

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:
In Washington, in academia, in the writing of biographies and fiction, several R-words have gained a new ascendancy. The words are "reinvent," "revise," "redefine," "reposition." "rehabilitate" and "redeem."
Shortly after his election, President Clinton put Vice President Al Gore in charge of "reinventing government"; then, after the Republican victory last year he refocused on reinventing himself. He summoned three self-help gurus (Stephen R. Covey, Marianne Williamson and Anthony Robbins) to Camp David last December, while his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, embarked on yet another image make-over with the help of Ann Landers and Cindy Adams. 
 The Clintons are hardly alone in their efforts to shuck off the past and redefine (or rehabilitate) their public images. Marion S. Barry Jr. and Oliver L. North have done their best to disprove F. Scott Fitzgerald's lament that "there are no second acts in American lives," while Gov. Pete Wilson of California was recently tagged by the columnist Anthony Lewis in The New York Times as a "political Zelig" for his repeated repositioning of himself on social issues.
In fact, for many people -- from Jerry Rubin, former Yippie turned entrepreneur, to Jane Fonda, former radical turned mogul's wife -- shape-shifting and metamorphosis seem to have replaced the conventional process of maturation. This same taste for chameleonlike transformation can be found in a host of recent novels, short stories and plays: works of fiction that have subverted the traditional idea of a Bildungsroman, turning it from a naturalistic coming-of-age story into something more hallucinatory and mythic.
The heroes of Stephen Wright's "Going Native" and Russell Banks's forthcoming novel "Rule of the Bone" hit the road, change their names and slip on new identities with the ease of actors changing costumes. Cut off from the past and any sort of familial definition, the characters in Sam Shepard's plays similarly spend their lives trying to manufacture new identities; in some cases, they actually undergo bizarre metamorphoses onstage, in effect becoming fantasy versions of themselves. The hero and heroine in Will Self's novellas "Cock & Bull" hopscotch back and forth across sex lines with Ovidian ease, while the very notion of a discrete personality has become obsolete in Douglas Cooper's novel "Amnesia."
Post-modernist notions of personality have also begun to affect the writing of biographies. More and more studies of artists contend that our views of their lives and works are merely functions of our own prejudices and preoccupations. In "The Mozart Myths," William Stafford examines the wildly disparate portraits of the composer that have come down to us over the years, some depicting him as a perpetual child inept at daily life, others depicting him as a manipulative Don Juan. He contends that successive generations of scholars have reinvented Mozart in their own image, filtering his life through shifting theories of genius and creativity. Gary Taylor makes a similar argument about Shakespeare in "Reinventing Shakespeare," and A. Richard Turner does the same for Leonardo da Vinci in "Inventing Leonardo."
So pervasive has this mutable sense of identity become that the psychiatrist Robert Jay Lifton has coined a name for it: "the protean self." In his recent book of the same name, he writes: "We are becoming fluid and many-sided. Without quite realizing it, we have been evolving a sense of self appropriate to the restlessness and flux of our time. This mode of being differs radically from that of the past and enables us to engage in continuous exploration and personal experiment."
Just why has this notion of a protean self taken hold in society today? In Mr. Lifton's view, it is a response to three historical forces: dislocation brought about by "the breakdown of social and institutional arrangements that ordinarily anchor human lives"; "the mass media revolution," which has given people "omni-access" to events around the world, and the prospect of human extinction (through nuclear war or environmental disaster), which he says "casts doubt in each mind about the self's larger connectedness."
Certainly signs of the flux and restlessness Mr. Lifton describes can be found everywhere one looks. On a superficial cultural level, we are surrounded by images of shape-shifting and reinvention, from sci-fi creatures who "morph" from form to form, to children's toys that metamorphose from people into robots; from Madonna's ever expanding gallery of ready-to-wear personas to New Age mystics who claim they can "channel" other people or remember "previous" lives.
On the global scale, the rapid spread of communications has erased ancient cultural boundaries and eaten away at traditional values, while wars, social upheavals and economic shifts have created waves of refugees and expatriates cut off from their roots. It's a situation vividly delineated by novels like Bharati Mukherjee's "Jasmine" and Salman Rushdie's "Satanic Verses," novels that not only feature characters addicted to change but also depict a world in extremis, a world of shortening attention spans and radical discontinuity, a world in which memory -- the ability to connect the past to the present -- has little if any hold.
There are other reasons, too, for the current predilection for protean change. Post-modernism and deconstruction have given us a fragmented view of the world, teaching us to doubt the very existence of a stable, objective truth; and this emphasis on appearances and perception has been reinforced by all the spin-doctors and marketing consultants who have helped politicians embrace image over idealism, strategy over ideology.
Equally important is the so-called recovery movement, which, as Wendy Kaminer points out in her wittily acute book, "I'm Dysfunctional, You're Dysfunctional," has perpetuated the notion that people can make the requisite journey from trauma to transcendence by confronting their inner demons through confession and public absolution. This movement, fostered by continual talk shows featuring survivors of dysfunction sharing and caring on camera, has not only encouraged people to think of all problems as responsive to easy 12-step solutions but has also galvanized a faith in limitless self-growth, a belief that sins and mistakes are but pit stops on the road to redemption.
As David Maraniss's new biography "First in His Class" attests, President Clinton has long evinced a faith in just this sort of thinking. Mr. Maraniss reports that the young Mr. Clinton, having just lost the Arkansas Governor's seat after one term in office, decided to announce for re-election by running a 30-second commercial in which he spoke of his earlier failings, arguing he would never make the same mistakes again if voters would only give him another chance. He later used a similar strategy of asking for public empathy when confronted with allegations of marital infidelity.
For Mr. Clinton, character "is a journey, not a destination," as he once told the reporter Joe Klein, and this dimly existential view of character as a "lifelong process" oddly echoes Fitzgerald's description, in "The Great Gatsby," of the hero's personality as "an unbroken series of successful gestures."
Like the Comeback Kid and Horatio Alger, Gatsby (a poor boy with romantic dreams who succeeded in inventing "just the sort of Jay Gatsby that a 17-year-old boy would be likely to invent") is a quintessentially American type. This country, after all, was supposed to be a place of new beginnings, a place where class and ancestry and history weren't supposed to matter. Here, people were supposed to be able to spring, like Gatsby, from their "Platonic conception" of themselves; here on the frontier, they were supposed to be able to move on, move up, move ahead.
In "The Protean Self," Mr. Lifton celebrates this sense "that we need never stand still, and that transformation may be just around the corner." As he sees it, proteanism is, all and all, a positive thing, enabling troubled individuals to transcend their pasts, and pressing everyone toward a "human commonality, as opposed to the fixed and absolute moral and psychological divisions favored by fundamentalism."
Mr. Lifton, however, seriously plays down the perils of proteanism -- namely, rootlessness, fragmentation and spinelessness -- and he completely ignores its encouragement of irresponsibility, hypocrisy and perpetual adolescence.
In a recent column, Meg Greenfield argues that Bill and Hillary Clinton "make a real mistake" in thinking "that personal reinvention is an option for those in office." "For one thing," she writes, "it has the opposite of a reassuring effect. It troubles people because it conveys an impression of unsureness and personal wobble and self-concern that is the last thing they want in a leader."
The notion of multiple lives (as in Carol Anshaw's novel "Aquamarine," which gives its heroine three very different sorts of lives) or multiple chances (as in the movie "Groundhog Day," which gives Bill Murray repeated chances to clean up his act) is amusing enough in fiction, but it represents a false option in real life. To believe that one need never really commit to a set of values or beliefs is ultimately to deny accountability, just as to believe that one can continually assume new identities is to end up having no identity at all.

HEADLINE: Eugenio Perente-Ramos Is Dead; Farm Labor Organizer Was 59

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
Eugenio Perente-Ramos, an organizer of migrant and seasonal laborers who founded the Eastern Farm Workers Association on Long Island and was a close associate of Cesar Chavez in the United Farm Workers Organizing Committee, died at his home in Brooklyn on Saturday. He was 59.
The cause was congestive heart failure, said Dan Fiske, a friend and fellow organizer. 
 In 37 years as an organizer, Mr. Perente-Ramos signed up machinists, miners and aerospace workers from New York to Texas and California. But his principal efforts were on behalf of those lowest on the economic ladder and hardest to organize: migrant and seasonal farm workers, domestic help and temporary and part-time workers unprotected by minimum-wage and other Federal labor laws.
Born in 1935 on a rented farm near Butte, Mont., the son of a domestic worker and a man active in the Industrial Workers of the World, Mr. Perente-Ramos trained as a machinist but went to work for the Agricultural Workers Organizing Committee in the 1950's. Later, he helped organize 50,000 machinists and other workers at Boeing, Lockheed and other aerospace companies.
In the 1960's, when his group merged with Mr. Chavez's National Farm Workers Association, he became a member of the general executive board of the United Farm Workers under Mr. Chavez and helped organize farm workers in California and Texas. He also was chairman of the Chavez-for-Governor Committee in California.
In the early 1970's, Mr. Perente-Ramos founded the Eastern Farm Workers Association and led 800 migrant and seasonal workers in a strike against potato processers in Suffolk County. It was the first successful drive -- after many failures -- to organize farm workers east of the Mississippi, Mr. Fiske said. The group now represents 10,000 workers on Long Island, he said.
Mr. Perente-Ramos, who left no survivors, lectured often on labor organizing and was the author of "The Essential Organizer," a 1973 book detailing his theory of systemic organization, in which permanent cadres of volunteers, and not leaders with short-lived charisma, are relied upon to conduct boycotts and other long-term activities on behalf of labor.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 21, 1995, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary of Eugenio Perente-Ramos yesterday gave an incomplete and partly inaccurate account of his activities and life. The article noted that he was an organizer of migrant and seasonal labor, but information from his associates omitted the fact that he was also the leader of a group that has been characterized as a cult. A corrected version, with fuller accounts by cult experts, parents of followers and a former wife of Mr. Perente-Ramos, appears today on page D20.
