HEADLINE: Bad Bargain for Children

 BODY:
As Congressional Republicans shred the social safety net, gaping holes are opening in programs designed to protect the nation's most vulnerable children -- the victims of abuse and neglect. As part of the assault on welfare, House Republicans want to overhaul federally funded foster care and adoption services. They would consolidate many existing programs into block grants and chop funding by nearly $3 billion. For a system that is already overburdened and underfunded, these proposals could spell disaster.
The child welfare system is a patchwork of programs, usually run by states and counties, that protect abused and neglected children and offer services to troubled families where children are at risk. It also helps families who take responsibility for neglected and abandoned children through foster care or adoption. The system has grown as families and neighborhoods, devastated by the economy, drugs and alcohol, have disintegrated. In 1993, almost three million children were reportedly abused or neglected, an increase of 130 percent from a decade earlier. Nearly 450,000 children were in foster care. 
 In many states, children are victimized as much by the child welfare system as by their families. They are often left too long with abusive relatives or languish in foster care for years without reasonable plans for permanent placements.
Since 1980, Washington has tried to impose minimal standards on states receiving Federal funds for child welfare programs. The standards require states to provide written plans for each child, with recommended services and timetables to move children into or out of foster care, help them return to their families or make them eligible for adoption or other permanent placement.
Now House Republicans seek to remove even these minimal protections, while imposing harmful budget cuts. In a plan approved by the House Ways and Means Committee, about two dozen Federal child welfare programs would be consolidated into one block grant per state, with overall funding reduced by $2.9 billion over five years.
Proponents insist that the loss of funds will be more than offset by increased program flexibility and reduced administrative burdens. Giving states more flexibility and less paperwork is desirable. But the new plan would scrap virtually all standards and prohibit Washington from exercising any meaningful oversight.
In addition, funds to individual states would be capped, leaving state and local governments to pick up the tab if caseloads soar. For New York, where both Gov. George Pataki and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani have proposed severe cuts in child welfare, the results could be particularly damaging.
As the plan heads for a vote in the House this week, supporters may think this is a good bargain for the states. But it's a bad bargain for children.

HEADLINE: KEY SENATE PANEL AGREES TO PURSUE BIG SPENDING CUTS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee said today that both Republicans and Democrats on the panel were prepared to make spending cuts "of an immense magnitude" -- up to $700 billion by 2002 -- to erase the Federal deficit if both parties will give their political blessing.
The chairman, Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, said the committee's members reached a consensus in support of huge budget cuts during a weekend retreat on the Chesapeake Bay. The retreat was attended by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who said they had also agreed that tax reductions should be postponed either until the deficit has been tamed or until responsible experts can prove that specific tax cuts will not raise the Federal debt. 
 "If there are any spending cuts of any magnitude that are real, we ought to consider -- before we consider tax cuts -- whether or not we would like to use that money to reduce the deficit," Mr. Packwood said in a speech today to the National Association of Manufacturers.
Other Finance Committee members said that big tax cuts were as good as dead in the committee and that procedural obstacles would make it difficult to steer such legislation to Senate passage by other routes.
That appears to put the panel at odds with more conservative Republicans in the Senate and especially the House, where Speaker Newt Gingrich has endorsed a five-year package of business and personal tax cuts totaling $189 billion.
The Finance Committee oversees all tax legislation and most of the mandatory programs, like Medicare and Social Security, that consume 70 percent of Federal spending. The annual Federal budget must pass through the committee on the way to a floor vote in the Senate. An accord on the deficit among committee members would be a major development, if it lasted.
But as Mr. Packwood himself said today, the forces working to unglue the agreement were many and strong. As if to prove it, the Senator barely finished his plea for shared sacrifice before his audience began peppering him for assurances that a swarm of corporate tax cuts and loopholes would either be enacted or preserved.
The political prospects for the agreement are also cloudy.
Mr. Packwood said today that any budget accord would fail unless the leaders of both parties showed "the courage and the will and a willingness to forgo partisan hammering" over the painful impact of spending reductions.
Mr. Rubin could not be reached for comment on the weekend's proceedings. But other Clinton Administration officials viewed a Republican helping hand with trepidation, noting that President Clinton's last package of spending cuts and tax increases, in 1993, passed without a single Republican vote.
Nor is it clear how much support the Finance Committee's majority of fiscal moderates will get from the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, who is also a committee member. Mr. Dole's candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination rests in part on his ability to attract conservative support, and conservatives are the principal supporters of the tax cuts that the committee opposes.
One participant in the retreat said today that the 15 or so legislators who attended had nevertheless agreed, almost unanimously, that deficit reduction was "the first, second and third order of priority" in this year's budget.
Another, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, summarized the senators' view on deficit reduction with a single word: "Now. And with great emphasis at this meeting. Now."
Mr. Packwood stressed, as have many Republicans before him, that balancing the budget was not literally a matter of cutting spending, but merely slowing the rate at which spending is growing. Federal spending is expected to rise by a total of about $3 trillion between now and 2002, he said, and restraining that growth to $2 trillion would probably reduce the deficit to zero.
That is much more difficult than it sounds, because both parties have refused to restrain the most expensive program, Social Security. And the programs growing at a breakneck pace, like Medicare and Federal pensions, are fiercely protected by beneficiaries or private companies, like health care providers, that profit from them.
House Republicans have also pledged to balance the budget by 2002, but have yet to propose more than a handful of specific spending cuts or reductions in growth. Mr. Packwood proposed very few today himself, but he differed from his House counterparts in that he said he had Democratic support for whatever cuts might be forthcoming.
Mr. Moynihan said committee members had generally agreed that the deficit should be attacked now, with the economy running at full steam and unemployment as low as it is likely to get, rather than later, when an economic slowdown will increase spending on the jobless and the poor.
And he said now was precisely the wrong time to cut taxes and give an already-hot economy a spending jolt that could ignite inflation.
Mr. Moynihan and a second leading Democrat on the panel, John B. Breaux of Louisiana, said they came away from the weekend session optimistic that the committee would find a long and specific list of spending reductions, even with the political wrangling that always accompanies the budget.
"I think the problem is big enough for both of our parties to work on at the same time," Mr. Breaux said.
He said he expected the Finance Committee to prepare its own deficit proposal "later rather than sooner," probably as budget legislation nears its final votes in Congress in July.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 22, 1995, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about plans for cuts in Federal spending misattributed a statement that senators on the Finance Committee had agreed to postpone tax reductions that might increase the Federal debt. The speaker was the committee chairman, Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, not Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
AT&T Cutbacks in Japan Rattle Old Sensibilities

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 21

 BODY:
In a drab industrial district of Tokyo, where the AT&T Corporation runs some Japanese operations, workers are handing out pamphlets attacking the American company's "bullying" of employees.
A half-day walkout has already been carried out, and the union is threatening a full-fledged strike if AT&T does not stop conduct it regards as outrageous. The problem is that AT&T is being assailed for doing what American companies think they should be doing: cutting costs to improve the bottom line. 
 "We cannot accept that this is a company that is making a profit, but to make more of a profit it is trying to cut jobs," said Akira Hashimoto, a union official. "It's trying to cut people with 20 to 30 years in the company, with a heavy responsibility at home, who cannot easily find new jobs."
The labor dispute is small potatoes by international standards, involving fewer than 4,000 employees. But it offers a window into contrasting perceptions in the United States and Japan about corporate responsibility -- and into the personal pain that is emerging as Japanese companies get tougher with employees.
In times of recession, shareholders ordinarily do better in the United States and workers fare better in Japan. But differences in employer behavior in the two countries are lessening, and labor unions say that more Japanese companies are acting like AT&T -- moving to cut costs even when longtime employees bear the burden. This more aggressive approach is straining Japan's lifetime employment system and perhaps helping to reshape the country's labor market.
AT&T has not actually laid off anyone in Japan, and says it has no plans to. Likewise, very few Japanese companies have dismissed employees. But the outcry over austerity measures, which to Americans might seem tame, demonstrates the extraordinary sensitivity of Japanese workers to any threat to interests that have long been held sacred.
The union leaders subscribe to a traditional Japanese view of a large company as a big family. To them, layoffs are as shocking as if a parent dumped children with a taste for steak and replaced them with potato-eaters who were cheaper to feed.
Most American companies, including AT&T, tend to see themselves more as shoppers trying to get the best deal. And it would be an unusual shopper who continued to patronize one store if another slashed its prices.
The current confrontation has its roots in AT&T's 1991 purchase of the NCR Corporation. The unit, renamed AT&T Global Information Solutions, has been a drag on the parent company, losing money in 1993 before struggling into the black last year. So AT&T has been closing its plants and cutting thousands of jobs.
In Japan, no one has been laid off, but the changes have been tumultuous by Japanese standards: A factory that makes cash registers and computers will no longer export them; a printing plant will move from a Tokyo suburb to a more remote area where costs are lower; repair workers are being spun off into a new subsidiary with a pay system that is more dependent on their performance. The workers are being abruptly reassigned at what they believe will be less pay.
The American telecommunications giant contends that it is playing by Japanese rules. "It's AT&T's view that each unit has to be viable and stand on its own two feet," said Mark R. Newburg, senior managing director of AT&T Global Information Solutions Japan Inc. "There are some efficiencies that we're trying to get, but we're working very hard to comply with Japanese labor laws as well as labor practices." He stressed that the new pay arrangement for service workers could lead to higher as well as lower incomes.
Some AT&T employees do not see the company in so charitable a light.
"This would be unthinkable in a Japanese company," Mr. Hashimoto, the union official, said. While a Japanese employer might take some of these measures, it would phase them in over several years and consult workers more, he said.
Many big Japanese companies, reluctant to engage in large-scale layoffs, instead eliminate overtime, move people around and even cut pay. That is why Japan's unemployment rate is 2.9 percent, compared with 5.4 percent in the United States, despite a four-year recession here.
"The first priority of a Japanese company is its employees; the second priority is its customers, and the third priority is its stockholders," said Mitsuya Goto, a former Nissan Motor Company executive who now runs a consulting company.
Yet to the dismay of union members, Japanese companies are clearly moving in American corporate direction. Nissan, for example, has reportedly worked out a plan to cut labor costs by shedding 6,000 to 7,000 jobs, though without layoffs.
A few companies have gone so far as to dismiss workers, but that is rare. Still, a job is so much a part of a person's identity in Japan that the prospect of being sloughed off on a subcontractor and taking a pay cut terrifies many Japanese.
"These things used to happen just in foreign-invested companies," said Teizo Hotta, an executive of AT&T Japan Ltd. "Now they're happening in Japanese companies, too."
To an American ear, the Japanese union's arguments may sound quaint, a bit like the charming old restaurants in Tokyo with armies of hostesses and bills that make you feel as if you've just bought the restaurant.
Indeed, the unions do not just resist cutbacks; they sometimes urge corporations to hire more people and pay them higher salaries. "Leading multinational companies like AT&T have a responsibility to maintain employment and even expand employment," Mr. Hashimoto said.
Clashes with foreign companies over what Japanese unions view as their rude behavior and unseemly haste to make money have been common. To the unions, the corporations act like overbearing foreign tourists who barge into Japanese homes without removing their shoes or plunge into communal baths without first scrubbing themselves clean.
These days, the tensions are becoming more acute, according to Eichi Yamane, secretary general of the Japan Association of Companies with Foreign Capital. "With the yen soaring, the salaries in Japan are looking out of whack to the people in headquarters," Mr. Yamane said.
Masaru Takagi, chief economist at the Fuji Research Institute in Tokyo, said change was long overdue. "Japanese companies can't keep the levels of labor they did 10 years ago," Mr. Takagi said. "The basic trend is moving toward the U.S. system. Maybe even layoffs will become more common in the future."

HEADLINE: Pakistan Asks for U.S. Help in Crackdown on Militants

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 21

 BODY:
Under growing pressure to crack down on Muslim militants suspected of plotting terrorist attacks abroad, Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto said today that her Government favored closing clandestine training centers in Pakistan's North-West Frontier Province but would need help from the United States.
"We in Pakistan simply don't have the resources on our own to carry out the entire cleansing operation," said Ms. Bhutto, who met with American reporters ahead of a two-day visit by Hillary Rodham Clinton that begins this weekend. Prime Minister Bhutto is scheduled to meet with President Clinton in Washington next month. 
 The Pakistani leader said she would appeal to the United States and to other countries to help her close down suspected bases of Arab and Asian militants, including Muslim religious schools and other organizations that have been used as fronts for terrorist activities.
Questioning of terrorist suspects seized recently in Peshawar, the capital of North-West Frontier Province, has revealed that the suspected mastermind of the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center in New York made a botched attempt to kill Ms. Bhutto during the 1993 election campaign that returned her to power, Pakistani newspapers reported last weekend.
The suspect, Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, was captured in a boarding house in Islamabad six weeks ago and was immediately deported to New York.
The newspaper reports quoted unidentified police officials as saying that Mr. Yousef had accidentally detonated a bomb he originally intended to place under a manhole cover near Ms. Bhutto's family home in Karachi in September 1993. The reports said Mr. Yousef was treated for injuries to his hands at the Aga Khan hospital in Karachi and released.
Confirming the reports, Ms. Bhutto said Pakistan had not known the extent of the terrorist underground here or its international links until Mr. Yousef's arrest by American and Pakistani agents in Islamabad on Feb. 7 set off a wider inquiry.
"It was deeply disturbing to Pakistan that somebody who is an international terrorist should have such deep roots within Pakistan, and that he should seek to influence the course of an election," she said.
Ms. Bhutto, who met with the reporters at the Prime Minister's sumptuous residence on a 35-acre estate overlooking Islamabad, said that the police are also looking for an uncle of Mr. Yousef. She did not identify him but said that he had recently disappeared from his position as the director of an Arab assistance organization in Peshawar, one of a cluster of Arab social, educational and relief organizations being investigated for possible terrorist links.
The Prime Minister added that the police had "plenty of photographs" of the man with what Ms. Bhutto described as "higher-ups in Pakistan."
The Pakistani leader said the photographs "could be innocent, or not," and that the police would investigate to determine whether Mr. Yousef's terrorist connections extended to influential people in Pakistan.
There is a growing sense among Pakistanis that those responsible for the widespread lawlessness that has swept the country in recent years -- the drug barons who control the country's pervasive heroin-trafficking, the armed gangs that have run amok in Karachi, and the terrorist underworld in Peshawar -- are protected by a network of influential politicians and businessmen.
Ms. Bhutto hinted that powerful forces are arrayed against the Government when she said that Pakistan could not move on its own against terrorists.
While her Government is prepared to move against "drug barons, militants and terrorists" in a way that previous governments have not, she said, "Pakistan on its own cannot just go and shut down" terrorist training camps, religious schools and other places used as terrorist fronts because doing so would prompt the militants to fan out across Pakistan and step up their campaign of violence.
Ms. Bhutto said her message to the United States would be: "You are a fair nation. You have been our allies. Help us to overcome militancy and terrorism."
In these and other remarks, she appeared to be suggesting that the Clinton Administration should bolster Pakistan's stability by moving to restore aid programs that were worth more than $600 million annually before Washington cut off all economic and military assistance to the country in 1990. The aid was suspended in a dispute over Pakistan's nuclear weapons program.
But aides to the Pakistani leader said her call for American help was also a reference to the use of United States influence in persuading other governments, particularly in the Middle East and North Africa, to take back their own nationals who have joined terrorist groups here.
Police officials and diplomats have said that the Peshawar underground may have as many as 1,000 members drawn from a wide range of Arab countries, including Algeria, Tunisia, Egypt, Iraq, Jordan, Saudi Arabia and the Sudan, as well as from nations in Central Asia and the Far East, including the Philippines.
A series of events has drawn international attention to Pakistan's role as a base for terrorists. On March 8, gunmen in a stolen taxicab shot and killed two Americans who were traveling to work at the American consulate in Karachi. Some suspect that they were killed in revenge for the arrest of Mr. Yousef, who faces a jail term of as much as 240 years if he is convicted in a bombing conspiracy trial in New York. The World Trade Center blast killed 6 people and injured more than 1,000.
Last week Pakistani investigators said that telephone calls Mr. Yousef made from Islamabad to Peshawar in the hours before his arrest had led them to six, and later several more, associates of Mr. Yousef who are being held on suspicion of involvement in an Arab-led terrorist underground in Peshawar and in Quetta, a city in west-central Pakistan that the police say has also been a sanctuary for terrorists.
It was in questioning those suspects, who include at least three Arabs and an Iranian, that Pakistani officials say they learned about the bombing attempt against Ms. Bhutto and of the involvement in the Peshawar underground of several relatives of Mr. Yousef, including two of his brothers who are now on a police watch list.

HEADLINE: Year's Effort by 5-Nation Group Accomplishes Little in Bosnia

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: PARIS, March 21

 BODY:
With great fanfare last spring, the United States, Russia, France, Britain and Germany formed the so-called contact group, confident that their collective diplomatic might would enable them to press Bosnia's warring factions to make peace.
A year has passed, and not only does peace in Bosnia seem as elusive as ever, but many diplomats also say the contact group is on the brink of falling apart. Nowadays, the five major powers seem to spend more energy quarreling among themselves about Bosnia than exerting pressure on the Muslims, Serbs and Croats. 
 In the type of understatement diplomats are known for, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Robert Frasure, the chief American representative to the group, said, "I would be misleading you if I tried to convince you that the contact group as an organization is working with perfection and smoothness right now."
There are as many differences within the group as there are members. The Clinton Administration says it wants the United Nations to lift the arms embargo against Bosnia's Muslim-led Government to step up pressure on Bosnian Serbs, but Britain, France and Russia oppose ending the embargo.
France has proposed a summit meeting of the leaders of the contact group and the former Yugoslav republics, but American officials say the idea is premature and bound to fail.
American diplomats complain that Britain and France are all too eager to make concessions to President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia to cajole him into pushing the Bosnian Serbs to make peace.
"The situation right now within the contact group is total disarray," said one of the Administration's top policy makers on the Balkans. "At this point, people will have to decide whether the contact group has any usefulness left or not."
In the group's biggest controversy, the United States and the Europeans insist that economic sanctions on Serbia should not be lifted until it formally recognizes Bosnia and Croatia. But Andrei V. Kozyrev, the Russian Foreign Minister, told President Milosevic last month to grant recognition only after sanctions were removed.
"The idea for the contact group was we were going to come up with a position, stick to it and use our leverage to make it happen," one American diplomat said. "The contact group has stumbled badly, primarily because Russia has often gone off on its own. The Russians have used the group as a means to advance the Serbs' agenda, rather than to impose the contact group's position."
Secretary of State Warren Christopher flew to Europe today to meet with the French Foreign Minister, Alain Juppe, and to meet with Mr. Kozyrev on Wednesday and Thursday in Geneva.
Aides accompanying Mr. Christopher said one purpose of the trip is to revive the contact group and push the stalled peace negotiations forward. At his meeting with Mr. Kozyrev, Mr. Christopher plans to discuss differences over not just Bosnia, but also Chechnya, NATO expansion and Russia's plans to build nuclear reactors in Iran.
The contact group can boast of a few, limited achievements. It helped persuade Mr. Milosevic to close Serbia's border with Bosnian Serbs, a closing that American officials say is full of holes. In perhaps its most important accomplishment, it put together a peace plan that would give Bosnia's Government 51 percent of Bosnia's territory and the Bosnian Serbs 49 percent.
Bosnia's Government has accepted the plan, while Mr. Milosevic has given it his grudging, partial blessing. But the Bosnian Serbs, who control 70 percent of Bosnia's land, have rejected it.
Bosnian officials have repeatedly criticized the contact group for creeping appeasement of the Serbs. They note that the contact group at first said Bosnian Serbs must accept the group's peace plan, but then it said they need only accept it in principle as a point of departure for negotiations in which the Muslims and Serbs might swap some land.
The best way to reinvigorate the contact group, some diplomats say, would be to have the foreign ministers of the five countries meet regularly, a move that could increase the group's visibility and press members to thrash out their differences.

HEADLINE: Fleeing America's Relentless Pace, Some Adopt an Amish Life

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER 

DATELINE: CHESTERHILL, Ohio, March 15

 BODY:
This town of fewer than 400 people in southeastern Ohio, founded by Quakers and now home to a sizable community of old-order Amish, has always been a place apart, a quiet celebration of simplicity. Its newest business, the nonprofit Center for Plain Living, will do nothing to disturb that tradition.
The center, a clearinghouse of criticism of technology-driven American culture, is little more than a desk, a table, an old printing press and several lamps housed in a 19th-century photography studio. Yet it is a distinctly visible symbol of a small migration of families from East Coast and Midwest cities and suburbs, many with no previous rural ties, to a new and quiet life in which they adopt the customs and even the religious beliefs of the Amish, other Mennonites or the most conservative of the Quaker sects, the plain Quakers. 
 Prompting this movement is the sense that people are losing control of their lives, largely as a result of the increase in stress and alienation bestowed by technology. "We've moved to a whole new speed in how we live," said Scott Savage, a 35-year-old former librarian who helped found the center four years ago and is now its director. "We started with the horse and buggy, and then to the automobile, and now we're moving at electronic speed. We're finding that people can't live at that speed. We're being crushed by the way we live, and it's on everybody's mind. It's right there on the surface."
Nobody knows exactly how many "homecomers," as these refugees are called, have migrated to plain living. But Mr. Savage puts the total at several hundred during the last year alone in Ohio and five surrounding states.
The center's philosophy -- rejection of technology coupled with a quest for healthier rural economies, a cleaner environment and a less frantic, more meditative life style -- is an amalgam of the 1960's back-to-the-land movement and the 1990's emphasis on family values.
Mr. Savage grew up in a Cleveland suburb as a liberal Quaker, accepting of modern culture, and holds a master's degree in library science from Kent State University. Now he, his wife and their two children are plain Quakers. With his long beard, black suit, white cotton shirt and straw hat, he is often mistaken for one of the Amish farmers who raise their cows and corn among the steep ridges outside Chesterhill.
Sometimes his appearance attracts rude behavior. Last year, he said, he was "semi-mobbed by camera-crazed tourists" when he stopped on a Saturday afternoon at Lehman's Hardware, an Amish supply store in the town of Kidron, to the north. Across the street, other tourists surrounded the bench where his 30-year-old wife, Mary Ann, also distinctively attired, was waiting with their children.
Such moments remind the Savages how far they have wandered from their old lives in the mainstream. But they are not alone on this quiet tributary: at the 159-year-old Quaker meeting house next door to their home, they worship with several other young former suburbanites who have adopted the life of plain Quakers.
"We are doing something offbeat," said Mr. Savage, "and somebody who's never considered it would think this is totally ridiculous. But we keep talking about it and writing about it. And when you do that in a personal way, one on one, you get past all the self-defensiveness, and the snickering just disappears."
Although the Center for Plain Living has sponsored programs on rural development, its focus is Plain, a bimonthly magazine that is both a thoughtful exploration of Amish and other Mennonite cultures and a provocative critique of modern American life.
In Plain, emotional turmoil and environmental deterioration are attributed to technology, the automobile, blind pursuit of career at the expense of family, rampant consumerism and children's lives so tightly structured that they have no time for free play.
The path to a less frantic life, the magazine teaches, begins with throwing out the family television and computer, then substituting sweat for electronics, generalists for specialists, and, where possible, bicycles and horses for cars.
More than 5,000 families have subscribed to Plain since the first issue was published 18 months ago. Part of the magazine's appeal is the Savages' serialization of their experiences in gradually abandoning technology.
Not that they have been able to do without every possible convenience. Mr. Savage -- who, faithful to the tenets of his plain Quaker faith, declined to be photographed -- works at Ohio University in Athens writing grants for the medical college and so must commute 25 minutes each way by car. The family's rented house has electric lights and a telephone. And Mrs. Savage, a professed radio addict, is still getting over her decision last year to give away the family's radio, her last connection to the electronic media.
What is more, Plain is edited and set on a computer and printed with modern offset presses. Mr. Savage is working with Seth Hinshaw, a young plain Quaker printer from North Carolina, to acquire and use hand-powered movable-type presses, but the transition is expensive and likely to take at least another year.
Such inconsistencies, which Mr. Savage details in each issue of Plain, attract occasional criticism among the 40 to 80 letters that the magazine receives each week. More frequently, though, readers respond to the magazine with high praise. After seeing the first issue, which dealt with agriculture, Craig Zolodger, an agricultural extension agent in Santa Clara, Calif., wrote, "You are giving voice to very deep feelings about what is wrong with society and, more importantly, offering hope and vision about what can be done to correct the dis-ease we are all experiencing."
And in response to an issue on threats posed by the information superhighway, Michael S. New, who identified himself as a computer specialist from Fort Worth, wrote: "The computer in the business world has replaced the requirement for face-to-face contact and trust building with an ever-accelerating and paranoid passion for precision. Those unable to see both edges of this sword, or to relish your noble though occasionally disagreeable alternative view, are already servants of the machine."
 
From Plain Magazine, Plain Voices

 
"My husband and I have lived without television for a long time -- the four years of our marriage plus at least five prior years, separately, for each of us. It has been more recently that we've given up radio as well. For over a year now we've lived without voices in our home save those of the real, live people who live here or those of visiting friends." MARY ANN LIESER
 
"My antipathy toward the automobile goes way back. For a period as a young child I refused to ride in the car unless coerced into it, because its noise frightened me. I had similar reactions to vacuum cleaners and flush toilets." CHRIS ROTH

HEADLINE: Whitewater Salesman Pleads Guilty to Fraud

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
The Arkansas real estate salesman who handled the Clintons' land dealings pleaded guilty today in Little Rock, Ark., to two charges of bankruptcy fraud, giving the Whitewater special counsel a witness with detailed knowledge of the venture.
The man, Chris V. Wade, handled the finances of the failed Whitewater enterprise from its earliest days and worked closely with James B. McDougal, the owner of a failed Arkansas savings and loan and Bill and Hillary Clinton's partner in the Whitewater Development Company. 
 "Mr. Wade has pledged to actively cooperate with our ongoing investigation and to provide complete, truthful and accurate information to the U.S. through the office of the independent counsel," the Whitewater special counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, told reporters shortly after Mr. Wade entered his plea in Federal District Court. "That cooperation has already begun."
Under the plea agreement, Mr. Wade faces a sentence of 12 to 18 months in prison. The sentence can be reduced to 10 to 16 months if Mr. Starr deems that Mr. Wade has provided "substantial assistance."
Mr. Starr is investigating, among other things, whether Mr. McDougal illegally diverted federally insured money from the Madison Guaranty Savings and Loan Association, which he owned. Madison later collapsed at a cost to the taxpayers of more than $60 million. The Clintons and Mr. McDougal bought the Whitewater land in 1978, before Mr. McDougal owned the savings and loan.
When interest rates rose in the early 1980's, Mr. Wade was unable to sell many of the Whitewater lots. The White House has acknowledged that Mr. McDougal ended up investing about twice as much as the Clintons to pay the mortgage and other obligations.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation has already asked Mr. Wade about a transaction in April 1985 in which Mr. McDougal raised about $35,000 to pay off bank loans that the Clintons had taken out to finance Mr. Clinton's 1984 re-election campaign for governor.
According to Whitewater's check register, on March 22, 1985, Mr. McDougal wrote a $25,000 check on Whitewater's account at Madison Guaranty to Ozark Realty, Mr. Wade's company in Flippin, Ark. At the time, the Whitewater account's balance stood at $258.
The check was paid, but the account remained overdrawn until April 9, when Mr. McDougal shifted money from another of his real estate ventures. A few weeks later Mr. McDougal held a fund-raising event at Madison, and gave the campaign checks totaling about $35,000, including $12,000 in cashiers checks that investigators suspect may have been diverted from the savings and loan.
Mr. Wade said in an interview last year that he and his wife contributed no more than $3,000 at the fund-raising event. He said that the $25,000 check, which was identified in the Clinton campaign's 1992 report on Whitewater as a real estate commission, was actually a down payment from Mr. McDougal for a venture that was never consummated. Mr. Wade said that soon after, he wrote a check back to Mr. McDougal for the same amount, though it is not clear what happened to the money.
Federal agents found substantial evidence about Mr. Wade's business dealings, according to the charges filed today in Little Rock. Although he was not charged with tax fraud, Mr. Wade agreed to file amended returns for 1989 through 1993 "in which defendant received income he previously did not report."
The two charges filed against Mr. Wade stem from his November 1990 bankruptcy filing. He owed four unsecured creditors $489,120, including $83,883 to the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency that deals with failed savings and loans.
Prosecutors charge that Mr. Wade fraudulently concealed his ownership of one Whitewater lot from the Federal bankruptcy court.
According to charges filed today, Mr. Wade had an intermediary pose as the landowner and fill out a false application for a $45,000 loan from an Arkansas bank. Mr. Wade then appraised the land himself and falsely asserted on the documents that he had no interest in it. The bank eventually made the loan, and Mr. Wade used it to build a house, the court papers said.

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall on Inflation Fears Raised by March Retail Sales Data

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Breaking a three-session rally, traders bid stock prices sharply downward, after an unexpectedly strong retail sales report fanned fears of inflation. The same report drove down bond prices, despite a surprise strengthening in the dollar overseas.
In the absence of similar market-moving economic reports, the dollar may be the main driver of the stock and bond markets in advance of the policy-setting meeting of the Federal Reserve on Tuesday. 
 But the dollar may have only short-lived speculative reasons for rising, analysts said. "When markets start trending, a lot of people who are not normally in the market start swooning and say, 'Oh, this will be easy money,' " said Graham Broyd, managing director for foreign exchange at Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale. "We call these people amateurs."
The value of the dollar is important to the stock market because a weaker dollar penalizes foreign investors, who have become an increasingly important source of capital for the financial markets in the United States. The Dow Jones industrial average, for example, has risen 6.21 percent so far this year in terms of dollars, but has fallen 3.08 percent in terms of German marks.
The plight of the dollar is "worrisome" for stocks, said Dirk van Dijk, equity strategist for C. H. Dean & Associates, which manages $4 billion in stocks and bonds. "You've got the world reserve currency, the dollar, for the most part, going down the tubes."
At any rate, the Dow rose as much as 26 points, before falling and then plummeting at 2:55 P.M., when Johnson Redbook, a research firm, announced that the estimated March retail sales were six-tenths of 1 percent higher than the February sales. The projection was higher than the gain of one-tenth of 1 percent that traders had expected.
By the end of the day, the Dow had fallen 11.07 points, to 4,072.61. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.07 points, to 495.07, and the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 0.71 point, to 809.78.
Bond prices also fell sharply, reacting to the possibility that the overheating economy could produce higher inflation. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 7.44 percent from 7.39 percent. Yields and prices move in opposite directions.
The dollar, meanwhile, rose against most leading currencies yesterday. The dollar rose against the mark, helped by comments by central bankers in Germany and France. The president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, said yesterday about German interest rates that "I will take everything into account to see whether there is room for a small rate cut." A cut would make the mark less valuable and the dollar more valuable to international currency traders.
But the dollar, which ended slightly lower against the Japanese yen, remains fragile.
Among the stocks moving the market yesterday, Kmart rose 1, to 13, adding $457 million to its market capitalization. The longtime chief executive of Kmart, Joseph E. Antonini, resigned yesterday. FSI International, which makes equipment for building silicon wafers, rose 3 5/8, to 42 3/4, after the company reported a rise in its second-quarter earnings to 57 cents a share, from 23 cents a share in the corresponding period a year ago.
Ascend Communications, a maker of telecommunications equipment, rose 3 1/4, to 63 1/2, after several analysts raised their earnings estimates for 1995.
The Norand Corporation, a maker of computer equipment, fell 63/16 , to 359/16 , after analysts questioned whether new products were hurting profit margins. Casino Data Systems, a maker of gambling equipment, fell 3, to 12, after its management said first-quarter earnings would fall 5 cents to 10 cents a share below Wall Street's estimates of 27 cents a share.
The volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above normal, with 367.1 million shares changing hands, about 12 percent higher than the daily average of 329 million shares this year.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 15 fell, led by I.B.M., which fell 1 1/4, to 82 1/4. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 226 stocks fell, led by SBC Communications, formerly Southwestern Bell, which fell 1 1/2, to 41 3/4.
The most active stock, with 26.4 million shares traded, was RJR Nabisco, which rose 5/16 , to 6 1/8.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Decline Sharply on Report of Robust Retail Sales

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities tumbled yesterday after a retailing industry report rattled investors' belief that the economy was slowing.
The market began with early gains in quiet trading, only to be jolted from its lull in the afternoon by the strength shown in a survey of the nation's leading department stores by the Johnson Redbook Service, a New York-based retailing consultant. The survey indicated that retail sales growth through the third week of March was a strong six-tenths of 1 percent; most economists had expected no change. The surprising gain challenged investor expectations of slower economic growth and subdued inflation. 
 In another report yesterday, the Treasury said that the Federal budget deficit ran $38 billion in February, slightly lower than expected and better than the $41.6 billion deficit seen in February 1994.
"The details of the latest budget report confirmed that the slowdown in tax refunds is not a myth and may go a long way in explaining the current consumption pause," Anthony Chan, chief economist for Banc One Investment Advisors, said. But, he added, "when these refunds begin to hit the mailboxes, we're likely to see an additional bounce back in consumer consumption, and retailers may start to see that stories of the demise of consumer spending were greatly exaggerated."
Mr. Chan also suggested that a bounce in retail sales could lead to a rebound in housing as well, indicating that the economy might be about to reheat. That might cause the Fed to raise interest rates again. "This data has caused market expectations to do a 180-degree turnaround," he said.
The 30-year bond fell 20/32 , to 1026/32 to yield 7.44 percent, up from 7.39 percent on Monday, in reaction to the stronger-than-expected retail number. Rates on short bills were slightly higher.
Elsewhere, in the municipal-bond market, yields were little changed.
Yields have fallen some two-thirds of a percentage point in the last four months amid widespread belief that munis will be harder to find later this year; new issues are currently down about 60 percent from last year.
The surge in prices, which move in the opposite direction of yields, has pushed the yields on bonds to about 78 percent of comparable Treasury securities. Investors generally consider muni bonds inexpensive when they yield more than 82 percent of Treasury securities.
In competitive bidding yesterday, Minnesota sold $115 million in general obligation bonds at yields lower than comparably rated securities. The debt offering was awarded to Bear, Stearns & Company, which repriced the issue to yield as much as 5.60 percent for a bond due in 2009.
Rated Aa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the bond was considered expensive by some traders.
Connecticut's negotiated sale of $438 million of its general obligation bonds through Morgan Stanley & Company, initially priced last week, was offered to institutional investors this week. The maximum yield was 5.90 percent for bonds due in 2014 and 2015, with the remainder of the serial bonds priced to yield from 4.50 percent in 1997 to 5.85 percent in 2013. However, with prices falling since the end of last week, some bonds like the ones for 2015 were priced to yield 5 basis points more. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In the day's largest new negotiated offering, Dade County, Fla., priced $240 million in aviation revenue bonds through Goldman, Sachs & Company. The bonds, which will be used to finance improvements at Miami International Airport, were tentatively priced to yield as much as 6.24 percent for an issue due in 2024. For some buyers the bonds are subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax.
The bonds are insured by the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation and will be rated triple-A by both Moody's and S. & P.

HEADLINE: Let a Free Market Take Its Course on Sex Shops

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The change in zoning for sex shops in Times Square and elsewhere in New York espoused by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican, and endorsed by your March 15 editorial, flies in the face of economic arguments presented by the United States Government to the world. 
 Our governments, both Republican and Democrat, have always endorsed the idea of a market economy. That is, the prices, quantities and types of goods and services that are produced should be governed by the market. We have always advocated that this policy would result in the most efficient economic system.
The policy on sex shops is contrary to this policy. If people patronize these shops and the shops are making money, they should be allowed to flourish. If people find them repugnant, they shouldn't buy from them. Lack of demand and related losses will cause the shops to close in order to stop losing money. This is a more efficient policy and furthers the idea of reducing government involvement.
 
JERROLD P. KATZ
Cambridge, Mass., March 17, 1995

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rebounds as Japan Denies It Accepts Big Drop

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar ended little changed yesterday after rebounding from a low against the yen as the Bank of Japan denied speculation that it would accept a large drop in the dollar.
The dollar tumbled in early New York trading amid rumors that the Bank of Japan had said in an internal document that Japan could tolerate a temporary fall by the dollar to 78 to 82 yen. 
 The dollar pared its losses after a Bank of Japan official in New York denied the document existed, saying, "At this moment, the Bank of Japan wouldn't tolerate a move to 78 to 82 yen."
After falling to an intraday trading low of 88.40 yen, the dollar recovered to 89.27 yen, down from 89.33 yen on Monday.
The dollar gained against the mark after French and German monetary officials meeting in Paris said the French franc was undervalued against the mark, traders said.
"We estimate that the current exchange rate between the two countries' currencies isn't reflecting economic fundamentals," the French and Germans said in a joint statement.
The communique helped push the mark, which reached a record high of 3.6168 francs March 8, down to 3.5376 French francs in New York trading, from 3.5507 francs on Monday.
The retreat by the mark helped support the dollar. In New York trading late yesterday, The dollar rose to 1.4132 marks from 1.4030 marks on Monday. The dollar also rose to 1.1740 Swiss francs from 1.1665 francs. The British pound rose to $1.5860 from $1.5763.
Many market participants, however, said yesterday that the dollar's rebound would be temporary.
"The dollar is going lower," said Ezra Zask, president of Ezra Zask Associates, a Norfolk, Conn., currency-trading fund with $100 million under management.
Tom Hoge, a corporate currency trader at the Bank of New York, said he expected the dollar to slide to 1.30 marks and 88 yen within the next one to two months.

HEADLINE: Thinkers and Doers on the Federal Bench

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Mediocrity on the Bench" (Op-Ed, March 17): Jeffrey Rosen's argument that more high-powered liberal scholars should be appointed to the Federal bench to counteract the conservative scholar-jurists typifies the arrogance of those who view intellectual credentials as the sole measure of potential judicial distinction. 
 Mr. Rosen laments the fact that President Clinton's appointees are "largely a group of soldierly and obscure judges and prosecutors." He neglects to mention that most Federal judicial appointments are for the Federal trial court, where experience as a Federal prosecutor or as a state court judge would prove significantly more valuable than a command of law and economics principles or other scholarly theories.
Second, it is questionable that judges' ability to "transform the law by the force of their arguments" matters more than ability to apply the correct law to a given case with a sense of context, which is gained by practical experience. Even if Mr. Rosen's argument were limited to the appellate courts, one could make a case that our most distinguished appellate judges were former District Court judges who practiced law before their appointments.
Instead of decrying the lack of name-brand Federal appointees as the by-product of a misguided effort to diversify the judiciary, Mr. Rosen might do better to withhold judgment until the careers of the "practitioners" and the "scholars" speak for themselves.
 
ANDREW Y. S. CHENG
Indianapolis, March 18, 1995

HEADLINE: World Trade Choice Draws Modest Praise Of U.S. Aides

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
Accepting the Clinton Administration's reluctant endorsement of his candidacy to be the first head of the World Trade Organization, Renato Ruggiero declared today that "the past is the past" and said he and the American officials who once opposed him had now had a "meeting of the minds."
Mr. Ruggiero, who was once Italy's trade minister, spoke in Washington as the Administration formally declared that it would support his appointment at a meeting of the major trading nations scheduled later this week in Geneva. The endorsement guarantees Mr. Ruggiero the post, and places him at the head of the new worldwide grouping of 124 trading nations. 
 In a statement of support for Mr. Ruggiero, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, was hardly effusive in his praise. After meeting with him this morning and confirming a series of conditions that the United States had placed on its support, Mr. Kantor declared that "we are satisfied that his stewardship will advance our mutually shared goals."
The decision ended a three-way struggle that has gone on for nearly nine months, and became a divisive issue among countries in Asia, Europe and the Americas. Washington and the Latin American nations had supported Carlos Salinas de Gortari, the former President of Mexico. But Mr. Salinas was forced to withdraw after it became clear that he bore some responsibility for Mexico's deep financial crisis and after his brother was arrested in connection with a political killing.
The other candidate, Kim Chul Su, a South Korean economist, withdrew his candidacy today. He has been assured that he will receive the No. 2 post in the organization, American officials said today. European nations and their former colonies backed Mr. Ruggiero.
In return for its support for Mr. Ruggiero, the United States insisted on a number of conditions, including an understanding that he would serve only one four-year term and that the next head of the organization would be a non-European. The World Trade Organization is the successor to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade's secretariat, which had been headed by Peter Sutherland of Ireland.
Mr. Kantor also said that he had reached an agreement that Asia, the Americas and Europe would not get into the same kind of intercontinental struggle over the group's leadership.
Today Mr. Ruggiero, a large man known as "Rocky" with a jolly demeanor, went out of his way to talk about how much he and Mr. Kantor agreed upon. He said everyone had benefited from the American concessions that led to an end to the competition.
"This became a hemispheric contest, and that can lead to some nationalism," Mr. Ruggiero said. "But believe me, all this is behind us."
When American officials were deriding Mr. Ruggiero's candidacy several weeks ago, they described him as an earnest bureaucrat who had little vision for the future of the new trade organization, which has been given far broader powers under the new world trade agreement.
He did nothing today to shake that view. Mr. Ruggiero talked at length but offered few specifics, describing his role as one of achieving accommodation among the trading partners, and declaring that he held little power himself "other than the power of moral suasion."
Mr. Ruggiero insisted that he had not agreed to any conditions on his appointment, and said his only priorities would be promoting free trade and strengthening the international trading system.
But several diplomats say that the United States exacted an agreement from the European Union that agricultural issues -- the most politically charged matters in reaching the last GATT accord -- would be the focus of the next round of global trade negotiations if another accord was sought. European countries had been hoping to avoid such negotiations, which would inevitably lead to a further reduction of protection for farmers.
Mr. Kantor declined today to describe the agreements he had struck with the Europeans in return for supporting Mr. Ruggiero.

HEADLINE: Massachusetts Seeks to Help Fish Industry

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOSTON, March 21

 BODY:
With stocks of cod, haddock and yellowtail flounder at historic lows in New England waters, Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts said today that he would ask President Clinton to declare the state's fishing industry a natural disaster and to authorize Federal relief.
Governor Weld, a Republican, is taking a new tack on the decline of the industry, and it might be one that is hard to support. To qualify for Federal disaster relief, he must show that the shrinking fish populations are the result of uncontrollable forces of nature. 
 The scarcity of fish in the Atlantic has been extensively studied in recent years, and almost all of the efforts to address the problem have been directed at curbing overfishing.
Scientists and Government experts generally agree that overfishing is the main reason for for the reduction of the fish populations.
In December, the Federal Government took one of the most drastic steps to try to bring back the fish. The Commerce Department ordered the emergency closing of more than 6,000 square miles of fishing area off the Massachusetts coast.
But the numbers have continued to decline. In his request for aid, to be submitted to the the Federal Emergency Management Agency later this week, Mr. Weld predicted "the likely complete collapse of the traditional Massachusetts fishing industry within the next six months."
Over the years, the New England Fishery Management Council, which regulates fishing in the region, met yesterday at the National Fishery Service in Woods Hole, Mass. to discuss stepping up efforts combat overfishing.
"We are working on a management plan to address overfishing," said Patricia Fiorelli a spokeswoman for the council. "We haven't been able to put a finger on environmental factors."
Governor Weld compared the situation in New England to that in the Pacific Northwest, where a natural disaster was declared last year after El Nino further diminished the salmon population. California, Oregon and Washington received $20 million in Federal aid. But whether the New England situation is a result of a natural disaster is debatable.
Bernie Bohn, harvest manager for the Oregon Department of Wildlife and Fisheries, said environmental problems were legitimate concerns.
"But it sounds to me like the principal problem is still the one that was there in the first place, which is too-high harvest rates that weren't controlled in time," Mr. Bohn said.
The most important benefit from Federal relief would be unemployment disaster assistance for fishermen. Most fishermen do not get unemployment benefits because they are self-employed. Other Federal aid might help pay for worker retraining and provide low-interest loans for the restructuring of fishing businesses.
To back up his request to the President, Governor Weld argues that fluctuations in water temperatures and rising predator populations have been killing off the cod, haddock and yellowtail flounder, the fish that are the industry mainstay.
"We have been concentrating on poorly understood natural factors," said John C. Phillips, the state Commissioner of Fisheries, Wildlife and Environmental Law, whose office prepared the request for Federal relief. "There has been a tremendous population boom of certain fish that prey on young ground fish including sea herring, mackerel and dogfish."
John Bullard an expert on New England fishing and a former Mayor of New Bedford, Mass., who now works at the Commerce Department, said that the struggling fishing communities along the coast had already been seriously hurt but that they still faced even harder blows. An estimated 20,000 depend on fishing or related business for their livelihoods in New England. He said recent scientific data indicated that fishing would have to be stopped completely for several years in the Georges Bank, off Cape Cod, to replenish the stocks of fish.
"Georges Bank is arguably the most productive fishing grounds in the world," he said. "You take the world's most productive fishing grounds and essentially shut them down. It's hard to overstate the severity of this problem."
Even harder to quantify is the emotional impact on the communities, Mr. Bullard said. In New Bedford, he said, "We were a seaport. If you no longer have a reason to go to sea, you are losing more than your economy, you are losing your character. You are losing you soul."
Mr. Weld made his announcement at a meeting of the state's Seaport Advisory Council, in the port city of Fall River, one year after the Commerce Department approved $30 million in Federal help for the fishing industry that was shared by all the New England states.

HEADLINE: Loral Plans to Pay $800 Million In Deal for Unisys Military Units

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
While most military contractors are looking for ways to scale back in the face of spending cuts at the Pentagon, the Loral Corporation is avidly pursuing growth. Yesterday, in the latest in a string of acquisitions during the last decade, Loral agreed to buy the military and aerospace operations of the Unisys Corporation for $800 million in cash, beating bids by the Hughes Aircraft Corporation and the Raytheon Company.
Loral, based in New York, said the deal would immediately lift its earnings by 20 cents a share and improve its capabilities in areas like radar, satellite communications and military information systems. The sale will allow Unisys to leave the military industry with a large amount of cash to spend on its core computer businesses. 
 The chairman and chief executive of Loral, Benjamin L. Schwartz, said he did not expect layoffs from the acquisition. Unisys Defense Systems, which is made up of four units in Great Neck, L.I.; Eagan, Minn.; Salt Lake City and Montreal, employs about 8,500 people and had revenue of about $1.4 billion last year.
"We like their businesses and we like their management and their people," Mr. Schwartz said. "We will be looking to expand rather than contract."
Such comments reflect the enthusiastic commitment of Mr. Schwartz to military contracting at a time when other companies like Unisys see few opportunities. Since taking over Loral in the early 1970's, Mr. Schwartz has turned the company around and expanded it rapidly, making more than a dozen acquisitions.
In 1990 Loral bought Ford Aerospace for $715 million, more than doubling the size of the company. Three years later it paid $1.57 billion for the Federal Systems Company unit of I.B.M., which provides computer hardware and software to Government agencies.
In the decade since 1985 Loral's annual sales have grown to $5.4 billion from $502 million, while the number of employees has jumped to 33,000 from 6,500.
"The company is very astute at purchasing properties and assimilating them into its business base," said Elliott Rogers, an analyst at Cowens & Company.
Mr. Schwartz said Loral had achieved efficiencies through economies of scale. His goal is for Loral to become one of the largest Government contractors when the current round of industry consolidation is completed.
Loral is a leading producer of training and simulation machines for pilots, command and control communications, satellite communications and tactical weapons and missile systems. The company also provides system integration and other specialized computer services to Government agencies like the Postal Service and the Internal Revenue Service, and it has invested nearly $70 million in Globastar, an ambitious worldwide wireless telephone system based on 48 satellites that will circumnavigate the earth.
Mr. Schwartz said Loral would finance the deal with Unisys from its cash flow and through borrowing from banks.
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, shares of Loral rose $1, to $43.875, while share of Unisys fell 50 cents, to $9.25.
Mr. Rogers praised the deal, even though revenues at the military-related units of Unisys have been shrinking in recent years. "From a stream-of-earnings standpoint, it's a plus," he said. "And the businesses throw off $100 million in cash annually."
But he added that Unisys was one of five suppliers of ground and surface ship radar in a market that he believed could support only three. "That means that Loral is either going to have to buy a competitor or sell," he said.
But Mr. Schwartz would not hear of it. "There is nothing in Unisys that we're going to sell," he said. "Every one of its operations fits very, very well with Loral."
For Unisys, the sale will net substantially more than the $600 million the company expected to receive when it attempted to spin off its military businesses to the public in an unsuccessful initial public offering in 1991.
The chairman and chief executive of Unisys, James A. Unruh, said the sale would help the company continue to transform itself from depending mainly on hardware sales into a service-led information management company. "That is the future of our business," he said.
Like other mainframe computer makers, Unisys suffered a big setback by failing to recognize the shift toward personal computers. From 1989 to 1991 the company lost nearly $2.5 billion. It had revenue of $7.4 billion last year, far lower than its peak in 1990 of slightly more than $10 billion.
But under the leadership of Mr. Unruh, who took over the company in 1990, Unisys has been given credit for recasting itself as a supplier of complete information systems and smaller, networked computers known as client-servers.
"It's been kind of an up-and-down ride for Unisys in recent years," said Bob Djurdjevic, president of Annex Research, a consulting firm based in Phoenix. "The more focused the company gets on what it considers to be its core business, the better the chances are that it will succeed."
Mr. Unruh said Unisys began seriously considering the sale about three months ago. After narrowing the field of interested parties, the company entertained bids from Hughes, Loral and Raytheon.
The cash offer from Loral was superior financially and from the perspective of the 8,500 Unisys employees affected by the sale, he said. Officials at both Hughes Aircraft and Raytheon declined to comment on the sale.
The actual purchase price is $862 million, but will be about $800 million after various adjustments, Mr. Schwartz said. The deal will close in June, he added.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 23, 1995, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about a proposed acquisition of the Unisys Corporation's military and aerospace operations by the Loral Corporation misstated the given name of the chairman and chief executive of Loral. He is Bernard L. Schwartz, not Benjamin.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
New Curbs Proposed on Foreign TV Programs in Europe

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: PARIS, March 22

 BODY:
In a protectionist move that was promptly criticized by the United States, the executive commission of the European Union proposed new rules today that would tighten restrictions on foreign programming on European television stations for the next 10 years.
The main effect of the proposal would be to strengthen a requirement that European television stations must dedicate at least 51 percent of broadcast time to European programming. Many stations have avoided meeting the quota by relying on a modifying phrase -- "where practicable" -- in the requirement. 
 It seems unlikely that the new rules will be approved, however, when they are debated by culture ministers from the union's 15 member countries in Luxembourg on April 3, because Britain is leading a group of European governments that strongly oppose the idea of programming quotas.
Coincidentally, Germany's high court ruled today that the Government had no constitutional right to commit regional German states to the existing broadcast rules. While unrelated to the current European debate, this decision may stiffen Bonn's resistance to the programming quotas.
The drive for stricter controls on foreign programming has been led by France, the region's largest film producer, which has argued that the struggling European television and film industries need the quotas to survive competition from Hollywood.
Several European governments, however, say that while the quota system may protect movie and television production inside the union, it will hinder development of a vast range of new global media services.
Though the United States reluctantly agreed to exclude audio-visual services from the Uruguay Round of global trade talks that went into effect on Jan. 1, it has long campaigned against European television restrictions that seem aimed at American entertainment companies.
After today's announcement, Stuart E. Eizenstat, the United States Ambassador to the European Union, said the commission had missed "an historic opportunity to take a bold step towards a more open system."
"In the high-risk, fast-moving world of telecommunications, 10 years is an eternity," he added.
But Mr. Eizenstat said the Clinton Administration was not planning immediate retaliation. He characterized the issue as an "internal European Union debate."
"It's our hope that the directive will improve as it goes through the Council of Ministers and the European Parliament," he added.
Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Pictures Association of America, responded cautiously. "We Americans are not part of this debate -- a debate between those who believe governments can force people to watch what they don't want to watch and those who say you have to be open to be competitive," he said.
But Mr. Valenti noted that today's proposal "keeps in place some very stern protectionist barriers and makes them mandatory throughout the European Union." Private investors who will be needed to finance "the audio-visual future" will be "very wary" if governments are making decisions for them, he contended.
The issue dates to 1989, when the union adopted a policy with the unlikely name Television Without Frontiers; in fact, the policy established a number of barriers to non-European programming. France has been pressing for elimination of the phrase, "where practicable," which has weakened the policy.
At a meeting of European ministers in Bordeaux last month, France was largely isolated. Britain, the Netherlands, Germany and Austria called for looser controls, and many other countries favored the status quo. At the meeting of the union's executive commission in Brussels today, however, 11 commissioners voted for the proposal, four voted against it and two were absent.
The proposal is a compromise: it eliminates the "where practicable" escape clause but gives television stations the option of dedicating 25 percent of their program budgets to creating new programs and assures protection for only 10 years. In practice, the new rules seem likely to please no one.
Predictably, Britain said it was disappointed. "It would seem that the European Commission has not taken account of the broad view expressed by a majority of states in Bordeaux that they don't want to see a tightening of the existing regime," a spokesman for the Department of National Heritage in Britain said.
Nor was France happy. A spokesman for the Communications Ministry said France welcomed removal of the loophole and reaffirmation of the quota principle, but opposed setting a date for ending the quota system and regretted that new multimedia services like video on demand had been excluded.
At present, 60 percent of programming on French television must be European, including at least 40 percent made in France, though many stations fail to meet the targets. The French film industry, which has demanded that Paris oppose the 10-year provision, has a particular interest because much of its financing comes from French television stations that are required not only to show French films but also to invest heavily in movie production.

HEADLINE: Ruling on Definition of 'Family,' Justices Back a Welfare Curb

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
The Supreme Court today unanimously upheld a California welfare regulation intended to save the state money by counting all needy children living in the same household under the care of a relative as a single family.
The regulation replaced an approach under which only members of the same nuclear family were counted as a family unit when calculating monthly welfare grants. 
 Two pairs of siblings living with a grandmother, for example, would get two separate welfare grants under the old rules, but under the regulations upheld today it would be a single grant calculated for a family with four welfare recipients. Because state welfare programs give lower per-capita grants for each additional family member, the larger family would get a smaller total grant than two separate families with the same number of people.
About half of the states have regulations similar to California's. But the lower Federal courts were divided over whether the regulations complied with various provisions of Federal welfare law.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, declared the California regulation invalid in 1993, but the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in Manhattan, upheld a similar New York welfare regulation last May. Connecticut and New Jersey are among the states with similar rules.
The Clinton Administration supported California in its appeal to the Supreme Court, telling the Court that states were supposed to have considerable latitude in administering their welfare systems under the Aid to Families With Dependent Children program, the main Federal-state welfare program at issue in the case. The Administration said that the Government had endorsed state approaches similar to California's since the 1960's.
Writing for the Court today, Justice Clarence Thomas said that while the California regulation resulted in lower per-capita grants to members of extended families, "California is simply recognizing the economies of scale that inhere in such living arrangements."
One plaintiff in the case, whose situation the Court highlighted today, was caring for a granddaughter and was receiving welfare on the child's behalf of $341 a month. She then began caring for two grandnieces, who were sisters and who received a separate benefit of $560 a month. When the new California rule took effect in 1991, the total monthly grant of $901 was cut to $694.
According to the California Attorney General's office, the state expects to save about $20 million a year by using this approach to calculating payments.
But the lawyer for the plaintiffs, Katherine E. Meiss of the Western Center on Law and Poverty in Los Angeles, said in an interview today that the decision might cost the state money. "I'm sure that thousands of kids will end up in foster care" rather than being cared for by relatives as monthly grants are cut, she said.
A brief filed in the case by the American Association of Retired Persons said the welfare rolls showed a "staggering growth" in the number of grandparents caring for their children's children.
The legal arguments in the case, Anderson v. Edwards, No. 93-1883, were quite technical. They concerned the interplay between the challenged state regulation and several Federal welfare regulations intended to make sure that a child's welfare benefits would not be reduced because of the presence in the home of an adult who was not legally responsible for the child's expenses.
Reflecting the Administration's explanation of those regulations, the Court said today that they were intended to address a different issue, that of a boyfriend or other adult male in the home who had no legal obligation to the children and whose income should not be assumed to be available to them.
