SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1163 words

HEADLINE: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT SOARS TO RECORD

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
In an ominous sign for the economy and the Clinton Administration, the nation's trade deficit soared by two-thirds in January to a record $12.23 billion.
There was strong evidence that the United States' usual imbalance, caused largely by Asian nations that export far more to this country than they buy in return, was being worsened as Mexico, recently a major importer of American goods, plunged deeper into economic crisis. 
 The severity of the trade gap reported today by the Commerce Department took the Clinton Administration by surprise. Although the dollar fell to a record low of 89 Japanese yen in New York trading, the decline was relatively modest, given the big jump in the deficit.
Still, the White House is particularly concerned, several Administration officials acknowledged, because a further deterioration in trade could keep the dollar weak. And if the economy slows as expected later this year, it could open the door to Republicans to attack what has been the Administration's stronghold: a healthy economy.
The exceptionally big trade deficit in January was the largest number ever reported, but it is hard to be absolutely sure that it exceeded all previous months because the Commerce Department recently changed its method of calculation.
Paradoxically, the big jump in the trade deficit can also be seen as a measure of the economy's continued strength. Imports continued to climb, reflecting strong consumer demand. But exports declined even faster.
What's worse is that the latest figures make clear that predictions about the fallout from the collapse of the Mexican peso are already coming to pass. Mexico, which has helped compensate for a chronic trade deficit with Asia, is now beginning to help widen the gap. Today's numbers are expected to be the first in a long series of Mexican trade surpluses with the United States as the steep devaluation of the peso hurts America's third-largest export market.
The trade gap with Mexico was $863 million in January after a $19 million surplus in December. Such figures seem certain to worsen: Some economists are expecting a deficit with Mexico of $15 billion or more this year as a recession caused by Mexico's economic austerity plan begins to bite into that country's imports. But the White House can hardly complain about the Mexican austerity plan, because its Treasury Department wrote much of it.
"Mexico has to run a big trade surplus with us if this plan has a chance of working," a senior Administration official said recently. "But it is not going to be easy to explain that to workers in Texas or California."
Until recently, the Administration was boasting that 700,000 new jobs had been created in the last year because of increased trade with Mexico. Now, no one in the Administration wants to speculate, at least publicly, about what could happen to many of those jobs in the next year.
"We're seeing a lot of bad things happen simultaneously," said Lawrence Chimerine, the chief economist of the Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington research organization that advocates a more aggressive trade stance. "In a few months this is going to be a political issue again, and an issue of economic growth."
Yet trade has hardly been mentioned in the months since the Republicans took control of both houses of Congress. That is little surprise at a time of continued economic expansion and low unemployment. But it usually flares up as a political issue as soon as there is any evidence of economic slowdown in which critics can argue that imports are costing American jobs.
The quandary for the Clinton Administration is that the classic economic solution for a big trade gap -- a weaker dollar that makes American exports less expensive abroad and imports more expensive -- could not only prove to be a political liability but is also unlikely to provide any relief this time around.
Already, the dollar's low levels against the German mark and the yen are hurting American prestige. So the Administration is hardly in a position to push the dollar lower. And even if it wanted to, the weak dollar is unlikely to help American exporters in the markets that count the most: Japan, Mexico, Canada and China.
For reasons that are as complex and confused as the trading relationship between Tokyo and Washington, the deficit with Japan has been virtually immune to currency shifts. The two countries have been trying for a decade to narrow the trade gap, only to find the effort frustrated by Japanese trade barriers, an inability by Detroit to overcome Japan's advantage in the automobile industry that accounts for much of the gap, and a low American savings rate, which requires constant injections of capital from abroad to finance both private investment and Government borrowing.
In fact, Japan was one of the few bright spots in today's trade report, with the deficit in the trade in goods -- a figure that excludes increasingly important American services like insurance and telecommunications -- declining to $4.86 billion, from $5.55 billion in December. But that decline was almost certainly a temporary result of the Kobe earthquake, which paralyzed one of Japan's busiest ports. Most Japanese companies have since worked out alternative routes for their exports.
Nor is the growing deficit with China, which jumped by a third in January to $2.72 billion, likely to be affected by the weakness of the dollar. China's currency loosely follows the dollar, as do the currencies of many of the Southeast Asian nations that also run large trade surpluses with the United States. And while the dollar is weak in comparison with the yen and the mark, it has strengthened by 50 percent in comparison with the peso, and is also stronger compared with the Canadian dollar.
The figures announced today indicated that exports in January totaled $60.70 billion in goods and services, while imports were $72.93 billion. The $12.23 billion deficit was $5 billion more than the December figure, and $4.8 billion more than the figure in January 1994.
The gap widened with most of American trade partners, with the deficit with Western Europe growing to $1.3 billion from $200 million and Asian nations contributing to about 80 percent of the total gap. The surplus with South and Central America fell sharply. But the deficit narrowed slightly with Canada.
Today's figures came out days before President Clinton is scheduled to begin a series of regional economic conferences around the country to listen to workers and business executives, and presumably to laud his Administration's economic successes.
In the past, he has always listed the nation's export boom as one of his proudest accomplishments, arguing that it creates jobs that are higher-paying than average. The statistics support his case. In political terms, however, the growing trade deficit may undercut his arguments that free trade is an undiluted advantage for American workers and companies.

HEADLINE: Christopher Says Russia May Pay High Price for Chechen War

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: GENEVA, March 22

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher warned Russia today that its military intervention in Chechnya could delay its efforts to win quick integration into the West.
Describing Russia's invasion of Chechnya as "foolhardy" and "tragically wrong," Mr. Christopher said its actions there had badly hurt Russia's image overseas and could frustrate Moscow's desire to gain full participation in several international groups, including the Group of Seven industrial nations. 
 At a working dinner here tonight, the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei Koyzrev, told Mr. Christopher that his nation wanted to expand its role in the Group of Seven so that it was involved in not just political issues, but economic issues as well.
But, according to a senior aide, Mr. Christopher told the Russian diplomat, "Given the situation in Chechnya, it would probably be too much for the market to bear to have an enhanced Russian role."
Shortly before meeting Mr. Kozyrev, Mr. Christopher told reporters: "They're paying a high price of their reputation in the international community. They were on an incline in their acceptance by various international organizations. You can see that slowing."
One senior official indicated that Russia's invasion of Chechnya could also delay its membership in the World Trade Organization.
At their meeting, Mr. Kozyrev said he was confident that by early May, Russia would agree on ways to end a dispute in which the United States has criticized Moscow for selling submarines and other conventional arms to Iran. Administration said Mr. Kozyrev had indicated that Russia would scale back the amount of arms it is supposed to supply Iran under existing contracts.
Mr. Christopher also had some welcome words for Russia, saying it would be wrong to cut off aid to Moscow because of Washington's unhappiness over Chechnya and Russia's plans to build nuclear reactors in Iran.
Asserting that ending aid might hurt the United States more than Russia, Mr. Christopher said cutting off aid would undermine American interests by slowing Russia's conversion to a free-market economy and its dismantlement of nuclear weapons.
"Some people would say that we should punish Russia when it does something we don't like," said Mr. Christopher. "I've gone over our aid programs one by one, and I've concluded that restricting them would injure United States interests. It would hurt us at least as much or more than the Russians."
Noting that he studied the idea of using economic leverage to punish the Russians, Mr. Christopher said it would work against America's security interests to cut off the $500 million authorized to help Russia dismantle nuclear warheads. Similarly, any move to cancel the $379 million in economic aid promised Russia this year would backfire, he said, because this money is to be used to advance privatization and other program he said were vital for moving Russia closer to the West.
Defending Mr. Clinton's decision to visit Russia from May 9 to 11 to mark the 50th anniversary of the Allies' victory in World War II, Mr. Christopher said America's relationship with Russia was too important and broad to allow it to break down over one or two issues.
"It's important not to let it be held hostage by any particular issue," he said.

HEADLINE: Survivors of Collapse Lose All to Demolition

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Ethel Johnson and her boyfriend, Robert Jacob, watched in terror Tuesday morning from the living room of their Harlem apartment as half their life's possessions vanished from their bedroom in a thunderous rush.
Yesterday morning, as they stood sullenly in front of the building, they were told that a wrecking ball would claim the other half -- demolishing the eastern corner of their building at 142 West 140th Street, which officials condemned after determining that it was too unstable for anyone to enter again. 
 A couch, a television, a futon and a closet full of clothes, photos and personal papers -- everything that Ms. Johnson had slowly accumulated in nine years in her second-floor apartment -- was to be buried under a mountain of bricks and timber.
"It's not fair, it's not fair," said Ms. Johnson, 31, weeping quietly and wearing the only possessions she managed to salvage. "Maybe they think poor people's belongings don't mean anything to them. But they meant something to me."
For Ms. Johnson, Mr. Jacob and the dozens of people who occupied the 12 apartments that were most heavily damaged in the collapse of the building's east wall, the last 36 hours seemed like a dream in which the very fabric of their lives was ripped.
Yesterday, the couple lined up expectantly in front of the building with dozens of other residents, hoping to be allowed back in briefly to gather the things that mattered to them most -- a small amount of cash, legal documents and, most important, pictures, videos and mementos of Ms. Johnson's son.
While residents who lived in the intact parts of the building were let in with black trash bags to grab a week's change of clothes, medicine, money and credit cards, those who lived in the 12 collapsed apartments were not allowed to enter.
Mr. Jacob and Ms. Johnson were escorted as far as the threshold of their apartment, 2E, its front door torn from the hinges, before they were turned back by other officers. "I could see all of our stuff right there," said Ms. Johnson, weeping. "We could have just reached out and grabbed it."
Capt. Edward Cannon, one of the police officials who were escorting residents back into the building, broke the bad news when the couple asked when they would be able to get their things.
"It's going to be a loss, basically," he said. "I'm sorry, but there's nothing I can do. It's a situation of life over property."
The couple's ordeal began soon after they rose early on Tuesday. Though he was usually difficult to get out of bed, Ms. Johnson' 4-year-old son, Krystian, got up on his own about 7:15 A.M.
As the couple lounged in their underwear and Krystian ate a bowl of bran flakes on his favorite Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles tray, they heard a noise that sounded like a clap of thunder from the bedroom where Krystian had just been sleeping.
"Ethel was yelling at me, 'Get up! Get up!" said Mr. Jacob, 25. "I ran back to the bedroom and I said, 'I can see daylight!' and she said, 'Daylight?' and I said, 'Daylight! Run! Run!"
The couple said the minutes that followed were the most terrifying of their lives. "We thought maybe the whole building was falling into a hole," Mr. Jacob said. "It felt like the rest of the building was going to come right down on us."
Ms. Johnson scooped up her son, clad only in long johns, and carried him into the hallway outside her apartment, where neighbors held him while she ran back in to try to call her family.
Mr. Jacob pulled on his pants, grabbed a coat and stumbled into the hallway, where he saw a woman in the adjacent apartment hoisting herself up from the precarious slope of her bedroom floor with a pair of blue jeans. "The jeans were on a hanger and she was pulling herself up on them like a rope," he said.
Before Ms. Johnson could get through to her family on the phone, neighbors grabbed her and rushed her from the building. "I guess the phone's still off the hook," she said yesterday, and then laughed when she realized how little that mattered now.
The couple spent the night of the collapse in a dingy room in the Belleclaire Hotel on the Upper West Side, where the Red Cross had placed at least five of the displaced families.
Krystian had been left for the night with his father and grandparents in West Harlem "because I wanted him to wake up in place he knew, not in some dirty hotel," Ms. Johnson said.
On Tuesday night, as Ms. Johnson, an unemployed home health aide, sat on a bed in the hotel, staring at three plastic bags full of items donated from friends -- a radio, an extra pair of pants, some shampoo -- she recounted that the building's collapse, as terrifying as it had been, was simply the finale in a series of smaller collapses.
Last year, the ceiling in the kitchen and the bathroom had caved in, she said. She said the leaks were so bad that sometimes she was forced to sit on the toilet with an umbrella over her head to keep dry.
Just last week, there was a leak in a hallway so big "that you could have gotten a washcloth and taken a shower in it," said Mr. Jacob, who is unemployed and had lived in the apartment for nearly a year.
"A week before that, all the lights had gone out one night -- no emergency lights, nothing," he said, relating how he had used a cigarette lighter to find his way upstairs.
While the building had been in fairly good condition when Ms. Johnson moved in in 1986, paying a rent of $215 a month, for the last three years it had been falling apart, even as her rent increased to $350, she said. She and several other residents said there was no heat or hot water during most of the winter.
More and more, they said, squatters were breaking into the building at night using a knife or a plastic card to jimmy the antiquated lock.
"And there were times when you'd come in and the hallway would be filled with smoke, like burning rubber, I guess from the boiler," Ms. Johnson said. "You'd just go into your apartment and shut your door and just hope nothing blew up."
Yesterday, as the couple stood in the rain with empty black plastic bags, waiting for the Red Cross to ferry them back to the Belleclaire Hotel, Ms. Johnson said that as bad as it got, at least it was a roof over their heads.
"What were we going to do?" she asked. "We didn't have enough money to move anywhere else. Now we've got nothing."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Trade Deficit's Unexpected Rise Sends the Dollar to Lower Levels

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar slumped against most leading currencies yesterday after a report showed that the United States trade deficit swelled sharply in January, much more than most analysts expected.
The large trade gap hurts the dollar by putting a wealth of dollars into the hands of foreign exporters, who sell them for their own currencies when taking revenue home. 
 Steady in European trading, the dollar fell after the Commerce Department said the deficit in goods and services widened to $12.2 billion in January, $5 billion more than in December. Economists had been expecting a deficit of $9.3 billion. .
"The number is just a shocker," said David De Rosa, director of foreign exchange trading at Swiss Bank in New York. "The dollar is dropping on this number. It means there are more dollars to be sold by our trading partners."
But while the trade gap was severe, the impact on the dollar was relatively restrained. Indeed, the dollar pared its losses briefly in early New York trading as investors focused on one bit of positive news in the report: a narrowing in the trade deficits with Germany and Japan. The United States deficit with Japan fell to $4.9 billion in January from $5.55 billion in December, while the gap with Germany shrank to $988 million from $1.1 billion.
"People are pointing to the two places where the dollar has been the weakest: Germany and Japan," said Ravi Bulchandani, international economist at Morgan Stanley. The dollar has fallen 10 percent against the German mark and 11 percent against the Japanese yen so far this year.
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.4030 marks from 1.4132 marks on Tuesday. The dollar slipped to 89.00 yen from 89.27 yen, a record low for late New York trading and near its record intraday low of 88.40 yen, which it touched in trading on Tuesday.
Despite its muted reaction yesterday, the dollar remains vulnerable, currency dealers and analysts said.
"The U.S. is spending more than it is producing," said Michael Perelstein, director of international investments for the MacKay Shields Financial Corporation, a money-management firm with $12 billion in assets. "As a result, the dollar is a structurally weak currency."
In addition to the huge trade deficit, the dollar is weighed down by Mexico's financial turmoil and the growing belief that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates again soon.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Treasury Issues End the Day Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, despite concerns over the weakness of the dollar and signs of brisk consumer demand.
The price of the 30-year bond slipped 1/32 , to 102 4/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, edged up to 7.45 percent, from 7.44 percent on Tuesday. But the rates on shorter-maturity bills dropped slightly as some investors sold longer maturities for the less volatile short end of the market. The yield on the two-year note fell to 6.70 percent from 6.72 percent. 
 The market's mixed performance came after the Commerce Department reported that the United States trade deficit widened 68 percent, to $12.2 billion, in January. Imports continued to climb, to a record $72.9 billion for the month, suggesting that consumer demand remains strong.
The market's ability to remain stable after such a strong number suggested to some traders and analysts that the market was confident in the ability of the Federal Reserve to engineer a "soft landing" for the economy. Economists regard a soft landing as a slowdown in economic expansion to a 2.5 percent annual rate, compared with 4 percent last year.
"A higher trade deficit means lower G.D.P. growth, assuming everything else remains the same," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York.
But the trade report failed to lift the market, she said, because it "has already reacted, or priced in a slow-growth scenario, so what the market now needs is evidence that the economy is either heading into a recession, or that growth is at a very meager pace, for it to do much better."
The bond market was also weighed down by the continued weakness of the dollar, which slumped after the release of the trade data.
Elsewhere in the market, the Treasury announced the size of next week's auctions of new two- and five-year notes. On Tuesday, the Treasury will auction $17.25 billion of notes with a two-year maturity and on Wednesday $11 billion of notes due in five years. In when-issued trading late in the day the notes were being offered at prices to yield 6.76 percent for a two-year note and 7.05 percent for a five-year note.
Yields in the municipal market were little changed in trading, as California sold $385.53 million of general obligation bonds through competitive bidding won by BA Securities.
A major portion of the financing, series BD, BE, BF, is subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax, which means some purchasers of the bonds will have income from the securities taxed at a higher rate. Yields for serial bonds range from 5.20 percent in 2000 to 6.20 percent in 2012 and 2016. Longer-maturity bonds are priced to yield 6 3/8 percent for an issue due in 2027; 6.55 percent for a bond due in 2025; 6.40 percent for those due in 2020 and 2022, and 6.25 percent for those due in 2014.
Bonds not subject to the alternative tax, series BC, are priced to yield from 5.10 percent in 2000 to 6.10 percent in 2015, with a longer maturity of 2018 priced to yield 6.15 percent.
The financing is rated A1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. Bonds due in 2016 and 2027 are insured by the Ambac Indemnity Corporation and are rated triple-A by the rating agencies.

HEADLINE: The Early Bird Gets the Audition;
Lining Up for Hours to Sing for Three Minutes or Less

BYLINE: By JENNIFER KINGSON BLOOM 

 BODY:
At 6 A.M. Monday, the sun was still weak in the sky but 35 actors had already lined up by the Actors' Equity Association building on West 46th Street, waiting to sign up for auditions that would begin at 8 A.M. First in line was Alexandra Kolb, who had risen at 2 A.M., driven an hour from Lacey, N.J., and parked herself at the building entrance at 4:30 A.M.
"It just keeps getting earlier and earlier," sighed Ms. Kolb, who at 22 is a four-year veteran of the New York audition scene. "This month is the craziest I've ever seen it." 
 Being first in line meant Ms. Kolb would be able to get an appointment for an audition -- dozens would be turned away -- and could choose a coveted early slot, when casting directors are fresh. Six hours of waiting would earn her a chance to sing for three minutes, auditioning for leading roles in the Broadway and road versions of "Phantom of the Opera."
"Sometimes, they only let you sing six bars," said Ms. Kolb, pulling her coat tight against the spring chill. "Sometimes, it's only eight bars."
By 10 A.M., more than 500 people had made the pilgrimage to the second-floor waiting room at Actors' Equity, which this month resembles an airport terminal with all flights canceled.
March is the height of the auditioning season for Actors' Equity, with a total of 202 auditions, including 44 for Broadway shows and 65 for summer stock. (The slowest month, last October, saw only 33 auditions.) Union rules require that Broadway productions hold tryouts every six months, and a large concentration of these legendary cattle calls happen to being falling right now. For many actors, the tedium of waiting to sign up for an audition time is enhanced by the futility: many of the auditioning Broadway shows don't actually have openings.
But it is in the spring that summer-stock directors converge in New York, casting central, desperately seeking the perfect Stella or the ultimate Peter Pan. Performing in chestnuts in small towns may not be every actor's thespian ideal, but it offers a paycheck as well as experience .
Susan Levin has played the Baroness and Maria in summer productions of "The Sound of Music," once on a tour of New Jersey and once in Lake Placid, N.Y. She recently auditioned for a summer job with a theater company in Allenberry, Pa.
"I have a wonderful job as a full professor with tenure, but I can't stop doing this," said Ms. Levin, who teaches literature at the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken. This month, Ms. Levin and thousands of fellow actors will audition for, among other shows, an "Evita" in Oklahoma, a "Gigi" at the North Shore Music Theater in Beverly, Mass., and a "Forever Plaid" in Forestburgh, N.Y.
More and more performers from around the country are flocking to the sidewalk of 46th Street near Broadway, convinced that he or she is that one singular sensation. The odds of being discovered are long and the discomfort is severe, but dreams die hard.
"This is the third time I've come for a 'Phantom' audition, and I did get called back once," said Todd Frizzell, 37, a Denver native who went from the audition to his day job as a tour guide at Macy's. Mr. Frizzell was 99th in line and had arrived at 6:50 A.M. "My break may not be until I'm 60, but I'm willing to accept a lot of anguish. It's all formative to the artistic process."
Of 36,000 members of the Actors' Equity Association, 18,000 live in the New York metropolitan area. In 1988, the National Labor Relations Bureau required the union to open auditions to nonmembers who had logged enough hours on stage; there are 7,000 such "eligible performers" nationally, including 4,500 in the New York area.
Tony Nicosia Jr., who has directed the Actors' Equity audition department since 1982, said that auditioning has become more humane. Before the present system, actors used to have to wait all day for a chance to audition, and many were turned away when time ran out. Now, actors sign up in the morning for time slots. Each casting director sees 120 people, and latecomers are placed on a seldom-tapped waiting list.
Last month, Actors' Equity surveyed 500 members and found that 47 percent had found jobs through open casting calls. In calls for chorus work, which has its own system, casting directors size up the hopefuls who show up and point to those who resemble the "type" they are seeking before holding auditions.
On a recent weekday, 350 women showed up for a chorus call for "Big," a new Broadway musical, based on the Tom Hanks movie, that will open in October. The notice advertising the audition in the trade newspaper Back Stage called for "young suburban parents of babies, young teen-agers, New York corporate lawyers . . . various Times Square street people and Manhattan yuppies."
Only 100 were given a chance to sing half a song and hoof a few steps. Vincent G. Liff, the casting director for "Big" and "Phantom of the Opera," who turned away no less than 250 women for "Big" alone, called the turnout "frightening" but said the system, while patience-trying, was valuable. "We have cast dozens and dozens of people through these calls," Mr. Liff said.
Many actors try to prove their versatility. Richard Rice Alan, who was 100th in line on Monday, had glossy photographs of himself scowling in a black turtleneck, cheerful in a casual work shirt and looking corporate in a business suit. "I have three different looks," said Mr. Alan, who while in line read the book "Monologues for Men."
"I've waited out here in the rain for an hour and a half before, so this isn't so bad today," Mr. Alan said. A Houston native, he sold his belongings and arrived in New York last year with a small suitcase and big aspirations. "I'm trying to get an agent so I don't have to do this anymore," he said.
Once in the sparse audition rooms, actors must sing with passion or emote for one to three casting directors. The only other soul in the room is a pianist. Unemployed union members are hired to monitor the waiting room, where people apply makeup, read trade magazines and fuss with garment bags and costumes.
The crush is so great that Mr. Nicosia sometimes has trouble getting to his office. "It's a zoo, but this is the life of the actor," he said.
As is the early morning sidewalk scene, where the weary and unshaven dozed, warbled bits of song and fought the cold with coffee. Diane and Thomas Bradshaw, husband and wife who were third and fourth in line, had invested in a footstool and took turns sitting from 4:50 A.M. until the doors opened.
"You never know which day is going to be the lucky one," Mrs. Bradshaw said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A simple proposal for cutting down on securities fraud suits.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
LET'S say you run a video game company. You've just been told that promised deliveries of this year's planned blockbuster, "Burn 'Em in Salem," will be delayed at least three months. The trouble is that the pitiful screams of the witches in the test version cannot be heard above the roar of the flames.
Who do you call first? Your ad agency? The big retail chains? Members of the corporate board? Ghostbusters? 
 More likely, the company's lawyers. For once the delay is announced, your stock is probably headed for a nose dive. And frequently -- arguably much too frequently -- securities fraud lawyers will be filing lawsuits on behalf of those who bought the stock (or chose not to sell it) on the implied promise that you were all set to send children to bed each night dreaming of incinerating witches.
Admittedly, not all cases in which a stock takes a sudden plunge lead to shareholder lawsuits. The law, after all, requires evidence of fraud or deceit to win a suit in Federal court. But enough horror stories about frivolous lawsuits aimed more at extracting big settlements than proving malfeasance have made the rounds that many lawmakers are convinced something needs to be done to curb the practice.
Representative Christopher Cox, a Republican from California, wrote the original draft of what is now known as the Securities Litigation Reform Act and shepherded a modified version of the proposal through the House. It is now pending in the Senate, where it faces a tougher battle. "The bill addresses all the key concerns," he says.
But does it? Experts who are sympathetic to the need to rein in securities suits see the final House bill as an unwieldy patchwork that will require years of court tests before its impact becomes clear. "Eventually," concluded Lester Brickman, a professor at the Benjamin Cardozo Law School in New York, "we'd find out just how many angels can dance on the head of this pin." Instead, Professor Brickman just may have a better idea.
In recent years, stockholders' lawsuits have grown like weeds. Originally seen as a desirable way to encourage full and timely disclosure, many people now believe that such litigation on behalf of injured "classes" has taken on a life of its own.
The law has not changed, but the aggressiveness of the plaintiffs' bar has. Hundreds of class action suits on securities fraud are filed in Federal court each year.
So what is wrong with that? Plenty. As Elliot Weiss of the University of Arizona Law School and John Beckerman of Cardozo Law School write in a forthcoming article in the Yale Law Journal, the market for such litigation responds to perverse incentives in which the cost of defending against these suits far exceeds the cost of pursuing them. Even where cases clearly lack merit, few defendants are prepared to spend millions of dollars in a lengthy discovery process or run the risk of a jury decision that might bankrupt the company. Rare as such extreme outcomes may be, the more prudent action is usually to settle any suit that survives the initial motion to dismiss. And because the burden of proof at the early stage is so low, most cases, legal experts for defendants say, make it past that first hurdle.
The House bill attempts to even the playing field, as Representative Cox put it, to help corporations avoid having "to pay ransom to the Barbary pirates." It includes measures ranging from a "loser pays" rule to a tougher standard of proof of fraud.
The corporate defense bar has probably gotten as much as it is going to get in the House bill. Still, Michael Halloran, general counsel for the Bank of America, is underwhelmed. "I give this bill a 7 at best on a 10-point scale," he said.
That's where Professor Brickman's idea comes in. He offers a disarmingly simple proposal that would eliminate institutional investors -- mutual funds, pension funds and the like -- from any class action fraud suit. They could file parallel fraud suits if they wished, but could not simply go along for the ride.
If the institutions chose not to sue, Mr. Brickman notes, the potential liability of the defendants (and the potential fees to plaintiffs' lawyers) would most likely be halved since institutions generally control about half the shares of most corporations. And if the institutions felt the case was worthwhile, the courts would generally consolidate the case, limiting the power of the plaintiffs' bar to run up fees. That could be better for everybody but the lawyers.
Would such a plan take a big whack at legal extortion? No one knows for sure. The Securities and Exchange Commission is uneasy about the House bill, fearing that it goes too far to undermine legitimate shareholder rights. But Simon Lorne, the S.E.C.'s general counsel, is prepared to say that the Brickman proposal at least "deserves further study."
Indeed, the highest virtue of the Brickman plan is that it represents an entirely fresh attempt to unravel a hopelessly twisted knot.

HEADLINE: Turkey Crosses a Line

 BODY:
In one of Turkey's largest foreign military operations since the days of the Ottoman Empire, 35,000 troops poured across its border with Iraq this week to attack the Kurdish guerrilla group known as the Kurdistan Workers Party, or P.K.K. Turkey contends its only purpose is to destroy a violent separatist group by wiping out its Iraqi base camps. But sending troops across another nation's border is a violation of international law that deserves harsh condemnation. The world would become even more dangerous if countries with strong armies and border frustrations felt free to take the law into their own hands.
France, which currently leads the European Union, a group Turkey desperately wants to join, has rightly condemned this invasion. The United States should have condemned it too. Instead, Washington, along with Moscow, has expressed understanding for the Turkish attack. 
 The P.K.K. is a Marxist revolutionary group that engages in deadly terrorism. But this foray into Iraq is symptomatic of Turkey's military approach to the whole Kurdish issue, of which P.K.K. terrorism is merely one element. Harshly repressive army tactics in Kurdish areas of southeastern Turkey have created a million and a half internal Kurdish refugees as well as driving thousands more into Iraq. These tactics have also encouraged five million Turkish Kurds to migrate to cities in other regions of the country. Kurds make up one-fifth of Turkey's population. No government can deliver on promises of democracy and economic growth if it wages so vast an internal war.
The fact that the international border being violated in this case is Iraq's should not obscure the underlying principle. Saddam Hussein may not show much respect for international frontiers, but the sanctity of borders was one of the main causes the Persian Gulf war's coalition fought to uphold.
The region of Iraq in which Turkish troops are now operating is currently under Western military protection as a result of the gulf war. That operation requires Turkish cooperation and rear bases on Turkish soil. That factor probably explains Washington's rush to bless the Turkish invasion.
But the only legitimate American military purpose in northern Iraq is to protect Kurdish civilians from Saddam Hussein's forces. Holding those forces at bay while Turkey invades Iraq is an abuse of American military power and an affront to the United Nations, whose authority governs American military activities in northern Iraq.
The Turkish Government has been promising that its operations in Iraq will be quickly completed. But now it says the fighting could last a month. The Clinton Administration has clearly bought into more than a brief border incursion. It is not too late for America to take a more principled stand.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: What Made the Dollar Swoon? Try the Deficit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Peter Passell's March 16 Economic Scene column on the dollar ignores the most important factor behind the long-term decline of the dollar relative to most major currencies: the prospect that our huge budget and trade deficits will remain unless policies are changed. 
 With respect to trade, the lion's share of the deficit is with Japan and Southeast Asia. It reflects not market forces or disparate growth rates but the known barriers that keep United States exports or export-promoting investment out of those economies, as well as the use of high profits from those protected markets to subsidize cheap exports to the wide-open United States market.
Regarding Japan in particular, these structural factors hold down imports even when the yen is stong and even when the Japanese economy is growing. Worse, recycling its dollar surpluses in United States holdings is no longer so attractive to Japan -- both because previous dollar depreciation stuck Japanese investors with huge losses in America, and because Japan's domestic needs beckon. The combination of these factors puts downward pressure on the dollar and upward pressure on the yen.
The dollar's latest swoon also proves that the conventional wisdom on trade policy has been wrong -- United States activism was never responsible for the dollar's weakness, and macroeconomic mechanisms alone will not significantly reduce America's trade deficits with Asia in ways consistent with long-term national economic health.
The dollar can reverse its slide against the yen only if Japanese markets are opened and Japanese demand for dollars to buy American goods rises. It's time for stronger trade efforts, not surrender.
At the same time, our Federal budget deficit is also hurting the dollar, especially because of our need for foreign capital to finance it; talk of substantial tax cuts, and growing resistance to big cuts in domestic programs, have raised questions about whether or not deficits will be reduced.
To demonstrate real seriousness on deficit reduction, the President should postpone his tax cut until the deficit is lower, send a clear message to the Republicans that he will veto their tax cuts if they reach his desk and take a first step toward serious entitlement reform. These moves would also help stabilize the dollar against the yen and against the German mark and other currencies.
 
LAWRENCE CHIMERINE
Managing Director and Chief
Economist, Economic Strategy Inst.
Washington, March 16, 1995

HEADLINE: Essay;
Happy V-E Day, Boris

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The accommodationists in charge of Clinton foreign policy put on a show of internal agonizing about whether to celebrate the golden anniversary of V-E Day in Moscow.
A visit by a U.S. President is eagerly sought by foreign leaders. President Nixon bombed Haiphong and mined its harbor confident that Leonid Brezhnev would not let that action interfere with an upcoming Moscow summit. Contrary to the dire predictions of dovish commentators, Nixon's provocative escalation did not stop the Moscow meeting. 
 Boris Yeltsin has just worked that same maneuver on Bill Clinton. Two headlines on the same page of The New York Times tell the story: "Russia Pounds Rebel Positions Outside Capital of Chechnya" and "Clinton Will Go to Moscow and Meet With Yeltsin in May."
Mr. Yeltsin desperately needs this meeting; why didn't Mr. Clinton use that need to gain major concessions beforehand?
Because he cannot tell a fig leaf from a real concession. In return for Mr. Clinton's propping up his increasingly autocratic Russian rule, Yeltsin promised not to embarrass the visiting American with a parade of the tanks that crushed resistance in Grozny.
As an added symbolic treat, Yeltsin will refrain from displaying nuclear missiles, lest they remind Americans of his deal with Iran to supply nuclear facilities that will enable the ayatollahs to build weapons to threaten U.S. cities.
Our naive President snatched the fig leaves and passed up the substance. It seems Mr. Clinton never learns; his last such blunder was to travel to Damascus to honor the leader of a nation high on our terrorist list. In return, Hafez al-Assad publicly stuck his thumb in Mr. Clinton's eye.
As critics like Senator Bob Dole deride his "Yeltsin-First" policy, Mr. Clinton will seek in Moscow what he failed to obtain in advance. Not a cessation of the brutal suppression of the Chechens' reach for autonomy; Clinton's pre-emptive cave-in has already given Yeltsin an additional six weeks to kill opponents. (To prevent the ironic juxtaposition of film clips at V-E Day ceremonies, Russian commanders may give the Chechen civilians a day off.)
Instead, Clinton's payoff for boosting Yeltsin's popularity should be an undoing of the Russian-Iranian nuclear deal. He must prevail on the Russian President to "do a Conoco" -- to sacrifice undoubted economic benefits by pulling back from a deal that would help make the dangerous Iranians a superpower.
If Clinton comes home from Moscow with less than that, his trip will not only be interpreted as having given Yeltsin a dismaying free pass on Chechnya, but as a personal diplomatic disaster.
We can also expect some Dole-deflection: well-photographed meetings with human rights leaders, long sessions with Russian reformers like Grigory Yavlinsky and Boris Nemtsov, a cold shoulder to Vladimir Zhirinovsky and Communist-agrarian apparatchiks. In his TV address to the Russian people, Clinton must not fail to dissociate the U.S. from the use of force in Chechnya.
On another aspect of his observance of the golden anniversary of World War II's end, I cannot cavil at Clinton's decision to skip London. The British Prime Minister, John Major, put the "special relationship" into a deep freeze with his contemptuous treatment of U.S. views on Bosnia. As Clinton showed on St. Patrick's Day -- courting Irish-American votes by turning the White House into an I.R.A. fund-raising platform -- it is now payback time.
Can you imagine Ike snubbing London on V-E Day? Or Ronald Reagan insulting Margaret Thatcher that way? Nope; Mr. Major has only his arrogance to blame. Would that Clinton had similarly suggested to Yeltsin that actions have consequences.
Looking ahead to V-J Day on Aug. 15, the Clinton Administration denies renaming it "Victory in the Pacific Day"; the reported renaming was probably a concoction of our hypersensitive Tokyo embassy.
This recalls the story of the Japanese tourist who walked down Broadway to 34th Street and, standing in front of the world's largest store, politely inquired of a New Yorker: "Where is Macy's?" To which the unforgetting native replied: "Pearl Harbor you found."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
FINGERHUT SHARES DIVE ON LOWER EARNINGS OUTLOOK

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
The Fingerhut Companies said yesterday that a slowdown in sales of big ticket items would mean lower earnings than previously expected. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of Fingerhut closed down $3.125 at $11.125. The company, a direct merchandiser of brand name and private label merchandise that is based in Minneapolis, said a slowdown in consumer spending was hitting its bottom line. The company said it expected first-quarter earnings to be 2 cents to 3 cents a share below consensus expectations of 15 cents to 17 cents a share. Second-quarter earnings are expected to be reduced by about 18 cents a share from consensus expectations, based on a continuation of current economic and consumer spending trends.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Carat Opening New York Office

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
The Aegis Group P.L.C., which owns Carat, Europe's largest media services company, said yesterday that Carat was opening an office, to be named Carat North America, in New York.
"This is a toe in the water," said Roger Parry, the former group development director of Aegis, who was named group vice president of Carat North America. "Within a few years' time, I suspect we'll be in it up to our neck." Aegis had hoped to expand into North America three or four years ago, he added, but postponed those plans to digest several acquisitions in Europe and wait out the worldwide advertising recession. 
 Initially, Mr. Parry said, the office would serve "as a gateway," making it easier for North American clients to work with Carat in Europe. Eventually, he added, the goal is to help serve advertisers' media needs in North America. The office, which opens today, is at 636 Broadway, between Houston and Bleecker Streets, in Manhattan.
Carat handles the media planning and buying on accounts with billings estimated at $6 billion for clients like Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., Reckitt & Colman P.L.C. and Volkswagen A.G. Of that, about $1 billion is from handling media services in Europe for American marketers like the Walt Disney Company, the Kellogg Company and the Philip Morris Companies.

HEADLINE: Where the Everyday Is a Scarcity

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: CAMPBELLTOWN, W.Va.

 BODY:
For nearly a century, most residents of this tumbledown mountain hamlet 80 miles east of Charleston have been drawing their drinking water from a common well on a hillside just above the town's 70 houses.
Three years ago, state officials found that the water was contaminated with pollutants, and issued an order to boil it before drinking. 
 Like most other people in Campbelltown, Carroll Barlow says it is high time that she and her neighbors were finally hooked up to the municipal water system in Marlinton, less than a mile away. But neither the state nor the local governments can afford to pay for the pipes or the pumps to carry the water up the valley.
"I hope I live long enough to get safe water in this house," said Ms. Barlow, 55, who says she has to clean her sinks and toilet twice a day to deal with rust-colored stains that the water from the well leaves behind.
State officials say no medical problems can be traced to the water, but Ms. Barlow is not taking any chances. She uses the well water only for washing and buys drinking water in 69-cent gallon jugs at the Foodland grocery store in Marlinton.
From small communities like Campbelltown to isolated hollows with no names, access to reliable supplies of clean drinking water has long been a problem in West Virginia. The state's rugged geography, coupled with the endemic poverty of rural Appalachia, has severely limited the ability of both local and state government to extend water lines. Neither the state nor the Federal Government is required to connect isolated residents to existing water systems, and money to build water or sewerage systems to spur economic development in rural areas is likely to become increasingly scarce.
"We just can't do everything," said W. D. Smith, a regional director of the Appalachian Regional Commission, a Federal agency that helps promote economic development but is a perennial target of budget-cutters in Congress.
Mr. Smith said that with so many communities seeking financing for new systems, only those that could demonstrate an unusually urgent need or immediate economic benefit would succeed.
"We've got a third-world situation here," he said. "I've seen human suffering, old people, people coming to me in tears. But I always have to ask them, 'What's so unusual about your situation?' It's not enough anymore just to say they don't have any water."
A recent study by the Agriculture Department concluded that more than a million people living in rural sections around the country, including large parts of the Mississippi Delta and areas along the Mexican border, did not have clean drinking water piped into their homes. But experts say no other state has so large a percentage of its population unserved by municipal systems as West Virginia. By the state's own estimate, almost a quarter of its 1.8 million people have no access to municipal water, and 40 percent are not served by public sewerage.
West Virginians who do not get municipal water rely mostly on wells; in places, a single well serves an entire community. Water drawn from the wells must in some cases be boiled or chemically treated to remove impurities like the contaminants that seep into underground water reservoirs from abandoned coal mines. People living near active mines are especially vulnerable to pollution; even subtle shifts in rock formations can unloose new contaminants into the aquifers that supply well water, or even destroy the aquifers altogether.
Senator Robert C. Byrd's ability to funnel Federal money home for West Virginia's highway system and other programs is legendary, but officials say state agencies have only recently focused on water and sewerage needs to bolster economic development. Last year voters approved a $300 million bond issue for water and sewerage projects.
"More people are being served now," said Amy Swann, a division director at West Virginia's Public Service Commission. "But there will always be people who won't be served. It's just too expensive to spend $1 million to construct a water line to hollows where 12 people live."
State officials say water problems exist in all 55 of West Virginia's counties but most acutely in the rugged eastern half of the state. Here, amid thick forests of maple, elm and oak, gurgling rivers and dazzling scenic overlooks, dozens of small communities, some with fewer than 100 residences, straddle narrow mountain roads that once served rich coal mines and timber stands.
The coal and timber industries are long past their peak, but many of the children and grandchildren of the workers remain, drawing from the same wells or roadside springs, some in use for more than 60 years. Most of the people are now too old, too poor or too proud to move.
In Marlinton itself, the latest problem is that officials do not have the $3 million needed to carry water from the town's water plant to the new hospital, which was built on a hill to keep it above the flood-prone banks of the Greenbrier River.
For now, the hospital, scheduled to open this summer, will draw its water from the well that serves the local school, across the street. "We're struggling to find the funding," said Marlinton's Mayor, Douglas Dunbrack, who doubts that the well water supply will be adequate for the hospital, which is intended to serve some 9,000 people in eastern West Virginia. "We need a big-time grant, but there's just no money available."

GRAPHIC: Photo: W. D. Smith, a director of the Appalachian Regional Commission, at an outfall of a mountainside spring that is used for drinking water by a small community near the town of Marlinton in eastern West Virginia. (Gary Truman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: DIARY;
Yesterday in Washington

 BODY:

LINE-ITEM VETO -- The Senate voted 69 to 29 to give the President the power to veto specific items in spending bills. The measure, passed in another form in the House, is a central part of the Republicans' Contract With America. The measure could produce a major power shift in Washington and could give the Democratic White House a far more potent say over the Republican agenda.
 
WELFARE REFORM -- The House voted 426 to 5 to require states to adopt procedures to suspend driver's licenses and professional licenses of people who fail to pay child support that they owe. It provided a victory for President Clinton, one of the few he has enjoyed on welfare legislation. But Mr. Clinton still opposes the overall bill, which would make vast changes in social welfare programs enacted over the last 60 years. 

PROPERTY RIGHTS -- Senate Republicans introduced legislation requiring the Government to pay "just compensation" for taking private property. The bill requires that owners get compensation if their property has been taken for public use, if their rights have been abridged, if they have been deprived of the economic benefits of the land or if the property is diminished in value by one-third. A similar measure has been approved by the House.
 
SMUT IN CYBERSPACE -- In a move that pushes the battles over free speech and pornography onto the electronic frontier, the Senate Commerce Committee approved a proposal that would subject people who transmit indecent or pornographic material over a computer network to fines as high as $10,000 and jail terms of up to two years.
 
THE ENVIRONMENT -- The Senate Governmental Affairs Committee approved relatively modest changes in how the Government writes rules protecting health, safety and the environment. A House version replaces health considerations with economic calculations of costs and benefits as the main factor in setting protective standards, while the measure the panel passed calls for agencies to make "a reasonable determination" that the benefits of a rule justify the costs.

HEADLINE: Senate Limits Rule Changes On Health

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
Considerably softening the radical changes that the House of Representatives approved last month, a Senate committee today approved relatively modest changes in how the Federal Government writes rules protecting health, safety and the environment.
The most important difference is that the version endorsed by Republicans and Democrats alike on the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee would not replace health considerations with economic calculations of costs and benefits as the main factor in setting protective standards under environmental laws. 
 Instead, the Senate bill calls for agencies to make "a reasonable determination" that the benefits of a rule justify the costs if such a finding is "not expressly or implicitly inconsistent with the statute under which the agency is acting."
If that language prevails over the House's, it will remove the central objection raised by the Clinton Administration, which opposes overturning the health-based standards of existing environmental laws.
But the Senate could also debate other alternatives that more closely resemble the House bill, including one sponsored by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader. His version awaits consideration in the Senate Judiciary Committee.
Separately, conservative senators including Mr. Dole and his rival for the Republican Presidential nomination, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, reached agreement on a proposal to compensate property owners when their land loses value because of regulations restricting its development. Their proposal is at least as far reaching as the House version.
Although both the House and Senate bills are principally directed at preventing Federal regulators from interfering with development when they enforce laws protecting endangered species and wetlands, the Senate bill would also compensate landowners when other kinds of regulations reduce property values by at least one-third.
Both developments today reflected cautious jockeying for position among moderates and conservatives, especially Republicans, over how the Senate should handle the anti-regulatory proposals that the House has passed as part of its new Republican majority's Contract with America.
The Administration and its environmentalist allies have been hoping that the Senate will water down the House measures, which if enacted would dramatically restrict the Government's ability to enforce laws like the Clean Water Act, the Clean Air Act, the Endangered Species Act and laws on toxic and hazardous wastes.
The Senate's course depends on whether moderate senators from both parties coalesce around proposals like the one unanimously approved today by the Governmental Affairs Committee. It is named after Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, the panel's chairman.
Like the measures that passed the House, the Roth bill calls for more extensive consideration by regulatory agencies of how best to reduce health and environmental risks and more examination of whether the expected benefits are worth the costs of proposed regulations.
But the Senate bill would apply to fewer rules -- those costing industries at least $100 million a year. It would not impose such an elaborate set of new procedures as the House bill and would not subject agency decisions to such extensive review by the courts.

HEADLINE: Cutbacks to Save Washington From Bankruptcy Leave Residents Angry and Fearful

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
With magnolias in bloom, tour buses crowding the streets and other welcome signs of spring in the nation's capital all about, Ollie Blocker stood in the noonday sun thinking about rats.
"I'm scared to death," she said, "With the city not picking up the trash, I'm fearful of them entering my house. All that debris, you know, that's how they breed." 
 A mother of three who works as a janitor for the Department of Labor, Ms. Blocker was about to join a noisy protest on Wednesday, one of a series of recent demonstrations by a public employees union to protest the way that District of Columbia officials are trying to resolve the city's $722 million fiscal crisis.
Today, members of the same group, the Service Employees International Union, disrupted a City Council hearing, and 20 others barged into the office of Speaker Newt Gingrich and demanded to meet with him. Mr. Gingrich was out, but 9 were arrested, bringing to 258 the number of union employees arrested in protests this week.
Two weeks ago, protesters complaining about cuts in the Police Department budget interrupted a City Council meeting, but there was no swift response to calls for help because the protesters were police officers.
To address the budget problems, the city has begun service cutbacks, layoffs and negotiations to win wage concessions from unions. And even harsher measures could result from negotiations involving Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., other city officials and Federal lawmakers to develop a plan to save the city from bankruptcy. Legislation is expected to be introduced in Congress next week to create a financial oversight board that would manage the budget and recommend changes.
Meanwhile, residents like Ms. Blocker, who earn little more than the minimum wage, say they feel angry, frustrated and powerless over the cutbacks, contending that the cuts are steadily eroding the quality of their lives.
Ms. Blocker said that in her case the cutbacks had made a bad situation worse. The city's rat-baiting patrols have ignored the alley behind her house in the northwest section of Washington for nearly nine months, she said.
"This city has always had rat patrols," she said. "Now there's no money for it."
For Clifton Smith, the city's financial crisis has compounded problems that started with Federal cutbacks last year. In his last job as a janitor for the Post Office, he earned $5.75 an hour. With his girlfriend working as a clerk at a variety store, they could afford the $635-a-month rent for a two-bedroom apartment in the southeast section, where they lived with their three children.
But Federal cutbacks cost him his job last year, Mr. Smith said, and his girlfriend lost hers eight months ago when the store refused to hold her job after she left to give birth to their third child.
Three months ago, he said, their money ran out. Mr. Smith moved back with his parents, while his girlfriend and the children moved in with hers.
Mr. Smith has periodically worked on construction projects. But with Congress insisting on larger cutbacks for the city than Mayor Barry has been willing to make, he said he was discouraged about finding steady work any time soon.
"When we were both working we were making ends meet," he said. "Now, I can't find anything. The city is getting rid of everybody. I'm hanging in there but only by a thin thread."
For the sake of his children, Mr. Smith said, he has vowed to avoid the opportunities of earning money illegally.
"It's crossed my mind," he said. "People in the neighborhood are selling drugs; everybody's kids have got to eat. But you've got to be stronger than that. You fight those thoughts because if you get caught, they will all be by themselves.
"But I know plenty of guys who have gone the other way. You just have to keep a positive attitude."
Jocelynn Johnson, who earns $30,000 a year working for the city's Department of Public Works, is fighting to maintain her middle-class status.
She has already felt the sting of two furlough days, and with Mayor Barry's plan that all non-essential city employees be furloughed for 10 days before the fiscal year ends on Sept. 30, she said she was worried about falling behind on her car payments and rent of $550 a month.
Unlike Ms. Blocker and Mr. Smith, who said they believed that the Mayor was doing the best he could under trying circumstances, Ms. Johnson, who is 40 and single, said she believed he had not done nearly enough to ease the city's financial crisis. She cited the city's decision to stop picking up bagged leaves as an example.
"I was on his transition team," she said of Mayor Barry. "We gave him a plan for the city to make money by selling the leaves for mulch and compost. That way, the city is cleaner and the city makes money. But he didn't do it.
"Meanwhile, signs on the street where I live make me move my car so they can clean the street or else I get a ticket. I move my car, but they never clean the street."
"What's going on here is scary," she said. "It's very scary."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Morgan Now Seeks $1 Billion for Mexico

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
J. P. Morgan & Company is now seeking to raise $1 billion in financing for Mexico to help bolster that country's banking system, New York bankers said yesterday.
The planned financing, which would have a maturity of several years, is intended to replace an earlier $3 billion short-term bank loan, proposed in January but never brought to fruition. 
 The apparent failure to complete arrangements for that $3 billion in financing has raised concern that bankers are having cold feet as Mexico's financial crisis worsened.
But Mexican officials say that the revised plan reflects the realities of the financial support the country has since received from the United States and others since Jan. 9, when Mexico first requested the $3 billion to shore up its frail banking system.
Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz, in a letter dated Wednesday to his country's most important foreign bankers, said "a great deal has changed" since Jan. 9.
Mexico is now receiving nearly $50 billion of financial support from the International Monetary Fund, the United States and other countries, the minister wrote. So, a $3 billion bank loan, which would take some months to collect, "and then would only remain available until the end of this year, will not be of real benefit to Mexico," his letter said.
In the light of these circumstances, Mexico is now consulting with a number of banks to design a new, "market-based Government of Mexico" loan to support a Government program with the purpose of safeguarding Mexican banks.
In December Mexico devalued, then floated the peso, and in the last three months, the peso has lost roughly half its international exchange value, ending trading today at 6.90 to the dollar.
Many foreign investors who had eagerly rushed into Mexico in recent years to reap high returns have pulled out their money, their holdings having been badly mauled by the devaluation and by drops in Mexican stocks and bonds.
The Mexico City stock market rose today, with the main index closing at 1,615.70, up 24.54 points or 1.54 percent. For the year to date, however, the market has fallen nearly 32 percent in peso terms and just under 50 percent in dollar value. Some short-term debt notes have sold at a yield as high as 82 percent.
Amid all this, Mexico has been struggling to prevent damage to its banking system, also badly shaken by the peso's plunge.
Last year, the country allowed its current-account deficit, a broad measure of trade and services, to balloon. Mexico is now trying to follow a program of economic austerity to regain international confidence and increase exports.
The austerity program is imposing heavy economic costs on much of the middle and lower classes. And it is still not clear how bad the political repercussions will be for the long-ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, which for decades has controlled Mexico's national Government as well as virtually all important state and local posts.
Mexico's commercial bankers seem to like the new economic program. The chairman of Citicorp, William R. Rhodes, told a group of American investors this week that the program was a good one, but he added that its success depended on its being carried out in disciplined fashion in order to restore confidence.

HEADLINE: Is Organized Crime Back at the Table?

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS

 BODY:
Just a few steps from the Cafe du Monde, a popular tourist spot here, is Frank's, a casual, Italian-style restaurant that not long ago caught the eye of a different class of sightseer -- the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
The restaurant's habitues included some intriguing characters with nicknames like Noogie, Mr. A and Muffaletta Frank. And their table talk was not limited to food. Based largely on F.B.I. surveillance, Federal prosecutors won indictments last year of 17 suspected members or associates of the Marcello crime family here and the Genovese and Gambino families in New York. 
 Among other things, the 17 are accused of controlling a distributor of video poker machines and draining millions from the machines' manufacturer, Bally Gaming International Inc. All of those indicted have denied wrongdoing and say they have no ties to organized crime.
For their part, prosecutors say the scheme is a case study of how the mob is trying to take its place again at the nation's gambling tables. As sketched out in documents from regulatory hearings and bankruptcy filings and in search warrants, wiretapped conversations and the indictments themselves, it is a story of sour deals, greedy hustlers and terrified corporate executives that also raises questions about Bally Gaming's actions in the case.
The gambling industry has long been trying to shed its image as a mob-controlled domain for one in which publicly traded companies like Bally Gaming operate under regulatory scrutiny. Experts agree that the vast majority of gambling companies are now free of criminal influence.
But as more states race to open casinos, cracks may also be opening in the licensing and hiring process. Federal and state investigations in places as far apart as California and Minnesota suggest that organized criminals and other questionable operators may already have a foothold.
"You have a proliferation of gaming, which makes it ripe for a takeover by organized crime," said Wilmore W. Whitmore, president of the Louisiana Economic Development and Gaming Corporation, a state regulatory board.
Bally Gaming is still reeling from its experience in Louisiana. The company, based in Las Vegas, Nev., makes a variety of gambling equipment. Originally a unit of the Bally Entertainment Corporation, a casino operator, it was spun off in 1992.
Bally Gaming's troubles here grew out of a brief marriage of convenience that began in 1991, when it came looking for a local distributor to break into a lucrative new market. Prosecutors say that those lurking behind the company it found, Worldwide Gaming, were simply looking for a mark.
By the time the marriage unraveled in 1993, Bally Gaming says it was out about $18 million and Worldwide was in bankruptcy.
Because Worldwide was a start-up, Bally Gaming bankrolled its entire business and also lent it money to finance truck stop owners and others who wanted to lease or buy the company's machines. But Worldwide repaid little to Bally Gaming. A key reason was that payments collected from the machine operators by a company related to Worldwide were skimmed by the same mob figures who were behind the distributor, prosecutors have charged.
Views differ sharply, however, over whether Bally Gaming was an innocent victim or a victim of its own making. Some critics have questioned whether the company, in its haste to cash in on a gambling gold rush, overlooked or brushed aside warning signals.
Daniel Horgan, a lawyer for Bally Gaming, said that company executives did everything they could at the time to uncover problems at Worldwide and root them out. "Everything looks different with the benefit of 20-20 hindsight," he said.
But Mr. Whitmore, the state regulator, has his doubts, suggesting that organized crime figures may have found the perfect victim in Bally Gaming. "These guys probably couldn't believe it," he said. "They didn't even have to reach into their own pockets."
In January, a few weeks after an article appeared in The Times-Picayune of New Orleans questioning Bally Gaming's actions, Mr. Whitmore denied the company a permit to sell equipment to the giant Harrah's casino being built here, saying that Bally Gaming had allowed itself to be "infiltrated" by organized crime. He was overruled, however, by the full board. The board agreed with prosecutors, who described Bally Gaming as blameless, and it issued a temporary permit.
A fuller picture of the company's role is certain to emerge this fall, when those indicted go to trial.
The episode's roots stretch back to the passage in September 1991 of legislation that soon put video-poker machines in every bar and truck stop from New Orleans to Baton Rouge and beyond. Gambling-equipment manufacturers viewed the state as a bonanza, but the catch was that they would be required to operate through a local distributor.
The legislation also apparently posed a challenge to suspected members of the Marcello crime family, which had been active in gambling. To get into the new video-poker market, Anthony (Mr. A) Carollo, the family's reputed acting head, and his aide, Frank (Muffaletta Frank) Gagliano, needed to take control of a distributor run by seemingly legitimate front men to avoid the scrutiny of regulators, according to last year's indictments, which named both men.
That company was Worldwide Gaming, whose president was Steven R. Bolson, a lawyer who had worked for several Atlantic City casinos, and whose vice president was Christopher J. Tanfield, a concert promoter. With the help of Mr. Bolson's contacts, Worldwide became a distributor for Bally Gaming in late 1991. By mid-1992, it graduated to exclusive distributor after bringing in an order for 2,000 machines.
But even before that pact was completed, a warning sign had appeared. In early 1992, The Village Voice published an article that linked Mr. Tanfield with Eugene (Noogie) Gilpin, a reputed associate of the Genovese crime family who was also named in last year's indictments. Mr. Tanfield abruptly resigned from Worldwide Gaming, but stayed on as a consultant. Executives of Bally Entertainment, then in the process of spinning off Bally Gaming, say they looked into the newspaper's allegation but found no support for it.
They may not have looked hard enough. Federal investigators, who stumbled onto Worldwide as a result of a run-of-the-mill bookmaking inquiry, later maintained that Mr. Tanfield was an associate of both the Genovese and Gambino families. In a recent interview, Mr. Tanfield, who was also indicted and who denies the charges, said that no one from Bally Entertainment or Bally Gaming asked him about the article until November 1992.
By then, Bally Gaming executives were wondering how they got involved with him and others at Worldwide and how they could get out. "It's all fraudulent," John Garner, Bally Gaming's controller, told Jamie Perdiago, an outside lawyer for the company, in a wiretapped conversation cited in court documents.
Meanwhile, those later indicted in the case were keeping busy. Mr. Gilpin and others flew in from New York for discussions with Mr. Carollo. And Mr. Tanfield, for one, wildly boasted of future success, court papers indicate.
"I got as much clout as you need, anything you need," he proclaimed in a wiretapped conversation with a Government informant. "I got the Governor, I got the Senate, I got the Congressmen, I got the legislatures and I got the streets."
Events at Worldwide, however, were of increasing concern to Bally Gaming. When its representatives visited the distributor, they found that money was being lent to those leasing equipment without proper liens being placed on the machines, Mr. Perdiago, the lawyer for Bally Gaming, recently testified at regulatory hearings.
"Chris Tanfield had a saying that was really accurate," said Mr. Perdiago, who had been retained by Bally Gaming to monitor Worldwide."It was like they were driving down the highway with a grocery bag of hundred-dollar bills and the windows were down."
Suspicious-looking individuals also hung around Worldwide's office in the New Orleans suburb of Metairie and Bally Gaming executives did not relish run-ins with them. Jerry Flynn, a former executive who was sent to investigate problems at Worldwide, was terrified of Felix A. Riggio 3d, who ran the company close to Worldwide that collected money from the bars and truck stops.
"He would even run out of the room, run out of Worldwide, you know, out the back door when Riggio came in the front door," Mr. Perdiago testified. Mr. Riggio was also among those indicted.
By the end of 1992, Bally Gaming executives recognized that Worldwide represented a potential catastrophe. In a wiretapped conversation, Mr. Garner, the controller, told Mr. Perdiago, "This pig is getting sloppier and sloppier," court papers indicate. He also related how he had told another man to go "perfume this pig" before the auditors arrived, according to the court papers.
Mr. Horgan, the Bally Gaming lawyer, said that Mr. Garner was just using a "colorful choice of words" and was not covering anything up. Arthur Lemann 3d, a lawyer who represents Mr. Carollo, said that he intended to show at trial that Bally Gaming controlled the activities of its distributor, a contention that Mr. Horgan rejected.
Following an inquiry by a private investigator, Bally Gaming demanded in November 1992 that Worldwide end its association with Mr. Tanfield and several others. It clearly hoped to salvage its investment and keep Worldwide afloat.
That would prove to be wishful thinking. By then, Mr. Bolson, Worldwide's president, knew that the company was controlled by organized crime, according to a plea agreement he entered last year.
Finally, in May 1993, Bally Gaming dropped Worldwide, and the distributor immediately filed for bankruptcy-law protection. A year later, a Federal grand jury handed up its indictments.
Separately, in plea agreements, Mr. Bolson acknowledged that he helped conceal those controlling Worldwide, and Alan Maiss, a former president of Bally Gaming, pleaded guilty in January to charges of failing to tell regulators that Mr. Tanfield did not have a gambling license. Mr. Bolson and Mr. Maiss are cooperating with the Government.
Bally Gaming must still pass muster for a final permit here. And it may even lose its name. Bally Entertainment, which licenses the name to its spinoff, said it was thinking about taking it back because of the Louisiana debacle.

Chronology: "Key Dates in a Tainted Partnership"
For its foray into Louisiana, Bally Gaming bet on an exclusive alliance with Worldwide Gaming, a distributorship prosecutors say was controlled by organized-crime figures.
 
Sept. 1991: Louisiana passes state video poker law that requires out-of-state manufacturers like Bally Gaming Inc. to sell through an in-state distributor.
 Dec. 1991: Worldwide Gaming is formed, allegedly at the behest of several suspected organized-crime figures whose own license to distribute gambling machines in the state had been denied renewal by the state police.
 March 1992: An article in The Village Voice details Worldwide's alleged ties to organized crime. Bally Entertainment officials look into the allegations but say they found nothing to support them.
 July 1992: After Worldwide brokers an order for 2,000 of Bally's poker machines, Bally Gaming names Worldwide its exclusive distributor in Louisiana. Bally Gaming agrees to underwrite Worldwide's operations.
 Aug. 1992: Bally Entertainment, a casino operator and the parent of Bally Gaming, the equipment maker, spins off majority control of Bally Gaming as a separate company.
 Oct. 1992: Bally Gaming hires a private investigator to start looking into backgrounds of individuals associated with Worldwide. The inquiry finds that some have criminal records. Nov. 1992: Following additional concerns, Bally Gaming directs Worldwide to end its association with several people, including its former vice president, Christopher J. Tanfield, the subject of VV article. Worldwide complies, but by this time its president, Steven R. Bolson, is also aware that organized-crime figures are behind the company. May 1993: Bally Gaming drops Worldwide as its distributor. Worldwide immediately files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.
 March 1994: A Federal grand jury indicts 17 people associated with Worldwide and a related company on racketeering charges.
 Jan. 1995: Bally is denied a permit by the president of a state regulatory board, Willmore Whitmore, to sell equipment to planned Harrah's casino in New Orleans on the ground that Bally allowed itself to be "infiltrated" by organized crime. He is overruled shortly afterward by the full board.
 Sept. 1995: Criminal trials of the Worldwide defendants are scheduled to begin. (pg. D2)

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Up 3,000 Last Week

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits rose last week by 3,000, the Labor Department said today, marking the first three-consecutive-week increases in nearly a year.
New applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 346,000 in the week that ended Saturday, the department said, up from 343,000 in the previous week and the highest since 348,000 in the week that ended on Feb. 11. 
 It was the first three-week increase since the period last April 2 through April 16, when claims rose 3,000, 14,000 and 11,000, respectively.
