HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Edge Higher in a Light Up-and-Down Session

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities edged up in light trading yesterday, following the dollar up and down through most of the session but holding their own at the end while the dollar sank against the yen.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 2/32 , to 1026/32 for a yield of 7.44 percent, down from 7.45 percent on Wednesday. The rates on shorter-maturity bills were also a bit lower. 
 Analysts say that when the dollar is strong, dollar-denominated investments are more attractive to foreign investors. A strong dollar also reduces the risk that rising import costs will accelerate inflation, which causes fixed-income securities to lose value.
Anthony Dwyer, chief market strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said bond market participants so far had ignored the recent signals of strong economic growth.
"There is much confusion in the market," Mr. Dwyer said, "but it is confusion on the plus side. It is optimism about a soft landing, low inflation and continued growth." And that, he added, is the reason "the bond market is holding up so well despite the declining dollar, despite recent economic reports suggesting robust growth."
Mr. Dwyer said he expected the economic reports in April to provide a better look at the first quarter. "I think the quarter will show continued above-average economic growth," Mr. Dwyer said. "And since the economy is holding up well, it suggests that there will be more interest rate hikes in the offing" that will lead to "a more pronounced slowdown in 1996."
Mr. Dwyer added: "This scenario continues to make long-term bonds attractive in my opinion. As long as the Fed can keep inflation in check, the historical real rate of return for the bond market will continue to be quite compelling."
But traders say they need more economic data to make big trades. The handful of economic reports so far this week have provided mixed signals on whether the economy is slowing enough to reduce the risk of inflation. In the only economic report today, the Labor Department said the number of initial claims for jobless benefits rose 3,000 last week, to 346,000. Expectations were for a drop of 3,000.
In when-issued trading ahead of next week's note auctions, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.73 percent, while the five-year note was offered at a price to yield 7.02 percent.
In the municipal bond market, which some investors are beginning to find a bit too expansive, there was little reaction to the news that the State of Wisconsin Investment Board posted a loss of $95 million from a derivatives deal, traders said.
Among corporate borrowers, the leading asset-backed issuer yesterday was the Beneficial Mortgage Corporation, a loan unit of the Beneficial Corporation. It sold $1.1 billion of floating-rate securities backed by home equity loans through a specially formed BCI Home Equity Loan Trust.
By packaging some of this debt into bonds, lenders like Beneficial can free cash on their balance sheets, making room for more loans.
Morgan Stanley & Company led the underwriters, who sold $913 million of senior securities, with an average life of 2.16 years, at a price of par to yield 22 basis points more than the one-month London interbank offered rate, which international banks charge each other for loans. Yesterday Libor was 6.125 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
For $50 million of senior securities with the same average life and price, the yield was 25 basis points higher than the 30-day commercial paper rate, which was 6.07 percent late yesterday. All the senior securities are rated triple-A by both Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's.
A $110 million tranche of subordinated securities, with an average life of 3.51 years, was priced at par to yield about 35 basis points more than the one-month Libor rate, while $30.4 million in subordinated securities, with an average life of 0.4 year, was also priced at par, to yield 25 basis points more than Libor. Underwriters said the subordinated debt was rated A-3 by Moody's and A by S.& P.

HEADLINE: Defending Affirmative Action, Clinton Details Plan to Review It

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
President Clinton today offered his most articulate defense yet of the concept of affirmative action -- and his most extensive explanation of his review of existing Federal programs to determine whether to drop some preferences based on race or sex.
Mr. Clinton said he wanted to find out which programs work, whether even some of those that do have resulted in reverse discrimination, and whether some economically disadvantaged groups are not adequately covered by current preferential treatment for women and minorities in hiring, promotion and Government contracts. But over all, he argued, such programs have greatly benefited American society since the mid-1960's. 
 "I'm against discrimination," Mr. Clinton told a group of college newspaper reporters in a question-and-answer session at the White House. "I'm against giving people opportunities who are unqualified. But we all have an interest -- including white males -- in developing the capacities of all of us to relate to one another, because our economy will grow quicker, it'll be stronger, and in a global society our diversity our greatest asset.
"We must not let this debate be another cheap political wedge issue to divide the American electorate."
Mr. Clinton also sharpened his vow to oppose Republican efforts to cut back college loan programs, saying, "The veto pen is always there."
Since Mr. Clinton announced the review of affirmative action last month in response to Republican calls to roll back preference programs, the White House has been under growing pressure from historically Democratic constituencies like blacks and women's groups to explain its purpose and to resist backing away from such programs.
On Friday, Deval L. Patrick, the Assistant Attorney General for civil rights, is to testify at a House subcommittee hearing on the subject. The White House had said for days that Mr. Clinton would find some opportunity before then to outline his views and set the tone, and he took the occasion of a friendly full-dress news conference with about 100 college journalists in the East Room to do so.
Reporters from Georgetown University (where Mr. Clinton went to college), Yale University (where he attended law school) and the University of Arkansas (where he taught at the law school) had seats of honor in the front row. Jeff Glasser of Yale asked the first question, and it brought satisfied smiles from senior White House aides standing at the side of the room.
"How do you plan to stop Congress from capping direct loans or cutting Pell Grants or paying the interest on loans taken out during college?" Mr. Glasser asked about various Republican proposals to trim popular college loan and grant programs. "Are you willing to veto legislation if it comes across your desk?"
Mr. Clinton replied: "Well, of course, I am in the areas of education, which are so important to me. But let me say again, what my first choice has been all along is to try to prevail in the debate in the Congress."
The President also said he thought Speaker Newt Gingrich's notion of making laptop computers more available to the nation's poor children as an educational aid was sound (though Mr. Gingrich himself allowed that his proposal for tax credits to do so might be "nutty").
But it was a question on affirmative action that seemed to animate the President most, as he summarized the history of the civil rights movement, recalling the days when restrooms were segregated and there were "no women in any number of jobs" where "we take it for granted that women will be."
"We have made a lot of progress because we tried to take action to open up more opportunities to people without regard to their race or gender," Mr. Clinton said. "It is in everyone's interest to see that everybody gets the best chance to live up to the fullest of their abilities. On the other hand, it is in no one's interest to see that people get positions if they are completely unqualified to hold them. So the question is, How do we now go forward?"
Mr. Clinton said he had no answers yet, but he listed the questions he has asked his aides: "I have said first of all how do these programs work, and do they have a positive effect? O.K.? That's the first question.
"Secondly, even if they work, are they sometimes, at least, unfair to others? Could you argue that in some cases there is reverse discrimination; and if so, how?
"Thirdly, are there now others in need who are not covered by affirmative action programs? Keep in mind that's really what's fueling this whole thing. You've got 20 years in this country where most hourly wage earners have not kept up with inflation. Most Americans are working harder for lower wages than they were making 20 years ago."

HEADLINE: Sammons Sells Remainder of Its Cable Systems for $800 Million

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
Sammons Communications Inc. completed its exit from the cable television business yesterday, selling its remaining cable systems with 440,000 subscribers for $800 million to a pair of companies associated with Tele-Communications Inc.
A spokeswoman for Tele-Communications, LaRae Schlichting, said the giant cable operator would divide the Sammons cable systems between the Lenfest Group, which is 50 percent owned by Jerry Lenfest and 50 percent owned by Tele-Communications, and TKR Cable, a joint venture of Knight-Ridder Inc. and Tele-Communications. 
 An industry executive with knowledge of the details of the transaction said about 293,000 Sammons subscribers, mostly in eastern and central Pennsylvania, would go to Lenfest. The other 147,000 subscribers, largely in central and northern New Jersey, would go to TKR Cable.
Sammons, based in Dallas, declined to comment on the transaction. But the executive said the company had issued an internal memorandum notifying employees that the cable systems had been sold. The transaction is being financed entirely with cash, according to the executive.
Earlier this month, Sammons agreed to sell cable systems with 650,000 subscribers to the Marcus Cable Company for $1 billion. That deal, which includes equity contributions from the leveraged buyout firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst and Goldman, Sachs & Company, is also being financed with cash.
In the latest transaction, the cable systems are being sold for roughly $1,820 a subscriber -- substantially more than the $1,520 paid in the Marcus deal.
Yesterday's deal reflects the premium that clusters of cable systems can fetch. Industry executives said the properties, which cover markets like Morristown, N.J., Atlantic City, and Harrisburg, Pa., are more closely grouped than the systems sold to Marcus, which are scattered throughout Texas, Northern and Southern California, the Midwest and the South.
Sammons is one of many small and midsized cable companies that have been selling their systems to giant operators like Tele-Communications and Time Warner in a striking consolidation of the industry. In general, the big buyers are seeking densely clustered cable systems, which are more economical to upgrade for new services.
Scripps Howard Cable said on Monday that it was seeking a buyer for its cable systems, which have 749,000 subscribers. And Viacom still hopes to sell its cable systems with 1.1 million subscribers, though Congress essentially derailed a deal that would have sold the systems to a minority-led investor group that included Tele-Communications.
Viacom had hoped to benefit from a Government program that allowed companies to avoid paying capital gains taxes on profits from the sale of television and cable properties to minorities. But the House of Representatives and the Senate Finance Committee voted to eliminate the tax break.
Sammons, a privately held company with interests in insurance and other businesses, was founded by Charles Sammons, who died in 1988. The company's assets were believed to be placed into a family trust, which is now selling the cable portion of the portfolio.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises to Another Record, but Broader Market Drifts

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
While the Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq indexes hit record highs yesterday, the overall stock market appeared to drift in advance of today's report on durable goods orders.
After rising as much as 12 points and falling as much as 15 points, the Dow finished the day up 4.84 points at 4,087.83. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 0.28 point, to 495.95, while the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 2.29 points, to a record 811.39. 
 Bond prices rose a little yesterday, with the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond edging down to 7.44 percent from 7.45 percent. The dollar edged up against the German mark, settling in New York at 1.4037 marks from 1.4030 marks on Wednesday. But the dollar slipped to another record low against the Japanese yen, falling to 88.15 yen from 89 yen.
Some analysts say that as the five-month-long rally in bonds appears to have stalled, the stock market rally may also begin to falter, despite a month of record-breaking rises in the Dow.
One clue will be the market's reaction today to the important report on the demand for durable goods, like cars and refrigerators. If the figures are higher than expected, and thus seen as inflationary, stocks may fall sharply. If the report is soft, as expected, and stocks fail to rally strongly, it will be evidence that the stock market rally is coming to an end.
The steadily rising Dow is "concealing a lot of action," said Christine A. Callies, equity strategist for Brown Brothers Harriman & Company. "It is not that nothing is going on, it's just that a lot is going on at cross-purposes."
Particularly worrisome, she said, is the rise in gold and oil stocks, which often indicates a thriving economy that could prompt further interest-rate increases from the Federal Reserve, thus hurting stocks. Since early January, the American Stock Exchange Oil Index of 16 oil stocks has risen more than 6.5 percent and the Philadelphia Gold and Silver Index of 9 gold mining stocks has risen 10 percent.
"The real issue is whether there is much money left on the sidelines that could go back into the market," Ms. Callies said. "I don't think so."
The reason is a rush of money into high-yielding six-month and one-year Treasury bills. And many investors do not review their fixed-income investments for at least a year. "There may not be much money out there to exploit any good news to come." she said.
Among the big movers in the market yesterday, Alliance Semiconductor, a maker of memory chips, rose 3 1/4, to 49 1/4, on an optimistic outlook for the computer industry.
Roberts Pharmaceutical, a drug maker, fell 8, to 26 3/4, after warning that first-quarter earnings would be below Wall Street estimates. Putnam Trust Company, a bank holding company in Greenwich, Conn., fell 3, to 37 3/4, after it said it was exploring a merger with a company it would not identify.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 321.5 million shares, down from this year's daily average of 329 million shares.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.12 point, to 267.92, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks by 1,046 to 1,012. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 2.37 points, to 458.52.
Of the component stocks of the S.& P. 500 index, 207 rose, led by Microsoft, up 113/16 , to 72 3/4, the second day after it announced a software venture with Dreamworks SKG, the new Hollywood studio formed by Steven Spielberg, Jeffrey Katzenberg and David Geffen.
The most active stock, at 7.7 million shares, was the Physicians Corporation of America, a managed health care company, which fell 4, to 20 3/4, after it announced an expected fall in earnings for the first and second quarter as a result of higher operating costs.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Lumber Prices in Sharp Decline On Shift in Canadian Rail Strike

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Lumber prices fell sharply yesterday after a move to end a rail strike in Canada raised concerns that a weak housing market could soon become flooded with supplies.
Lumber prices tumbled after talks resumed between CP Rail, one of the largest railroads in Canada, and a striking union. The news of the meeting raised hopes for a settlement that would end a series of walkouts that have brought the three big rail lines in Canada to a halt. But the talks broke off later in the day. 
 In other trading, coffee and cotton also fell, driving down the Commodity Research Bureau index by 1.42 points, to 234.06.
With as much as three-quarters of the lumber produced in Canada shipped by rail, an extended strike could slow lumber shipments and inflate prices, as mills scramble for more expensive and hard-to-find alternative shipping routes.
Lumber for May delivery fell $8.90 yesterday to settle at $275.60 for 1,000 board feet on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the lowest for the active contract since July 24, 1993. Lumber prices have plunged 12.6 percent in the last month.
A settlement of the strike would bring more lumber to a housing market in the United States that is suffering because of higher interest rates. Coffee dropped to its lowest price in five weeks, as producers opposed a plan to set export quotas in hopes of raising prices.
Under an agreement reached on March 13 by members of the Association of Coffee Producing Countries, individual countries have the option of either retaining coffee in warehouses until prices rise or setting overall export quotas that cannot be exceeded.
While Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer, had been expected to choose the quota system, producers are now calling for a retention plan. The opposition threatens to delay the decision by Brazil and has lowered the confidence in the overall agreement, traders said.
Coffee for May delivery fell 3.9 cents, to $1.6565 a pound, on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.
Cotton fell the daily trading limit amid concern that a Government report would show sales for export were canceled last week because of record high prices. May cotton fell its 2-cent daily limit, to $1.0430 a pound, on the New York Cotton Exchange.
After the close of trading yesterday, the Agriculture Department said in its weekly report on export sales that cancellations had caused net new sales to fall by 7,100 bales.

HEADLINE: International Briefs;
German Metal Concern In Deal on Creditors

 BODY:
An effort to revamp Metallgesellschaft A.G., the troubled German metals and engineering conglomerate, was bolstered yesterday after Germany's two biggest banks agreed to buy out the company's American and French creditors for $107 million.
The last-minute move by Deutsche Bank A.G. and Dresdner Bank A.G. strengthened Metallgesell schaft's plan to seek fresh equity capital from stockholders. The plan, presented to shareholders today, had been opposed by nearly a dozen American and French bank creditors, notably Societe Generale and Credit Lyonnais of France. 
 The buyout was announced to reporters at the shareholders meeting by a member of the banking consortium, who refused to be identified by name. The announcement was made as Metallgesellschaft reported that all its operations, including its subsidiary in the United States, the MG Corporation, had returned to profitability.
Metallgesellschaft was on the brink of collapse in January 1994, after MG accumulated $1.33 billion in losses from trading in oil futures. A collapse was averted by $1.9 billion bailout by the creditor banks. Bloomberg Business News

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Trade Gap and Japanese Selling Send Dollar to Low of 88.15 Yen

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar continued its slide against the Japanese yen yesterday, slipping to another record low in New York trading.
Currency dealers attributed the dollar's decline yesterday to lingering concern over the huge United States trade deficit and selling by Japanese companies and investment funds ahead of the close of their fiscal year. 
 On Wednesday, the Commerce Department reported that the United States trade deficit widened sharply in January. The strong gain in imports suggested that foreign exporters have a wealth of dollars to sell. The deficit with Japan is at a record high.
And the dollar generally slumps leading up to March 31 as Japanese companies try to bolster their balance sheets by selling off dollar-denominated United States assets and converting the dollars into yen.
The decline yesterday prompted the Bank of Japan to intervene in the currency markets, buying dollars to prop up the value of the currency against the yen, dealers said. The Bank of Japan has repeatedly expressed its concern that a strong yen will make its exports too expensive for foreign markets.
 Japan's central bankers are "uncomfortable because their exporters are uncomfortable," said David Munro, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics. "The playing field has been tipped maybe 10 percent in our favor."
The dollar fell as low as 88.01 yen before settling in late New York trading at 88.15 yen, breaking the previous New York low of 89 yen set on Wednesday. The dollar has fallen nearly 12 percent against the yen in the last three months.
Some economists said they expected the Japanese asset flight might end by next week, but they expressed concern the decline might undermine international confidence in the dollar.
 "The problem is not based on U.S. economic fundamentals," said Robert Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities.
Against the German mark, the dollar fared better yesterday -- a by-product of the recovery of other European currencies against the mark.
 The Bank of France was rumored to have intervened to lift the French franc against the mark, creating momentum that spread to other European currencies.
In New York trading, the dollar edged up to 1.43037 marks, from 1.4030 marks on Thursday. But the dollar slipped to 1.1605 Swiss francs from 1.1642 francs. And the British pound rose to $1.5948 from $1.5884.

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;
From 1936 and 1956, Documentary Artworks

BYLINE: By CHARLES HAGEN 

 BODY:
There's no reason that an exhibition whose sole organizing principle is to present photographs taken in a single year should be meaningful, let alone interesting. If anything, the opposite is true: the overall quality of work produced in a given year is apt to be average.
On the other hand, no period is without some good work; judicious selection could make any year look good. And such a selection might suggest other understandings about the period in question. 
 No doubt that was the thinking behind "1936," at the James Danziger Gallery, and "Circa 1956," a companion show at the 292 Gallery, both in SoHo. Both focus on works made in a given year, although only "1936" adheres closely to that restriction; the show at 292 includes works from throughout the 1950's.
Marianne Courville, who organized "1936," increased her chances of success by choosing a particularly rich year. Despite, or in some cases in response to the economic and political upheaval that engulfed Europe and the United States, photographers produced significant images that year in a wide range of styles and genres.
The dominant pictorial mode of the day was documentary, which in photography meant images presented as evidence of social facts. But documentary works can be used for everything from propaganda to entertainment, and examples of this are included in the Danziger show.
Not only was 1936 a peak moment in the life of the Farm Security Administration, whose photographers were trying both to promote New Deal farm policies and to record the American social landscape, but it was also the year in which the first issue of Life magazine was published. Works from both sources are featured prominently in "1936."
Representing the Farm Security Administration are images by several of its most famous photographers, including Walker Evans, Dorothea Lange, Russell Lee and Arthur Rothstein. Margaret Bourke-White's cover shot of the Fort Peck Dam in Montana, for Life's first issue, is also on display, as is a gag photo of the exhausted Life editors after putting the first issue to bed.
Photo-reporting in Europe tended to have a more voyeuristic edge than in the United States, a quality that is fully apparent in Bill Brandt's photograph of a couple, locked in an embrace, in a dimly lighted bedroom. But Brassai, another leading practitioner of this sort of keyhole documentary work, is represented not by his titillating photographs of Parisian night life but by one of his strangely expressive close-ups of graffiti.
The Surrealist overtones of Brassai's picture can be found in other seemingly straightforward images here. The row houses in Berenice Abbott's "Fifth Avenue Houses" stand apart from their neighbors in blistering sunlight, and seem ready to spring to life. A more openly Surrealist image is Josef Breitenbach's hand-painted image of biomorphic cutouts squiggling across the surface of the print.
Some of the most interesting pictures in the show, even by well-known artists, are relatively unfamiliar. A prime example is a sweet and mysterious image by Andre Kertesz, the Hungarian photographer then working in Paris, which shows his wife, Elizabeth, shading her eyes with her hand.
In general, the 1930's were a period of high modernism in photography, and many pieces reflect the emphasis on form and the sharp-focus clarity that characterized the movement. A classic Edward Weston nude, of a model sitting on a stool with one knee raised so her body forms an elegant triangle, is present, as is Weston's quieter but equally moving image of feathery clouds over the beach in Santa Monica, Calif.
But photographic activity in 1936 was not limited to documentary work, photojournalism and art. The Danziger exhibition gains strength from its inclusion of sports and fashion photography; in fact, more examples would have been welcome. Harold Edgerton's prints of film strips showing a bullet exploding a balloon offer at least a reference to scientific photography, and there's even a snapshot by an anonymous photographer.
Behind the sense of exuberant experimentation in many works was the growing threat of war. Not that photographers were unaware of the direction of events: Robert Capa's photograph from the Spanish Civil War, of a Loyalist soldier felled by a bullet, foreshadowed the outbreak of World War II; Roman Vishniac's image of Jews in Poland studying the cabala was part of an effort to record the Jewish culture of Eastern Europe, soon to be destroyed in the Holocaust.
The time-capsule approach of "1936" challenges traditional notions of history, suggesting that a chronological slice through time can be as telling as a narrative approach. But the diversity of the images, and of the purposes for which they were created, frustrates attempts to organize them into a single conceptual structure.
The limitations of this strictly chronological approach are apparent in "Circa 1956." While it includes several notable images, from Robert Frank's shot of a glowing jukebox in New York City to Saul Leiter's delicate study of two men in hats outside a store window, the show lacks the scope or unity of the Danziger exhibition.
Of course, this may reflect a lack of available material rather than some deficiency in the work of that period. Nevertheless, in both shows the tantalizing notion persists that the pictures fit into some larger order. After all, weren't they all made in the same year?
The show "1936" is at the James Danziger Gallery, 130 Prince Street, SoHo, and "Circa 1956" is at the 292 Gallery, 120 Wooster Street, at Prince Street, in SoHo. Both shows are to remain on view through April 8.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Elizabeth," by Andre Kertesz, at the James Danziger Gallery. (D. James Dee/James Danziger Gallery)

HEADLINE: Turks Plan to Keep 35,000 Troops in Iraq

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, March 23

 BODY:
The 35,000 Turkish troops that now occupy the border area of northern Iraq will not be withdrawn until a buffer zone is set up to insure that Kurdish rebels do not move back into the region when the army withdraws, senior officials said today.
The decision by the Turkish Government caused some consternation among Turkey's European allies. 
 It defied earlier promises by Ankara to withdraw quickly from the region, which it entered on Monday, and raised the possibility of a prolonged occupation of Iraqi territory, which Turkey's allies, including the United States, have repeatedly cautioned against.
The French Foreign Minister, Alain Juppe, and his German counterpart, Klaus Kinkel, who were in Ankara today for meetings with the Turkish Prime Minister, Tansu Ciller, criticized the decision and asked that Turkish troops withdraw from the region as soon as possible.
[Turkish warplanes staged bombing runs into northern Iraq again early Friday, the fifth day of the assault, Reuters reported from Ankara. Other flights brought in reinforments and supplies to four points along the 178-mile border, the news agency added, quoting a military spokesman.
["We have reports of an increase in the number of rebels killed, from the 128 which we announced last night," the spokesman said. He gave no further details. ]
Western diplomats said Turkey's continued presence in northern Iraq could jeopardize Ankara's ambitions to build closer economic ties with the European Union, the subject of today's talks, which the Foreign Minister of Spain also attended.
The European Union, despite its questioning of Turkey's human rights record, signed a customs union with Ankara earlier this month. If approved by the European Parliament, the accord would begin in 1996 and would eliminate duties between Turkey and the European Union.
The German Foreign Minister said that if public opinion in Europe were to turn against the Turks, it would be difficult for the European Parliament to approve the customs union. Turkey's image has also suffered in Europe after its decision to imprison eight Kurdish members of Parliament and to charge Turkey's best-known author, Yaser Kemal, with sedition for criticizing the Government's treatment of the Kurds.
"The moment the world sees the picture of the first civilian casualty in northern Iraq, things will become very difficult for Turkey," Mr. Kinkel told reporters today in Ankara.
Europe, with a large and vocal Kurdish immigrant community, carefully follows Turkey's treatment of its some 11 million Kurds.
The Turkish troops have entered a region set up by the Western allies as a "safe haven" for Iraq's Kurds after Baghdad's defeat in the Persian Gulf war in 1992. The area is currently controlled by the two main Iraqi Kurdish rebel groups and monitored by Western forces.
The two Iraqi factions are vying with each other for control of the north. The Turkish Kurdish rebels have used the area to set up base camps outside the control of the Iraqi Kurds.
The Turks are attacking four principal guerrilla camps in the current offensive and since Monday have pushed 25 miles into Iraq. The army claims to have killed about 200 of the estimated 2,400 rebels based there and captured numerous munitions and weapons. It says 13 soldiers have died in the fighting.
This is not the first time Ankara has mounted huge military operations with the aim of wiping out the Kurdish rebels. The guerrilla war in southeastern Turkey has killed 15,000 people in the last 10 years.
Some 13,000 Kurds fled from southeastern Turkey last year after the army forced them to evacuate their villages or burned their settlements. Many have settled across the border in Zakho and in camps near Atrush, 45 miles to the southeast. Those refugees receive assistance from the United Nations.
Turkish officials said they hoped to bring their troops back eventually, but they also said they would not make the same mistake as in 1992, when 20,000 Turkish troops swept the border area and withdrew, allowing Kurdish rebels to move back and mount new cross-border raids.
"We have to have a guarantee and a new form of collaboration there before we go back," said Emre Gonensay, the chief adviser to the Prime Minister. "We realize now that just going in and pulling out is not sufficient. Those who criticize us for going in and staying there should find a solution with us."
Turkish officials contend that northern Iraq has descended into chaos since Iraqi forces withdrew after the gulf war. That power vacuum, they say, has allowed the rebel Kurdish Workers Party to establish base camps and arms depots. These officials say they will not permit a return to the status quo, even in the face of severe international criticism.
Ankara also dismissed criticism from Baghdad today that it had violated Iraqi sovereignty. Turkish officials said that since Baghdad did not have a presence in the north, it did not have sovereignty.
"This is not a violation of Iraqi sovereignty," Mr. Gonensay said. "Since there is really no authority there, as there are no forces there, we have a power vacuum in northern Iraq."
The de facto authorities in northern Iraq, the Turkish officials argue, are the Western coalition forces that established the safe haven there after the gulf war. The safe haven, which lies north of the 36th parallel, includes flights by coalition jets to monitor a no-fly zone. It also includes a tiny team of military observers in Zakho.
Turkish officials said they were considering various options to maintain control over the region, including a buffer zone similar to that set up by Israel in southern Lebanon. They also said they would consider manning the area with Western coalition forces if the allies, including the United States, would oversee a truce.

HEADLINE: Wisconsin Has Big Loss In Derivatives

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
In the latest fallout from the use of the complex financial instruments known as derivatives, The State of Wisconsin Investment Board said yesterday that one of its funds had lost $95 million speculating on the Mexican peso and on European currencies.
The board sought to play down the impact of the losses, saying they would be spread over many years and would not affect the fund's principal. 
 But an official conceded that the losses would cut the fund's earnings for the last year by about a quarter of a percentage point. That would reduce the affected fund's annual payout rate to 5.30 percent from 5.55 percent. Earnings during the next 5 to 10 years will also be reduced by a quarter of a percentage point.
Most of the money invested in the fund, known as the State Investment Fund, is cash balances from the state and local governments. But a part of the fund is from the state's pension system.
Patricia Lipton, executive director of the Wisconsin Investment Board, said that the bets on the peso and Eurpean currencies using derivatives were "inappropriate" and that the fund's portfolio manager was "under review."
She also indicated that the losses might be far worse than they had to be. The loss on the peso was touched off by the sudden devaluation of the Mexican currency in December and the sharp slide of the peso since then. But the fund kept its bet in until recently, even as the value of the peso slid an added 25 percent since mid-February.
Derivatives, which are financial products that are based on, or derived from, the underlying price movements of stocks, bonds, currencies or interest rates, have become controversial in the last year because institutions including Orange County, Calif., Gibson Greetings Inc. and the Procter & Gamble Company have announced sudden and heavy losses from their use.
Orange County, for example, reported losses of $1.7 billion from a combination of heavy borrowing to speculate on interest rates and the use of derivatives contracts. The county has declared bankruptcy and cut back its spending. Questions still remain concerning its ability to pay pensions, and the county faces a slew of pending litigation.
The Bankers Trust New York Corporaton, which sold the derivatives to Gibson and P.& G., has settled with Gibson but is still fighting with P.& G. to determine responsibility for the losses on its derivative contracts.
Wisconsin officials emphasized that the fund's losses were much smaller than in other recent debacles involving derivatives. The losses represent only 1.4 percent of the value of the $6.7 billion State Investment Fund, which handles cash balances for about 1,000 local governments, and manages the state's general cash reserves and some of its retirement monies. The state's investment board also manages another $30 billion in retirement funds, which were not affected by the losses.
Ms. Lipton said that the fund had sufficient liquidity "to meet any cash withdrawals by local government participants in the S.I.F."
"I'd like to differentiate us from Orange County," Ms. Lipton added. "We haven't leveraged the whole fund," referring to the borrowing done by Orange County's treasurer, Robert L. Citron, to support the bets he had made on interest rates swings.
"We found a problem, and we dealt with it immediately, we acted quickly, we got rid of it," Ms. Lipton said.
In general, she added, Wisconsin had used derivatives to manage and offset risk. Wisconsin officials also point out that the state investment fund, in the last 12 years, has averaged returns that have been about a percentage point higher than some index measurements for performances by money market funds.
The Mexican peso, of course, crashed in December, losing almost half its value in the following weeks. Why hadn't the state unwound the Mexican peso contract then?
"The portfolio manager hadn't made that determination," Ms. Lipton said. It was only later that "the management and the trustee decided to get out of the investment," she added.
In short, the portfolio manager was hanging on to a loss-making position in the hope that things would get better. The conduct of the portfolio manager is "under review," Ms. Lipton said.
Ms. Lipton also said that such swap investments were "inappropriate for that fund," and that they had been looked into as part of a recent review of the whole fund, conducted with the Price Waterhouse accounting firm. "The whole industry is scrambling to come to terms" with the risks posed by derivatives, she said.
While the loss was a surprise, the fact that the Wisconsin investment board took risks should not have been. The board has been among the most aggressive state money managers in the country. It has invested in a fund established by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the leveraged buyout firm that has specialized in big takeovers and has at times struck fear in the hearts of many of America's top managers.
For example, the board, as one of the Kmart Corporation's largest shareholders, helped to start the revolt against its chairman, Joseph E. Antonini, that led to his ouster this week.
The Wisconsin board moved to contain the loss in the fund by getting out of 10 losing derivatives transactions in the last several days. The losses arose mainly from recent falls in the value of the peso, Ms. Lipton said. There were other, smaller losses from derivatives tied to movements by European currencies, according to bankers with knowledge of the transactions. Ms. Lipton said the derivatives were restructured to get rid of the risks they posed to the state fund.
Among the firms that sold the original derivatives to the fund, according to one banker, were J. P. Morgan & Company, Bankers Trust, Goldman Sachs & Company, Merrill Lynch & Company and Morgan Stanley. J. P. Morgan and Bankers Trust helped to unwind the losing positions.
Spokesmen for J. P. Morgan and Bankers Trust confirmed their role in helping to restructure the derivatives, and acknowledged their roles in organizing the original investments. Goldman and Merrill declined to comment. Morgan Stanley representatives could not immediately be reached for comment.

HEADLINE: Public Hospitals Chief Quits, Opposing Giuliani Over Cuts

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
The chairman of New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation resigned unexpectedly yesterday, saying he could not support the deep Medicaid cuts that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki are seeking.
The chairman, Luis A. Miranda Jr., resigned minutes before the agency's board of directors was to vote on a resolution condemning the cuts, which would effectively slash the agency's budget by close to 30 percent. 
 Mr. Miranda said that as an appointee of the Mayor, he was obliged to support the administration's position, but that he could not in good conscience vote against the board's resolution.
But some people in the agency who were familiar with the move said the Giuliani administration made it clear to Mr. Miranda that if he defied the Mayor by voting to condemn the Medicaid cuts, he would be forced from his position.
The Mayor immediately appointed Maria Mitchell, his special adviser on health, as the interim chairwoman of the agency, which operates the city's 11 public hospitals. After she arrived to take Mr. Miranda's seat at the board meeting, Ms. Mitchell cast the deciding vote to defeat the resolution. The vote was 7 to 6 with 1 abstention. Two members of the 16-member board did not vote.
Just a day earlier, the Mayor added another supporter to the board, John Ballan, an attorney specializing in public finance. He replaced Dr. Calvin J. Simons, who was appointed by former Mayor David N. Dinkins and whose term expired on Monday.
The board changes consolidate the Mayor's influence on the agency at a time that the administration is seeking to sell at least three public hospitals and considerably reduce the size of the remaining institutions and the agency's bureaucracy. The Mayor has indicated that he would like to get the city entirely out of the health delivery business.
Mr. Miranda said that he generally supported the Mayor's goals of streamlining the agency and forcing it to be more efficient. He said that over the last 14 months, he had stood by the Mayor's decision to eliminate nearly 4,000 agency jobs, to shrink the number of beds and to consolidate overlapping departments at some of the hospitals. "I support this Mayor and I have supported his positions on many, many issues as they relate to H.H.C.," said Mr. Miranda, who is also president of the Hispanic Federation of New York, an umbrella organization of health and social service agencies in the Hispanic community.
As chairman of the hospitals agency, he said, "I need to reflect the views, the aspirations, the psyche of the administration and for 14 months I did and put them through to the board."
But on the issue of the Medicaid budget, Mr. Miranda said, there was no common vision. While acknowledging the need to control soaring Medicaid costs, Mr. Miranda said that many of the proposed cuts were wrong and unjustly penalized the city's hospitals because of the vast numbers of patients with special needs that the system treats, including those with AIDS and tuberculosis.
And so, after he failed to persuade the Mayor to re-evaluate the proposed cuts, he said he decided that "the right, honorable thing to do" was to resign.
Cristyne F. Lategano, the Mayor's press secretary, said Mr. Miranda was neither pressured to resign nor ordered by the Mayor to vote against the Medicaid resolution. She said Mr. Miranda came to his decision on his own after he and Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers discussed the resolution yesterday morning. "It was a mutual understanding," she said. "I don't think he agreed with the Mayor's philosophy on this."
One key City Hall official, speaking on condition of anonymity, noted that if Mr. Miranda was angry at the administration, he could have remained on the board, voted for the resolution and then resigned. That he did not do so, and chose not to fight City Hall's position on the issue, demonstrates a general lack of rancor between the Mayor and Mr. Miranda, the official said.
Some board members said they felt that the Mayor has been bypassing them as he plans the future dismantling of the agency. They cited as an example the fact that many of them first learned of the proposed sale of three public hospitals from the news media and that even the agency's president, Dr. Bruce Siegel, was left out of the deliberations leading to that decision.
In response, several board members introduced a resolution yesterday demanding that before any agency official discusses with city officials the sale of any of its hospitals or other facilities, the board must first be given a detailed plan about the overall restructuring of the agency.
The resolution failed by a vote of 9 to 6, with many board members saying that such a demand would only increase the bureaucracy everyone wanted to cut and noting that Dr. Siegel had always been forthright in sharing information with the board.
But it was the resolution about the Medicaid cuts that revealed the schisms within the board and underscored the Mayor's need for the cushion of support he now has.
James R. Dumpson, who was appointed to the board during the Dinkins administration, said that the Medicaid cuts, combined with simultaneous income tax cuts, served to "balance the budget on the backs of the poor."
He chided his fellow board members for not speaking out more strongly against such policies.
"It's high time this board made clear where it stands on a number of social and economic issues," he said, adding that "none of us get down to what the people we are mandated to serve in health care really need."
He urged the board to, "for the first time in a long time," send a message to the administration and the people of the city.
David R. Jones, another Dinkins appointee, agreed, saying that it "becomes ridiculous after a point" for the board to "sit on its hands at a time of such great crisis, when a third of our budget is being slashed."
But under the guidance of Ms. Mitchell, the majority of the board was persuaded to show their support for the Medicaid budget cuts by voting against the resolution.

HEADLINE: Trade Won't Make Cuba More Democratic

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Cuba: Time to Change Direction" (editorial, March 19): The claim that trade and contact will bring about the end of the Castro regime ignores facts that make the argument inapplicable to Cuba. 
 Fidel Castro has taken no steps that would allow increased trade and contact to lead to political or economic liberalization. Instead, any hard currency from United States trade and investment, and multilateral development loans that would follow, would substitute for reform.
The Cuban Government controls every industry that generates significant hard currency, including agriculture, mining, medical supplies and tourism. Almost none of the hard currency generated by foreign companies reaches ordinary Cubans.
Foreign companies in Cuba are not permitted to hire employees except through Communist Party-controlled agencies. The Government pays these workers the equivalent of $5 a month in pesos. Cubans themselves cannot hire employees, buy supplies from nonstate sources or protect earnings from arbitrary confiscation by Government squads created by decree to seize assets of those deemed unduly wealthy.
If, as the argument goes, the purpose of rapprochement with Mr. Castro would be to get money into the hands of ordinary Cubans, make them less dependent on the regime and enable them to support institutions independent of state control, like political parties, newspapers, church groups, and professional and labor organizations, the argument is settled. Mr. Castro is not permitting it. Investors from France, Spain and Mexico have been providing crucial support for the Castro regime for years, yet there is no benefit to ordinary citizens.
It is curious that you present Cuba's military threat as a paranoid fantasy. Cuba may not pose the same military threat it once did, but Mr. Castro's inclinations apparently remain unchanged. In November a Russian military delegation led by the chief of staff of Russia's armed forces visited Havana to discuss, among other things, the creation of a joint weapons production facility.
Russia is also providing $200 million annually in continued financing for Cuba's eavesdropping facility at Lourdes. Unsafe Soviet-era nuclear power plants are the subject of a possible French renovation project.
The attempt to ascribe continued support for the embargo and other anti-Castro measures solely to Senator Jesse Helms is inaccurate, and you should know better. Twenty senators, including Bob Dole and me, not to mention the Democrats Charles Robb, Joseph Lieberman and Ernest Hollings, support continued pressure on Mr. Castro by co-sponsoring the Cuban liberty and democratic solidarity bill.
 
CONNIE MACK
U.S. Senator from Florida
Washington, March 20, 1995

HEADLINE: What Feminism Has Done in Workplace;
Welcome to the Battle

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your March 16 front-page article provides needed clarity to the subject of affirmative action, which has been deliberately misrepresented as an economic sop for less qualified black men. Though virtually ignored in the debate, white women have benefited far more than black men. 
 For example, in office towers in midtown Manhattan and on Wall Street, thousands of administrative, middle-level management, supervisory jobs once held exclusively by white men have now been filled by white women, not black men.
Yet all the attacks on affirmative action have been leveled against the latter. Oddly, white women were silent on this until recently, letting the opposition frame the argument in a black-white context and dredge up the old bugaboo of racism, a sentiment escalated by the racist commentary of right-wing pundits and talk-radio hosts. Their goal is to eviscerate major civil rights legislation.
With the Republican Party's offensive in full gallop, white women have finally raised their voices. I hope they haven't waited too late to join the battle.
 
LOYLE HAIRSTON
New York, March 21, 1995

HEADLINE: Art in Review

BYLINE: By PEPE KARMEL 

 BODY:

'The City'
'New York Visions, 1900-1995'
 ACA Galleries
 41 East 57th Street
 Manhattan
 Through April 1
Dealing with the first half of the century, "The City" concentrates on images of daily life: neighbors chatting on a tenement rooftop, unemployed men loafing in front of garish storefronts, the boardwalk at Coney Island. The heroic modernist vision of New York is evoked in a few works on paper by Abraham Walkowitz, Joseph Stella and John Marin. Otherwise the tone is set by pictures like Edward Laning's 1931 "Street Orator" and Reginald Marsh's 1940 watercolor of guys and dolls at the beach. The subject matter is modern, but the style is not: the listeners surrounding Laning's orator are wearing suits and dresses of monochrome yellow, red, blue and green, like the saints in a quattrocento altarpiece, and Marsh's near-nude beachgoers are positively Michelangelesque. 
 The exhibition jumps abruptly from 1945 to the 1980's and 90's. Its second chapter fits uneasily with its first: what interests artists like Richard Estes, Rackstraw Downes and Yvonne Jacquette is the city's physical structure, not its street life. Romare Bearden's "Street," done in 1985, succeeds in capturing the vitality of a trio of street musicians, but it does so by using collage techniques dating from the 1920's. The paintings of two lesser-known artists, David Kapp and Robert Birmelin, are overly derivative of photographers like Alexander Rodchenko and Garry Winogrand. Architecture and life finally seem to come together in a 1992 canvas by Philip Pearlstein, "Two Models With Empire State Building, Night," but you can tell that the skyscraper is only making a guest appearance. PEPE KARMEL

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

 
Salomon Brothers Bids For Block of Derivatives
 
Salomon Brothers offered to buy up to $8.1 billion of derivative securities, clearly deciding that the worst is over for derivatives and they are now probably underpriced.
Other securities firms quickly followed Salomon. Within hours, Morgan Stanley said it would bid for the same block of derivatives, and J. P. Morgan and Merrill Lynch also said they were active in the market. The firms hope to profit by trading, retaining or restructuring the securities. Page 1.
By using relatively simple techniques to diffuse the risk of the derivatives immediately, these firms can lock in a hefty profit. 38.
 
Durable Goods Signal Slowdown, Sending Stocks, Bonds Soaring
 
Orders for durable goods fell 0.8 percent in February to $163 billion, the first decline in four months. The report provided further evidence that the manufacturing expansion was slowing and eased fears that the Fed would increase interest rates next week. 36.
The report helped send the Dow up 50 points, to a record 4,138.67, and 30-year bonds up a full point, reducing their yield to 7.36 percent That's the lowest level in a week. The dollar rose to 1.4210 marks and 88.95 yen. 37.
 
Signs of Success Help Peso, Stocks
 
The peso rebounded to 6.815 to the dollar and the Mexican stock exchange roared back 107 points amid signs that the country's economic recovery plan was beginning to work. 38.
 
Senate Votes to Repeal Tax Break
 
The Senate voted to repeal a tax break aimed at helping minorities buy cable and broadcast companies. The vote is a setback for Viacom, which agreed last year to sell its cable operations for $2.3 billion to a black entrepreneur in California. 39.
 
Group Demands Tax Cut Delay
 
Dozens of moderate Republicans in the House, joined by 23 Democrats who have consistently voted with the majority, demanded that any reductions in taxes be delayed until Congress has passed spending cuts sufficient to compensate for the lost revenue as well as to balance the budget. 1.
 
Rules Proposed for Small Aircraft
 
The Transportation Department proposed tougher operating requirements and equipment standards for small commuter planes, bringing them closer in line to the standards for planes operated by the major airlines. Among the requirements, commuter pilots could no longer work longer hours than pilots for the major carriers and would receive the same level of training. 1.
 
Boeing Offers Retirement Option
 
Boeing announced retirement incentives intended to reduce the number of involuntary layoffs needed to reach its goal of cutting 7,000 jobs this year. The plan will result in a one-time charge of $350 million to $400 million in the company's second fiscal quarter. 39.
 
Time Warner to Sell Atari Stake
 
Time Warner plans to sell part or all of its 24.5 percent stake in Atari in a move to reduce its debt. The stake is worth about $42.9 million. 41.
 
Shareholders Say No to Rowland
 
Roland (Tiny) Rowland narrowly lost a shareholder vote to become president of Lonrho, after having been dismissed as co-chief executive. He was to be named president, but the board withdrew its support. 38.
 
Bronco II Settlement Rejected
 
A judge has rejected Ford's settlement stemming from claims that the Bronco II is prone to rolling over. The judge said the agreement provided huge fees for lawyers but "zero" benefits for Bronco owners. 7.
 
H.M.O. Membership Rises in New York
 
New figures show that more than a quarter of the residents of New York State have joined health maintenance organizations, up from 19 percent two years ago. It is estimated that 4.5 million New Yorkers now belong to the health organizations. 1.
 
Pharmacy Fund Tackles Cash Woes
 
The Pharmacy Fund is dealing with the problems that pharmacists have getting reimbursed by insurers. The new company buys bills from the previous day's prescription sales at a slight discount, paying the pharmacist immediately and eliminating weeks of cash flow delays. The Pharmacy Fund then collects from the health plans. 39.

HEADLINE: Upstate, Democrats Face Budget Quandary

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

DATELINE: JAMESTOWN, N.Y.

 BODY:
Assemblyman William L. Parment drives his 1989 Chevy, a harmonica on the dashboard and 121,600 miles on the odometer, around the hills of his district these days trying to figure out what his voters want. He is a Democrat who won re-election unopposed, but his constituents also voted overwhelmingly for the new Republican Governor, George E. Pataki.
And therein lies his quandary: Does support for Mr. Pataki in his district translate into support for Mr. Pataki's deep-cutting budget? 
 "If the perception in people's minds is, you blocked the new direction, it could cost you a lot of votes," said Mr. Parment, a seven-term incumbent who is only the second Democrat to represent the conservative 150th District in western New York since the Civil War.
Mr. Pataki and his fellow Republicans have made much of Democrats like Mr. Parment, casting them as the G.O.P.'s ace in the hole in this year's contentious budget battle: the Republicans are pouring hundreds of thousands of dollars into advertising in 19 Assembly districts outside New York City where voters elected a Democrat but supported Mr. Pataki. It is a high-stakes campaign to pressure the Democrats to break ranks with their leadership and support the Governor's budget.
And Mr. Parment, like many others, is beginning to feel the effect, even if he is not yet convinced the Republican strategy will work. By 11:15 A.M. on March 17 -- the day after the television ads went on the air, as part of a campaign that included radio spots and mailings -- his office received 22 calls urging him to support the budget. Over the previous six weeks, the calls had run 250 to 20 against it. A week after the ads began to run, Mr. Parment said, calls for and against were running about equal.
So far, Mr. Parment, 53, a soft-spoken country lawmaker and occasional blues harmonica player who is fond of quoting Walt Whitman, is treading a middle ground. He said he supports Mr. Pataki's broad goals of cutting taxes and spending, but is outspoken against many of the specific cuts, especially in higher education and health care. He said that in the end, he would listen to his voters, even at the expense of loyalty to his fellow Democrats.
"Neither side needs to count on my vote unless they present a budget that makes sense to me," Mr. Parment said on a drive through Jamestown, which has been hit hard by the state's economic decline and is apparently eager for change, based on the voting in November.
The Republican strategy assumes a breakdown in the normal way a budget is hammered out -- in private talks by the Governor and the Senate majority leader, currently both Republicans, and the Assembly Speaker, a Democrat. There are 94 Democrats and 56 Republicans in the 150-member Assembly. Of the Democrats, 25 represent districts that voted for Mr. Pataki. If the Republicans can pressure 20 of them to support Mr. Pataki's budget, they can pass it, even over the opposition of Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver.
"A great many Democrats in the Assembly, certainly more than the 20 that you would need to pass it, believe we are doing the right thing," Mr. Pataki said in an interview. He has sent his own mailing, paid for by the Republican Party, to most of the Democratic districts that supported him.
For his part, Mr. Silver said the strategy will never work. Diverse as the Assembly Democrats might be -- there are eight who run with the Conservative Party endorsement -- he said that opposition to the budget would hold them together. "I've been around the state, and I think people don't like the Pataki budget, plain and simple," Mr. Silver said.
But the Republicans say that even if they cannot put together enough renegade Democrats for a vote on Mr. Pataki's budget that excludes the Speaker, their strategy will put pressure on Mr. Silver. The idea is that upstate Democrats will push Mr. Silver closer to Mr. Pataki's version of the budget in internal Assembly negotiations.
The Republicans could also use the hold-outs' votes as a campaign issue against them in the elections of 1996.
There is also a worst-case scenario for Mr. Silver involving the upstate Democrats, though it is improbable. If Mr. Silver ultimately cannot make a deal with the Governor and the Senate majority leader because his members are too divided, he could simply let the upstaters vote with the Assembly Republicans to pass Mr. Pataki's fiscal plan. That would, in theory, allow Mr. Silver to avoid compromising his opposition to Mr. Pataki, but it would come at an enormous cost to Mr. Silver's leadership. "It just won't happen that way," Mr. Silver said.
In many ways, Mr. Parment -- a wry and dry fiscal conservative who has defied his party before by voting against budgets -- symbolizes the problem facing both upstate Assembly Democrats and Mr. Silver. The members of the Assembly's Democratic majority range from people like Mr. Parment, who grew up milking his family's cows before school, to representatives from New York City whose constituents rarely see a cow. Residents here in the westernmost corner of the state say that it is an easier drive to Wrigley Field in Chicago than it is to Shea Stadium, and that his district is midwestern in mindset and geography.
This translates into political interests that often put Democrats at odds, especially on state spending, and the November rejection of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo -- seen as the big-city liberal with little interest in upstate problems -- was but the most dramatic example.
But even while upstate voters rejected Mr. Cuomo, it is unclear how far they embrace Mr. Pataki and his budget. Judging from a dozen interviews with voters here, there appears to be a perception even among some Pataki voters that his budget is simply too much, too fast.
Kathleen Healey, 49, the co-owner of a frame shop, said of Mr. Pataki's budget: "In the long run, it's going to help -- in the next 10 years. Something has to be done, but why are we hitting the elderly and low-income people?"
But as the campaign on both sides heats up -- and if the Governor, the Assembly and the Republican-controlled Senate fail to agree on a budget through negotiations -- people like William Salter, a 44-year-old Republican banker, will no doubt have more say. Mr. Salter is not enthusiastic about many of the cuts either, but he said Mr. Pataki's budget was the only way to jump-start the state back to economic health.
"I've known Bill Parment for 10 years, and I believe in my heart Bill Parment will make the right decision," he said.
But, he added, if Mr. Parment votes against the Governor's budget, "he's going to have to tell me why he's not for it. And if he is picking one or two special interests and he is throwing the baby out with the bath water, then I've got a problem with Bill Parment."
Mr. Parment himself calls his position these days a "tightrope" and is busily working his district to learn where people stand. In November, he received 22,375 votes, but even without an opponent, 18,585 people who voted in other races failed to pull the lever for him. Misreading the electorate, he said, could be a fatal political mistake.
"It presents to me the possibility I could lose an important group of constituents in future elections," he said. "My job is really to convince them that however this battle appears, I'm fighting for their interests. And that's a tough job because it has to be done almost on a one-to-one basis."

HEADLINE: Securities Firms Seeking to Turn Derivatives Debacle Into Profits

BYLINE: BY PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Wall Street is setting out to try to profit on the widespread fear of the complex financial instruments known as derivatives.
After creating the derivatives that have resulted in spectacular losses for investors ranging from Orange County, Calif., to Gibson Greetings of Cincinnati, Wall Street is trying to increase profits by recycling these much maligned instruments for making side bets on stocks, bonds, currencies and interest rates. Several firms, including those who sold the derivatives in the first place, now want to buy back the hybrid securities at low prices, clean them up and sell them again. 
 Salomon Brothers Inc. started the gambit yesterday morning by announcing that it would buy up to $8.1 billion of certain types of derivatives that were sold by a handful of quasi-government agencies. Other big securities firms quickly followed Salomon's lead, with executives muttering about the big trading firm's marketing savvy.
"We have done something that we hope will be beneficial for the market, and beneficial for us," said a managing director in Salomon Brothers' fixed-income department.
Here's the angle. Shaken by losses in Orange County, by Wisconsin's investment board and in parts of Corporate America, prices have dropped and buyers are scarce. The Wall Street firms are betting, therefore, that they can buy these derivatives cheaply.
And by buying so many of these derivatives, almost a quarter of such issues, the firms are getting the financial equivalent of a huge box of slightly used Legos. This makes it easier for them to mix and match these individual red, yellow and blue financial structures to create less risky new securities that they can sell to new customers at a higher price.
For those who own the derivatives now, the sale may mean a loss. But that may be better than having to hang on to them and worry whether the markets would rebound enough to find buyers and get out unscathed.
The Salomon official, who declined to be named, said this was the largest such offer he had ever seen, and underlined that his firm wanted to offer selling opportunities to holders of these derivatives, and show that there was a large and easily negotiated market for them.
Within hours of Salomon's announcement, Morgan Stanley & Company said it too would bid for the same $8.1 billion of derivatives, which are made up of a total of 59 different securities issued by several groups, including the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, and the Student Loan Mortgage Association, or Sallie Mae. "We wanted to have a chance to bid on these bonds," said David Carroll, a principal at Morgan Stanley.
A spokesman for Merrill Lynch & Company said: "We have been, we are, and we will continue to be, bidding in this market. If the Salomon offer illustrates the existing liquidity in the market, it can't be a bad thing."
J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. said it too continued to make markets in these derivatives -- known as agency structured notes. These notes, many of which involve twists that allow an investor to speculate on the direction and timing of interest rate changes, were mostly issued in the last couple of years.
Derivatives rely on the performance of stocks, bonds or currencies without actually having to own the underlying assets. When used prudently, derivatives can be useful tools that allow treasurers and financiers to manage risk. But they also can be used to make big bets on the direction of financial markets. And they became controversial last year when many of these bets went sour and many investors were faced with big losses.
Just this week, the State of Wisconsin Investment Board said that one of its funds suffered losses of $95 million mainly because it used derivatives to speculate on the Mexican peso and European currencies.
Clearly the big securities firms, following a recent rally in the bond markets, think the worst may be over in the derivatives debacle. Just yesterday, a senior investment banker speculated that if Orange County had held onto much of its derivatives portfolio it would now be happy with many of those investments. Many of these investments would have appreciated, he argued, as it has become clearer that the United States is close to the top of a series of interest rate increases.
Salomon, after almost $400 million of losses in 1994, is seeking ways to use its traditional trading strengths to take advantage of the current dim view that many investors take of derivative securities. After such a bad year in 1994, the firm is more eager than ever to find trading opportunities to make big profits.
This was also something of a publicity stunt by Salomon, its competitors assert. "We're open for business every business day," said Mr. Carroll of Morgan Stanley, "and these bonds have been traded in the past." Salomon's marketing ploy clearly unnerved its competitors. Morgan Stanley officers said they had received several telephone calls from investors inquiring whether Salomon had some kind of exclusive right to make offers to buy these derivatives.
The spread between bid and offer prices for many of these derivative securities has widened and their prices also have dropped, two Morgan Stanley executives explained. Thus, there are some interesting buying opportunities, particularly when many of the smaller investors like local governments may be unnerved by recent scandals involving derivatives, they added.
The Salomon offer to buy the 59 different securities issues gives investors the opportunity to sell either in a dutch auction or to sell using the firm's continuous price quotes for these securities. Unless it is extended, Salomon's tender offer will expire on April 7.

HEADLINE: In SoHo, an Outcry From the Lofts;
Artists Organizations to Fight Hotel in Neighborhood

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
To listen to neighbors, one would think the new hotel that is going up in SoHo portends a biblical scourge. Sunlight will be obliterated. Traffic will become even more congested as cars sputter out poisons during the endless wait at the Holland Tunnel. The sewer system, already overtaxed, will overflow. Tour buses will multiply, carrying with them that dread of dread, the untasteful.
 Preliminary construction began this week on the 370-room SoHo Grand, the first hotel to be built in SoHo in a century. An agreement was reached on Monday in which the developer, Hartz Mountain Industries, promised to drive piles gently so as not to rattle artworks near the site. 
 The agreement, reached in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, replaced a temporary restraining order obtained by the daughter of the late Chaim Gross, a legendary name in sculpture, whose works she feared might be literally shaken.
 The restraining order was just the first shot. The community is intensifying its campaign against the hotel, with plans to sue the city, mount protests, and contact eminent artists around the world to add their famous signatures to a petition.
 Over the years SoHo has evolved from a seedy manufacturing district into New York's biggest Euro-mall, with its vast minimalist stores, downtown-grunge cafes and pedestrians from the Continent. But it is also a tight community, locals insist, as well as a global art center and retail hub for ultra-trendy furnishings.
 Residents are fighting in the manner of any neighborhood defending its interests, especially one in which many acquired million-dollar lofts for peanuts. But they are also doing so with the conviction that they are defending Art from the barbarians.
 If the hotel is stopped, it would be the eighth proposed hotel for SoHo to be killed by opposition, or economics, in the last decade.
 Emanuel Stern, the Hartz executive vice president guiding the project, said it may be impossible to satisfy his opponents, who credit themselves not only in having brought human habitation but also style and attitude to what is still officially a manufacturing zone. The only SoHo they will stand for, he said, is the SoHo they pioneered -- one without a hotel.
 "To many of them, there is no such thing as change that's acceptable," he said.
 Stopping the Grand, opponents acknowledge, will be their biggest challenge, since there are few regulatory avenues. Hotels in manufacturing zones require no extraordinary permits. The most recent attempt to build a hotel on the same site failed because it also included housing, which needs a variance from the Board of Standards and Appeals to be built in a manufacturing area.
 The Grand, at 310 West Broadway between Grand and Canal Streets, is not in the landmark district that begins across West Broadway. Another hotel, planned for the corner of Mercer and Prince Streets, lies in this district, but its small-scale and artful restoration of a historic building has minimized opposition. That hotel, the Mercer, is still seeking financing but the developer, Andre P. Balazs, who owns the Chateau Marmont in Hollywood, hopes to begin construction this year. The Grand's ceremonial groundbreaking is scheduled for April 3.
 It is the Grand's size that opponents say offends them. Because of the purchase of air rights from surrounding property owners, the hotel will be 15 stories in a neighborhood of 5- and 6-story buildings.
 Although construction has consisted only of preliminary digging, neighbors contend that their life styles are already threatened.
 "It feels like an earthquake," Lauren Hyman, a movie publicist and spokeswoman for the Soho Alliance, a community group opposing the project, said of the excavation work. "I'm terrified."
 Nina Meledandri, an abstract painter whose loft overlooks the construction site, said: "I grew up on the Upper East Side and I never expected to find a community like this anywhere. Now I feel somebody is coming in and just taking what he needs. It's like being raped."
 Accordingly, the opponents led with a seeming ace, Chaim Gross, who died three years ago. Gross was a longtime resident of SoHo. Neighbors said they still expect the affable artist with a head of bushy white hair to amble around the corner, padding contemplatively between his two SoHo studios.
 Mr. Gross's daughter, Mimi, tends to one of the studios, which contains more than 100 important sculptures, bronze casts and plaster originals. When pile-driving tests began on March 14, she said, she felt vibrations in her building, adjoining the hotel site. Supported by neighbors, Ms. Gross got the restraining order.
 In Monday's agreement, Hartz Mountain agreed to proceed gently in driving 299 piles as far down as 85 feet -- at least for the two weeks likely required to pack and remove the art.
 "I understand development has to happen, but a 15-story hotel is a monster," Ms. Gross said.
 Mr. Stern said that he will go to great lengths to protect the Gross sculptures. "Tell us what you want," he said. "We'll drive piles so gently a nickel will stand on its edge."
 Mr. Stern pointed out that the hotel was designed to conform to its cast-iron environment with slabs of slate and a cast-aluminum facade. He also promised residents that Hartz, which manufactures pet food, develops real estate and owns The Village Voice, would operate the hotel itself and not turn it over to a management chain like Ramada.
 He expects the hotel to generate $1.2 million a year in property taxes and to employ 200 people full-time. He said that the Grand, a moderately priced hotel at $150 a double, will be stylish on the order of the Paramount Hotel on West 46th Street. A marketing study predicted that guests will come from visitors to New York University and Cooper Union, the arts communities of SoHo and neighboring TriBeCa, and trainees for Wall Street positions. Though Mr. Stern said tour buses would not be a central part of his business, he did not deny that they would be invited.
 Hartz bought the property in 1988 for $7 million with the thought that a luxury hotel would be the perfect thing for Gotham's booming economy. Then came the recession, and the land lay idle. Hartz thought hard about a youth hostel where lodgers would pay about $40 a night, but the numbers just wouldn't crunch. For years the property was on the market for $5 million. The community wants the land for a park.
 "I want to be accepted by the people who live and work in SoHo," Mr. Stern said.
 At a meeting of the SoHo Alliance this week in a loft filled with abstract art and many trees, about 40 people, many of them artists, mapped out their multifront war against the hotel. It did not include accepting Mr. Stern into the fold. In fact, one woman suggested trying to embarrass Emanuel Stern because he is "31 years old and vulnerable." Another strategy was to "build drama" in the media.
 They decided to collect signatures from artists and publish them in a downtown newspaper other than the Stern-owned Voice.
 Kathryn E. Freed, the City Council member representing SoHo, then advised them on how to hold an effective protest march.
 "You need a lot of people in the community to show up with dogs and baby carriages," she said. "The whole business."
