HEADLINE: Are 'Cuts' Really Cuts? That Depends

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
If the just-concluded House debate over welfare spending underscores anything, it is that Republicans and Democrats do not differ merely over ideology. They also use different accountants.
The result was a baffling skirmish in which Democrats, wielding their numbers, accused Republicans of slashing aid to hungry children and pregnant women, and Republicans, wielding their own numbers, claimed to be increasing aid to the same groups. Even more confusing, both arguments were accurate. 
 But neither was the whole truth. The fact is that any spending proposal can be judged only against a yardstick: what future Federal spending would be if the proposal were not enacted into law. Without such a measure, it is nearly impossible to say what effect any spending change would have.
Accountants call such yardsticks "base lines." And in effect Democrats are measuring by feet and inches in the present budget debate, while Republicans are calculating by the metric system.
The Democratic view of base-line budgeting, solidified over 40 years of control of Congress, is that any spending forecast must employ the best guesses of experts about what the future holds.
Inflation, and changes in demographics, the economy and social trends, all figure in: spending predictions for school breakfasts, say, rely in part on the assumption that more schools will join the program, raising the daily number of breakfasts to 1.4 million by 2000 from the current 1.1 million.
Republicans take a directly opposite view. They believe that future spending should be measured not against predictions, which never prove completely on target, but against what is actually being spent right now. And so when Republicans pushed a five-year, $95 billion package of cuts in domestic discretionary spending through the House Budget Committee this month, their base line was this year's level of such spending -- about $545 billion -- projected as far as the eye could see.
Republicans have advocated such flat-line spending forecasts, called "current law" base lines in budget parlance, since at least the 1970's.
In theory, this numbers-crunching debate should have no effect on policy or politics. Neither of the base lines is wrong; they simply offer different ways of looking at the same numbers.
But as the welfare debate in the House demonstrated, the method of budget calculus takes on immense significance when the Government is divided into opposing ideological camps.
In this week's welfare debate, for example, Democrats seeking to protect social spending assailed Republicans for reducing spending on child nutrition programs below the "current services" base lines, used by the White House and the Congressional Budget Office. And so Representative Dale E. Kildee of Michigan could accuse the House majority of favoring "drastically reduced funding" for school lunches. And Representative Lynn Woolsey of California could try to shame the Republicans by telling them, "Starving children is not the solution to balancing our budget."
While the language may be hyperbolic, the central argument, viewed through the Democrats' accounting prism, has some basis in fact: the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal policy group, calculates that the block-grant approach in House welfare legislation would cut some $2.3 billion, as measured by the Democrats' base line, over the next five years.
But from where Republicans in the House see matters, the picture is radically different.
"What is indisputable is that we are not proposing a cut of one penny in the school lunch program," Representative James C. Greenwood of Pennsylvania told Democrats on Wednesday. "The President, in this year's budget proposal -- the President of the United States, the one who went to visit the schoolchildren in Maryland for lunch -- he proposed a 3.6 percent increase this year. And we proposed 4.5 percent."
That may not be precisely true; other experts place the Republicans' increase, as measured by their own base line, at 4 percent. But Mr. Greenwood's basic contention -- that spending will rise as measured against what is now spent -- is accurate.
In a city where perception often creates its own reality, the use of numbers to tailor a political image -- of caring, compassionate Democrats or prudent, common-sense Republicans -- is no small matter. But the choice of budgeting base lines has even bigger implications.
Republicans make a case that the Democrats' method, with its built-in inflators, has created a fantasy world in which spending "cuts" are often really increases, with big increases made to look tiny when compared with a rising line on a graph. Budgeting by crystal ball removes all discipline from the spending process, they say, because it relies on assumptions that can be changed at a whim.
True enough, perhaps, but the Republicans' current-law base lines defy reality in their own way by ignoring the inevitability of changing circumstances. The 1994 Pentagon budget, for example, was roughly the size of the Pentagon budget in 1987 but paid for 600,000 fewer soldiers and 200 fewer ships.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "ON THE OTHER HAND: A Closer Look at Budget Proposals"
How much politicians cut spending depends entirely on how much spending politicians start with. Both the Clinton Administration and House Republicans have proposed cuts in discretionary spending that each says would pay for tax relief. But as the chart shows, they use different assumptions about the future to forecast spending - and so the savings they project are not comparable.
 
For example, when President Clinton's proposed cuts are measured against his base line, the cuts are quite substantial - about $100 billion over five years, But measured against the Republican base line, the president's proposals would cut spending not at all. Similarly, the Republicans say they are cutting $95 billion from discretionary spending over five years. But measured against the Clinton or Congressional Budget Office base line, they have proposed much deeper cuts.

HEADLINE: Texarkana Journal;
Twice as Difficult to Be Twice as Nice

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: TEXARKANA, U.S.A., March 23

 BODY:
The only post office in the nation that straddles a state line is evenly split between the cities of Texarkana. Its base is made of Texas pink granite and its walls of Arkansas limestone. The Chamber of Commerce logo features a hugging Razorback and Longhorn, and the tourism motto is, "Texarkana: Twice as Nice."
But there is a problem these days in these twin cities, which take their names from the two states they join, as well as nearby Louisiana, and which are divided through most of the downtown section by a yellow stripe down the middle of State Line Avenue. The two Texarkanas may be joined at the hip, but the people who run them are barely speaking to each other. 
 Mayor John Jarvis of Texarkana, Tex., says of his counterpart in Texarkana, Ark., the Rev. Londell Williams: "I've called many times and don't get a response. I understand he's very hard to get in touch with."
A visitor to the two Texarkanas, shuttling a few hundred feet to the Arkansas side's City Hall, found Mayor Williams sitting at his desk right inside the front door. "No, I don't see him that often," he said of Mayor Jarvis. "Of course, when I do, it's always courteous."
The Arkansas side recently formed its own economic development commission, a rival to the Chamber of Commerce that has theoretically represented both sides equally since 1914. And the two Mayors broke a Texarkana custom when they rode in separate parade cars in the local fair last fall.
The feud between the two cities stems from growing economic disparities between Texarkana, Ark., and its larger, somewhat wealthier Texas neighbor, and is exacerbated by a dispute over where to build a new Interstate highway to Shreveport, La., 60 miles to the southeast, that could bring major tax revenue to either side. And some people here also suggest that racial tensions are at work, as Mr. Williams is the first black Mayor from either side.
Whatever the cause, the rivalry provoked a warning this week from the Congressman representing the Arkansas side, Jay Dickey, who said it was undermining the efforts that he and his Texas counterpart, Representative Jim Chapman Jr., are making to save the Red River Army Depot, a major employer in the area. The depot was recently listed among the military bases the Pentagon plans to close. It is on the Texas side, but its 4,500 workers come from both states.
"What I'm observing is that we're pulling away from each other in Texarkana," Mr. Dickey, a second-term Republican, told the Chamber of Commerce this week. "We're harming the cause, making it extremely difficult for us to represent you, if, in fact, you want representation."
To be sure, many people here seem more bemused than bothered by the bickering.
"It's no big deal," said Jack Mills, the owner of Fat Jack's Oyster Bar, which is on the Arkansas side but is a shell's throw from Texas. "I don't think the people are fighting. But city officials are fighting."
There are clear differences between the two Texarkanas, some simply quirky -- one can drive south on State Line Avenue at 40 miles per hour, but northbound, on the Arkansas side, the speed limit is 45. And the Texas side, with a population of 51,815, is about twice the size of its Arkansas twin.
There are plenty of shuttered buildings in both downtowns, but the Texas side is nonetheless a bit more stylish. It has, for instance, the elegant Perot Theater, originally the Saenger, a 1924 Italianate Renaissance building that was restored several years ago with a nearly $1 million donation from a Texas-side native, Ross Perot.
While neither city can be characterized as affluent, the Texas side is better off economically. The 1990 census showed a per-capita income of about $12,000 on the Texas side and $10,000 on the Arkansas side.
One reason frequently cited by store owners on either side of the border is the Arkansas anti-usury law, which caps interest charges at about 10 percent, five percentage points above the Federal discount rate, while Texas retailers have no such limit. The most significant effect is that all new-car dealerships, the largest mall and many other stores are on the Texas side, where dealers can charge higher interest.
In addition, one of the largest employers in the downtown Arkansas city, the St. Michael Health Care Center, recently moved to the Texas side, saying it was simply a better place for a planned expansion. The departure blew a major hole in the Arkansas city's tax base and has left the downtown with an empty, peach-colored hulk.
Eventually, part of the building is to be converted to what is officially termed a community punishment center. "That's what we used to call a jail," Mayor Williams said, adding bitterly, "We'll take it, because one-tenth of something is better than no-tenths of nothing."
Mr. Williams also wonders whether racial factors are at work in the widening disparities. About one-third of the Arkansas side's population is black, and that percentage is growing, while the Texas side remains at about one-quarter black.
The president of the Texarkana Chamber of Commerce, Robert E. (Swede) Lee, insisted that city officials in Arkansas would be better off if they spent less time fighting over issues like the location of the new Interstate highway and more time trying to improve the whole region.
"We have always said one thing about the highway," Mr. Lee said. "We don't care which side of the line it passes on. What we want to do is get it built as fast as we can, and we'll all accrue the benefits from it."
But Mayor Williams said the location of the highway, and the tax money it will generate from gas stations, hotels and other businesses, was critical.
"People say it doesn't make any difference which side it comes on," he said. "Well, it does. When the cash register rings on the Texas side, it's for Texas. When it rings on the Arkansas side, it's for Arkansas."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Texarkana, Ark., on the right, and Texarkana, Tex., on the left, are divided by a yellow stripe and a growing economic feud. The post office in the top, center, is the only one in the nation that straddles a state line. (Robert T. Coleman for The New York Times)
 
Map showing locations of Texarkana Ark. and Texarcana Texas.

HEADLINE: Americans Held by Iraq Are in Good Health

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
Polish diplomats have visited two Americans held in Iraq and found them in good health, the White House said today as it renewed its call on Baghdad to release the men as a humanitarian gesture.
The two men have been imprisoned since they were arrested last week for crossing into Iraq from Kuwait. While expressing relief that Iraq had allowed access to them, the White House warned that Baghdad could serve no purpose in holding the men longer. 
 "Any delay will simply raise questions as to the motives of Iraq," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman.
But signals from Iraq suggest that it is unlikely the matter will be resolved quickly. Tariq Aziz, the Deputy Prime Minister, was quoted today as saying that the men could face jail sentences of up to eight years.
"The Americans violated Iraqi law," Mr. Aziz said in an interview with Energy Compass, an oil publication. "I expect they will be sentenced according to the nature of their violation."
The two men, William Barloon and David Daliberti, are civilian employees associated with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, which maintains Kuwaiti aircraft. They were arrested on March 13 after reportedly visiting friends in the demilitarized zone between Iraq and Kuwait.
Iraqi officials had offered assurances that Mr. Barloon and Mr. Daliberti were in good condition. But Iraq had refused to permit foreign diplomats or Red Cross representatives to visit them, and today's announcement was the first indication that they are indeed in good health.
The Administration relies on Poland to handle United States interests in Iraq. Washington has not had diplomatic relations with Baghdad since Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990, and relations have become even more strained in recent weeks after Washington persuaded the United Nations to maintain economic sanctions against Iraq.
Mr. Aziz was quoted as saying there was no connection between the treatment of the prisoners and the sanctions, which were imposed after the 1990 invasion. But other Iraqi officials have suggested that attention should be focused more on the suffering of the Iraqi people than on the fate of two prisoners.
In its statement, the White House was clearly intent on discouraging such comparisons.
"It remains our view that this situation is the result of an innocent mistake on the part of these two Americans and no purpose can be served by prolonging it or trying to link it to other, unrelated issues," Mr. McCurry said. He said Iraq "should now resolve this matter by releasing the two Americans on humanitarian grounds, and we hope this will occur in the near future."
Two other Americans are known to have crossed the border from Kuwait since the gulf war ended in 1991. One was released soon after his capture; the other served about six months of an eight-year sentence for illegal entry before he was released.

HEADLINE: Consumers Must Pay to Clean Environment, Commissioner Says

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 23

 BODY:
As he seeks to make New York State's environmental bureaucracy less adversarial toward business, Michael D. Zagata, the new Commissioner for Environmental Conservation, says the state should begin telling people that if they want cleaner air and water, they must pay more of the bill.
 "We've got to start educating the public about the fact that some of the burden for getting the last increment that's left is going to shift from industry to the consumer," he said in an interview after his confirmation by the State Senate on Monday. "We have not done a good job of that, and that's why I think you're seeing a revolt."
 That revolt, he said, is being led by ordinary citizens who object to paying more for cleaner-burning gasoline and cleaner-running cars, for public purchases of scenic land and the cleanup of toxic waste on industrial sites. He said that if people do not want to pay, they must understand that making industry foot the bill will hurt the economy.
 "Do we want to say, 'Industry, you're going to have to clean up even though it's a 200-to-1 higher cost,' and run the risk of driving industry out of the state?" he asked.
 In his quest to balance economic interests with environmental ones, Mr. Zagata reflects the dual -- critics would say contradictory -- mission of Gov. George E. Pataki. The Governor has won plaudits from environmentalists, but also campaigned last year to reduce regulation, often citing the Department of Environmental Conservation as a prime example of burdensome bureaucracy. Mr. Pataki now wants Mr. Zagata to satisfy both sides: be less onerous to industry without being less vigilant about pollution.
 Without offering details, Mr. Zagata said he envisioned a variety of policies to reverse his agency's reputation for punishing companies rather than working with them to solve environmental problems.
 He said he would establish programs to educate companies about regulations so arcane that "the way a piece of paper is filed" can be a violation. He would require inspectors to perform their work in fewer visits to avoid "interrupting production." He would speed issuance of pollution and building permits.
 And he would give companies more opportunities to correct pollution problems before the state takes enforcement action. To do that, he would have inspectors perform "environmental audits" that inform companies about possible pollution violations. Six months later, another team of inspectors would review whether the company had taken steps to reverse those problems. If steps were taken, no fines or penalties would be levied.
 "For the last several years, the appearance has been that our mission has been enforcement rather than compliance," he said.
 But Mr. Zagata said he did not want the agency to be all carrots and no sticks. "Enforcement is definitely a tool in my bag of tricks," he told a State Senate committee on Monday.
 Mr. Zagata cites economic issues in suggesting that he might change the department's direction on other matters. He questioned whether the state should continue plans to centralize its auto-inspection system and to require that 2 percent of all new cars offered for sale by 1998 be electric-powered. He voiced concerns about whether the state should buy more land in the Adirondacks, saying he did not want to hurt local towns by reducing their tax bases.
 And he said that any plan to protect New York City's watershed must not harm the economies of watershed towns, criticizing city officials for "walking away from the table" during negotiations with those towns.
 Mr. Zagata's comments have already infuriated some environmentalists. Lee Wasserman, executive director of Environmental Advocates, a nonprofit group, said Mr. Zagata's policies mean polluters "will get one free bite at the apple." Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, chairman of the Assembly Environmental Committee, attacked Mr. Zagata for allowing Mr. Pataki to make budget cuts that he said would gut the agency's enforcement abilities.
 Mr. Zagata, 52, is a native New Yorker who speaks with a Texas twang developed during 14 years working as an environmental manager in Houston for oil and natural gas companies. There, he pioneered a concept known as mitigation banking, which allows companies to earn permits for building on protected wetlands by first expanding existing wetlands. He said he planned a similar policy for New York State, starting with state highway projects.
 In 1994, he lost his job as vice president of environmental affairs for Transco Energy during a corporate downsizing, and was hired by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to be the Environmental Conservation Department's liaison to business.
 He holds a doctorate in wildlife ecology, has worked as a lobbyist for the National Audubon Society and has taught wildlife resources at the University of Maine.
 Born in the tiny rural town of West Davenport, Mr. Zagata is an outdoorsman whose office walls are hung with photographs of him hunting and fishing. Though he is only 5 feet 8 inches tall, he is a former football tackle who clearly takes some pride in his toughness.
 He recalls, for instance, being rapped on the knuckles by his parochial-school teachers whenever he wrote left-handed. Today, Mr. Zagata remains a proud and unrepentant southpaw with a pen.
 "Every time they hit me, I'd go home and practice with my left hand," he recalled with a smile.

HEADLINE: In Jericho, Pledges of U.S. Aid and a Glimpse at Arafat

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

DATELINE: JERICHO, West Bank, March 24

 BODY:
As the highest-ranking United States official to call on an area governed by Palestinians, Vice President Al Gore came to town today offering $65 million in American aid and trade benefits for exporters here and in the Gaza Strip.
But bigger news for many residents was the arrival of another stranger, Yasir Arafat, who for months had communicated with his Palestinian Authority constituents in Jericho mostly by rumor. 
 It was the first time that they laid eyes on Mr. Arafat, who is based in Gaza, since he visited for a few hours when he took the authority's helm last July. Even townspeople who support him feel bruised by the neglect. It is one reason, they say, that they are still waiting for a coveted economic boom in this place where many planned projects amount to nothing but billboard advertisements posted on vacant lots.
Mr. Arafat sensed the hurt feelings, and after flying in aboard an Egyptian military helicopter, he dealt with them in a speech from a City Hall balcony overlooking the main square. This time, he plans to stay for at least two days.
"I was supposed to have my headquarters here -- you know that," he said. Blame Israel for his long absence, he added, for it has yet to open promised land passages across its territory to connect the far-flung self-rule areas of Gaza and Jericho.
"I don't want to say that it's a conspiracy, but it is an Israeli attempt to keep us from being together," the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization said. But for all the difficulties, he asserted, the time is near when Palestinians will have autonomy throughout the West Bank and then a state, with its capital in Jerusalem.
If turnout is an indicator, Mr. Arafat no longer causes a sensation by his mere presence in the territories. Not many more than 1,000 people turned out for his speech in this town of 15,000 despite sunny, breeze-stroked weather. He even endured a rude sermon from a preacher at a mosque where he had gone for Friday noon prayers.
The speaker, Sheik Abdel Salam Abu Shkhaidem, railed at his congregants that Jews always break their agreements and are "the killers of prophets," according to a Palestinian journalist who was there. And anyone who trusts them and deals with them is their ally, he reportedly said, even "if they wear Arab dress."
That sounded suspiciously like a reference to Mr. Arafat. He was said to have glowered with enough menace that a mosque official signaled silently to the preacher to mind his tongue, which Sheik Abu Shkhaidem did, turning his thoughts to how, of course, "everyone has to do whatever he can."
With a presumption that the P.L.O. leader needs bolstering, Mr. Gore visited for about two hours, going to Jericho instead of Gaza because the Secret Service felt he could be better protected in this relatively staid desert oasis than in the roiling coastal strip.
As part of a United States pledge to give the Palestinian Authority $500 million over five years, the Vice President announced plans to spend $40 million on badly needed sewerage projects in Gaza and $25 million on programs that are supposed to show quick results. For a start, the Americans gave $8 million today to pave streets and improve refugee housing in Gaza, plans that officials said should create more than 5,000 short-term jobs.
In addition, Mr. Gore said manufacturers and farmers in Gaza and Jericho would have duty-free access to the United States market, although the dollar benefit to Palestinians was not clear.
The Vice President, who had traveled through the Middle East all week, warned that the Palestinian Authority must control Islamic suicide bombers and others whose repeated attacks against Israel have contributed to months of stagnation in peace talks. He welcomed as "an important step forward" a fresh promise by Mr. Arafat to set up special courts to hear security cases, even if there is no sign of when the first suspect will be put on trial.
On Thursday, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel told Mr. Gore that a recently set target date of July 1 for completing the next phase of negotiations hinged on Mr. Arafat's "curbing terrorism." It was a mild version of Mr. Rabin's often-stated caution that there are "no holy dates" in the talks, which are already many months behind schedule.
Mr. Arafat did not mention this matter. But a senior aide, Nabil Shaath, questioned whether the Israelis are serious about coming to terms, saying of the July 1 target that he "never believed that date in the first place."
"If Mr. Rabin says that dates are not holy, then it means the agreement is not holy and then that peace is not holy," Mr. Shaath said.

HEADLINE: DIARY;
Yesterday in Washington

 BODY:

TAX CUTS -- Agitation over the Republicans' promised tax cuts broadened as dozens of moderate House Republicans, joined by 23 Democrats who have consistently voted with the majority, demanded that the cuts be delayed until it was clear how they would be paid for. Earlier in the week, 102 Republicans in the House broke ranks with the leadership on the proposed $500 tax credit for families with children. The combined developments suggest trouble for Speaker Newt Gingrich.
 
SPENDING CUTS -- The Senate Appropriations Committee slashed $13 billion from hundreds of Federal programs as a way to reduce the budget deficit and pay for disaster aid to California. The measure cleared the committee by unanimous consent after Democrats agreed to hold their amendments, and their rancor, for the Senate floor.
 
WELFARE REFORM -- The House approved one of the most important items on the Republican agenda, a measure to undo six decades of Federal social-welfare legislation. The vote, almost entirely on party lines, was 234 to 199.
 
AFFIRMATIVE ACTION -- The Senate voted to repeal a communications tax break intended to bolster minority ownership of cable and broadcast companies. The repeal, passed on a voice vote, is a blow to the entertainment giant Viacom Inc. The company's plan to use the 17-year-old tax break to defer nearly $500 million in Federal taxes on the sale of its cable systems propelled the provision into the spotlight.
 
On another issue, Deval Patrick, Assistant Attorney General for civil rights, told a House panel: "This Administration is committed to the goal of expanding opportunity for all Americans in education, employment and the economy generally. There will be no retreat from that commitment." The White House is reviewing affirmative action plans.

HEADLINE: Making Derivatives Pay: Take Apart, Sell Pieces

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
When Salomon Brothers announced yesterday that it wanted to buy up to $8.1 billion in unwanted and complex derivatives, it might have seemed to Main Street as sensible as offering to buy up spent uranium rods from nuclear reactors.
After all, there seems to be no end to the stories of investors who have lost money from complex bets made with derivatives. Just Thursday, the State of Wisconsin said these newfangled financial instruments cost it $95 million. 
 But in fact, Salomon -- or a competing Wall Street firm -- can avail itself of relatively simple techniques to diffuse the risk of the derivatives immediately while locking in a hefty profit.
That's why half a dozen other banks and brokerage firms said they wanted to buy the same derivatives that Salomon was trying to get.
The reason they can do this is that these derivatives, while large, are not so complex as they may appear. They were created originally by combining several of the simpler actively traded derivatives into a single package. These securities, known as structured notes, matched the market predictions of various investors, many of whom turned out to be quite wrong.
Now, Salomon -- or the successful bidder -- can buy the structured notes and in essence take them apart and sell the pieces for more than the whole.
"Think of a structured note as a sports car," one senior trader at a large bank said. "It's risky if you drive too fast and crash it into a tree, but you can buy a sports car, take all the components out and sell them for a profit with no risk."
Despite Salomon's unusual announcement yesterday, this is actually a routine business on Wall Street these days. Traders are constantly buying structured notes and various bonds and using derivatives to add or subtract features to make them more palatable to investors.
For example, one of the derivatives that Salomon wants to buy is a $300 million note issue from the Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae, that pays interest of 10 percent minus the interest rate known as Libor -- the London Interbank Offered Rate -- which is what banks pay for large one-month deposits.
Since interest rates have risen sharply in recent months, the yield on this bond has fallen, causing its value to plunge as well. If rates rise more, it will lose even more value.
But Salomon or another Wall Street dealer that buys this bond is not likely to take that risk. Instead, the firm will simply buy two interest rate swaps, which are the most common and actively traded form of derivative, and combine them with the note to make an investment that simply floats up and down with Libor. There is a huge market for such conservative floating rate investments. And Salomon would have no trouble finding a buyer for the neutralized note.
Some of the notes are more complicated. There is a $175 million Federal Home Loan Bank issue that pays based on a formula of the prime rate charged by banks, plus 2.75 percentage points, minus the three-month Libor. So the owner of that would get more money if the prime rose faster than the London rate.
These more involved contracts may require Salomon to assemble a dozen different swaps, options or futures contracts to neutralize the risks fully. But from Wall Street's point of view, the more the merrier, because since they buy these hedges from their own derivatives departments, they make a profit on each component.

HEADLINE: Stock Prices Surge to Yet Another High

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
After essentially drifting for five sessions, the stock market vaulted to record levels yesterday, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index finishing above 500 for the first time in history. Bond prices rose, too, helped by a stronger dollar overseas.
Stock prices were lifted, in part, because of a new Government report on factory orders for costly machinery and consumer goods, a key measure of economic strength. The report that durable goods orders had slipped eight-tenths of 1 percent in February appeared to indicate that the economy was slowing, exactly as traders had hoped. 
 But some analysts discounted the report's effect, saying the numbers were too volatile and unreliable. Other analysts discussing the rise in stocks pointed to the end of the first quarter, a time when many portfolio managers must move assets from cash to stocks to try to meet performance targets.
Still, the dollar, which has declined more than 12 percent against the yen so far this year, could mean a bumper crop of first-quarter profits for American multinationals, which get part of their revenues in stronger foreign currencies and then trade them in for a greater number of dollars. Stock traders may be bidding up prices for this reason. Meanwhile, the firmer dollar encourages foreign investors to buy stocks.
And there were clearly buyers yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average started out strong and continued to build strength throughout the day, surging more than 50 points at 3:43 P.M. That set off the New York Stock Exchange's so-called circuit-breaker rules, which are intended to slow high-speed computer-guided trading.
By the close, the Dow had surged 50.84 points, to a record 4,138.67, while the broader S.& P. 500 rose 5.02 points, to 500.97, also a new high. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 7.27 points, to 818.66, still another record.
On the New York Stock Exchange, advancing stocks outnumbered declining issues by 1,625 to 657. New highs were hit by 108 stocks, new lows by only 25.
In the logic of the market, too strong an economy is just as bad, or worse, than too weak an economy. Traders hope for a "Goldilocks" economy, with just the right dose of economic growth to make stocks more valuable but too little inflation to hurt the value of fixed-income investments, like bonds.
The Commerce Department's report that orders for big-ticket durable goods, as diverse as airplanes, cars and refrigerators, declined eight-tenths of 1 percent in February was slightly less steep than private-sector economists' expectations of a nine-tenths of 1 percent decline, but it was the first drop since October.
But economists point out that durable goods orders are notoriously volatile, and some contended that the report was not a harbinger of a significant slowing. A big commercial aircraft order, for example, can send a single month's report skyward, as well as make the succeeding month seem earthbound by comparison.
Orders for nonmilitary capital goods like tractors, cranes, and cement mixers actually rose 5.5 percent a month on average for the January to February period after falling five-tenths of 1 percent in the November to December 1994 period.
Still, there has been some slowing in the economy. For the November 1994 to February 1995 period, durable goods orders rose an average of three-tenths of 1 percent monthly, only half the six-tenths of 1 percent average in the July 1994 to October 1994 period.
More important, according to Maria Fiorini Ramirez, who runs an economic consulting firm that bears her name, is the dollar, which firmed yesterday -- a good sign because traders dump worrisome currencies in advance of the weekend, when markets are closed. Yesterday, the dollar rose to 88.95 yen from 88.15 yen, a record low, and advanced to 1.4172 German marks from 1.4037 marks.
"I don't know whether we've reached a plateau level against the yen," Ms. Ramirez said, "but we've probably reached it against the mark."
However, she said the dollar was still fragile. "A Polish newspaper editor told me the other day," Ms. Ramirez added, "that even the poor little Polish zloty has appreciated against the dollar."
The fate of the dollar will be important for stocks, according to David D. Holt, vice president for research and strategy at Wedbush Morgan Securities. "If the dollar firms because of central bank intervention, then it's a sloppy Band-Aid on a major wound," he said. "If it's because currency traders have milked everything they could possibly milk out of the dollar, then you've got a net positive for stocks."
Among the day's big gainers was Adobe Systems, a developer of computer software, which jumped 11 1/2, to 50 1/4. It reported late on Thursday that first-quarter per-share profit was 54 cents, far more than the 38 cents expected by Wall Street.
Canandaigua Wine climbed 3 1/2, to 40 1/2, the second day after it said it planned to buy certain Guinness liquor brands.
The American depository receipts for Telefonos de Chile advanced 3 1/8, to 69, as the overall stock market in Chile gained.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was about 12 percent above normal, with 369.5 million shares changing hands.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 2.58 points, to 270.50; the American Stock Exchange market value index rose 2.38 points, to 460.90.
Of the Dow's 30 component stocks, 26 rose, led by Caterpillar, which tacked on 1 1/2 to close at 51. AT&T led the S.& P. 500's component stocks, rising 3/4, 52 5/8.
The most active stock, at 12.45 million shares, was Telefonos de Mexico, whose A.D.R.'s gained 3/4, to 27 3/4, even after a CS First Boston analyst downgraded it to "hold" from "buy."

HEADLINE: As H.M.O.'s Rise, New York Is Catching Up With Others

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Long considered stuck in the medical dark ages with respect to managed care, New York State is fast catching up with the rest of the country, experts say, as new figures show that a quarter of the state's residents have now joined health maintenance organizations.
Experts say that the 25 percent mark -- which means that about 4.5 million New Yorkers now belong to the organizations -- is a milestone for the H.M.O. industry, signaling that more change is right around the corner. 
 Once the 25 percent mark is achieved, the experts say, most patients will at least know someone in an H.M.O., making this new type of health care more familiar and therefore easier to sell. In addition, most doctors will now feel they have to participate in order to survive.
"That 25 percent means a lot," said Dr. Peter Kongstvedt, a partner at the consulting firm of Ernst & Young in Washington. "It's a critical mass, and after that you can see very rapid change. It's like dropping a crystal into a supersaturated solution and the rest crystallizes very quickly."
What's more, the experts say, once H.M.O.'s control a quarter of any market, they begin to have a profound influence on how all patients, hospitals and doctors do business, leading to the the possibility of cheaper health care and lower insurance fees in the next few years.
"Above a certain threshold, the H.M.O. philosophy begins to permeate the marketplace," said Dr. Alan L. Hillman, the director of the Center for Health Policy at the University of Pennsylvania. "With 5 or 15 percent H.M.O. penetration, the market is not likely to pay a lot of heed. But when you have 25 or 30 percent, they command enough patients that doctors and hospitals have to play ball."
Once H.M.O.'s become powerful in an area, he said, they tend to force even reluctant members of the local medical establishment to change their ways. Under common insurance policies, hospitals are paid for each outpatient procedure they perform and each patient they admit, and so have little financial incentive to scrutinize the need for medical services to control costs. Until very recently, they have focused on expensive, technologically advanced specialty services, like cardiology or neonatal intensive care.
But H.M.O.'s offer patients full medical care for a set yearly fee, most often, in New York, by contracting with existing doctors and hospitals. And when they are looking to buy health care for their members, they demand comprehensive low-cost care, with an emphasis on primary care and prevention.
Already, hospitals in the New York City area are scrambling to upgrade their primary care capacity and shrinking their inpatient and specialty departments, to appeal to the area's newly powerful H.M.O.'s. And doctors, who once regarded a contract with an H.M.O. as a pact with the devil, are now organizing into physician networks to give them more leverage when negotiating with these groups.
"This is the wave of the future and there is no way we're going to stop it," said Dr. Stanley A. Steckler, a urologist who heads one such network of doctors formed by the Medical Society of the State of New York, a physicians' association. "But we do have problems with managed care programs as they now exist."
He said that while some patients liked the fact that all medical care was free after joining an H.M.O., many disliked the restrictions and limited access to specialists. Patients in H.M.O's generally pay little or nothing when they visit doctors within the network and have free access to preventive health care. But their use of medical care is meted out through a primary care physician and the patients cannot consult specialists without a referral.
From March 1993 to January 1995, the percentage of New York State residents who joined H.M.O.'s rose to 25 percent from 19 percent.
These figures include patients enrolled in all types of H.M.O.'s: from "staff-model" H.M.O.'s, which own clinics and employ their own physicians, to "network model" plans, which contract with existing doctors and hospitals to provide care. The new data include patients who belong to traditional H.M.O.'s, where members are entirely restricted to the plan's physicians, as well as people enrolled in the newer "point-of-service" H.M.O.'s, which encourage members to stay in their networks, but allow patients to leave the plan for some services if they are willing to pay part of the cost.
"We have seen strong growth in H.M.O. enrollment and we expect that to continue," said Leslie Moran, director of communication for the New York State H.M.O. Council, an industry group, which released the figures. She added that the New York City region had seen particularly impressive growth, with the enrollment rate rising from below 15 percent to above 20 percent in the last 20 months.
Some areas in upstate New York have had strong H.M.O. enrollment for a number of years. But New York still lags behind states like California and Minnesota, where H.M.O. enrollment tops 30 percent overall, and is above 40 percent in some major cities.
Douglas Sherlock, president of the Sherlock Company, an H.M.O. investment firm in Philadelphia, predicted that the rise in H.M.O. enrollment rates would mean a drop in insurance premiums in New York State over the next two years and a decline in the rate of medical inflation in the area. He said that these changes had occurred in other parts of the country, like Los Angeles and San Francisco, when H.M.O. enrollment topped 30 percent.
In its annual tabulations of H.M.O. membership in New York State, the H.M.O Council found particularly rapid growth among employees of small businesses, as well as the number of New Yorkers who belonged to point-of-service H.M.O.'s.
Such plans are popular with people who are new to managed health care and unlikely to join H.M.O.'s that restrict the choice of doctors and hospitals. The industry views such plans as bait to lure in reluctant customers to the world of managed care; once they become members, patients tend to stay with the H.M.O. and switch to its more restrictive but cheaper version within a few years, health economists say.
The largest H.M.O.'s in New York are the Health Insurance Plan of New York with 913,682 members, Blue Choice with 502,507 members, U.S. Healthcare with 479,351 members, and Oxford Health Plans with 353,100.
A few New York H.M.O.'s have recently experienced rapid growth, such as Oxford Health Plans, Aetna Health Plans of New York and U.S. Healthcare. Oxford, whose plans are known for offering patients a larger degree of choice than most H.M.O.'s, increased its membership to 353,100 from 170,000 between January 1994 and January 1995, a rate of over 500 people a day. "You blink and Oxford grows," Ms. Moran said.

HEADLINE: International Business;
Mexico's Recovery Plan Shows Signs It Is Working

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 24

 BODY:
Two weeks after it was introduced, Mexico's tough new recovery plan is showing the first signs that it may be working: The foundering peso has started to stabilize while the economy is being squeezed even more tightly.
The peso rebounded strongly today for the second consecutive day, ending at 6.815 pesos to the dollar from 6.9 pesos on Thursday. The gains in the peso are seen as a positive response to several moves taken by the Mexican central bank to control the currency's recent volatility. 
 The Mexican stock exchange, which has drifted aimlessly recently, surged today, with its main index rising 106.86 points, or more than 6.5 percent, as investors showed growing confidence in the new plan.
While analysts in New York and Mexico were cautious not to attribute too much to a one-day rally, they were clearly encouraged. "We're looking at the bottom of the market now," said Chip Brown, an economist with Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. "I don't see it getting much worse than it was a couple of weeks ago."
Stabilization, however, is so far coming at a high cost for Mexico. Although the official data will lag by several weeks, there are daily indications that soaring interest rates, a shrinkage of credit, higher prices for gasoline and other products produced by the Government and federal budget cuts are causing even more pain than what President Ernesto Zedillo had told Mexico to expect when he announced the recovery plan on March 9.
Indeed, there are increasing signs that the economy was even weaker than the Government had described when outlining the austerity measures.
Official unemployment figures now show that around 400,000 Mexicans lost their jobs in January, much more than the 250,000 jobs that the Government said just two weeks ago were lost for both January and February.
Recent figures show that domestic car sales fell more than 70 percent in February, while retail sales over all dropped 2.7 percent in January. Despite the slowdown, inflation has stubbornly refused to come under control. The latest figures for the first half of March show an inflation rate of 3.1 percent, the sharpest increase since the Government started keeping track of figures on a twice-monthly basis in 1988.
A 50 percent increase in Mexico's value-added tax, which applies to the manufacture and sale of most goods and services, is scheduled to go into effect April 1, and is likely to keep the pace of inflation high.
And while interest rates for the important 28-day Government treasury certificate dropped slightly in Wednesday's auction, they remain above 80 percent, assuring continued problems for consumers and businesses. Interest rates for credit cards, commercial loans and mortgages are directly tied to movements in the certificates.
Despite the rally in the market and the peso today, there have been indications this week that foreign investors were still skittish about Mexico.
The United States banks that announced in January that they would syndicate a $3 billion loan for Mexico quietly scuttled the transaction this week. One of those banks, J. P. Morgan & Company, is now seeking to raise $1 billion in financing to help bolster Mexico's banking system,
On Wednesday, the Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered its credit rating on the Government's long-term peso debt to BBB+ from A and darkened the outlook on Mexico's foreign currency debt to negative from stable.
But there were some slighlty encouraging signs this week. And in an economy as battered as Mexico's, any bit of positive news can be cause for celebration.
For the first time, the Bank of Mexico paid off holders of maturing Government bonds called tesobonos in dollars instead of pesos. Some $29 billion in such bonds at the beginning of the year spooked investors, and as the bonds matured every week, holders rushed to convert their pesos into dollars. This flooded the market with pesos and created a huge demand for dollars that sent the peso exchange rate into wild gyrations.
The Mexican Government released trade figures showing Mexico had exported $452 million worth of goods more than it imported in February, providing a measure of hope that Mexico will be able to slash its huge current account deficit, which contributed to the crisis that erupted last December.
Also this week, the Bank of Mexico started to issue what will be regular reports to help investors anticipate the peso exchange rate. The first balance sheet showed that Mexico's international currency reserves declined 12.5 percent from the end of February, while the nation's money supply -- the amount of coins and bills in circulation -- had shrunk more than 12 percent since the beginning of the year.
"There's a little bit more confidence in Mexico," said Francisco Blanco, director of analysis at the Arka brokerage firm here. "Things are getting better, but there's still a long way to go."

HEADLINE: Stay Tuned for 24-Hour Fairfield News

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

 BODY:
Cablevision, the Long Island-based cable television company, plans to bring round-the-clock local news to Fairfield County, Conn., this spring and is planning similar programming for Westchester County, northern New Jersey, the Bronx and Brooklyn.
 "I think it will be great," said Joseph P. Ganim, the Mayor of Bridgeport, whose city would share in the expanded coverage. "It will open up all kinds of new avenues for everyone in Fairfield." 
 The service will be modeled after News 12 Long Island, which the company says has become the fourth most-watched channel among Cablevision's 700,000 subscribers in Nassau and Suffolk County since it began operating in 1986 as the first 24-hour-a-day local cable news service in the country.
 Cablevision now broadcasts a local half-hour daily news program on Channel 12 in Fairfield, from offices in Norwalk. Its 25-member staff there will be more than doubled when the 24-hour service begins in June, said Norman Fein, vice president of news development.
 The format will be similar to that of News 12 Long Island, which focuses on Long Island news, weather, traffic, and feature stories, and then adds some national and foreign news from other news organizations.
 The Long Island news staff, which underwent cutbacks because of the recession in 1991, is now back to full strength at around 100, Mr. Fein said.
 "Although our emphasis is local, we are basically a part of the overall New York television market, which has 16.5 million people and is the largest in the country," Mr. Fein said.
 "It's so large, that each area -- Long Island, Fairfield, Westchester and northern New Jersey -- is a major television market on its own, and each is a vacuum we are trying to fill," he said.
 When News 12 Long Island provided live coverage of the trial of Colin Ferguson, who was convicted of killing 6 people and wounding 19 others on the Long Island Rail Road, it had its second highest ratings ever and drew more local viewers than the live coverage of the O. J. Simpson trial by CNN or Court TV.
 "We drew our highest Nielsen ratings -- between 16 and 23 -- when big storms hit the Island," Mr. Fein said. "The Ferguson trial drew ratings of 10 to 12, compared with 4 and 5 for soap operas on the three major networks."
 News 12 Long Island has cost Cablevision more than $20 million over the last nine years, but it is now starting to break even, Mr. Fein said. By developing similar 24-hour news services throughout the metropolitan area, Cablevision hopes to turn a profit by attracting more national advertisers.
 "Our goal is to complete the News 12 metro-ring, to make 24-hour News 12 services available to all our customers in the New York metropolitan area," said Charles F. Dolan, chairman and founder of the Cablevision Systems Corporation, which is headquartered in Woodbury, L.I..
 Industry experts said that 24-hour local cable news is a relatively new market for advertisers, but has made inroads in Orange County, Calif, and the suburbs of Chicago, as well as the New York area.
 "It's a tough market to crack, but if you can prove to national advertisers that you've got a track record, you can probably convince them to come aboard," said William Marchetti, an analyst with Paul Kagan Associates of Carmel, Calif., a television industry consulting firm.
 "There is a critical mass of potential customers that advertisers can reach in heavily populated communities ringing big cities," he said. "If you've got affluent households where there's a programming void and hunger for local news, then you have a market.."
 Next on line after Fairfield, where Cablevision has 190,000 customers, will be Westchester, where Cablevision has 60,000 subscribers and its Channel 12 has a half-hour nightly news program produced in Yonkers.
 In northern New Jersey, where Cablevision has 275,000 subscribers, there is a half-hour daily news program on Channel 12 in Monmouth and Ocean Counties. A 24-hour format would expand coverage to include Bergen, Essex and Hudson Counties.
 Cablevision Systems is the nation's fifth largest operator of local cable television systems. It serves 2.6 million subscribers in 19 states, about 1.5 million of them in the New York metropolitan area.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
A Conference on Gangs Where Gangs Have a Say

BYLINE: By Evelyn Nieves 

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
WHEN Mildred marched to the podium to plead her case, two middle-age women in the packed University of Connecticut auditorium gasped in sympathy. "She's so pretty," one whispered. "And young," the other said. "So young."
 Mildred, 22, looked like a chic high school student, with her gray pants and vest, and white blouse, and brown hair hanging down like a model's. In another life, she could have been homecoming queen or -- who knows? -- valedictorian. And she could still be what she says she wants to be, a social worker, though being a single mother of two makes studies harder. 
 In fact, she was on stage looking for help, for herself and the other women in her Hartford street gang.
 "Violence?" Mildred said. "That's the last thought in our minds. The best thing that I very much would like is help for our sisters. We would like very much to be as professional as most of you are today."
 She was part of a first in Hartford -- a conference on gangs where gang members had their say. The conference, organized by the university's Institute for Violence Reduction, included police officers, social workers, sociologists, clergy and students, as well as 15 members of two gangs, Los Solidos and 20 Love, and a couple of members of The Latin Kings.
 "One goal is dialogue," said I. Michael Borrero, the institute's director. "What conference have you been to where there has been the police chief and gang members in one room?"

ACTUALLY, the Hartford Police Chief, Joseph F. Croughwell Jr., who has stated that he does not negotiate with gangs, left after reminding the audience that gang warfare killed a 7-year-old girl last year. But police chiefs from nearby towns stayed all day. So did the gang members, who showed gumption by showing up. They could have been lectured and screamed and yelled at if the conference included more residents of neighborhoods where gangs have warred, or if any of the city's elected officials had accepted invitations to the forum.
 Spared a hostile public, gang members talked freely (though most did not give their full names). They discussed the love and support they receive from the gangs, or "families," and stressed their peacemaking efforts.
 In the last three months, they pointed out, the streets of Hartford have been quiet because they are determined not to start fighting.
 "That's our main goal," said Book, a professional barber and a member of 20 Love. Back in December, when some members of 20 Love and Los Solidos began shooting each other, he said, other members were negotiating a truce. "Every day, every hour on the hour, we were on the phone saying we got to stop that," he said.
 Members talked about being abused as children, ending up in prison, joining a gang for comfort. They described the economic peer pressures that lead members to deal drugs. They said the police harass them. Dr. Borrero's graduate students at the university's School of Social Work read gang members' accounts of police barging into their apartments, planting drugs, beating them up.
 Skeptics might say the gangs were whining, but the audience was sympathetic. People quickly corrected themselves when they used the word "gang" instead of "family." Many joined gang members in blaming the news organizations for reporting bad news and not telling the world what Kelly, a Solido, called "the positive side."
 "There's a lot of positive in the families," said Kelly, a 26-year-old with long corn rows, as she explained why she joined Los Solidos two years ago. "I was reaching out for someone to be there. And they helped me."
 "They paid for my mother's burial," she said, wiping away tears. "They paid for the whole thing."

SHE is irked, she said, when people believe being in a gang precludes a normal life. "My daughter's in the Girl Scouts," she said. "I go to Girl Scout meetings, like any other mother."
 But Kelly admitted she hides her membership in Los Solidos from her two children. "I have hid it for two years and I can hide it for two or three more years," she said. Did she mean, someone asked, that she didn't want her children to join a gang?
 "No, no, no, no," Kelly said, aware she was giving a mixed message. "It's a lot of hardship you go through," she added. "There's a lot of funerals you go through."
 In the end, Dr. Borrero said, the conference showed that there are gang members who want good jobs and education and opportunity. Until the conference, Dr. Borrero had been one of the few people in Hartford willing to deal with gang members. But members gathered five or six business cards apiece from organizations or individuals offering jobs, he said.
 On Thursday night, after the conference, younger members of the gangs who had heard about the excitement asked why they hadn't been invited. The institute is now looking at putting on a conference in June on youth violence. "At their request," Dr. Borrero said, "not at our request."

HEADLINE: Time Warner to Sell Part Or All of Its Stake in Atari

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
Time Warner Inc., seeking to reduce its debt load, disclosed today that it planned to sell part or all of its 24.5 percent stake in the Atari Corporation.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the giant media and entertainment company said it expected to dispose of "some or all" of its 15.6 million common shares of Atari "from time to time in open market transactions or otherwise." 
 Time Warner recently said it would sell assets that were not part of its core businesses to improve its financial position and reduce its debt. In the S.E.C. filing, it included the Atari stake on the list of noncore assets.
At current prices, the stake is worth $42.9 million.
"This will make a little dent" in Time Warner's debt, said David Londoner, a media analyst at Wertheim Schroder & Company. Time Warner and its 63 percent owned subsidiary, Time Warner Entertainment, have $19.5 billion of debt.
The disclosure weighed on Atari's stock, which fell 37.5 cents, or 15.4 percent, to close at $2.75 on the American Stock Exchange.
But Time Warner's shares rose 25 cents, to $38.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Atari stake is held by Time Warner and its Warner Communications Inc. subsidiary. The investors have already begun selling shares, according to the S.E.C. filing. Warner Communications sold 154,500 Atari shares between Feb. 17 and March 22 at $3.25 to $3.62 a share, the filing said.
"We're not going to sell at any price, but when it's economically beneficial to Time Warner," a Time Warner spokesman said.
Atari, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., manufactures video game systems.
The company was just taking off in the mid-1970's when the Warner Communications founder, Steve Ross, bought the company. From 1980 to 1982, Atari fueled profits at Warner Communications, almost dwarfing Warner's movie and cable business in size, and driving up Warner's stock price.
Emerging competitors in the game business gradually knocked Atari off its pedestal.
In 1984, Time Warner sold the bulk of the Atari Corporation to the Tramiel family. But it retained 80 percent of the video software games part of Atari, now called Atari Games.
Mr. Londoner said a likely candidate for a sale to raise money at Time Warner would be the cable systems that are not part of larger, and more profitable, clusters.
"They would have to sell them off piecemeal or swap them," Mr. Londoner said. "There is a significant amount of money there."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Recovers Against Mark And Climbs From Low vs. Yen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rallied against leading currencies yesterday, rising to a two-week high against the German mark as speculation grew that the Bundesbank might lower interest rates next week.
The dollar was also bolstered by gains in American stocks and bonds. And aggressive dollar purchases by the Japanese central bank helped the dollar rebound from record lows against the yen. 
 "It was a good day for the dollar," said Karl Halligan, a trader at the CIC Bank New York. "The mark was so high that it had to come down." The slightest possibility of a German rate cut was enough to send the mark lower, he said.
Though few traders said that they believed the Bundesbank would cut rates, many sold the surging mark to protect themselves against that possibility. A rate cut would lower the attraction of mark-denominated assets and could cause the mark to decline against the dollar.
The dollar rose to 1.4210 marks, its highest level since March 10, before settling at 1.4172 marks, up from 1.4037 marks on Thursday. The dollar rose to 88.95 yen from 88.15, which was a record low for New York trading.
Speculation that the Bundesbank might lower interest rates intensified this week after a report showed money-supply growth -- the central bank's preferred gauge of future inflation -- remained steady in February after four months of contraction.
The dollar rallied against the yen after the Bank of Japan mounted an aggressive effort to keep its currency from climbing higher against the dollar. Currency dealers estimated that the central bank bought $500 million to $1 billion with yen.
"It looks like the Bank of Japan really wants to hold the dollar up," said Richard Vullo, manager of currency sales at Bayerische Hypotheken und Wechsel Bank in New York.
The Bank of Japan may be stepping up its dollar purchases to keep the yen from rising 15 percent against the dollar compared with its rate on April 1, 1994, Mr. Vullo said.
Under Japanese accounting rules, if the yen rises 15 percent or more against another currency in a fiscal year, Japanese companies and institutional investors must declare losses on investments denominated in that currency.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Rally on Stronger Dollar and New Economic Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
A stronger dollar and further signs that economic growth is slowing combined yesterday to fuel a strong market rally and help drive the long bond's yield down to its lowest level in a week.
The price of the 30-year bond gained a full point, to 103 6/32 , for a yield of 7.36 percent, down from 7.44 percent on Thursday. Investors gained about $10 per $1,000 invested in bonds. Shorter-maturity bill rates also improved, rising about four basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. 
 The Commerce Department reported yesterday that durable goods fell in February for the first time since October; that eased investors' concern that inflation would accelerate and prompt the Fed to raise interest rates once again. Orders fell eight-tenths of 1 percent last month, after gaining a revised 1.4 percent in January.
For bond investors, the durable goods report was definitely a positive. It suggested that expectations of a "soft landing" were still very much alive, traders said. A soft landing would be a period of slower economic growth and moderate inflation without an increase in unemployment.
The resilient dollar also provided a comfort zone for the bond market. A stronger dollar enhances the return on United States Treasury securities for foreign investors when they sell the issues and convert their dollar proceeds into other currencies. It also reduces the risk of higher import prices, which would accelerate inflation.
Volume was initially low, but more traders jumped in as the session progressed. One reason was short-covering. Short-sellers borrow securities and then sell them, hoping to buy them back later at lower prices to repay the loan and pocket the difference. However, if prices begin to rise instead of fall, which was the case yesterday, short-covering ensues: the shorts buy back the securities either to protect profits or limit losses.
Kim Rupert, an economist with MMS International in San Francisco, a market research and analysis firm, said the market had a lot of bullish momentum behind it and was looking for an excuse to go even further. "And the durable goods report gave it just that today," she said.
However, she said that it was only the headline, or overall number, that was market-friendly, while the underlying data still indicated momentum for growth.
"The market continues to fool itself into believing what it wants to see," she said, "and so we'll probably stay on this bullish track."
Ms. Rupert added: "You can expect to see bonds remain in this range near term, but not necessarily lock with the dollar, but more likely to shadow it. I'm not looking for any Fed action to come out of next week's Federal Open Market Committee meeting, but I still think a tightening is in order somewhere down the line, most likely at the May 23 meeting of the F.O.M.C."
Traders reported hearing rumors yesterday that the Fed was actively buying Treasuries, and the rumors helped lift bond prices. That is something the bank never announces, and traders noted that if the Fed was in the market to buy, it was most likely for a foreign central bank and not a signal of change in the Fed's monetary policy.
Supply will probably be of concern to traders next week as the Treasury auctions $69.5 billion in bills and notes, beginning on Monday with its regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, totaling $24 billion.
On Tuesday, the Government will auction $17.25 billion of new two-year notes and on Wednesday, $11 billion of five-year notes. On Thursday, it will auction $17.25 billion of a new one-year bill. In when-issued trading ahead of next week, dealers were offering the two-year issue at a price to yield 6.64 percent and the five-year issue at a price to yield 6.91 percent.

HEADLINE: Orders for Durable Goods Drop In Evidence of Slowing Economy

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
Factory orders for durable goods fell in February for the first time in four months -- fresh evidence, analysts said, that the once robust manufacturing expansion was slowing.
The evidence of an economic soft landing eased fears that the Federal Reserve would push up interest rates again next week to brake inflationary growth and propelled the financial markets into record territory. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 50.84 points, to 4,138.67 -- its third new high this week. 
 "We're making a transition to more moderate growth," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist for Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. But he and other analysts emphasized that the industrial sector was not facing a collapse.
The Commerce Department reported today that orders for durable goods -- items like carpets and computers that are expected to last more than three years -- dropped eight-tenths of a percent in February, to a seasonally adjusted $163.2 billion. The drop was in line with analysts' expectations.
Still, it was the first decline since October, although growth had slowed in December and January from November's 3.4 percent surge. The report said orders in January rose 1.4 percent, which was larger than the initial six-tenths of a percent estimate.
Manufacturing has been a major component of the economic recovery, paced by orders for durable goods, which shot up 13.9 percent last year, the steepest in 16 years.
But the seven short-term interest-rate increases engineered by the Fed over the last 13 months appear to have softened demand recently and, as Mr. Roach said, "Manufacturing is driven by demand."
In addition to higher interest rates, Cynthia Latta, an economist for DRI McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass., said another reason durable orders were off was that consumers had assumed large debt burdens recently and were becoming less willing to take on more debt.
Orders for nonmilitary capital goods excluding aircraft fell 2 percent in February. These orders, a gauge of business plans to expand and modernize, have been a major contributor to economic growth during the recovery.
Orders for electronic and other electrical equipment posted the largest decline, falling 5 percent and erasing gains of seven-tenths of a percent in January and 4 percent in December. The decrease, largely in orders for communications equipment like telephones and facsimile machines, was the first since last July.
Primary metals were down 1.9 percent for the second straight drop.
Orders for industrial machinery and equipment such as computers rose 1.5 percent after jumping 9.4 percent a month earlier.
Military orders, an often volatile component, were up 3.4 percent after plunging 32.7 percent in January. They had risen 65.6 percent in December.

HEADLINE: Observer;
A Little Cyber Grouch

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
Does your blood run cold, friend, when you read about the glories of "cyberspace"? Do you have to repress a shriek of protest every time you hear or read or think about "the information highway"?
If so, it means you are an old stick-in-the-mud and are doomed to end up in the dustbin of history unless you surrender immediately and come along quietly into the age of electronics amok. 
 As a devout reactionary, I naturally despise what these zealous engineers propose to do to us, but cruel experience reminds me it is foolish to oppose them when they are in the heat of re-inventing the world.
My distaste for this latest creative onset begins with petty, unworthy, whining objections. Why, for instance, must they refer to what is being advertised as a magical, irresistible electronic playground as "cyberspace"?
People capable of afflicting anybody, anything or anyplace with a name like "cyberspace" surely cannot have the spiritual and esthetic delicacy essential to creation of a magical, irresistible playground, can they?
All right, call it a captious quibble, but if you were given a choice of places to spend a month, which name would you select -- Tuscany or Cyberspace?
As for "the information highway," sometimes called "the information superhighway," the underlying assumption strikes me as fatally defective. The modern world is not dying for want of more information. Quite the opposite; its plight is too much information. It is being battered senseless, then buried under avalanches of information.
Day and night it is assaulted by a ceaseless flow of information. Often so much information arrives so swiftly that no one can digest it, make sense of it or judge whether it's information worth having.
The national love of gadgetry is involved here. The prospect of hundreds and hundreds of TV channels emptying into our minds, of movies pumping into our eyeballs through the telephone while incoming messages are depleting our fax-paper supply and our computer is talking to the bank and paying the gas bill --
It is a horror reminiscent of the Mickey Mouse sequence in "Fantasia," in which the magically activated water buckets cannot be restrained in their determination to drown the world. Our love of gadgets, however, makes us see it as a delight.
Already people who once walked abroad on the great green earth and breathed the outdoor air now sit glued through the night to their electronic machines, chatting it up with similarly afflicted cyberspaceniks around the world.
All this is being promoted, most notably by Vice President Gore, as a blessing for humanity. And who is to argue with a Vice President?
Still, considering only that part of humanity that is American, it is hard to see how it is going to bless the substantial part of the population that (a) can't afford the machinery and (b) lacks the know-how to make it work.
Many high schools regularly graduate their young so innocent of computer knowledge that they have never worked a keyboard. This considerable part of the population is already going to have trouble avoiding the dustbin of history. The advent of Cyberspace Triumphant is likely to cripple it more thoroughly.
Holding itself together as a nation is already becoming difficult for the United States. The trend everywhere is toward slicing the country into slivers.
Congress, suddenly uneasy with the Union, tries to give power back to single states. Ethnic groups once content to parade one day a year now insist on year-round awareness of their tribal identities. A country that once insisted everybody be "American without a hyphen" is now restoring its hyphens.
The famous Kerner Report's prediction that increasingly divisive racial and economic-group differences would turn the United States into "two nations" looks more accurate with each passing year.
Mr. Gore apparently sees a happier future in which the good old one nation indivisible will go through life with a laptop on every knee. Let us hope so. The mood of the prevailing half of the country as expressed in the election just past and by the present Congress does not, however, seem to bode well for cyberspace for all.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Filipino Migrant Workers Find a Harsh World

 BODY:
To the Editor:
On March 17 Flor Contemplacion, a Filipino maid from Laguna, was hanged in Singapore on murder charges despite evidence from witnesses who claim she was innocent (news articles, March 17 and 18). Her execution has become the rallying point of nationalistic rhetoric on the violent treatment of Filipino women migrant workers in Singapore, Malaysia, Japan, Hong Kong, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Spain, Britain -- in short, all over the world. 
 Most of the people who have written in the Manila newspapers appropriating Flor Contemplacion's execution are the elite. Most of these same Filipino elite treat their own women servants like animals and actually call them "hayup" (the Tagalog word for "animal").
I know too well the plight of Filipino women migrant workers abroad. I was born in Laguna, but grew up in Pangasinan, one of the poorest provinces in the Philippines with one of the highest rates of workers going abroad. I have an army of aunts, uncles and former neighbors who work as domestic servants in Abu Dhabi, the Netherlands, Britain and Japan, who send me letters about their humiliating experiences, of not being treated as human beings.
Like Flor, most of these aunts do not see their children and families for years, some as long as 10 years. Many have stories about being raped by their bosses, about escaping horrible working conditions by jumping from the third floor of a tall building, about organizing a trade union in Saudi Arabia and being arrested, imprisoned and sent home without pay.
I would be as expendable, a poor woman from some obscure village in a marginal former colony, if I had not been privileged to receive scholarships to study for a Ph.D.
It is easy to rouse anger about foreign injustice when it is done in a police state like Singapore. Almost anyone could be outraged. But it is much more difficult to talk about what is being erased -- the question of class. This is part of a pattern woven into a fabric of exploitative labor and daily humiliation.
The ruling elite all over Southeast Asia, regardless of nationality or race, collaborate and use the same tactics to make poor people shut up. This is really what the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and Asia Pacific Economic Conference "solidarity" is all about. They turn dead women workers into martyrs and national heroines, then everyone will shut up. Then they can say that these women did not die in vain.
Meanwhile, women languish in prisons with no right to a fair trial and are executed for someone else's crimes.
The rhetoric of nationalism, which works best by obscuring class and gender, is inadequate to explain the complexities of the exploitation of female labor and the expansion of international capital in Southeast Asia. Poor women like Flor Contemplacion do not matter. Business goes on as usual.
 
JACQUELINE SIAPNO
Irvine, Calif., March 21, 1995
