SECTION: Section 7; Page 32; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 930 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Laurel Graeber 

 BODY:

UNCHAINED MEMORIES: True Stories of Traumatic
Memories, Lost and Found
By Lenore Terr. Basic Books, $13.
A child psychiatrist explains the process of remembering and how certain painful events, such as sexual abuse, may not be recalled until many years after their occurrence. At the same time, she acknowledges that some recollections may be false, consisting of fantasies brought on by suggestion. The result is "a balanced and valuable work," Walter Reich said here last year. 

MERRY MEN
By Carolyn Chute. Harvest/Harcourt Brace, $15.
Egypt, Me., a scruffy rural town in which most of the people are related to one another -- and for all the wrong reasons -- is this author's fictional landscape. In her third novel, Lloyd Barrington, one of Egypt's own, decides to wage war on economic injustice by stealing from the town's few rich residents and giving the spoils to the poor. Last year our reviewer, Ann Hulbert, praised Ms. Chute's "eye for the surreal commonplace" and prose that "at its best continues to mix choppy concreteness with idiosyncratic elegance." Harvest/Harcourt Brace has also reissued both of Ms. Chute's earlier novels about Egypt. LETOURNEAU'S USED AUTO PARTS ($11) centers on two families connected through past marriages and present misery. One patriarch is big and kind, the other a vicious bully. It is "an energetic and unsentimental book," Clarence Major said here in 1988. THE BEANS OF EGYPT, MAINE: The Finished Version ($10), which has been revised by the author, reveals a degenerate and incestuous clan through the eyes of a neighbor, Earlene Pomerleau, who has the misfortune to take up with more than one of the irascible Bean men. In 1985 our reviewer, Bertha Harris, called it a "startling and original first novel," in which Ms. Chute shows "a gift for humor and image making."
THE AGENDA: Inside the Clinton White House
By Bob Woodward. Pocket Books, $6.50.
This portrait of the Presidency shows a chief executive who avoids conflict at all costs and frequently insists on the compatibility of mutually exclusive concepts. It offers "a compulsive, Grisham-like read" rendered in a "pleasingly breathless style," Andrew Sullivan said here last year. The same publisher has also reissued the autobiography of the President's mother, LEADING WITH MY HEART: My Life, by Virginia Clinton Kelley with James Morgan ($6.50). Its subject comes across as warm and unpretentious, a woman whose Arkansas odyssey was often painful but never inspired self-pity. Last year our reviewer, Joyce Carol Oates, said, "To the end, she maintains her stoical good humor; she does indeed strike us as an 'American original.' "
THE BILLION-DOLLAR MOLECULE: One Company's Quest for the Perfect Drug
By Barry Werth. Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $14.
Pharmaceutical research is often a hit-or-miss process: existing substances are marshaled against disease to see if they work. This book explores the world of biotechnology, which seeks to create such medications from scratch. The focus is on Vertex Pharmaceuticals, a young company experimenting with possible cures for autoimmune rejection and AIDS. The work is "exciting and timely," Charles C. Mann said here last year.
THE MUSEUM OF LOVE
By Steve Weiner. Overlook, $11.95.
This novel is a hallucinatory journey across the United States and through the mind of its narrator, a 12-year-old French Canadian boy subject to both strange imaginings and homoerotic desires. Set in the 1950's, "the novel's high-speed pageant of lust and loss is as painful as shrapnel, yet extraordinarily seductive and sublime," our reviewer, Michael Upchurch, said last year.
CUT WITH THE KITCHEN KNIFE: The Weimar
Photomontages of Hannah Hoch
By Maud Lavin. Yale University, $22.50.
An avant-garde artist who was the only woman in Berlin's Dada circle, Hannah Hoch used images cut from the illustrated weeklies of the Weimar era to critique sex roles in German society. In 1993 our reviewer, Christoph M. Kimmich, praised the author's "careful analysis" and "useful insights."
LOOSE WOMAN
By Sandra Cisneros. Vintage Contemporaries, $10.
This collection of poems by the author of "The House on Mango Street" and "Woman Hollering Creek and Other Stories" examines love, sexuality and the Mexican-American experience. Hers is "a unique feminist voice that is at once frank, saucy, realistic, audacious," one critic said last year.
A DRINKING LIFE: A Memoir
By Pete Hamill. Back Bay/Little, Brown, $11.95.
Son of an Irish immigrant who was a regular at Brooklyn's bars, the author discovered both literature and liquor as he grew up during the 1940's and 50's. This book recounts his journey toward a successful career and eventual sobriety. Last year our reviewer, Vincent Patrick, said it shows "the pacing and eye for telling detail learned as a novelist and the hard, spare prose of a fine journalist." Another writer reaches maturity in LEAVING HOME: A Memoir, by Art Buchwald (Fawcett Columbine, $12). This well-known humorist recounts a distinctly unfunny youth, which included stints in foster homes, orphanages and the Marines. His book is "at turns touching, at turns comic," Avery Corman said here last year.
BROTHER TERMITE
By Patricia Anthony. Ace Books, $5.50.
If the Government sometimes seems as if it's from another planet, this narrative gives a reason: insectlike aliens have taken over; one of them is White House chief of staff. In 1993 our reviewer, Newgate Callendar, called this novel "dark, moody, scary, imaginative, sensitively written." LAUREL GRAEBER

HEADLINE: METHOD & MADNESS;
Dead Sure

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS WADE 

 BODY:
IN A LABORATORY IN Zurich, a creature that lived some 50 million years ago and was the unlikely ancestor of both the hippo and the camel has been restored to life. Well, a kind of life anyway.
Religions aside, there are two principal recipes for resurrection. Both are lurching toward the brink of possibility, thanks to recent enhancements in the power tools of molecular biology. 
 One recipe, "Jurassic Park"-style, is to find some ancient DNA and grow the creatures specified by the long-extinct genes. The other is computational, and works backward from the present. Take the gene for a protein -- hemoglobin, say -- from a bunch of different species and determine the sequence of each one. Then have a computer figure out the ancestral DNA sequence from which this family of genes most probably descended. With this data in hand, change the DNA sequence of a present-day gene at certain key points, converting the extant to the extinct.
The study of ancient DNA is still in its troubled youth. DNA was once thought to degrade after death just like the rest of a body's constituents. And so it usually does. But scientists suspected that DNA might sometimes survive in special circumstances. In 1984, intact DNA was extracted from the brains of Native Americans buried 7,000 years ago in a peat bog near Cape Canaveral. Smidgens were found in the tissues of a frozen mammoth some 40,000 years old.
Insects trapped in ancient amber were another source of preserved DNA, but the specimens didn't easily yield enough material for analysis. There the chase paused until a technique called the polymerase chain reaction came along. It permits even a single strand of DNA to be copied and recopied to produce usable amounts. The potential sources of ancient DNA multiplied overnight. With varying degrees of credibility, extremely ancient DNA sequences have now been reported from a variety of specimens, including a 17-million-year-old magnolia leaf and a 120-million-year-old weevil.
The DNA amplification technique vastly enlarges a narrow window into the past, but it brings its own distortions too. It will multiply any DNA it meets, no matter the source: cells sloughed off from the skin of museum curators; the ancient bacteria that attacked the specimen when it died.
Even when such pitfalls are carefully sidestepped, the DNA sequences that emerge from these ancient organisms are frequently very short, and the chemical groups that constitute the genetic information are liable to be changed or lost altogether. The disciples of ancient DNA, many of them former students of the late Allan C. Wilson, a biochemist at the University of California at Berkeley, are now wondering how to make sense of the degraded fragments they have triumphantly recovered.
The other path to resurrection is marking time while a voluminous new data base is being constructed through initiatives like the Human Genome Project. Though focused on humans, biologists are also sequencing the genomes of many lower organisms, like the mouse, the fruitfly and sundry bacteria.
A lot of history is written in these dry chemical sequences. In principle, given enough DNA sequences and computing power, it should be possible to reconstruct the tree of life, from its living leaves down to the twigs and branches, to a point near its very origin some 3.5 billion years ago. But much groundwork remains to be done.
The method of reconstructing ancestral gene sequences is still under test. In charting the genealogy of a family of protein molecules, computer programs are designed to walk back the cat in the most economical number of steps. But though biologists assume that nature loves parsimony, this remains to be proved.
Last month in Nature, Steven A. Benner and colleagues at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich reported an ingenious test of these computer reconstructions. They looked at a digestive enzyme that is used by some ruminant animals to break down bacteria. The chemical sequence of this enzyme, called ribonuclease, is known for some 20 living members of the artiodactyls, a group that includes buffaloes, deer, camels and hippopotamuses.
A computer then generated a family tree with 10 major branching points showing how an ancestral ribonuclease gene might have accumulated one mutation after another, giving rise to all the variants seen in living artiodactyls. Benner's team verified the computer's inferences by synthesizing the 10 genes it had predicted and then having bacteria make the proteins they specify.
All 10 proteins behaved just as digestive enzymes should, suggesting their parent genes had been accurately reconstructed. The earliest ribonuclease gene belongs to the animal that lived just before hippos broke away from the rest of the artiodactyl line. To have recreated a working protein that last existed 50 million years ago is an unusual achievement.
How far will this line of practical inquiry be extended? Biologists are intensely interested in evolution, and you can almost hear one arguing that the best way to learn how a pteranodon flew is to make one. The power to resurrect extinct animals would also raise some odd questions. Would the timber industry argue that old-growth forests should all be clear-cut forthwith, since the spotted owl could be put in cold storage and regenerated when the forests had regrown? Why would sperm banks continue to sell the sperm of famous fathers -- a sort of genetic lottery ticket -- when they could offer an allegedly sure thing: a cloned chip off the old block?
Such fantasies lie years away. Reconstructing ancient DNA sequences is one thing, cloning them is quite another. A set of genes embodies a program that unfolds in the special environment of its own species' egg cell. Even supposing the entire gene sets of long extinct animals can one day be reconstructed, finding appropriate wombs in which to nurture the creatures the genes specify would be quite another matter.
Nor is it a present goal of science. Some scientists feel that recreating an extinct species, or a chimera formed from ancient and contemporary DNA, would be unethical. "Any steps toward the realization of such vision would be prevented" because of "unsolvable problems and conflicts with other organisms and ecological systems," write the editors of "Ancient DNA," Bernd Herrmann and Susanne Hummel of the University of Gottingen in Germany.
The stirring of the ancient artiodactyl ribonuclease is a foretaste of biology's demiurgic powers. It may well prove best to keep resurrection an unroutine event.

HEADLINE: Coming Soon: Swatch Watch, the Sequel

BYLINE: By RITA REIF 

 BODY:
SWATCH COLLECTORS, TAKE note: The frenzy is back. The boldly graphic watches that were hot collectibles in the late 80's are attracting crowds again. And now the draw is several new lines of watches: one by hip-hop artists, another by famous film directors and a third to mark next year's Olympics in Atlanta. There's even a new museum.
The Swiss watch maker SMH International introduced the Swatch quartz watch in 1983. The watches took off when the designs, taken from motifs in art, food and fashion, made them irresistible to the public and collectors alike. By the end of the decade, 80 million Swatches had been sold around the world. But with recession in the early 90's, they had slipped out of the spotlight. 
 The new momentum began building last September when Swatch, the official timekeeper of the 1996 Olympics, unveiled a collection of nine watches decorated with images of Olympics posters, past and present. A second group of nine, due in July, will bear images of torches and medals.
This month, to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the United Nations, Swatch issued a chronograph embellished with symbols of world peace and racial understanding. The watch's plastic band is emblazoned with images of locked arms of different colors and a ravaged world being sewn together; sections of the band are transparent so the color of the wearer's skin becomes part of the design. The watch was conceived by young artists who are members of Ya/Ya, a nonprofit arts organization in New Orleans.
Three other watches, designed by the film directors Robert Altman, Akira Kurosawa and Pedro Almodovar, commemorate the 100th anniversary of the motion picture. The sleekest of the three is Mr. Altman's shimmering watch with a mirrored face and tiny black hands that say "time to reflect." The red and green Kurosawa watch has a face within a face, and Mr. Almodovar's has a floral-patterned face and leather bands encrusted with seed-size beads in a rainbow of hues.
Swatch seems to be trying to create the ultimate in packaging for a limited edition of the directors' watches, 36,500 of which were produced. A set of all three watches comes in a tin reel can with an 8-millimeter film strip about each designer and a miniature projector to view the films. The price for the set: $280.
"It's a collector's dream," said Lynne Cheson, who publishes the newsletter of the Swatchfanatics Worldwide Club from her home in Tenafly, N.J. "We've never before had packaging like this. The most important thing is that the set is limited in number to only 5,555."
Actually, Swatch sells more sports watches than artist-designed "specials," which are produced in smaller editions. But it was the artist designs that became a corporate trademark 10 years ago when Swatch introduced a watch by Christian Chapiron, who works under the pseudonym Kiki Picasso, that became an instant collectible. It was made to sell for $75, but the 100 produced were given away to celebrities and members of the press.
By then, Swatch had put Switzerland back on the map as a manufacturer of low-cost watches. Its quartz watches are housed in a solid plastic case and use 51 parts instead of the standard 91. Swatch prices were competitive in price and still are: $40 for most Swatch watches, $80 for the artist specials.
These days Swatch watches are exhibited at the Pompidou Center in Paris and the Peggy Guggenheim Collection in Venice. The most complete display is in Swatch's new museum, which opened this month in its largest store, near Harvard Square in Cambridge, Mass. That collection includes 900 of the 1,200 models that have been made to date.
"Alas, we don't have the Kiki Picasso watch, but we do have Mimmo Paladino's," said Raman Handa, the store owner. The Paladino watch has a black mask at the center of its face and hands shaped like a red arrow and a black sickle. Produced in 1989 to sell for $75, the watch made Swatch history when two brought record prices at auction: the first was sold in 1990 at Sotheby's in Milan for $20,512 and the second in 1991 at Christie's in Zurich for $25,432.

AMONG THE RARITIES ON VIEW in Cambridge are watches by Keith Haring, Jean-Michel Folon, Alessandro Mendini and Kenny Scharf. And there are numerous other favorites, including the gilded watch, inset with glass jewels, by Christian Lacroix that stopped traffic last December when it was introduced at a Swatch store at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street in Manhattan. Only 75 of the 22,222 produced were delivered to the store; so when 400 people turned up to buy, the crowd spilled onto the sidewalk.
"The police came because people were pushed out into the street," Mrs. Cheson said. "It was great." A lottery was held in the store to determine who could buy the watches. Mrs. Cheson missed out in that drawing but found a Lacroix elsewhere -- and had the designer autograph it.
"I paid $80 for the Lacroix, and it's now going for $350," she said. "Of course I won't sell. Every collector dreams of wearing a special Swatch."

(Swatch)

HEADLINE: Go Ahead, Make Him Cry

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
CLINT EASTWOOD APPEARED. HE FILLED the whole doorway of his office bungalow. He wore a shiny maroon golf shirt, old blue pants hiked up high on his waist and black rubber loafers.
"Hi," he said. 
 He had a curious shamanlike power.
He was a leopardlike creature who rode in on the tail of a comet.
He was a graceful, hard, male animal who did nothing overtly to dominate yet dominated completely.
He was a prairie wind you could ride like some temple virgin toward the sweet, compliant fires marking the soft curve of oblivion.

 But enough wallowing, or Wallering, in the overripe prose of "The Bridges of Madison County." Clint Eastwood, who will be honored tomorrow night at the Oscars (on ABC at 9 P.M.) with the Irving G. Thalberg Memorial Award, is bringing Robert James Waller's huge best seller to the screen in June. He will trade in his spurs for the sandals of Robert Kincaid, the shamanlike, leopardlike, prairie-windlike photographer who falls for Francesca Johnson, an Italian-born Iowa farmer's wife.
Francesca, played with dark hair and -- no doubt -- another perfect accent by Meryl Streep, senses that her lover is a "half-man, half-something-else creature." He is, in Waller's portrait, a vegetarian who wears a bracelet, names his truck, tacks up favorite words ("blue," "wood smoke") on the wall, writes ditzy metaphysical essays and poetry ("Before I became a man, I was an arrow") and, in the heat of passion, murmurs lines like this: "I am the highway and a peregrine and all the sails that ever went to sea."
Isn't this the sort of guy Dirty Harry wouldn't have even bothered to shoot?
Mr. Eastwood frowned a bit and languidly moved his Modigliani legs around, trying to find a comfortable place for them under, on top of or beyond the glass coffee table in his office at Malpaso Productions on the Warner lot in Burbank. The 64-year-old star does not see Kincaid as so far removed from his usual cadre of emotionally spare rebels.
"He is a vegetarian, but he's smoking all the way through the thing," Mr. Eastwood said in that famous voice, a mixture of caress and threat. "He's lighting up Camels all the time, and they're drinking beer all the time. He was a guy who was maybe a little more New Age. He's sort of an aging hippie, you know.
"He's traveling on these jobs in mid-America, and he meets that one woman. And everybody likes to think that there are moments in time when two people can just jell in the best possible way."
With Sharon Stone doing Clint Eastwood in her turn as a sneering, taciturn gunslinger in "The Quick and the Dead," it was perhaps inevitable that Clint Eastwood would go as soft and fuzzy as Alan Alda.
"I know a score of actors who would avoid exposing their emotions the way he does in this movie," Ms. Streep said. "He was very raw. I was shocked. I think he's just reached a point in his life where he doesn't give a damn."
She has not yet seen "Bridges" (the movie will open on June 2) but added excitedly, "I heard Steven Spielberg cried for 40 minutes" after a screening. Mr. Spielberg's company Amblin produced the film with Mr. Eastwood's company, Malpaso.

IN A SIGN OF THESE MORE tender times, Mr. Eastwood now keeps a stroller in his office for toddlers who drop by, among them Francesca, his 18-month-old daughter with the actress Frances Fisher, with whom he lives in Los Angeles. He met Ms. Fisher when she was cast in his 1989 film "Pink Cadillac," and he gave her the part of an unforgiving prostitute in his Oscar-winning 1992 western, "Unforgiven."
"I'm all for day care," said the man who put the phrases "Go ahead, make my day" and "Do you feel lucky, punk?" into the national lexicon.
The actor who made a career out of blowing away bad guys says he enjoyed losing control in the tale of a man "desperately in love." His longtime press agent, Joe Hyams, said that it was weird to watch a rough cut of the film. "Clint has kissed ladies before -- he kissed that nice woman in 'In the Line of Fire' -- but this is a serious romance," Mr. Hyams said.
Mr. Eastwood said, "There are a lot more men that are romantics than I think people give them credit for."
Is he one?
"Yeah," he said. "I enjoy a fantasy thing like that."
Asked his idea of a romantic evening, he replied, "I like atmosphere, candlelight, a nice glass of wine, good music."
Is there a woman present?
He laughed. "Once in a while I call someone," he said, "and tell her 'You should have been here. I was never better than tonight.' "
Mr. Eastwood comes across as the sort of man many women might want want to run off to a covered bridge with, if they were anywhere near a covered bridge, which most people are not. What is most noticeable is his stillness. He laughs easily, which is startling, since he hardly ever laughs in his movies. He looks laid-back, but there is also something coiled about him, a watchfulness.
When he talked about Hollywood and politics this particular evening, he noted the importance of presence and mystery and great vocal quality. And certainly, in person, Clint Eastwood conveyed all those qualities, as he slouched on his couch, his face in the shadows thrown off by one dim lamp and his own famous image squinting down from posters for "A Fistful of Dollars" and "The Outlaw Josey Wales."
He has the cool economy of his characters, scorning the traditional excesses of Hollywood -- from illegal drugs to bloated budgets to warped egos. This is not the sort of man who would find himself in a profligate fiasco like "Waterworld." He brags that he has the same brown curtains and nondescript beige office furniture that the guy who had the bungalow before him left behind two decades ago. "We may have had it recovered once," he said, fondly patting the nubby cotton couch.
While other big-name actors seem to work hard at projecting a certain image, Mr. Eastwood seems casual about his stardom. He once compared his shock at getting famous to waking up with an "ugly hooker." Now he has a wry attitude about his status as an establishment favorite. "I didn't worry about that when I was on the far outside, and I sure as heck don't worry about it now," he said.

 HE RARELY WATCHES HIS movies, except to catch a few moments of ones he likes on television, to see how they are holding up. And, like Cary Grant, he says he will stop acting when he no longer likes seeing that guy up on the screen.
Mr. Eastwood's 31-year marriage to Maggie Johnson ended in 1984, following a long separation. His son, Kyle, 26, is a musician and appeared with his father in "Honky Tonk Man"; his daughter Alison, 22, who appeared with her father in "Tightrope," is a model in Paris. But Mr. Eastwood's second long relationship ended more acrimoniously.
He still faces legal fallout stemming from a nasty palimony suit filed against him in 1989 by his longtime co-star and girlfriend, Sondra Locke. It was a difficult period for Mr. Eastwood because it was the only time, as one of his pals told GQ magazine, that he wasn't "treated like Mother Teresa" by the press. Ms. Locke, still bitter, has now involved him in a second lawsuit, this one over business matters.
Professionally, however, the man once scorned by the Hollywood elite as too right-wing and lowbrow continues to pile up accolades. He has been hailed as intellectually chic in Europe -- despite appearing with an orangutan in "Every Which Way But Loose" in 1978 -- and as a feminist director. Two years ago, he won Oscars for best picture and best director for "Unforgiven."
The Thalberg award he will receive tomorrow night has been given in the past to producers like David O. Selznick, Walt Disney, Alfred Hitchcock, Steven Spielberg and George Lucas. Perhaps, by reshaping Mr. Waller's New Age cowboy in his own lean image, Mr. Eastwood is hoping to capture the one honor that has eluded him -- an Oscar for acting. It has been a gradual transformation from the cigarillo-smoking, dirty-poncho-wearing Man With No Name and the flinty, squinty Dirty Harry to the romantic lead for the middle-aged version of "Love Story."
Mr. Eastwood had already made what the movie historian David Thomson called "welcome departures from male supremacy" -- the 1980 film "Bronco Billy" and the 1982 "Honkytonk Man." (In those films, Mr. Eastwood played a New Jersey shoe clerk and an aging alcoholic country singer, respectively.) The actor has always preferred spunky female leads, because they make better foils for his unreconstructed (but secretly sensitive) males.
"I loved the actresses from the 30's and 40's -- Barbara Stanwyck, Rosalind Russell, Bette Davis," he said. "They all had great voices, and they weren't afraid to be salty."
His Secret Service agent in the hit 1993 thriller "In the Line of Fire" was a big jump on the evolutionary scale, the kind of guy who played "As Time Goes By" on the piano, sniffled helplessly with the flu and offered to give up his career for the woman he loved. Now the actor has gone that final step, as the star and director of "Bridges," a purely sentimental movie.
Some are skeptical. Movieline magazine tweaked: "Sex objects (don't laugh) Meryl Streep, Clint Eastwood."
Some are thrilled. "My mother's 86 and she liked the book and she's very excited about me doing it," Mr. Eastwood said. "She thought Meryl was a great choice."
Mom may have considered Meryl Streep a great choice, but, Hollywood being Hollywood, those making the movie for Warner Brothers were reluctant to allow a 45-year-old actress to play a 45-year-old farmer's wife. (On the other hand, letting a 64-year-old actor play a 52-year-old photographer made perfect sense.)
The first director on the movie, Bruce Beresford, "was not a fan," Ms. Streep said. "I hear they were interested in all sorts of authentic European women."
Mr. Eastwood added: "I had a huge argument when we started this project. They were testing all these 30-year-old women. And it just shocked me. I said, "You know, the best actresses in this world are somewhere probably between 40 and 60. I said, 'What about Meryl Streep?' And they said, 'Well, she's not Italian, and she'd just be doing another accent.' And I said, 'Yeah, but she does them so marvelously.' "
The film makers thought they could get away with casting a younger foreign actress, Mr. Eastwood said, because, as they put it, "some European women are more mature looking at a younger age."
He said the pressure on women to stay young is unfair. "Men are taught the 40's are great, the 50's are great. And women are taught, 'I'm past 30. What do I do now?' They are taught, as soon as they get their first wrinkle, they should go out and have it removed. And really, the character a person has in his face, whatever life has been lived, can really be the most interesting part of them.
"Actresses, at 35, they're looking back at the 28-year-old behind them, and the 28-year-old's looking back at the 22-year-old, the flavor of the month . . . the chickadee-down-the-street. There's something about a woman who knows something that is more interesting."
Those sentiments could not have been rendered better by Robert Kincaid, who considered the "subtleties of the mind and spirit" as important as the way a woman fills out a pair of jeans.
It might have seemed that there would be a clash of mind and spirit between Mr. Eastwood's instinctive acting style and Ms. Streep's elaborate technique. She was groomed at Yale Drama School and in Shakespearean drama. After a stint as a lumberjack and some time in the Army, he was discovered hanging around the coffee wagon at CBS and learned his art playing Rowdy Yates in the television series "Rawhide" in the 1950's and early 60's.
"It doesn't matter whether you get a Ph.D. in engineering or come up through the ranks as an apprentice to engineers," he said. "It's all the same knowledge."
Ms. Streep objected to the notion, too, drawling, "I'm the instinctive one."
As a director, Mr. Eastwood often tries to get a scene down in one take, a trait that some people ascribe to his notorious thriftiness. He said that working swiftly "keeps the energy and the inner life going" and that actors should not use the first 10 takes as a warm-up period. Was his speed a problem for the meticulous Ms. Streep?
"She loved to kind of go for it," he said. "Sometimes we'd go for it without ever rehearsing it."
Ms. Streep said she "fought long and hard not to do this movie" because she found the book overwrought. But when Mr. Eastwood sent her a script, she loved it. "All that florid stuff from the book is gone," she said, slyly sending up Mr. Waller's prose: "He still moves over me like a panther." (Actually, it's like "some fine leopard might do in long grass out on the veld.")
"The only daunting thing" Mr. Eastwood said to her during the filming was -- here she imitates the Eastwood purr -- "I don't think you should do an accent."
"That threw me completely for a loop," she said, "because Francesca had lived in Italy for the first 20 years of her life." She had already prepared for the role by drawing on an Italian war bride who lived down the street from her when she grew up in Summit, N.J. When they shot the first scene, in which Robert Kincaid asks Francesca for directions, Ms. Streep simply came out on the porch and did her Italian accent.
"I ignored him like I do with most directors," she said, "and he laughed."
For the first two weeks he said nothing about her performance. Then he came up to her and said, "You know, if I don't say anything, that means it's good."
Asked how she would describe his voice, she said that its flat, husky character came from the fact that very little vocal range. "On the rare -- very rare -- occasions when he screamed on the set, he would blow out his voice for the rest of day," she said.
Mr. Eastwood's icon-hood was underscored earlier this month when the Society for Cinema Studies Conference at the College of Staten Island, part of the City University of New York, offered a panel on Clint Eastwood in the 1990's. One paper, presented by Peter Lehman of the University of Arizona, was titled, "In an Imperfect World, Men With Small Penises Are Unforgiven." (The treatise examines Mr. Eastwood's "attempt to foreground and integrate issues . . . narratively and thematically" about the male anatomy and the threat of inadequacy.)
Although Mr. Eastwood now seems more involved in movie making than ever, he still follows politics. He was Mayor of Carmel, Calif., from 1986 to 1988, and has been approached for higher office, but says he is not interested. He describes his philosophy as more libertarian than conservative: "The less you mess around with people, the better off people are." He believes that the last two Presidents have not been Presidential enough. "People want the President to be somebody who's rock solid, not arguing with every guy who yells at him over a fence."
He does, however, think the Republicans are on to something with their nostalgia for the old values. "Everything that's the fodder for comedians -- terrible, violent instances, like the current trial here" -- a reference to the O. J. Simpson trial, which he will not watch -- "and people telling Jeffrey Dahmer jokes. In the old days, people would have gone, 'Maybe that's in bad taste.' The country should be interested in better things."
These days he is spending time again being a father, and he has already noticed a genetic quirk. "My daughter doesn't even completely talk yet, but sometimes she'll look at me like this and go" -- here Mr. Eastwood gives his famous squint -- "or she'll make a lot of faces like kids do and you'll say, 'O.K., squint,' and she'll go" -- again he demonstrates his daughter's squint.
His idea of a good evening is still pretty basic: "I have two Budweisers in front of the fireplace. Squeeze the cans. Even though they're aluminum and it's easy to do nowadays, you know, you still feel kind of macho about it. You toss 'em in the wastebasket, you belch three times and go to bed."

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2648 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Hotels;
At New York Hotels, Things Are Looking Grand

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
CDL International, a Hong Kong hospitality company, buys the Hotel Macklowe on West 44th Street for nearly $164,000 a room, second in per-room price nationally in 1994 only to the Phoenician, the Babylonesque Arizona resort hotel that sold last year for about $386,000 a room.
Thayer Capital Partners, an investment group, raises $120 million to invest in all-suite hotels, while LaSalle Partners forms a hotel group to help clients pick which properties to buy. 
 Hartz Mountain Industries, proving it really means it this time, invites Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to attend a groundbreaking ceremony on April 3 for the SoHo Grand, a 370-room hotel at West Broadway and Grand Street that it first talked about building in 1989.
"We've been in circle-the-wagons mentality since then, even tried to sell the property once," said Emanuel Stern, Hartz Mountain's executive vice president. "Now we are again ready to bet on the future of SoHo and the city."
For the first time in a long time, New York hoteliers have a lot to smile about -- and even more to talk about. The much-despised 5 percent state surcharge on hotel rooms has been gone since September, and 1 percentage point of the New York City tax disappeared in December. Average room rates were up 6.8 percent last year, to $144 a night, the first increase since 1989. PKF Consulting, which specializes in the hospitality industry, says that in December, average room rates hit $157.14, the highest average ever.
And people readily paid the hefty rates. A surge in both business and tourist travel combined to bring occupancy last year to 75.5 percent, the highest it has been since 1988. The persistently cheap dollar, which makes it inexpensive for foreigners to come here and very expensive for Americans to go overseas, is boosting room sales even higher.
"We are having our best quarter since 1990," said an exuberant Arthur A. Surin, senior vice president of the New York Hilton. Hotel consultants say the good news is echoed throughout the hotel community. "Last year was the best year this industry has seen since 1988, and this year will be even better," said Michael Fishbin, a senior manager of the Kenneth Leventhal accounting firm's hospitality services practice.
But while the business recovery may represent the hotel world's most heartening news, it is not the most intriguing. That designation goes to the sales activity bounding through the industry.
"Two years ago, 'hotel' was a nasty word in real estate circles," said Daniel H. Lesser, director of Cushman & Wakefield's national hospitality valuation group. "But investors see a real window of opportunity now."
Indeed, sellers report that buyers have grown much easier to find. Chemical Bank took control of the Millenium Hotel in 1993 and of the Macklowe in 1994, and marketed both hotels immediately.
"We got three bids for the Millenium, yet a year later 11 buyers wanted the Macklowe," recalled Ben McGrath, Chemical Bank's managing director of real estate investment banking, who says that differences in location and facilities were built into the prices. "There were bidders with money in 1994 who did not have money in 1993." (CDL International eventually bought both hotels.)
Apparently, investors now see the hospitality industry as a lucrative place to be. Last year, the Millenium, on Church Street, went for $75 million, or $133,700 a room, while the Macklowe commanded a total of $101 million. Metromedia, the investor John W. Kluge's company, grabbed the Barbizon Hotel on East 63d Street for $19 million, about $62,300 a room. Host Marriott Corporation, which had been running the Marriott East Side, at Lexington Avenue and 48th Street, bought it, with the investor Morris Bailey, for $55 million -- $82,800 a room.
Off-the-beaten-track hotels attracted buyers, too. Bernard Goldberg, a real estate lawyer, has bought and renovated several older New York hotels, including the Wales at 92d Street and Madison Avenue and the Shoreham on West 55th Street. He just took a long-term ground lease on the Roger Williams Hotel at 31st Street and Madison Avenue, and is ready to renovate that. "I believe you make your own location," said Mr. Goldberg, who often holds free classical music concerts at his hotels.
The buyers run the gamut, from hotel companies to investor groups to hotel-based real estate investment trusts. "As with any real estate investment, there's a herd mentality, with everyone coming into the market at the same time," said Joseph D. Long, a LaSalle vice president who says that the market for hotels has "heated up dramatically" over the last 18 months. "People no longer have to speculate about a turnaround -- hotels have turned the corner."
Nor is Hartz Mountain the only company with construction plans. Four development teams are vying to build a 1,000-room hotel at 43d Street and Eighth Avenue, and the city is expected to pick a winner this spring. Hotel analysts say that this may be the year that developers get financing to turn a 100-year-old building in SoHo into the Mercer Hotel, a tiny (73-room) but much discussed boutique hotel at Mercer and Prince Streets. And talk has started up again about possible new hotels near Battery Park City and the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.
Still, today's hotel boom bears little resemblance to the one of a decade ago. Back then, travelers would seemingly pay anything to stay in a glitzy setting. Corporations would include breakfast, lunch, dinner and free-flowing drinks as part of meetings. Investors and hoteliers flooded the country with new hotel rooms. When the recession hit in the late 1980's, the hotel market was suffering from a glut.
This time, the market is recovering at a time when the supply of hotel rooms has remained static. "If the economy turns down again, there will be a soft landing because there's been virtually no new room growth," said Frederic V. Malek, a former Marriott executive and now chairman of Thayer Capital Partners, which recently teamed up with Marriott International to buy part of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company.
But the conservatism of the 90's poses difficulties, too. Today's travelers, hoteliers say, are less free-spending. Meetings are shorter, and include fewer meals. And guests willing to spring for high-priced rooms expect telecommunications systems, fax machines and other services.
"People will pay $150 a night, but they will not settle for $20 worth of value for it," said Franz Zeller, general manager of the Vista International, at the World Trade Center.
That search for value has made hotel management a less hit-or-miss proposition. Increasingly, hotel owners are insisting on cancellation clauses in the management contracts they give hotel chains, stipulating that they can terminate the contract if they do not like the way the hotel is being run. They are demanding a greater say in how much is spent and what it is spent on.
"In the past there was a lot less oversight," noted Michael Littler, the Hotel Macklowe's general manager.
MANY investors, in fact, are teaming up with hotel chains: the investors supply the funds, the hotel companies the expertise. The Blackstone Group has aligned with Interstate Hotel Corporation to seek out new properties; it is particularly active in Texas. Thayer Capital has bought hotels with Marriott and Doubletree.
"It is savvy investors who are back in the market, and they recognize they need expertise to turn hotels into viable investments," said John A. Fox, a senior vice president of PKF Consulting, who says that he is averaging two or three calls a week from investors looking to buy New York hotels.
There is no dearth of properties available for would-be buyers. Prudential wants to sell its half of the New York Hilton hotel, at 54th Street and Sixth Avenue. Last week speculation was rife throughout the industry that CDL would buy The Plaza Hotel, at 59th Street and Fifth Avenue. Some industry experts say that Donald Trump, who still owns 51 percent of the hotel, wants to hold out for a very high price. But he may not have the choice. Under a settlement that kept Mr. Trump out of bankruptcy, a group of banks, led by Citibank, got 49 percent of the hotel and the right to sell it for a specified (but undisclosed) minimum price, as long as they give Mr. Trump rights of first refusal.
The Mayfair Regency on East 65th Street, the home of Le Cirque (which is said to be looking to move, a rumor its owner denies), is for sale. So are all of Doral's properties, including the Tuscany, the Doral Court and the Doral Park, all clustered around East 39th Street. And Mayor Giuliani is talking about putting the United Nations Plaza Hotel, which was built by the United Nations Development Corporation in 1976 as part of a larger project to help meet the U.N.'s growing demands, on the market for somewhere between $70 million and $90 million. The development corporation gave the entire project, which is on 44th Street and First Avenue and which includes office space, to the city so that the properties would not be taxed, thus keeping the U.N.'s rents low. The hotel, which Hyatt International has been running, has been perennially profitable, but the Mayor wants to sell it to raise cash to help close the city deficit.
And those are just the hotels everyone acknowledges are for sale. Industry insiders say that ITT Sheraton has been looking to sell the Sheraton Park Avenue hotel at 38th Street, which it owns with John Hancock, although some say the partnership, which could not get the price it wanted, is now taking the hotel off the market. Hotel experts also say that Hilton Hotel Corporation is looking to spin off all of its non-gaming facilities, and thus would happily sell its share of the New York Hilton, too. (Spokespersons for both Hilton and Sheraton would only acknowledge that they were evaluating their strategies.)
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which has openly discussed privatizing airports, the World Trade Center and other properties it owns, is said to be considering selling the Vista. (Also in keep-mum mode, spokespersons for both the Port Authority and for Hilton International, which manages the Vista, would neither confirm nor deny the talk.)
The for-sale hotels are not necessarily unprofitable. Many are simply laboring under debt burdens that, once the booming 80's ended, no property could sustain.
"We were operationally successful from the first," said Mr. Littler of the Macklowe. "The problem was always debt service." (Chemical Bank confirms that, in 1994, the property's debt service was higher than its cash flow, of just under $7 million.)
AND many older hotels went through expensive refurbishing programs in the last few years, some in anticipation of the Democratic Convention of 1992, others because their aging facilities could no longer entice customers. "There's no question our business is up, but we figure only about 40 percent of that is due to the general market," said Mr. Zeller of the Vista, which renovated extensively after the World Trade Center bombing caused it to close two years ago. "At least 60 percent is due to our renovation."
The hotels also have learned to target specialized customer bases. The large, centrally located hotels like the Hilton -- and even smaller ones like the Macklowe, which has an adjoining theater and convention center -- continue to rely on conventions and meetings for much of their business. But many newer hotels are marketing themselves to other groups.
The SoHo Grand, for example, is going after Wall Street trainees, as well as art aficionados attracted to SoHo. The Vista, which lost much of its corporate business while it was out of commission, has chased tour groups. Mr. Goldberg, who is also renovating the Mansfield Hotel, on West 44th Street, is targeting Europeans and overflow guests from the myriad university and other private clubs on the block, and even from the Royalton and Algonquin.
Marketing, in fact, is becoming a more economical proposition for many New York hotels as more of them get snapped up by worldwide chains. CDL, Doubletree, Marriott, Hilton, all are seeking ways to get more mileage out of their international reservations systems and their marketing dollars.
Even mini-chains may get marketing synergies. Metromedia, the Barbizon's new owner, also owns the Empire Hotel. Both hotels appeal to travelers who consider being on the northern fringes of midtown a viable sacrifice for a lower room rate, and who have things other than business on their agendas. The Empire, after all, is right across from Lincoln Center, while the Barbizon is convenient to Bloomingdale's and the luxury shops, museums and galleries on upper Madison and Fifth Avenues.
"You stand on 57th and Fifth, you see all these hotels charging more than $200 a night, and then there's the Barbizon," said Thomas Arasi, executive vice president of Tishman Realty, which represented Metromedia in the purchase. "Metromedia has mid-priced hotels at great locations."
Moreover, the smaller hotels are hoping that the larger ones will mount marketing blitzes that will woo more business to New York in general. The Macklowe's Mr. Littler, for one, relishes the idea of the anticipated behemoth on Eighth Avenue, between 42d and 43d Streets.
"This whole area is already a hub of family entertainment, and a new hotel will market the area even more,"he said.
Of course, lots of factors could mitigate all the good cheer. Last year's stellar numbers cannot be attributed solely to a healthy industry; the World Cup soccer matches and the Gay Games brought business to town that will not be repeated this year.
And hotel labor costs may soon rise. Hoteliers say that wages and work rules in the current contract with the Hotel Trades Council, the primary hotel workers union, have made New York's operating costs 50 percent higher than in comparable cities. That contract expires this summer, and the hotels are gearing for a strike.
"The union has made ridiculous demands, the hotels are taking a tough stance and a big fight seems inevitable," said one hotel consultant who insisted on anonymity.
MOREOVER, room supply is creeping up. After pumping $65 million into the aging building, Wharf Holdings, which bought the Omni Berkshire Place Hotel at Madison Avenue and 52d Street for $84 million in 1988, is putting the hotel's 396 rooms back on the market this fall. The Kitano Hotel, at Park and 38th Street, has been renovated and expanded, and will reopen this year. Mr. Goldberg should finish renovating the Mansfield by June. The New Yorker Hotel at 34th Street and Eighth Avenue, once used to house followers of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, has opened 240 rooms to the public.
Even more rooms should turn up in the next couple of years. The SoHo Grand is slated to open in the summer of 1996. The Trump Organization has incorporated 150 hotel rooms into its plans for the former Gulf & Western Building at Columbus Circle. City officials, meanwhile, still talk of a hotel and meeting center where the Coliseum now stands. And of course, there is the prospect of the new Times Square hotel.
Prospective developers insist that their projects will create business, not siphon it from other hotels. "This hotel will capture latent demand from the Javits Center and from Times Square, but its impact on existing properties will be minimum," said Mr. Arasi of Tishman, which has bid for the job of building the Times Square hotel.
Not everyone is so sure. Indeed, there are still many investors who, beset with sour memories of the 80's, are refusing to drink at the hotel trough this time around.
Chemical Bank, for one, has no further hotels in its portfolio. Nor does it intend to add any. As Mr. McGrath put it, "There are easier ways to make a buck."

HEADLINE: Ladies' Mile Restoration

To the Editor:
It has been a pleasure to witness the restoration and revitalization of Ladies' Mile ("Restoration for the Final Stretch of the Ladies' Mile," Feb. 12). These magnificent buildings, protected by the Landmarks Preservation Commission, now draw thousands of shoppers to the neighborhood and have growing economic viability. HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
Sales Rising at Big Downtown White Plains Condos

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
AFTER years of stalled sales, sponsor defaults and other financial difficulties, Westage Towers and Stewart Place, two large high-rise condominium buildings in this city's downtown area, have been attracting renewed sales interest, especially in the last few months, according to brokers.
A third building, the Seasons, the largest of the three major downtown condominiums with 316 apartments, has temporarily taken its available units off the market in the hope that their values will appreciate. Westage Towers has 254 units and Stewart Place has 182. 
 "Since February, all of my people say that things have picked up for the high-rise condos," said Rita Cohen, president of The Prudential Rita Cohen Realty, in White Plains. "The weather helped, and so did the concern over rising interest rates."
Some of the uptick in interest can also be attributed, Ms. Cohen said, to the impact from construction projects in the city: the new Federal courthouse scheduled to open in the spring, and, to some extent, The Westchester, a 2.5 million-square-foot megamall that opened on March 17.
"With the courthouse, we've gotten a lot of lawyers," she said, adding that the impact from the Westchester had not been as strong. "Some of the people who were transferred to work at the mall are helping the upper rental market now," she said. "If they are transferred in permanently, then we'll probably see them buying."
Westage Towers, at 25 Rockledge Avenue, is closing on its final three units this month, said Mitchell Rutter, president of Essex Capital Partners, a Manhattan-based real estate investment company. Fourteen months ago, Mr. Rutter's firm, which specializes in buying undervalued properties, acquired the Westage Tower's 36 remaining unsold units.
"This has been a very fine transaction for us," he said. "Our first buyer was a New York Knick, and the second was a New York Ranger. I think people like that prefer our building, because we're not on a city street, but in a gated enclave community." He declined to disclose the athletes' names.
Both the Seasons, which is across from the White Plains Metro-North station, and Stewart Place, near the College of White Plains, are directly on city streets.
In January 1994, Haseko Corporation, a real estate company based in Tokyo, purchased 91 unsold units at Stewart Place. "We didn't start marketing the units until April 1994," said Edward G. Bissen, sales manager. "In less than a year, we've sold 40 units, 12 since the first of the year."
Mr. Bissen said the building has been attracting a wide range of buyers, including "first-time home buyers, who can be young married couples or singles."
"We're also getting people who have recently become single, some transferees and empty-nesters," he said.
When 25-year-old Louis Mauro decided to move out of his parents' home in Scarsdale he wanted an "ultramodern one-bedroom condominium, with new appliances and a clean look," he said. He was the second buyer at Stewart Place when it reopened sales last April, purchasing a one-bedroom with a terrace for $135,000.
"I was prepared to pay anything from $125,000 to $200,000 to get what I wanted," Mr. Mauro said. "But this had everything I was looking for, including low taxes and a central location. The taxes here are low compared to a place like Scarsdale." And the business he owns, A & C Autobody, is around the corner from his new apartment.
ALL three condominium buildings were constructed in the late 1980's, when one-bedroom apartments commanded prices as high as $210,000. Soon afterward, demand for such units dropped off. The Robert Martin Company, the sponsor of the Seasons, converted its unsold units to rental apartments in November 1991. At Stewart Place, only half the units were sold when the recession hit. The sponsor defaulted on the remaining units in October 1991.
What's spurring sales now at all the buildings is price, Ms. Cohen said. "They've gone back to 1986 prices, which is realistic," she said. "If people would only realize that 1988 and 1989 were aberrations. We're not going to see those prices again. Everything is price point today. If apartments are priced well, they will sell."
That strategy accounts for the sales success at Westage Towers, Mr. Rutter said. "The key for us was buying the remaining units at a discount," he said, "then offering them at below-market prices," which translates to one-bedrooms at $139,000, two-bedrooms at $240,000 and three-bedrooms at $315,000. "This way there's still a profit for us and a gain for our buyers," he said. "We were also able to offer buyers 90 percent financing."
Mr. Bissen said that at Stewart Place, one bedrooms are about $130,000, two-bedrooms $161,500 and two- and three-bedroom penthouses $300,000.
PRICE was the primary concern of Floria Watson and her husband, Philip, when they bought their one-bedroom apartment at Stewart Place. "We had looked at the other buildings, but thought they were overpriced for what you were getting," Ms. Watson said. The Watsons had been renting their apartment for four years before deciding to buy.
"We wanted to see how things were with the building and wait for the prices to come down," she said. "When they decided to sell again, the price for our apartment was $127,500, which we thought was really, really great. For that we got a one-bedroom with two baths, a terrace, a dressing area and a parking space in an indoor garage."
The current selling activity is quite a change from a year ago, when high-rise condominiums in downtown White Plains were just beginning to be remarketed after a period of few or no sales. Hoping to jump-start sales and determine market prices, the Robert Martin Company, a real estate developer and manager based in Elmsford, held an auction last summer of 50 units at the Seasons.
It generated the sale of 26 apartments, at an average sales price of $159.75 per square foot, or about $115,000 for a one-bedroom. "We had hoped to sell for $160 per square foot, so we were pretty pleased," said Robin B. Steiner, a vice president with Robert Martin's real estate division.
A few months later, a Hong Kong-based investment group, Glorious Sun, purchased the remaining 173 unsold units for a reported $18 million. Mr. Steiner said that the company planned to continue renting the units until their values appreciate.
"Seeing a white knight like that come in could have helped things along for the other buildings," he said. "It brought a new interest to this kind of housing."
Sales at the Westage Towers picked up before the announcement of that transaction, Mr. Rutter said. "Around the time of Robert Martin's auction, we saw an increase in sales. We benefited by all the publicity surrounding that. I thought people would wait until they saw what prices the auction would bring but they didn't."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Louis Mauro, the second buyer at Stewart Place condominium (rear). (Alan Zale for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The View From: Taftville;
Life Returns to a 19th-Century Textile Mill

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
THE rhythmic hum of a twister, a machine used to ply yarn, fills the turn-of-the-century red brick building at the Ponemah Mill in Taftville. A pile of grayish-white Cotswold wool lies on the floor near a carding machine. Boxes overflowing with skeins of Ponemah woolen yarn are everywhere. The mill, which closed in 1972 after a century of textile manufacturing, is stirring with life again.
In 1990, the newly formed Quinnehticut Woolen Company moved into 10,000 square feet on the ground floor of Ponemah's Mill No. 3. Antiquated textile machines are again spinning Ponemah yarn for knitters and weavers. Squeezed into a corner of the ground floor is the factory store, where samples of sweaters, socks, and other items made from the yarn hang on the walls. The company also supplies yarn to several hundred small retail shops aroud the country, said Dale Plummer, a founder of the company. Its list of mail order customers is growing, he said, and business at the factory store is steady. 
 There are other signs of a revival in New England's textile industry, Mr. Plummer said, pointing to what he described as prosperous mills in Stafford Springs and Unionville.
"There has been a lot of investment in new machinery and equipment in the larger mills in New England," said Mr. Plummer, 45. "That's a good sign. I don't think you're going to see anything like the old Ponemah Mill, which employed thousands. There will be smaller operations that do specific kinds of things, like spinning or weaving."
Unlike the successful mill owners of the late 1800's and early 1900's, who lived in hilltop mansions overlooking their mills and rarely became involved in the daily operations of their businesses, Mr. Plummer works long hours on the factory floor. His customary work outfit these days consists of a plaid flannel shirt and black work boots.
Mr. Plummer was a self-employed consultant in historic preservation for 20 years before starting Quinnehticut Woolen Company. The idea to go into yarn manufacturing grew out of his discussions with Mary Wellemeyer, an economist from Manchester who is now a partner in Quinnehticut. "Eastern Connecticut has all this vacant mill space, old machinery, sheep and people with skills to make yarn," Mr. Plummer said. "I asked why we couldn't take that and make something worthwhile out of it."
When the recession took hold in the late 1980's, and landmark-preservation projects were cut back, Mr. Plummer thought about opening a mill, he said. The fact that he knew nothing about the business did not faze him. He plunged in, he said, even though "some of the old-timers in the textile industry told us not to do it, because we didn't have any experience."
Ms. Wellemeyer and Mr. Plummer saw opportunities to market their product to individual knitters, who complain about a shortage of good quality yarn, and to New England's textile weavers. "A lot of the small yarn stores are disappearing, and I have gotten letters from customers asking to buy it directly from me," Mr. Plummer said.
Ms. Wellemeyer, who said she enjoys starting businesses, is in charge of marketing Ponemah yarn. (The original mill owners took the name, meaning "our future hope," from Longfellow's "Song of Hiawatha.") In her previous job with Habitat for Humanity in southeastern Connecticut, Ms. Wellemeyer said, she realized that the shortage of jobs was a growing problem.
"I talked with Dale about reusing old equipment and buildings and undervalued fibers. There seemed to be a potential there," she said.
With an initial investment of less than $100,000, the partners bought and transported picking, carding, spinning and winding machines from defunct mills as far away as Quebec and Pennsylvania. Some machines came from Hale Manufacturing in Putnam, makers of synthetic yarn until 1989, Mr. Plummer said.
Mr. Plummer said he turned to mill owners and former textile workers when he needed help in assembling, installing and repairing the machines. "I learned as I went along," he said. "It's an unusual industry in many ways. It's a closely knit community of people who feel very supportive of one another. They see their fortunes as being linked. What harms one harms everybody."
Many different processes go into making a skein of Ponemah yarn. Mr. Plummer buys wool from sheep farms in northwestern Connecticut and other parts of New England. He sends the wool to Philadelphia for scouring, to clean it of lanolin and sweat, and then to Woonsocket, R.I., for dyeing. The wool is carded -- basically, untangled -- and spun in Taftville.
The Quinnehticut Woolen Company discovered another niche in the market when it started accepting jobs from mills that needed extra spinning time in order to fill their own orders. Shortly after the business opened, Mr. Plummer said, a woolen mill in Maine called looking for a mill that could spin 20,000 pounds of wool a week.
"That was a challenge," he said. "We had one carding machine and one spinning frame at the time. The most we could do was 2,000 pounds a week. But the man took our offer because he needed the help. We called in all the old-timers for advice and managed to do it."
The company also takes custom orders to spin small lots to particular specifications or to make yarn in a particular color. It has also devised ways of swapping materials and labor with other mills, Mr. Plummer said. For instance, the company spins wool for a weaving mill in Pennsylvania, which pays for the service with woven blankets, which Quinnehticut sells in its factory store. But Mr. Plummer said he expected to make the greatest profits by selling as much yarn as possible at the factory store and by mail order.
Photos on the wall at the Quinnehticut Woolen Company tell the story of profits made by the Ponemah Mill, which was said to be the largest cotton manufacturing plant in the world. The mill produced typewriter-ribbon cloth, cambric and percale. During World War I, it added cloth for airplane wings to its product line.
The mill's first building opened in 1871. Designed in the French second empire style, it has five floors. Two square stair towers topped with ornate cupolas dominate the facade. The building is 750 feet long and 74 feet wide, and a 228-foot-long L-shaped section extends from the rear of the main structure toward the Shetucket River. Five granite-and-masonry arches beneath the rear section collected water from the river to generate electric power for the mill. Two more brick mills were built later to house Ponemah's expanding weaving operation.
At one time, 1,500 workers lived in Taftville, the mill village. The village's name came from two investors in the mill, Cyrus and Edward P. Taft. The owners of the Ponemah Mill built more than 200 identical workers' houses on streets laid out in a grid pattern. Each had a white picket fence in front. The mill and village are on the National Register of Historic Places, and every original building is still standing.
Six people now work, either part or full time, at the woolen company. Although business this winter has been slow, because of the mild weather, Mr. Plummer said, he expects to show a profit for the first time this year and to create more full-time shifts. The company has already begun diversifying by making woolen batting for a futon manufacturer in Manchester.
The mills in Connecticut are beginning to shed the stigma of their long decline, Mr. Plummer said. "Now, there is more pride among people in the industry," he said, "and we're taking a different look at its history."
People who worked at the Ponemah Mill visit the woolen company and stop to examine the pictures on the wall, Mr. Plummer said. "They want to see these skills continue," he added. "It has a lot of meaning for them."

HEADLINE: INNUMERACY2

 BODY:
I read with interest and hope Max Frankel on "Innumeracy2 " (Word & Image, March 5).
Is it possible that journalists, Washington's "experts" and all media may take this information and use it wisely? I rather think not. Obviously, to the careful reader/ listener, numbers are crunched and molded to one's direction. 
 One of the most interesting was done during the Nixon Administration. A Department of Labor spokesperson came on camera to say:
"The rate of increase of unemployment has slowed."
Small comfort to the man/ woman registering at the local unemployment office. Unemployment, in fact, was increasing even as the Department of Labor representative spoke.
It was interesting that when I tried to discuss this with my generally wise and critical groups that I made no sense to them.
If reporters would report and check facts and media would not try so hard to look wise, perhaps people would be less led down dead-end paths.
 
ELAINE M. ANDREWS
Teaneck, N.J.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Picking Stocks Its Own Size

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
A TINY mutual fund just two years old is popping up at the top of many stock fund rankings and attracting new money at a fast clip. But before investors send their checks, they should take a close look at the fund's portfolio and decide how much risk they are willing to take.
The fund, called Perkins Opportunity, belongs to one of the riskiest categories -- funds that buy stocks of small companies. And even within that category, it appears to be among the riskiest. 
 Largely because of its aggressive investment style, the fund has gained a stunning 15.2 percent already this year, compared with 4.9 percent for all growth funds. It rose 14.8 percent in 1994, while the group lost 2 percent, according to Morningstar Inc., fund researchers in Chicago.
Such performance does not go unnoticed. The fund's assets have nearly doubled since the beginning of the year, from $5 million, to $9 million, though that total keeps it below the $30 million cutoff for listing in this newspaper.
The Perkins fund specializes in the smallest companies, many of which are not tracked by Wall Street and which are thinly traded. The median market capitalization, or the number of shares multiplied by the share price, of the stocks it owns is $70 million. Only four of the 1,620 diversified stock funds tracked by Morningstar own smaller stocks. Stocks of small companies tend to be more volatile than their large counterparts. And very small companies, sometimes called micro-caps, are more volatile still.
"We've always been more interested in micro- and small-cap stocks," said Richard W. Perkins, who manages the fund with his son, Daniel, from Minneapolis. In total, their firm manages $200 million in assets.
The managers are fond of shopping for penny stocks, a bit of a misnomer since the classic definition is a stock that costs less than $5 a share. By this measure, more than a third of their portfolio is in penny stocks.
The companies that issue such stocks often have erratic revenue and earnings histories, if they have any record at all. Many of these stocks do not trade on the major exchanges either, meaning the fund may have trouble finding a buyer when it decides to sell.
The fund's largest holding is Innerdyne Inc., a maker of surgical equipment based in Salt Lake City. The company went public at $11 a share in 1992 and leaped to $17 on its first day of trading. By the fall of 1993, its stock had fallen to $1.25.
Although Innerdyne has yet to have a profitable quarter, it has been a winner for the Perkins fund. It paid an average of $2.65 for the company's shares, which have risen in value to $4.38, and the stock accounts for 3.6 percent of the fund's holdings. Innerdyne's market capitalization is $72 million, typical of a Perkins stock.
In another attempt at bottom fishing, Mr. Perkins bought shares of the Cooper Companies, whose chief executive was convicted of fraud and whose board recently paid a multimillion-dollar fine to settle charges of lax oversight brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The fund paid $2.02 a share for Cooper stock, now trading at $2.13.
"This is a forgotten, down-trodden company," the senior Mr. Perkins said of Cooper, which is based in Fort Lee, N.J., and makes ophthalmic supplies. "New management came in, saved it from bankruptcy and is fixing it."
A stock that has not proved profitable is General Magic Inc., a computer software company. The fund bought it at $22 a share, but the price now hovers at $13.38. "I wish I hadn't bought it," Mr. Perkins conceded.
Perhaps the most notable thing about the Perkins fund besides its small-company bent is its technology fascination. About 45 percent of the fund's assets were invested in technology stocks in June 1994. Such shares now account for roughly a quarter of the portfolio, Mr. Perkins said.
Technology and small companies add up to volatility in the stock market. But the volatility has all been positive for shareholders of the Perkins fund -- so far.
The fund "is lucky enough to have been around in an environment that hasn't punished really small-cap technology funds," said John Rekenthaler, who edits the Morningstar 5 Star Investor, an investment newsletter.
The fund dabbles in restricted securities and warrants. Restricted securities, which accounted for nearly 3 percent of the fund's assets on Sept. 30, cannot be sold on stock exchanges, and their prices are determined by the fund's trustees. What the fund would actually get for them if it needed to sell is impossible to know.
With warrants, investors get the right to buy a certain amount of common stock at a fixed price for a period of time. If the stock never reaches that conversion price, the warrants expire worthless. The Perkins fund carried warrants for Work Recovery Units of Tucson, Ariz., which makes equipment and supplies for medical rehabilitation, on its books at $33,000 on Sept. 30 but has since marked them down to nothing.
While not a good fit for the timid, the Perkins fund does have one big advantage. Its small size allows it to buy and sell stocks in companies without driving the price up or down the way a behemoth Fidelity fund would.
On the flip side, the Perkins fund owns only 56 stocks. That highly concentrated portfolio means declines in just a few stocks could send the fund reeling.
"If we have too many stocks, we will have market performance," rather than above-average performance, Mr. Perkins said of his strategy. Acknowledging the risk, he said that investors might want to put only a portion of their assets, perhaps 5 percent or 10 percent, in the fund.
One final caveat for investors. The Perkins fund's expenses are sky high, perhaps because the fund is so small and cannot reap economies of scale. Expenses exceeded 5 percent of assets on Sept. 30, leading the fund to pay more than 2.5 percentage points of those costs itself to comply with various state laws. Should annual returns decline from their double-digit levels, those expenses could be a big drag on performance.
Of course, Mr. Perkins expects the fund to grow and expenses to wane. And there's little danger of this fund turning investors away anytime soon. How big would be too big for a fund that specializes in the teeniest companies? About $100 million, Mr. Perkins ventured.
