LENGTH: 1372 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Making Gains on the Winds From Washington

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
IN its fervor to challenge unnecessary government regulation, the Republican-dominated Congress will soon place another Federal agency in the cross hairs: The Food and Drug Administration. For many investors, this political hunting party may signal a time to bag some big game -- or to duck for cover.
Of course, the average person may pay more attention to the moral and economic aspects of the F.D.A. dispute than to its meaning for stocks. House Speaker Newt Gingrich has denounced the F.D.A. as the "leading job-killer in America," for instance, while the agency's supporters have conjured up the specter of babies deformed by drugs like thalidomide under deregulation. Big questions, and great theater. 
 But as the Republican Congress puts affirmative action, product liability, the F.D.A. and other topics on the table during this session, the average investor should learn to do what investment professionals do: study exactly how the winds from Washington can buffet Wall Street.
The F.D.A. makes a good case study.
Lesson No. 1 is about uncertainty. With the F.D.A., no one knows which, if any, of the harsh medicines proposed will be administered. The calls range from outright abolition of the agency to privatization to merely a vigorous housecleaning.
And some of the ideas for the agency, like privatization, are so thorny that prediction is particularly difficult. "Do you really want to privatize the F.B.I.?" asked Paul Brooke, a managing director at Morgan Stanley. "That, too, is an enforcement agency, like the F.D.A."
But uncertainty is no reason for investors not to pay attention. Once things are clear, it is too late on Wall Street. So, before the political dust settles, investors must understand not only the impact of potential change but also the roster of likely potential winners and losers.
With the F.D.A., the stakes are huge. The agency's province, which includes prescription drugs, biotechnology and food safety, reaches deep into the American economy. If the agency were drastically transformed, said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer, "It would be one of the great bullish wild cards in American business, because it costs half a trillion dollars a year for American businesses to comply with tens of thousands of pages of regulations."
And even a slight relaxation of F.D.A. regulation could be a bonanza for some companies. For a new drug that is expected to earn $500 million over its life, every week's delay costs $10 million in revenues as a company awaits approval, said Viren Mehta, a partner at Mehta and Isaly, pharmaceutical investment advisers.
Also, even the possibility of change can make things happen. Health reform failed, but many health-care companies merged and downsized anyway. Similarly, there are signs that the F.D.A. itself is already speeding up some regulatory procedures, analysts say.
Who stands to gain if the agency's approval procedures are liberalized? One clear set of winners is companies "that have a track record of innovation," said Margo L. Vignola, an analyst for Salomon Brothers. "Companies with plenty of product in the pipeline," she said, include such drug and medical-device businesses as Johnson & Johnson, Abbott Laboratories, Medtronic and St. Jude Medical.
Mr. Mehta said that other active product creators are Pfizer, Allergan and -- in Europe -- Astra, Roche, Sandoz and Schering.
Many biotechnology companies -- Amgen and Immunex are strong examples -- are product innovators by definition, and they may thrive in another way under deregulation. Because biotech companies are symbols of innovation, and because Republican reformers charge that the F.D.A. restricts new product development, biotech companies may benefit from the "sympathy-vote factor," said Mr. Mehta. "The F.D.A. realizes that they are taking the risk of doing cutting-edge science, and the F.D.A. is more likely to help these companies, permitting them not to have to jump through so many hoops."
Companies that regularly enhance their products also may gain greatly, said Ms. Vignola, such as manufacturerers of pacemakers and sutures. Follow-up approvals for product extension often involve "modest controversy," she explained, and already "the F.D.A. appears to be loosening up." Also, "since in the past the length of the approval time has been very extended" for these products, she said, the time savings may be particularly large.
Investors should also ask if deregulation might benefit a whole industry. For example, many European sodas contain noncaloric sweeteners that taste more like sugar, but that have not yet been approved by the F.D.A. If the rules get looser, "the growth of the soft-drink companies could increase if they could market a better diet product that would taste the same as the regular soda," said Emanuel Goldman, a food and tobacco analyst for Paine Webber.
Other food companies that have many dealings with the F.D.A., such as Conagra, Hormel, Tyson Foods and other meat producers, also might realize savings from relaxed regulation, said Terry Bivens, a food analyst for Argus Research.
What does the F.D.A. think about the proposals? The agency "doesn't comment on advice to investors," said William E. Schultz, the deputy commissioner for policy. Still, investors may want to think about his observation that F.D.A. review "not only benefits consumers here, but also benefits the companies." Many other countries, he explained, "look to the F.D.A.'s approval as a criterion for their own approval."
Who will be the big losers if F.D.A. regulation is relaxed? "Companies whose existing products have served them well because there isn't any new competition," said Ms. Vignola.
In general, looser regulation may hurt incumbent companies. "Any existing product will lose if a competing product finds it easier to come to market," Mr. Metz said. High regulatory hurdles, in other words, protect companies from competitors who have not cleared them.
According to industry executives who declined to be identified, among the companies that are benefiting from such regulatory protection are American Home Products and Upjohn.
As they look at the F.D.A. issue through an investing lens, however, people must be sure not to overassess the impact of Washington on Wall Street. For example, tobacco companies already look like big winners; they no longer face the embarrassment of hearings in the Democratic Congress or the threat that the F.D.A. might declare tobacco an addictive drug.
But because the low price of tobacco stocks is "a function of the threat of litigation, not regulation," said Mr. Goldman, it is unlikely that tobacco shares would rebound even if the F.D.A.'s operations were substantially curtailed.
 
Chart: "From Discovery To Drug Store"
Som e Republicans say business id hobbled by F.D.A. approval procedures, Here is the path a company must follow to bring a drug to market.
 
1 -- Discovery of a Drug
The sponsor of a drug must be able to describe it in detailed chemical formulas and must try it out on animals for human toxity. This testing can take months or decades.
 
2 -- First Formal Permission
Data from animal tests is submitted to a local Institutional Review Board. If the board approves, human testing can begin.
 
3 -- Initial Human Tests
The drug is given to a few people, at low doses. They are carefully watched for harful side effects. These tests take several months.
 
4 -- Primary Human Tests
The drug is tested to see if it works against targeted disease. Under medical supervision, hundreds of people are given the drug and are folloed closely. This phase can take several months to two years.
 
5 -- Late Human Tests
Full-scale human testing is performed with thousands of patients. Doctors watch again for side effects and proof of effectiveness, and carefully adjust doses. This phase may take two to four years.
 
6 -- F.D.A. Review
The sponsor presents all the collected data to the F.D.A., along with a new-drug application. Agency approval takes about 19 months.
 
7 -- Market Approval
After the drug is approved, the sponsor can market it. But the F.D.A. continues to monitor the medicine.

LENGTH: 1130 words

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

ENTERTAINMENT
Investing in a Dream Team
For a decade or so, Paul Allen has followed his bliss about as far as money could take him. That's pretty far, for Mr. Allen was a Microsoft co-founder -- he went to high school with Bill Gates -- and left as a billionaire in 1983. Since then, he has indulged all manner of passions -- from buying a basketball team to financing a Jimi Hendrix museum in Seattle. Now he's made his biggest investment yet, putting $500 million -- even for him, a hefty bet -- into that ultimate entertainment dream team, Dreamworks SKG (Spielberg, Katzenberg and Geffen, that is). That sum gives him an 18.3 percent stake, with the three founders retaining two-thirds. Mr. Gates later got in on the act, too (does he have a finger in everything?), with Microsoft forming a multimedia joint venture with Dreamworks. 

HISTORY
A Lot of Water Over the Dam
William Clark's grandfather, it seems, worked for Morrison Knudsen when it built Hoover Dam in the 30's, and that link to the past brings vividly to life the contrast between the company's glory days and its current sad state. One possible cause for the problems has emerged: the directors who for so long backed William Agee's actions as chairman, even as warning signs flared, also had close ties to a charity run by Mr. Agee's wife, Mary -- ties so close that one expert on such matters said, "I have never seen a situation like this." And last week, in the latest blows, Mr. Clark resigned as acting chairman, even as Morrison disclosed losses even worse than expected. To top it off, the next day Zbigniew Brzezinski also resigned from the board. Hoover Dam is intact.
 
COLA WARS
D.C.U.'s? XL to the Rescue
Don't look now, but there's a vast, confused group taking shape across the land -- "dual-cola users" is what Pepsi calls them, with that poetic solemnity special to marketing. And those fickle souls just won't stick with either regular or diet cola, so -- yes -- they switch back and forth. Now this is heavy stuff. Sodas are a $50 billion business, and $30 billion of that's in colas; the cola wars are BIG. Just last week, to try to nab those D.C.U.'s (as marketers no doubt call them), Pepsi introduced a low-sugar concoction called Pepsi XL in a few Florida cities. The company had some convoluted explanation for that "XL" -- it mixes sugar with artificial sweetener -- but what it surely comes down to is that Pepsi wanted it to sound like a car. Slurp. Vrrooom. Help.
 
EXECUTIVE SUITE
At Sony, Software Is In
In consumer electronics, there's "hardware" and "software" -- the machines and the stuff they play, like movies or CDs. For half a century, Sony has been the master innovator of hardware -- just look at the Walkman and its billions of descendants. In software it's been a rougher ride -- look at its billions in Hollywood losses. But it's a new era at Sony -- its visionary co-founder Akio Morita just stepped down as chairman, Norio Ohga moved up to that job from president, and all eyes were on his successor. And the choice, last week, was a shock: Nobuyuki Idei, who leapfrogged over at least 10 higher-ranking executives. But the appointment sent a crystal-clear message: with Mr. Idei, a movie buff with the "software spirit," running things, software is definitely in.
 
THE PRESIDENT
And Think of His Aching Wrist
In the spirit of the latest times, here's a stock tip: invest in companies that make pens. In the House version of the line-item veto, the President could strike offending budget items. But in the Senate version, passed last week, he would accept or reject each budget morsel separately -- by one estimate, perhaps 10,000 separate bills. That's a lot of Presidential autographs -- and a lot of pens. But why do (Republican) legislators want to give the (Democratic) White House such power? Maybe they figure it's the only way they can get out the pork (which they, of course, put in). Or maybe it's because they have this idea that Bill Clinton will be back in Arkansas come 1997. Another point: Is a line-item veto even constitutional? Probably not, said Pat Moynihan.
 
POLITICS
Snippets of Discontent
Yes, old-style liberalism may be dying, gunned down by Republican assault rifles, but it's not going quietly. All last week, protests rippled across the land against Federal and local budget-slashing. In the House welfare debate, several lawmakers, including Sam Gibbons, showed a commitment to children by wearing ties or scarves designed for Save the Children. And hundreds of children, with the message "Pick on someone your own size," rallied on the Capitol steps to protest school lunch cuts. Later, more students converged on the Capitol -- one, in a towel, bearing a sign reading "We Are Being Stripped" -- to protest cuts in school aid. Al Sharpton and Jesse Jackson led a march to Albany to battle Governor Pataki's proposed cuts to Medicaid, education and programs for the homeless. And New York City's hospitals chief quit abruptly, saying he couldn't back deep Medicaid cuts.
 
CYBERSPACE
alt.ban.internet.sex.but.how
There they are on the Internet listings, news groups like "alt.sex.beastiality" and "alt.sex.masterbation." Such spelling, apparently, causes no outrage, but the content does. Everything from Playboy photos to the crudest of language is available at a click, no matter how young the wielder of the mouse, and many people want it stopped. But how? Cyberspace is the Wild West of the 90's, untamed and, for now, untamable. Stuff can come as easily from across the street as from across the globe. Trying to control it would be like spitting digits into the wind. But the Senate Commerce Committee is trying anyway. Last week it approved a ban on cyberporn, vowing $100,000 fines and two-year prison terms. Senator Jim Exon, who wrote the bill, admitted that it was probably futile, but he said he had to try.
 
THE MARKETS
A Slowdown, and Stocks Soar
The stock market loved Friday's economic news -- an 0.8 percent drop in orders for durable goods (stuff that's supposed to last longer than bananas or most electronic gadgets). By the market's current upside-down thinking, any slowing means less chance that the Fed will raise interest rates this week. And such a strong negative number was especially positive, as the Dow jumped 50, to 4,138.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 12; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 145 words

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
A Suspect Story of Success

 BODY:
The franchising industry says franchises have a 95 percent success rate. That sounds terrific, especially since four out of five independent businesses fail within five years. But the figure comes from a survey done by the Commerce Department in 1988 that has serious flaws, according to Tim Bates, an economics professor at Wayne State University in Detroit. Dr. Bates said that the survey was conducted by mail and that weak franchisers simply didn't return their questionnaires. "There's no question that the franchise industry has overhyped its success rate," he said. 
 Dr. Bates's own research paints a gloomy picture. His study of 7,300 small businesses that were started in the mid-1980's, including 400 franchises, found that about 35 percent of the franchises had gone out of business by late 1991, as against 28 percent of other small businesses.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Best and Worst Franchise Bets" shows ranking of selected businesses by the prospect of franchise success over the next five years. The analysis, conducted by Marketdata Enterprises, was based on economic and demographic forecasts, including the projected growth of the industries and the current share controlled by franchises.
